title: Fractions
translated_description: How to multiply fractions?
column10: The first step when multiplying fractions is to multiply the two numerators. The second step is to multiply the two denominators. Finally  simplify the new fractions. The fractions can also be simplified before multiplying by factoring out common factors in the numerator and denominator. Simplifying before multiplying helps avoid dealing with large numbers.

translated_description: Sal solves a word problem by multiplying 2 fractions.

title: Fractions
translated_description: Using a number line  we'll explain why multiplying by the inverse is the same as dividing.

title: Fractions
translated_description: Learn to divide two fractions.  The answer is a fraction.

title: Fractions
translated_description: Dividing two fractions is the same as multiplying the first fraction by the reciprocal of the second fraction. The first step to dividing fractions are to find the reciprocal (reverse the numerator and denominator) of the second fraction. Next  multiply the two numerators. Then  multiply the two denominators. Finally  simplify the fractions if needed.

title: Fractions
translated_description: Dividing a whole number by a fraction? Turn the tables and multiply by the reciprocal of the fraction. Boom!

translated_description: Decimals can be written in fraction form. To convert a decimal to a fraction  place the decimal number over its place value. For example  in 0.6  the six is in the tenths place  so we place 6 over 10 to create the equivalent fraction  6/10. If needed  simplify the fraction.

title: Arithmetic properties
translated_description: This example shows the steps and clarifies the purpose of order of operations: to have ONE way to interpret a mathematical statement.

title: Arithmetic properties
translated_description: The order of operations tells us the order to solve steps in expressions with more than one operation. First  we solve any operations inside of parentheses or brackets. Second  we solve any exponents. Third  we solve all multiplication and division from left to right. Fourth  we solve all addition and subtraction from left to right.

title: Arithmetic properties
translated_description: The identity property of 1 says that any number multiplied by 1 keeps its identity. In other words  any number multiplied by 1 stays the same. The reason the number stays the same is because multiplying by 1 means we have 1 copy of the number. For example  32x1=32.

title: Arithmetic properties
translated_description: Sal shows how any number plus 0 is the original number.

translated_description: The simple idea that a number plus its negative is 0

translated_description: Simple idea that multiplying by a number's multiplicative inverse gets you back to one. 5 × 1/5 = 1

title: Reading and interpreting data
translated_description: Here are a few of the many ways to look at data. Which is your favorite?

title: Reading and interpreting data
translated_description: A stem and leaf is a table used to display data. The 'stem' is on the left displays the first digit or digits. The 'leaf' is on the right and displays the last digit. For example  543 and 548 can be displayed together on a stem and leaf as 54 | 3 8.

title: Reading and interpreting data
translated_description: Common sense tells you that a pictograph must be some kind of....picture. Yes! A pictograph is basically a way to represent data with pictures that relate to the data. Let's look at this word problem that asks to interpret a pictograph.

title: Fractions
translated_description: Think of a mixed numbers as a number AND a fraction. You can subtract numbers....you can subtract fractions with like denominators. Therefore  you can subtract mixed numbers! Watch.

title: Fractions
translated_description: Sal rewrites 5 1/4 as an improper fraction.

title: Fractions
translated_description: Sal rewrite 7/4 as a mixed number.

title: Fractions
translated_description: Worked examples comparing improper fractions and mixed numbers

title: Fractions
translated_description: Sal adds 5/6+1/4 using a fraction model for help.

title: Fractions
translated_description: Sal subtracts 3/4-5/8 using a fraction model for help.

title: Fractions
translated_description: Sal adds fractions like 3/4 and 1/5.

title: Fractions
translated_description: Sal subtracts fractions like 4/3 and 1/5.

title: Fractions
translated_description: Sal adds 19 3/18 + 18 2/3 by rewriting each mixed number to have a common denominator.

title: Fractions
translated_description: Sal subtracts 3 2/5 from 7 6/9 by rewriting each mixed number to have a common denominator.

title: Fractions
translated_description: Sal adds 2 2/3 + 8 3/4.

title: Fractions
translated_description: Sal subtracts 17 4/9 - 12 2/3.

title: Fractions
translated_description: Sal solves a fraction word problem about practicing piano.  The fractions have common denominators.

title: Fractions
translated_description: Sal solves a fraction word problem about the length of a lizard.  The fractions have common denominators.

title: Fractions
translated_description: Sal solves a word problem by adding mixed numbers with unlike denominators.

title: Fractions
translated_description: Sal solves a word problem by subtracting mixed numbers with unlike denominators.

title: Fractions
translated_description: Sal gives a visual explanation of multiplying a fraction and a whole number.

title: Fractions
translated_description: Sal relates mixed numbers to whole number/fraction multiplication problem.

title: Fractions
translated_description: Sal compares the following expressions by thinking about multiplication as scaling: 2/3x7/8  8/7x2/3  and (5x2)/(3x5)

title: Fractions
translated_description: Sal introduces multiplying 2 fractions.

title: Fractions
translated_description: Sal uses a fraction model to multiply fractions.

title: Fractions
translated_description: Sal uses a number line to multiply fractions.

title: Fractions
translated_description: How to multiply fractions?
column10: The first step when multiplying fractions is to multiply the two numerators. The second step is to multiply the two denominators. Finally  simplify the new fractions. The fractions can also be simplified before multiplying by factoring out common factors in the numerator and denominator. Simplifying before multiplying helps avoid dealing with large numbers.

title: Fractions
translated_description: Sal introduces multiplying mixed numbers.

title: Fractions
translated_description: Sal solves a word problem by multiplying 2 fractions.

title: Fractions
translated_description: Sal solves a word problem by multiplying 2 fractions.

title: Fractions
translated_description: Sal solves a word problem by multiplying a fraction by a mixed number.

title: Fractions
translated_description: Sal shows how a/b and a/b are equivalent. That is  the fraction bar and the division symbol mean the same thing.

title: Fractions
translated_description: Sal explains how 3 / 2 is the same as 3 • 1/2  which is the same as 3/2.

title: Fractions
translated_description: Using a number line  we'll explain why multiplying by the inverse is the same as dividing.

title: Fractions
translated_description: Learn to divide two fractions.  The answer is a fraction.

title: Fractions
translated_description: Dividing two fractions is the same as multiplying the first fraction by the reciprocal of the second fraction. The first step to dividing fractions are to find the reciprocal (reverse the numerator and denominator) of the second fraction. Next  multiply the two numerators. Then  multiply the two denominators. Finally  simplify the fractions if needed.

title: Fractions
translated_description: Dividing a whole number by a fraction? Turn the tables and multiply by the reciprocal of the fraction. Boom!

title: Fractions
translated_description: Learn to solve a word problem that involves dividing a unit fraction by a whole number.

title: Decimals
translated_description: Sal introduces decimal numbers and understanding place value to the right of the decimal.

title: Decimals
translated_description: Sal writes 0.17  and 40.03 in words.  He also writes twenty-four hundredths using numbers.

title: Decimals
translated_description: Learn to write 905.074 in expanded form.

title: Decimals
translated_description: Sal uses grid diagrams to determine what decimal is represented by a shaded area.

title: Decimals
translated_description: Lindsay graphs 0.6 on a number line.

title: Decimals
translated_description: Lindsay identifies a point graphed on a number line.

title: Decimals
translated_description: Sal finds decimals with hundredths on a number line.

title: Decimals
translated_description: Lindsay graphs 0.04 on a number line.

title: Decimals
translated_description: Lindsay identifies decimals graphed on a number line.

title: Decimals
translated_description: Learn to round 9.564 to the nearest tenth.

title: Decimals
translated_description: Sal compares decimals like 0.0093 and 0.01 with greater and less than symbols.

title: Decimals
translated_description: Sal compares decimals like 45.675 and 45.645 with greater and less than symbols.

title: Decimals
translated_description: Sal compares 9.97 and 9.798 using place value.

title: Decimals
translated_description: Sal compares 2 decimals using place value.

title: Decimals
translated_description: Sal orders 5 decimals from least to greatest.

title: Decimals
translated_description: Sal orders 5 decimals from least to greatest.

title: Decimals
translated_description: Sal shows the connection between decimals and fractions using a grid diagram and number lines.

title: Decimals
translated_description: Decimals can be written in fraction form. To convert a decimal to a fraction  place the decimal number over its place value. For example  in 0.6  the six is in the tenths place  so we place 6 over 10 to create the equivalent fraction  6/10. If needed  simplify the fraction.

title: Decimals
translated_description: Sal converts 0.8 to a fraction.

title: Decimals
translated_description: Sal converts 0.36 to a fraction.

title: Decimals
translated_description: Sal writes 11/25 as a decimal.

title: Decimals
translated_description: Learn how to write the fraction  7/8 as a decimal.

title: Decimals
translated_description: Sal adds tenths  like 0.1+0.8 using visuals and place value.

title: Decimals
translated_description: Sal adds numbers  such as 3.53+4.72  by breaking them down into place values.

title: Decimals
translated_description: Sal solves 9.087+15.31 using the "standard algorithm".

title: Decimals
translated_description: Sal solves 0.822+5.65 using "standard algorithm".

title: Decimals
translated_description: Sal adds 7.056+605.7+5.67 using the "standard algorithm".

title: Decimals
translated_description: Sal uses place value and decomposing numbers to subtract decimals to the tenths place  such as 2-1.2.

title: Decimals
translated_description: Sal uses place value and numbers in expanded form to subtract decimal to hundredths  such as 8.38-4.54.

title: Decimals
translated_description: Just like when add  be sure you align decimals before subtracting.

title: Decimals
translated_description: In this example where we subtract decimals we do so up to the thousandths place. It's a little tricky  but not if we do it together.

title: Decimals
translated_description: Here's a simple word problem asking us to put our adding decimals skill to work.

title: Decimals
translated_description: Let's get fancy and practice adding and subtracting decimals in the same word problem.

title: Decimals
translated_description: Sal introduces multiplying decimals with problems like 9x0.6.

title: Decimals
translated_description: Sal uses place value and equivalent fractions to multiply decimals.

title: Decimals
translated_description: Sal uses an understanding of place value to multiply 2.91x3.2.

title: Decimals
translated_description: Sometimes multiplying really small decimals (with all those zeros!) can be a little intimidating. Watch as we show you a handy trick to simplify these problems and solve them.

title: Decimals
translated_description: Sal divides 63/35.

title: Decimals
translated_description: Sal uses an understanding of place value and fractions to introduce dividing with decimals.

title: Decimals
translated_description: Sal uses understanding of place value  expanded form  and fractions to help divide with decimals.

title: Decimals
translated_description: Sal uses equivalent fractions to divide both whole numbers and decimals by tenths.

title: Decimals
translated_description: Sal shows how to divide 6.3 by 0.25.

title: Decimals
translated_description: Decimal divisors in the hundredths place can be a little confusing. In this video we'll show you how to move the decimal and make it a whole number. Pretty nifty! Watch.

title: Decimals
translated_description: Sal divides 6.7 by 2.211.

title: Decimals
translated_description: Sal shows that when there is a decimal divisor  you need to shift the decimal first and then divide.

title: Negative numbers and coordinate plane
translated_description: Mysterious negative numbers! What ARE they? They are numbers less than zero. If you understand the nature of below zero temperatures  you can understand negative numbers. We'll help.

title: Negative numbers and coordinate plane
translated_description: Sal puts -25  -30  -7  -10  and -40 in order from least to greatest.

title: Negative numbers and coordinate plane
translated_description: Learn about number opposites like 3 and -3 or -4 and 4 using a number line.

title: Negative numbers and coordinate plane
translated_description: Sal explains more challenging opposites like -(-3).

title: Negative numbers and coordinate plane
translated_description: Learn how to find the absolute value of 5  -10  and 12.

title: Negative numbers and coordinate plane
translated_description: Learn how to compare absolute value like | -9 | and | -7 |.

title: Negative numbers and coordinate plane
translated_description: Learn how to place | - 27 |  -17  -28  and 22.4 on the number line.

title: Negative numbers and coordinate plane
translated_description: In this video  we think about what |a-b| really means  and we verify that |a-b| = |b-a| by looking at an example.

title: Negative numbers and coordinate plane
translated_description: Use a number line to add -15 + (-46) + (-29)

title: Negative numbers and coordinate plane
translated_description: Use a number line to add 15 + (-46) + 29

title: Negative numbers and coordinate plane
translated_description: Learn how to add and subtract negative numbers. The problems solved in this video are 2 - 3 = -1 and -2 - 3 = -5 and -2 + 3 = 1 and 2 - (-3) = 5 and -2 - (-3).

title: Negative numbers and coordinate plane
translated_description: Find out why subtracting a negative number is the same as adding the absolute value of that number.

title: Negative numbers and coordinate plane
translated_description: Use a number line to add 15 + (-46) + 29

title: Negative numbers and coordinate plane
translated_description: Learn some rules of thumb for multiplying positive and negative numbers.

title: Negative numbers and coordinate plane
translated_description: Discover the basics of dividing with negative numbers.

title: Negative numbers and coordinate plane
translated_description: Use the repeated addition model of multiplication to give an understanding of multiplying negative numbers.

title: Negative numbers and coordinate plane
translated_description: Use the distributive property to understand the products of negative numbers.

title: Negative numbers and coordinate plane
translated_description: The coordinate plane is a two-dimension surface formed by two number lines. One number line is horizontal and is called the x-axis. The other number line is vertical number line and is called the y-axis. The two axes meet at a point called the origin. We can use the coordinate plane to graph points  lines  and more.

title: Negative numbers and coordinate plane
translated_description: We're plotting an ordered pair on the x (horizontal) axis and y (vertical) axis of the coordinate plane.

title: Negative numbers and coordinate plane
translated_description: Some of the given ordered pairs are already graphed on the coordinate pane in this example  but not all of them. Can you tell which haven't?

title: Negative numbers and coordinate plane
translated_description: Learn about the 4 quadrants that make up a coordinate plane.

title: Negative numbers and coordinate plane
translated_description: Plot an ordered pair like (-4  -2) and then decide which quadrant it is in.

title: Negative numbers and coordinate plane
translated_description: In this word problem  we need to plot the ordered pairs and then figure out the difference in the y coodinate between the two. This will give us our answer!

title: Negative numbers and coordinate plane
translated_description: Just like looking at a mirror image of yourself  but flipped....a reflection point is the mirror point on the opposite axis. Watch this tutorial and reflect :)

title: Negative numbers and coordinate plane
translated_description: Sal completes a pattern using a table and then graphs the results on a coordinate plane.

title: Negative numbers and coordinate plane
translated_description: Sal examines the points on a number line and interprets the patterns to discover relationships.

title: Negative numbers and coordinate plane
translated_description: Sal interprets and graphs the relationships between patterns in the given ordered pairs.

title: Ratios rates proportions
translated_description: A ratio is a comparison of two quantities.  Learn how to find the ratio between two things  for example apples to oranges.

title: Ratios rates proportions
translated_description: How are fractions and ratios the same? How are they different? Is 2:5 the same as 2/5?

title: Ratios rates proportions
translated_description: We're displaying ratios in a table format here  and then asking: given a ratio  solve for equivalent ratios. Here are a few examples to practice on.

title: Ratios rates proportions
translated_description: In this example we'll plot points on the x and y axis to reflect the given ratios.

title: Ratios rates proportions
translated_description: Sal uses ratios to figure out how far apart two cities should be on a map.

title: Ratios rates proportions
translated_description: Sal solves a tricky ratio word problem.

title: Ratios rates proportions
translated_description: Sal introduces rates using examples like 35 miles per hour and 10 dollars per hour.

title: Ratios rates proportions
translated_description: Jayda takes 3 hours to deliver newspapers on her route. What is the rate per hour at which she delivers the newspapers?

title: Ratios rates proportions
translated_description: Miranda's Maid Service charges \$280 to clean 8 offices. What is the company's price for cleaning a single office?

title: Ratios rates proportions
translated_description: Sometimes you'll need to solve for multiple parts of the equation before getting at the answer. Here we solve for average speed  but first we have to determine total distance and total time.

title: Ratios rates proportions
translated_description: Sal puts three fish tanks in order by volume of water per fish.

title: Ratios rates proportions
translated_description: Using the formula for finding distance we can determine Usian Bolt's average speed  or rate  when he broke the world record in 2009 in the 100m. Watch.

title: Ratios rates proportions
translated_description: Sal converts feet to inches to help solve a rate problem.

title: Ratios rates proportions
translated_description: Let's think about what percent really means by looking at a 10 by 10 grid.

title: Ratios rates proportions
translated_description: Percents are parts per hundred. So  how does this work for percents greater than 100% like 109%?

title: Ratios rates proportions
translated_description: Percents can be written in decimal form. ​Per-cent means per-100. So  we divide the percent by 100 to get an equivalent decimal. Then  we remove the percent sign (%). For example  65% can be converted to decimal form by solving 65/100. So  65%=0.65. Another way to think of dividing by 100 is moving the decimal two places to the left.

title: Ratios rates proportions
translated_description: Sal converts 1.501 to a percent.

title: Ratios rates proportions
translated_description: Decimals can be written in percent form. ​Per-cent means per-100. So  we multiply the decimal by 100 to get an equivalent percent. Then  we add a percent sign (%). For example  0.8 can be converted to percent form by solving 0.8✕100. So  0.8=80%. Another way to think of multiplying by 100 is moving the decimal two places to the right.

title: Ratios rates proportions
translated_description: Sal converts 113.9% to a decimal by demonstrating how to move the decimal point

title: Ratios rates proportions
translated_description: Sal writes 18% as a decimal and as a fraction.

title: Ratios rates proportions
translated_description: Ordering numbers expressed as decimals  fractions  and percentages.

title: Ratios rates proportions
translated_description: Percent means per-hundred.  Use that knowledge to solve problems like what percent of 16 is 4?

title: Ratios rates proportions
translated_description: There are several different ways to solve problems involving percentages  decimals  and fractions. Watch as Sal finds the percentage of a whole number.

title: Ratios rates proportions
translated_description: Sal identifies the percent  amount  and base in a percent problem.

title: Ratios rates proportions
translated_description: This word problem is expressed simply which can be confusing to some. Take your time and focus on the what is being asked for.

title: Ratios rates proportions
translated_description: In this example  you working with us to find the number that is expressed as a given percentage. We'll create a simple algebraic equation to solve!

title: Ratios rates proportions
translated_description: We're putting a little algebra to work to find the full price when you know the discount price in this percent word problem.

title: Ratios rates proportions
translated_description: It's nice to practice conversion problems  but how about applying our new knowledge of percentages to a real life problem like recycling? Hint: don't forget your long division!

title: Ratios rates proportions
translated_description: You're given the percent in this example and asked to find the whole number represented by the percent.

title: Ratios rates proportions
translated_description: In this example we grow a whole number by a percentage of itself. Growing by percentage is a common skill often used when figuring how much is owed or earned with interest.

title: Ratios rates proportions
translated_description: We'll use algebra to solve this percent problem.

title: Ratios rates proportions
translated_description: Remember units of measurement? Convert minutes into hours and put your knowledge of fractions to work in this word problem.

title: Ratios rates proportions
translated_description: Budgeting money is one of the most valuable math skills you'll learn. Practice with us as we figure out how much money is left after a cab fare.

title: Ratios rates proportions
translated_description: First visualize this word problem then use subtraction and multiplication of decimals and fractions to get at the answer.

title: Ratios rates proportions
translated_description: Sal introduces the idea of a proportional relationship by looking at tables of values.

title: Ratios rates proportions
translated_description: Given a table of ratios  watch as we test them for equivalence and determine whether the relationship is proportional.

title: Ratios rates proportions
translated_description: A proportionality problem about eating bananas

title: Ratios rates proportions
translated_description: When going to the movies  is the price you pay proportional to the number of tickets you buy?

title: Ratios rates proportions
translated_description: Learn the reasoning behind solving proportions. We'll put some algebra to work to get our answers  too.

title: Ratios rates proportions
translated_description: Some examples of writing two ratios and setting them equal to each other to solve proportion word problems.

title: Ratios rates proportions
translated_description: Mika can eat 21 hot dogs in 66 minutes. She wants to know how many minutes it would take her to eat 35 hot dogs if she can keep up the same pace.

title: Ratios rates proportions
translated_description: A recipe for oatmeal cookies calls for 2 cups of flour for every 3 cups of oatmeal. How much flour is needed for a big batch of cookies that uses 9 cups of oatmeal?

title: Ratios rates proportions
translated_description: Sal solves a word problem where he finds the cost of gas in a road trip given the car's fuel efficiency  length of the trip  and price of gas.

title: Equations expressions and inequalities
translated_description: Our focus here is understanding that a variable is just a symbol that can represent different values in an expression. We got this. Just watch.

title: Equations expressions and inequalities
translated_description: Great question. In algebra  we do indeed avoid using the multiplication sign. We'll explain it for you here.

title: Equations expressions and inequalities
translated_description: Learn how to evaluate an expression with variables using a technique called substitution (or "plugging in").

title: Equations expressions and inequalities
translated_description: We've done a few examples together where we were faced with 1 variable. Why not try one that has 2 variables?

title: Equations expressions and inequalities
translated_description: Learn how to evaluate expressions that have two different variables in them by using a technique called substitution (or "plugging in").

title: Equations expressions and inequalities
translated_description: Explore how the values of algebraic expressions like 100-x  5/x + 5  and (3y)/(2y) change as the values of the variables change.

title: Equations expressions and inequalities
translated_description: Sal solves a word problem by constructing a numerical expression.

title: Equations expressions and inequalities
translated_description: Sal evaluates an expression with and without parentheses

title: Equations expressions and inequalities
translated_description: In this example we have a formula for converting Celsius temperature to Fahrenheit. Let's substitute the variable with a value (Celsius temp) to get the degrees in Fahrenheit. Great problem to practice with us!

title: Equations expressions and inequalities
translated_description: In this example of evaluating expressions  we're dusting off some geometry. On top of that  it's a word problem. We're seeing how different concepts in math are layered on top of each to create more interesting and complex problems to solve.

title: Equations expressions and inequalities
translated_description: We're going to put our order of operations knowledge to work as we evaluate this expression. Exponents  specifically  are our focus here.

title: Equations expressions and inequalities
translated_description: Sal writes an expression to represent 11 more than a.

title: Equations expressions and inequalities
translated_description: Learn how to write simple algebraic expressions.

title: Equations expressions and inequalities
translated_description: Learn how to write algebraic expressions that involve grouping quantities in parentheses.

title: Equations expressions and inequalities
translated_description: Learn how to write basic expressions with variables to describe situations described in word problems.

title: Equations expressions and inequalities
translated_description: Learn how to write expressions with variables to describe situations described in word problems.

title: Equations expressions and inequalities
translated_description: Learn what variables  expressions  and equations are.

title: Equations expressions and inequalities
translated_description: A solution to an equation makes that equation true. Learn how to test if a certain value of a variable makes an equation true.

title: Equations expressions and inequalities
translated_description: The example of a scale where we try to achieve balance helps to explain why we do the same thing to both sides of an equation.

title: Equations expressions and inequalities
translated_description: Equations are about relationships (no  not girlfriends and boyfriends!) between the two sides of the equation. Let's again use a scale example to help us understand.

title: Equations expressions and inequalities
translated_description: Let's get a conceptual understanding of why one needs to divide both sides of an equation to solve for a variable.

title: Equations expressions and inequalities
translated_description: This equation can be simplified through a single step to solve for the variable. Can you help?

title: Equations expressions and inequalities
translated_description: Learn how to solve one-step addition and subtraction equations by adding or subtracting the same thing from both sides of the equation.

title: Equations expressions and inequalities
translated_description: Learn how to solve this equation: a + 5 = 54

title: Equations expressions and inequalities
translated_description: Learn how to solve one-step addition and subtraction equations that have fractions and decimals in them.

title: Equations expressions and inequalities
translated_description: Let's ease into this  shall we? Here's an introduction to basic algebraic equations of the form ax=b. Remember that you can check to see if you have the right answer by substituting it for the variable!

title: Equations expressions and inequalities
translated_description: Remember that what you do to one side  you have to do to the other. Will you multiply or divide both sides to dump the fraction  x/a? Let's do it together.

title: Equations expressions and inequalities
translated_description: Learn how to solve equations in one step by multiplying or dividing a number from both sides. These problems involve decimals and fractions.

title: Equations expressions and inequalities
translated_description: Using information from the Super Yoga word problem  explore all the possible combinations and create equations which express the possibilities. Let's figure out which plan is best!

title: Equations expressions and inequalities
translated_description: If you're coming to this video before seeing the previous one  back up! Otherwise  we're solving one-step equations to learn which Super Plan is the best value for our budget.

title: Equations expressions and inequalities
translated_description: Learn how to write basic equations to model real-world situations.

title: Equations expressions and inequalities
translated_description: Greater than and less than symbols can be used to compare numbers and expressions. The greater than symbol is >. So  9>7 is read as '9 is greater than 7'. The less than symbol is <. Two other comparison symbols are > (greater than or equal to) and < (less than or equal to).

title: Equations expressions and inequalities
translated_description: To plot an inequality  such as x>3  on a number line  first draw a circle over the number (e.g.  3). Then if the sign includes equal to (≥ or ≤)  fill in the circle. If the sign does not include equal to (> or <)  leave the circle unfilled in. Finally  draw a line going from the circle in the direction of the numbers that make the inequality true.

title: Equations expressions and inequalities
translated_description: We're writing inequalities by using information from the word problems.

title: Equations expressions and inequalities
translated_description: This time we're creating a variable to represent a number  and then writing an inequality. We're building on our knowledge.

title: Equations expressions and inequalities
translated_description: Learn how to plot a simple inequality on a number line. The example used in this video is x < 4.

title: Equations expressions and inequalities
translated_description: The example of a scale where we try to achieve balance helps to explain why we do the same thing to both sides of an equation.

title: Equations expressions and inequalities
translated_description: Here's how we solve a two step equation. It begins with the concept of equality: what we do to one side of the equation must be done to the other.

title: Equations expressions and inequalities
translated_description: This example demonstrates how we solve an equation expressed such: ax + b = c. It's a little more complicated than previous examples  but you can do it!

title: Equations expressions and inequalities
translated_description: Sal solves the equation -16 = x/4 + 2. It takes two steps because he first has to subtract 2 from both sides and then multiply both sides by 4.

title: Exponents radicals and scientific notation
translated_description: introduction to exponents and exponential growth

title: Exponents radicals and scientific notation
translated_description: Sal shows how exponents are repeated multiplication

title: Exponents radicals and scientific notation
translated_description: Discover a pattern that explains why any non-zero number to the zero power equals one.

title: Exponents radicals and scientific notation
translated_description: Use odd and even rules to determine the sign of an exponential expression.

title: Exponents radicals and scientific notation
translated_description: Any non-zero number to the zero power equals one. Zero to any positive exponent equals zero. So  what happens when you have zero to the zero power?

title: Exponents radicals and scientific notation
translated_description: Learn about the square root symbol (the principal root) and what it means to find a square root. Also learn how to solve simple square root equations.

title: Exponents radicals and scientific notation
translated_description: Learn how square root means what number multiplied by itself will result in the given number.

title: Exponents radicals and scientific notation
translated_description: Learn how to approximate the decimal value of √45 without using a calculator.

title: Exponents radicals and scientific notation
translated_description: Roots are nice  but we prefer dealing with regular numbers as much as possible. So  for example  instead of √4 we prefer dealing with 2. What about roots that aren't equal to an integer  like √20? Still  we can write 20 as 4⋅5 and then use known properties to write √(4⋅5) as √4⋅√5  which is 2√5. We *simplified* √20.

title: Exponents radicals and scientific notation
translated_description: Learn the meaning of cube roots and how to find them. Also learn how to find the cube root of a negative number.

title: Exponents radicals and scientific notation
translated_description: Simplifying Radical Expressions1

title: Exponents radicals and scientific notation
translated_description: Learn how to find the cube root of -512.

title: Exponents radicals and scientific notation
translated_description: Learn how to simplify expressions like (5^6)/(5^2). Also learn how 1/(a^b) is the same as a^-b. Towards the end of the video  we practice simplifying more complex expressions like (25 * x * y^6)/(20 * y^5 * x^2).

title: Exponents radicals and scientific notation
translated_description: Learn two exponent properties: (ab)^c and (a^b)^c. See WHY they work and HOW to use them.

title: Exponents radicals and scientific notation
translated_description: Learn how to simplify expressions like (5^6)/(5^2). Also learn how 1/(a^b) is the same as a^-b. Towards the end of the video  we practice simplifying more complex expressions like (25 * x * y^6)/(20 * y^5 * x^2).

title: Exponents radicals and scientific notation
translated_description: Learn how to rewrite expressions with negative exponents as fractions with positive exponents.

title: Exponents radicals and scientific notation
translated_description: Intuition on why a^-b = 1/(a^b) (and why a^0 =1)

title: Exponents radicals and scientific notation
translated_description: For any base a and for any exponents n and m  aⁿ⋅aᵐ=aⁿ⁺ᵐ and aⁿ/aᵐ=aⁿ⁻ᵐ. These are worked examples for using these properties with integer exponents.

title: Exponents radicals and scientific notation
translated_description: For any integers a and b and for any exponents n  (a⋅b)ⁿ=aⁿ⋅bⁿ and (a/b)ⁿ=aⁿ/bⁿ. These are worked examples for using these properties with integer exponents.

title: Exponents radicals and scientific notation
translated_description: Introduction to scientific notation. An in-depth discussion about why and how scientific notation is used.

title: Exponents radicals and scientific notation
translated_description: More scientific notation examples

title: Exponents radicals and scientific notation
translated_description: Scientific notation is a way of writing very large or very small numbers. A number is written in scientific notation when a number between 1 and 10 is multiplied by a power of 10. For example  650 000 000 can be written in scientific notation as 6.5 ✕ 10^8.

title: Exponents radicals and scientific notation
translated_description: Can you imagine if you had to do calculations with very  very small numbers? How would you handle all those zeros to the right of the decimal? Thank goodness for scientific notation!

title: Exponents radicals and scientific notation
translated_description: Learn how to multiply (9 * 10^9) (-2 * 10^-3).

title: Exponents radicals and scientific notation
translated_description: Now that we understand how to interpret an exponent and how the patterns in zeros are related to the exponent  we can solve more complicated problems!

title: Exponents radicals and scientific notation
translated_description: Learn how to solve a multiplication problem using scientific notation: (9.1 * 10^6)(3.2 * 10^-5)

title: Exponents radicals and scientific notation
translated_description: Multiplying really big or really small numbers is much easier when using scientific notation. This video gives an example of multiplying three numbers that are written in scientific notation.

title: Exponents radicals and scientific notation
translated_description: Learn how to simplify a multiplication and division expression using scientific notation. The expression in this problem is (7 * 10^5) / ((2 * 10^-2)(2.5 * 10^9)).

title: Counting

title: Measurement and data
translated_description: A picture graph  or pictograph  is a graph used to display information that uses images or symbols to represent data. For example  a picture graph displaying ​the amount of points scored by 5 basketball players could use the image of a basketball to represent 2 points and then display a basketball over each player's name for every 2 points she scored

title: Measurement and data
translated_description: To create a line plot  ​first create a number line that includes all the values in the data set. Next  place an X (or dot) above each data value on the number line. If a value occurs more than once in a data set  place an Xs over that number for each time it occurs.

title: Measurement and data
translated_description: Sal reads and interprets bar graphs.

title: Measurement and data
translated_description: Sal reads and interprets bar graphs.

title: Measurement and data
translated_description: Sal creates and interprets bar and picture graphs.

title: Measurement and data
translated_description: A line plot is a graph that displays data using a number line. To create a line plot  ​first create a number line that includes all the values in the data set. Next  place an X (or dot) above each data value on the number line. If a value occurs more than once in a data set  place ​an Xs​ over that number for each time it occurs.

title: Measurement and data
translated_description: To create a line plot  ​first create a number line that includes all the values in the data set. Next  place an X (or dot) above each data value on the number line. If a value occurs more than once in a data set  place an Xs over that number for each time it occurs.

translated_description: Sal combines shapes to make other shapes.

title: Geometry
translated_description: When a whole is divided into equal size pieces  the pieces are fractions of the whole. If the whole is divided into 2 equal sized pieces  each piece is ​one half of the whole. If the whole is divided into 4 equal sized pieces  each piece is one fourth of the whole.

title: Geometry
translated_description: Sal determines if shapes are divided into 2 or 4 equal sections.

title: Introduction to algebra
translated_description: Where did the word "Algebra" and its underlying ideas come from?

title: Introduction to algebra
translated_description: The general idea behind the word 'abstract'

title: Introduction to algebra
translated_description: Why the abstraction of mathematics is so fundamental.

title: Introduction to algebra
translated_description: Bridging algebra and geometry. What makes linear equations so linear.

title: Introduction to algebra
translated_description: Jesse Roe and Sal Khan talk about why we use letters in algebra.

title: Introduction to algebra
translated_description: Our focus here is understanding that a variable is just a symbol that can represent different values in an expression. We got this. Just watch.

title: Introduction to algebra
translated_description: Great question. In algebra  we do indeed avoid using the multiplication sign. We'll explain it for you here.

title: Introduction to algebra
translated_description: Learn how to evaluate an expression with variables using a technique called substitution (or "plugging in").

title: Introduction to algebra
translated_description: We've done a few examples together where we were faced with 1 variable. Why not try one that has 2 variables?

title: Introduction to algebra
translated_description: Learn how to evaluate expressions that have two different variables in them by using a technique called substitution (or "plugging in").

title: Introduction to algebra
translated_description: In this example we have a formula for converting Celsius temperature to Fahrenheit. Let's substitute the variable with a value (Celsius temp) to get the degrees in Fahrenheit. Great problem to practice with us!

title: Introduction to algebra
translated_description: In this example of evaluating expressions  we're dusting off some geometry. On top of that  it's a word problem. We're seeing how different concepts in math are layered on top of each to create more interesting and complex problems to solve.

title: Introduction to algebra
translated_description: We're going to put our order of operations knowledge to work as we evaluate this expression. Exponents  specifically  are our focus here.

title: Introduction to algebra
translated_description: Sal writes an expression to represent 11 more than a.

title: Introduction to algebra
translated_description: Learn how to write simple algebraic expressions.

title: Introduction to algebra
translated_description: Learn how to write algebraic expressions that involve grouping quantities in parentheses.

title: Introduction to algebra
translated_description: Identifying the dependent and the independent variables in a word problem.

title: Introduction to algebra
translated_description: It's helpful to express an equation on a graph where we plot at least 2 points. Watch and we'll show you.

title: Introduction to algebra
translated_description: We're flipping the last video on its head and doing the opposite. This time we give you the graph and ask you to express it as an equation.

title: Introduction to algebra
translated_description: In simple addition we learned to add all the numbers together to get a sum. In algebra  numbers are sometimes attached to variables and we need to make sure that the variables are alike before we add the numbers.

title: Introduction to algebra
translated_description: We've learned about order of operations and combining like terms. Let's layer the distributive property on top of this.

title: Introduction to algebra
translated_description: This example of combining like terms in an expression get a little hairy. Listen closely.

title: Introduction to algebra
translated_description: Learn how to simplify algebraic expressions by combining like terms. The expressions in this video have decimal and fraction coefficients.

title: Introduction to algebra
translated_description: Sal finds equivalent expressions by combining like terms and using the distributive property.

title: Introduction to algebra
translated_description: We match the expressions to their meaning in this example. We're reinforcing our knowledge of linear expressions.

title: Introduction to algebra
translated_description: Let's practice matching expressions to their meaning in this example of interpreting linear expressions.

title: Introduction to algebra
translated_description: As much as we would like to have an answer for "what's 1 divided by 0?" it's sadly impossible to have an answer. The reason  in short  is that whatever we may answer  we will then have to agree that that answer times 0 equals to 1  and that cannot be ​true  because anything times 0 is 0.

title: Introduction to algebra
translated_description: One can argue that 0/0 is ​0  because 0 divided by anything is 0. Another one can argue that 0/0 is ​1  because anything divided by itself is 1. And that's exactly the problem! Whatever we say 0/0 equals to  we contradict one crucial property of numbers or another. To avoid "breaking math " we simply say that 0/0 is undetermined.

title: Introduction to algebra
translated_description: Revisiting the problems of dividing any number by zero and dividing zero by zero. Using general mathematical considerations  we see why those are undefined and indeterminate problems.

title: One-variable linear equations
translated_description: Learn what variables  expressions  and equations are.

title: One-variable linear equations
translated_description: A solution to an equation makes that equation true. Learn how to test if a certain value of a variable makes an equation true.

title: One-variable linear equations
translated_description: The example of a scale where we try to achieve balance helps to explain why we do the same thing to both sides of an equation.

title: One-variable linear equations
translated_description: Equations are about relationships (no  not girlfriends and boyfriends!) between the two sides of the equation. Let's again use a scale example to help us understand.

title: One-variable linear equations
translated_description: Let's get a conceptual understanding of why one needs to divide both sides of an equation to solve for a variable.

title: One-variable linear equations
translated_description: This equation can be simplified through a single step to solve for the variable. Can you help?

title: One-variable linear equations
translated_description: Learn how to solve one-step addition and subtraction equations by adding or subtracting the same thing from both sides of the equation.

title: One-variable linear equations
translated_description: Learn how to solve this equation: a + 5 = 54

title: One-variable linear equations
translated_description: Learn how to solve one-step addition and subtraction equations that have fractions and decimals in them.

title: One-variable linear equations
translated_description: Let's ease into this  shall we? Here's an introduction to basic algebraic equations of the form ax=b. Remember that you can check to see if you have the right answer by substituting it for the variable!

title: One-variable linear equations
translated_description: Remember that what you do to one side  you have to do to the other. Will you multiply or divide both sides to dump the fraction  x/a? Let's do it together.

title: One-variable linear equations
translated_description: Learn how to solve equations in one step by multiplying or dividing a number from both sides. These problems involve decimals and fractions.

title: One-variable linear equations
translated_description: Here's how we solve a two step equation. It begins with the concept of equality: what we do to one side of the equation must be done to the other.

title: One-variable linear equations
translated_description: This example demonstrates how we solve an equation expressed such: ax + b = c. It's a little more complicated than previous examples  but you can do it!

title: One-variable linear equations
translated_description: Sal solves the equation -16 = x/4 + 2. It takes two steps because he first has to subtract 2 from both sides and then multiply both sides by 4.

title: One-variable linear equations
translated_description: Learn how to construct and solve a basic linear equation to solve a word problem.

title: One-variable linear equations
translated_description: Here's a nifty word problem in which we find the dimensions of a garden given only the perimeter. Let's create an equation to solve!

title: One-variable linear equations
translated_description: Learn how to solve a word problem by writing an equation to model the situation. In this video  we use the linear equation 210(t-5) = 41 790.

title: One-variable linear equations
translated_description: We will use a scale to try to achieve balance and help explain why we do the same thing to both sides of an equation  even when the variable appears on both sides.

title: One-variable linear equations
translated_description: Worked example: Learn to solve the equation 2x + 3 = 5x - 2.

title: One-variable linear equations
translated_description: Sal solves the equation 20 - 7x = 6x - 6.

title: One-variable linear equations
translated_description: Sal solves the equation (3/4)x + 2 = (3/8)x - 4.

title: One-variable linear equations
translated_description: Sal solves the equation 7 - 10/x = 2 + 15/x.

title: One-variable linear equations
translated_description: Sal solves the equation -9 - (9x - 6) = 3(4x + 6) using the distributive property.

title: One-variable linear equations
translated_description: See how some equations have one solution  others have no solutions  and still others have infinite solutions.

title: One-variable linear equations
translated_description: Sal attempts to solve 8(3x + 10) = 28x - 14 - 4x only to find that the equation has no solution.

title: One-variable linear equations
translated_description: Sal shows how to complete the equation -11x + 4 = __x + __ so that it has no solutions.

title: One-variable linear equations
translated_description: Sal shows how to complete the equation 4(x - 2) + x = 5x + __ so that it has infinitely many solutions.

title: One-variable linear equations
translated_description: Sal solves the following age word problem: The sum of 4 consecutive odd integers is 136. What are the 4 integers?

title: One-variable linear equations
translated_description: Sal solves the following problem: The sum of three consecutive odd integers is 231. What is the largest integer?

title: One-variable linear equations
translated_description: Sal solves the following word problem: You have 50 ounces of a 25% saline solution. How many ounces of a 10% saline solution must you add to make a solution that is 15% saline?

title: One-variable linear equations
translated_description: Sal solves the following problem: Drink A with 40% sugar is mixed with Drink B to obtain Drink C which has 25% sugar. What is the percentage of sugar of Drink B?

title: One-variable linear equations
translated_description: Sal solves the equations ax+3x=bx+5 and a(5-x)=bx-8 for x. Note that these equations include other unknowns (a and b) but we solve them for x.

title: One-variable linear inequalities
translated_description: A solution to an inequality makes that inequality true. Learn how to test if a certain value of a variable makes an inequality true.

title: One-variable linear inequalities
translated_description: To plot an inequality  such as x>3  on a number line  first draw a circle over the number (e.g.  3). Then if the sign includes equal to (≥ or ≤)  fill in the circle. If the sign does not include equal to (> or <)  leave the circle unfilled in. Finally  draw a line going from the circle in the direction of the numbers that make the inequality true.

title: One-variable linear inequalities
translated_description: Learn how to plot a simple inequality on a number line. The example used in this video is x < 4.

title: One-variable linear inequalities
translated_description: Learn how to write inequalities to model real-world situation.

title: One-variable linear inequalities
translated_description: Our discussion of linear inequalities begins with multiplying and dividing by negative numbers. Listen closely for the word "swap." Super important!

title: One-variable linear inequalities
translated_description: In addition to solving the inequality  we'll graph the solution. Remember to swap if you mutiply both sides of the inequality by a negative number.

title: One-variable linear inequalities
translated_description: Inequalities are more than abstract concepts and exercises. They help solve real life problems. Here's an example.

title: One-variable linear inequalities
translated_description: Two-step inequalities are slightly more complicated than one-step inequalities (duh!). This is a worked example of solving ⅔>-4y-8⅓.

title: One-variable linear inequalities
translated_description: We'll talk you through this fun and challenging inequality problem.

title: One-variable linear inequalities
translated_description: Let's tackle this word problem together. We'll interpret the information and then construct a linear inequality to solve it.

title: One-variable linear inequalities
translated_description: Sal solves the inequality -3p-7<p+9  draws the solution on a number line and checks a few values to verify the solution.

title: One-variable linear inequalities
translated_description: Sal solves the inequality 5x+7>3(x+1)  draws the solution on a number line and checks a few values to verify the solution.

title: One-variable linear inequalities
translated_description: Sal solves several multi-step linear inequalities.

title: One-variable linear inequalities
translated_description: Sal solves the compound inequality 5z+7<27 OR -3z≤18.

title: One-variable linear inequalities
translated_description: Sal solves the compound inequality 3y+7<2y AND 4y+8>-48.

title: One-variable linear inequalities
translated_description: Sal solves the compound inequality 5x-3<12 AND 4x+1>25  only to realize there's no x-value that makes both inequalities true.

title: One-variable linear inequalities
translated_description: Sal solves the double inequality -16≤3x+5≤20  which is the same as the compound inequality -16≤3x+5 AND 3x+5≤20.

title: One-variable linear inequalities
translated_description: Sal solves several compound linear inequalities.

title: Units of measurement in modeling
translated_description: Sal shows how we can treat units of measurement algebraically  and use these tools in order to convert between different units of the same quantity.

title: Units of measurement in modeling
translated_description: Sal shows how we can describe the rate 50 km per hour in a variety of different units  using dimensional analysis.

title: Units of measurement in modeling
translated_description: Examples for determining the appropriate units to use to measure a quantity of interest.

title: Units of measurement in modeling
translated_description: Sal finds an appropriate measurement unit for Power given the formula P=W/t where P is Power  W is Work  and t is Time.

title: Units of measurement in modeling
translated_description: Sal finds an appropriate measurement unit for carrot yield given the formula Y=2C/P where Y is yield  C is # of carrots  and P is # of plants.

title: Units of measurement in modeling
translated_description: Sal solves two related proportion word problems about a squirrel crossing the road and a car that approaches it. He does that using dimensional analysis.

title: Units of measurement in modeling
translated_description: Sal solves a word problem where he finds the cost of gas in a road trip given the car's fuel efficiency  length of the trip  and price of gas.

title: Units of measurement in modeling
translated_description: Sal solves a US customary distance word problem involving miles  yards  and feet.

title: Units of measurement in modeling
translated_description: Future doctors and nurses out there  take note. This unit conversion word problem deals with converting drug dosage units  something that is commonly done in hospitals. Give it a try with us.

title: Two-variable linear equations
translated_description: Learn about a class of equations in two variables that's called "linear equations." They are called that way because their graph is a line. These are the most basic and probably most useful equations you will ever know!

title: Two-variable linear equations
translated_description: The solution of an equation with one variable is a number. How does the solution of a 2-variable equation look like? Well  it is an ordered pair. Learn more about it and how to test solutions to 2-variable equations.

title: Two-variable linear equations
translated_description: How do you check if an ordered pair is a solution to a given equation? You need to plug in the numbers and see what equality results. Watch this video to see a worked example.

title: Two-variable linear equations
translated_description: Given a 2-variable equation and the x or y values of a solution  Sal finds the value of the other variable in the solution.

title: Two-variable linear equations
translated_description: Learn what x- and y-intercepts are.  The equations used in this video are y = 0.5x - 3 and 5x + 6y = 30.

title: Two-variable linear equations
translated_description: Sal determines the x-intercept of a linear equation from a graph. Afterwards  he checks his work by plugging values back into the equation.

title: Two-variable linear equations
translated_description: Sal finds the x and y-intercepts of -5x + 4y = 20.

title: Two-variable linear equations
translated_description: Sal finds the y-intercept of the graph of a linear function given a table of values.

title: Two-variable linear equations
translated_description: Sal shows how to find the slope of a line.

title: Two-variable linear equations
translated_description: Sal analyzes what it means for a slope to be positive or negative (spoiler: it affects the direction of the line!)

title: Two-variable linear equations
translated_description: The slope of a line is rise over run. Learn how to calculate the slope of the line in a graph by finding the change in y and the change in x.

title: Two-variable linear equations
translated_description: Find the slope of the line that goes through the ordered pairs (4 2) and (-3  16).

title: Two-variable linear equations
translated_description: Given two points on a line  you can find the slope of the line. Watch Sal doing a bunch of examples.

title: Two-variable linear equations
translated_description: When two points have the same y-value  it means they lie on a horizontal line. The slope of such a line is 0  and you will also find this by using the slope formula.

title: Two-variable linear equations
translated_description: Worked examples identifying the equations and slope of horizontal and vertical lines.

title: Two-variable linear equations
translated_description: Slope-intercept form  y=mx+b  of linear equations  emphasizes the slope and the y-intercept of the line. Watch this video to learn more about it and see some examples.

title: Two-variable linear equations
translated_description: Worked examples practicing the relationship between slope  y-intercept  and linear equation in slope-intercept form.

title: Two-variable linear equations
translated_description: To graph a linear equation in slope-intercept form  we can use the information given by that form. For example  y=2x+3 tells us that the slope of the line is 2 and the y-intercept is at (0 3). This gives us one point the line goes through  and the direction we should continue from that point to draw the entire line.

title: Two-variable linear equations
translated_description: Learn to write equations in slope-intercept form for three different lines.

title: Two-variable linear equations
translated_description: Learn how to find the equation of the line with a slope of -3/4 that goes through the point (0 8).

title: Two-variable linear equations
translated_description: Learn how to find the equation of the line that goes through the points (-1  6) and (5  -4).

title: Two-variable linear equations
translated_description: Learn how to solve problems involving writing an equation in slope-intercept form.

title: Two-variable linear equations
translated_description: Point-slope is the general form y-y₁=m(x-x₁) for linear equations. It emphasizes the slope of the line and a point on the line (that is not the y-intercept). Watch this video to learn more about it and see some examples.

title: Two-variable linear equations
translated_description: Sal finds a point-slope equation for a line from two points  then converts that equation to slope-intercept form.

title: Two-variable linear equations
translated_description: The standard form for linear equations in two variables is Ax+By=C. For example  2x+3y=5 is a linear equation in standard form. When an equation is given in this form  it's pretty easy to find both intercepts (x and y). This form is also very useful when solving systems of two linear equations.

title: Two-variable linear equations
translated_description: Sal creates a graph of the linear equation 5x + 2y = 20.

title: Two-variable linear equations
translated_description: Sal converts the slope-intercept equation y=2/3x+4/7 to standard form.

title: Two-variable linear equations
translated_description: Worked examples of finding the slope of a line given its equation  using many forms of equations.

title: Two-variable linear equations
translated_description: Sal finds the equation of a line that passes through (-3 6) and (6 0) in point-slope  slope-intercept  and standard form.

title: Functions
translated_description: Functions assign a single unique output for each of their inputs. In this video  we see examples of various kinds of functions.

title: Functions
translated_description: Learn how to evaluate f(x)=49-x² at x=5.

title: Functions
translated_description: Evaluating a function at x=-1 using the graph of that function.

title: Functions
translated_description: Evaluating -2⋅f(-6)+g(1) given the graphs of f and g.

title: Functions
translated_description: Sal finds the input value for which f(t)=13  given that f(t)=-2t+5.

title: Functions
translated_description: Sal finds the input value for which g(x)=-2 given the graph of g.

title: Functions
translated_description: Sal finds the input value other than -5 for which f(x)=f(-5)  given the graph of f.

title: Functions
translated_description: Equations and functions are not the same thing  but they can be related in several ways. Watch Jesse Roe and Sal talk about the difference between equations and functions

title: Functions
translated_description: Equations and functions are not the same thing  but they can be related in several ways. In this video  we obtain a function from an equation. The function represents the same relationship between the quantities in the equation.

title: Functions
translated_description: Learn how to interpret expressions that contain a function within a real-world context. In this video  the function we interpret models an account balance over time.

title: Functions
translated_description: Learn how to interpret expressions that contain a function within a real-world context. In this video  the function we interpret models the number of people at the beach over time.

title: Functions
translated_description: Introducing intervals  which are bounded sets of numbers and are very useful when describing domain and range.

title: Functions
translated_description: Functions assign outputs to inputs. The domain of a function is the set of all possible inputs for the function. For example  the domain of f(x)=x² is all real numbers  and the domain of g(x)=1/x is all real numbers except for x=0. We can also define special functions whose domains are more limited.

title: Functions
translated_description: Sal introduces the concept of "range" of a function and gives examples for functions and their ranges.

title: Functions
translated_description: Finding the domain and the range of a function that is given graphically.

title: Functions
translated_description: Finding the domain of f(x)=√(2x-8).

title: Functions
translated_description: Many examples of determining the domains of functions according to mathematical limitations.

title: Functions
translated_description: Determining the domain of a function that models the height of a plant over time.

title: Functions
translated_description: Determining the domain of a function that models the price of candy bars.

title: Functions
translated_description: Determining the domain of a function that models going up and down a ladder.

title: Functions
translated_description: Checking whether a given set of points can represent a function. For the set to represent a function  each domain element must have one corresponding range element at most.

title: Functions
translated_description: Explaining why a vertical line doesn't represent a function.

title: Functions
translated_description: Checking whether a table of people and their heights can represent a function that assigns a height to a name.

title: Functions
translated_description: Checking whether y can be described as a function of x if y is always three more than twice x.

title: Functions
translated_description: Checking whether a description of the price of an order can be represented as a function of the shipping cost.

title: Functions
translated_description: Sal explains all about minimum and maximum points  both absolute and relative.

title: Functions
translated_description: Sal gives multiple examples where he identifies relative maximum points  relative minimum points  absolute maximum points  and absolute minimum points.

title: Functions
translated_description: Function values can be positive or negative  and they can increase or decrease as the input increases. Here we introduce these basic properties of functions.

title: Functions
translated_description: Finding the positive or negative intervals of a function from its graph.

title: Functions
translated_description: When a function models a real-world context  we can learn a lot about the content from the function's graph. In this video  we consider a graph that models temperature over time.

title: Functions
translated_description: When a function models a real-world context  we can learn a lot about the content from the function's graph. In this video  we interpret the y-intercept of a graph that models a basketball free throw.

title: Functions
translated_description: What's the average rate of change of a function over an interval?

title: Functions
translated_description: Finding the interval in a function's graph where the function has an average rate of change of -4.

title: Functions
translated_description: Finding the average rate of change of a function over the interval -5<x<-2  given a table of values of the function.

title: Functions
translated_description: Finding the interval where a function has an average rate of change of ½ given its equation.

title: Functions
translated_description: Average rate of change tells us how much the function changed per a single time unit  over a specific interval. It has many real-world applications. In this video  we compare the average rate of change of temperature over different time periods.

title: Functions
translated_description: Average rate of change tells us how much the function changed per a single time unit  over a specific interval. It has many real-world applications. In this video  we find the average rate of descent of a skydiver over a specific time interval.

title: Functions
translated_description: Average rate of change tells us how much the function changed per a single time unit  over a specific interval. It has many real-world applications. In this video  we represent the average rate of water draining with an algebraic expression.

title: Linear equations and functions word problems
translated_description: Sal finds the slope of a linear relationship between the number of work hours and the money earned. He then interprets what this slope means in that context.

title: Linear equations and functions word problems
translated_description: Sal finds the y-intercept and the slope of a linear relationship representing someone climbing a volcano. He then interprets what the y-intercept and the slope mean in that context.

title: Linear equations and functions word problems
translated_description: Sal discusses how we would go about making sense of the direction of a linear graph that represents a relationship between two real-world quantities.

title: Linear equations and functions word problems
translated_description: Sal finds the y-intercept and the slope of a linear relationship representing someone accumulating cats! He then interprets what the y-intercept and the slope mean in that context.

title: Linear equations and functions word problems
translated_description: Sal finds the y-intercept and the slope of a linear relationship representing someone filling a glass tank with marbles. He then interprets what the y-intercept and the slope mean in that context.

title: Linear equations and functions word problems
translated_description: Sal finds the y-intercept and the slope of a linear relationship representing a top secret file transfer. He then interprets what the y-intercept and the slope mean in that context.

title: Linear equations and functions word problems
translated_description: Sal is given the formula of a linear function and the graph of another  and is asked to determine which function increases faster.

title: Linear equations and functions word problems
translated_description: Sal is given a table of values of a linear function and four linear graphs  and is asked to determine which graph has the same rate of change as the function represented in the table.

title: Linear equations and functions word problems
translated_description: Sal is given a table of values of a linear function and four linear graphs  and is asked to determine which graph increases faster than the function represented in the table.

title: Linear equations and functions word problems
translated_description: Sal is given the formula and a table of values that represent two people climbing a wall  and is asked to determine which one started out higher.

title: Linear equations and functions word problems
translated_description: Sal is given a table of values that represents four people walking to school  and is asked to determine which one started out farther from the school.

title: Linear equations and functions word problems
translated_description: Sal is given a table of values that represents a person walking to work  and is asked to determine which verbal description represents someone starting at the same distance from work.

title: Linear equations and functions word problems
translated_description: Sal is given a verbal description of a real-world relationship involving a truck's fuel consumption  and is asked to draw the graph that represents this relationship.

title: Linear equations and functions word problems
translated_description: Sal is given a verbal description of a real-world relationship involving a pool being filled with water  and is asked to draw the graph that represents this relationship.

title: Linear equations and functions word problems
translated_description: Sal is given a verbal description of a real-world relationship involving a melting iceberg  and is asked to find the formula of the function that represents this relationship.

title: Linear equations and functions word problems
translated_description: Sal is given a verbal description of a real-world relationship involving a person painting his room  and is asked to find the formula of the function that represents this relationship.

title: Linear equations and functions word problems
translated_description: Sal solves a word problem about a person reading a book  The solution involves the modeling of the situation as a linear function.

title: Linear equations and functions word problems
translated_description: Sal solves a word problem about a person filling a glass tank with marbles  The solution involves the modeling of the situation as a linear function.

title: Sequences
translated_description: Sequences are ordered lists of numbers (called "terms")  like 2 5 8. Some sequences follow a specific pattern that can be used to extend them indefinitely. For example  2 5 8 follows the pattern "add 3 " and now we can continue the sequence. Sequences can have formulas that tell us how to find any term in the sequence. For example  2 5 8 ... can be represented by the formula 2+3(n-1).

title: Sequences
translated_description: Sal introduces arithmetic sequences and their main features  the initial term and the common difference. He gives various examples of such sequences  defined explicitly and recursively.

title: Sequences
translated_description: Sal extends the arithmetic sequences -8  -14  -20  -26 ... and 2  -1  -4  -7  -10 ... to find their next terms.

title: Sequences
translated_description: Sal finds terms of arithmetic sequences using their explicit and recursive formulas.

title: Sequences
translated_description: Example finding the 4th term in a recursively defined arithmetic sequence.

title: Sequences
translated_description: Sal finds the recursive formula of the arithmetic sequence 4  3⅘  3⅗  3⅖ ...

title: Sequences
translated_description: Sal finds explicit formulas of arithmetic sequences given the first few terms of those sequences. He also explores equivalent forms of such formulas.

title: Sequences
translated_description: Sal finds the 100th term in the sequence 15  9  3  -3...

title: Sequences
translated_description: Sal is given an arithmetic sequence in explicit form and he converts it to recursive form. Then he does so the other way around!

title: Sequences
translated_description: Sal introduces geometric sequences and their main features  the initial term and the common ratio.

title: Sequences
translated_description: Sal finds the next term in the geometric sequence -1/32  1/8  -1/2  2 ...

title: Sequences
translated_description: Sal finds the 5th term in the geometric sequence whose explicit formula is 3(-¼)^(i-1).

title: Sequences
translated_description: Sal finds the 4th term in the sequence whose recursive formula is a(1)=-⅛  a(i)=2a(i-1).

title: Sequences
translated_description: Sal finds an explicit formula of a geometric sequence given the first few terms of the sequences. Then he explores equivalent forms the explicit formula and finds the corresponding recursive formula.

title: Sequences
translated_description: Sal solves the following problem: The explicit formula of a geometric sequence is g(x)=9*8^(x-1). Find the recursive formula of the sequence.

title: Sequences
translated_description: Sal solves two word problems about modeling real-world situations with arithmetic and geometric sequences.

title: Sequences
translated_description: Sal shows how to evaluate a sequence that is defined with a recursive formula. This definition gives the base case and then defines how to find the subsequent terms using the base case.

title: Systems of linear equations
translated_description: A troll forces us to use algebra to figure out the make-up of his currency. We end up setting up a system of equations.

title: Systems of linear equations
translated_description: Solving the system of equations visually. Now we can save the prince/princess.

title: Systems of linear equations
translated_description: Sal uses simple elimination to figure out how many cupcakes are eaten by children and adults.

title: Systems of linear equations
translated_description: Sal solves another system of equations using elimination.

title: Systems of linear equations
translated_description: To solve a system of equations using substitution...
column9: 1. Isolate one of the variables in one of the equations  e.g. rewrite 2x+y=3 as y=3-2x.
column10: 2. You can now express the isolated variable using the other one. *Substitute* that expression into the second equation  e.g. rewrite x+2y=5 as x+2(3-2x)=5.
column11: 3. Now you have an equation with one variable! Solve it  and use what you got to find the other variable.

title: Systems of linear equations
translated_description: Sal gives an example of a system of equations that has no solution!

title: Systems of linear equations
translated_description: Sal gives an example of a system of equations that has infinite solutions!

title: Systems of linear equations
translated_description: A troll forces us to use algebra to figure out the make-up of his currency. We end up setting up a system of equations.

title: Systems of linear equations
translated_description: Solving the system of equations visually. Now we can save the prince/princess.

title: Systems of linear equations
translated_description: Sal checks whether (-1 7) is a solution of the system: x+2y=13 and 3x-y=-11.

title: Systems of linear equations
translated_description: Sal graphs the following system of equations and solves it by looking for the intersection point: y=7/5x-5 and y=3/5x-1.

title: Systems of linear equations
translated_description: Sal solves a system of two linear equations in standard form  and then approximates the solution of a system whose solution isn't clearly visible.

title: Systems of linear equations
translated_description: Sal uses simple elimination to figure out how many cupcakes are eaten by children and adults.

title: Systems of linear equations
translated_description: Sal solves the following system of equations by eliminating x: x-4y=-18 and -x+3y=11.

title: Systems of linear equations
translated_description: Sal solves another system of equations using elimination.

title: Systems of linear equations
translated_description: In some cases  we need to slightly manipulate a system of equations before we can solve it using the elimination method. So how it's done in this video.

title: Systems of linear equations
translated_description: The example of a scale where we try to achieve balance helps to explain why we can subtract one equation from the other in a system of equations.

title: Systems of linear equations
translated_description: Sal analyzes a couple of systems of equations and determines whether they have the same solution as a third given system.

title: Systems of linear equations
translated_description: Sal analyzes a couple of systems of equations and determines whether they have the same solution as a third given system.

title: Systems of linear equations
translated_description: To solve a system of equations using substitution...
