column9: 1. Isolate one of the variables in one of the equations  e.g. rewrite 2x+y=3 as y=3-2x.
column10: 2. You can now express the isolated variable using the other one. *Substitute* that expression into the second equation  e.g. rewrite x+2y=5 as x+2(3-2x)=5.
column11: 3. Now you have an equation with one variable! Solve it  and use what you got to find the other variable.

title: Systems of linear equations
translated_description: Learn to solve the system of equations -3x - 4y = -2 and y = 2x - 5 using substitution.

title: Systems of linear equations
translated_description: Given that a+b=0  Sal finds an expression equivalent to a*b.

title: Systems of linear equations
translated_description: Given that a+b=2a  Sal finds an expression equivalent to b-a.

title: Systems of linear equations
translated_description: Sal gives an example of a system of equations that has no solution!

title: Systems of linear equations
translated_description: Sal gives an example of a system of equations that has infinite solutions!

title: Systems of linear equations
translated_description: A consistent system of equations has at least one solution  and an inconsistent system has no solution. Watch an example of analyzing a system to see if it's consistent or inconsistent.

title: Systems of linear equations
translated_description: A dependent system of equations has infinite solutions  and an independent system has a single solution. Watch an example of analyzing a system to see if it's dependent or independent.

title: Systems of linear equations
translated_description: Sal is given three lines on the coordinate plane  and identifies one system of two lines that has a single solution  and one system that has no solution.

title: Systems of linear equations
translated_description: Sal determines how many solutions the following system of equations has by considering its graph: 10x-2y=4 and 10x-2y=16.

title: Systems of linear equations
translated_description: Sal solves several examples where he reasons about the number of solutions of systems of equations using algebraic reasoning.

title: Systems of linear equations
translated_description: Sal answers this question for you!

title: Systems of linear equations
translated_description: Sal solves the following age word problem: In 40 years  Imran will be 11 times as old as he is right now. How old is he right now?

title: Systems of linear equations
translated_description: Sal solves the following age word problem: William is 4 times as old as Ben. 12 years ago  William was 7 times as old as Ben. How old is Ben now?

title: Systems of linear equations
translated_description: Sal solves the following age word problem: Arman is 18. Diya is 2. How many years will it take for Arman to be 3 times as old as Diya?

title: Systems of linear equations
translated_description: Systems of equations can be used to solve many real-world problems. In this video  we solve a problem about distances walking and riding bus to school.

title: Systems of linear equations
translated_description: Systems of equations can be used to solve many real-world problems. In this video  we solve a problem about a toy factory. In this case  the problem has no viable solution  which means the information describes an impossible situation.

title: Systems of linear equations
translated_description: Systems of equations can be used to solve many real-world problems. In this video  we solve a problem about a vegetable framer. In this case  the problem has infinite solutions  which means there's not enough information to find a single solution.

title: Systems of linear equations
translated_description: Sal solves a word problem about the weights of TVs and DVDs by creating a system of equations and solving it.

title: Systems of linear equations
translated_description: Sal solves a word problem about the price of apples and oranges by creating a system of equations and solving it.

title: Systems of linear equations
translated_description: Sal solves a word problem about the number of nickels and quarters in a piggy bank by creating a system of equations and solving it.

title: Systems of linear equations
translated_description: Sal solves a word problem about the price of coffee and croissant by creating a system of equations and solving it.

title: Two-variable linear inequalities
translated_description: Sal checks if the ordered pairs (3 5) and (1 -7) are solutions of the inequality 5x-3y≥25.

title: Two-variable linear inequalities
translated_description: Sal checks whether the ordered pair (2 5) is a solution of the following system: y≥2x+1 and x>1.

title: Two-variable linear inequalities
translated_description: Learn how to graph two-variable linear inequalities like y≤4x+3.

title: Two-variable linear inequalities
translated_description: Sal graphs the inequality y<3x+5.

title: Two-variable linear inequalities
translated_description: Sal is given a graph and he analyzes it to find the two-variable inequality it represents.

title: Two-variable linear inequalities
translated_description: Learn how to graph systems of two-variable linear inequalities  like "y>x-8 and y<5-x."

title: Two-variable linear inequalities
translated_description: Sal graphs the solution set of the system "y≥2x+1 and y<2x-5 and x>1."

title: Two-variable linear inequalities
translated_description: Sal solves a word problem about scores in a chess tournament by creating a two-variable linear inequality.

title: Two-variable linear inequalities
translated_description: Given a two-variable linear inequality that models a context about watering plants  Sal finds how many flowers can be watered.

title: Two-variable linear inequalities
translated_description: Given the graph of a two-variable linear inequality that models a context about dog biscuits  Sal finds if the dog can get enough biscuits.

title: Two-variable linear inequalities
translated_description: Sal analyzes a two-variable linear inequality that models a context about YouTube videos.

title: Two-variable linear inequalities
translated_description: Sal models a real-world context into an algebraic system of linear inequalities and graphs it.

title: Two-variable linear inequalities
translated_description: Sal models a word problem about baking cupcakes and muffins by creating a system of linear inequalities.

title: Two-variable linear inequalities
translated_description: Given a system of linear inequalities that models a context about making chairs and tables  Sal finds how many can be made.

title: Two-variable linear inequalities
translated_description: Given the graph of a two-variable linear inequality that models a context about chopping vegetables  Sal finds if there's enough time to chop!

title: Two-variable linear inequalities
translated_description: Given a real-world context about the number of fruits bought  we find a linear inequality that correctly depicts the situation.

title: Two-variable linear inequalities
translated_description: Given a real-world context about the number of balls in a bag  we find a linear inequality that correctly depicts the situation.

title: Absolute value & piecewise functions
translated_description: The graph of y=|x-k|+h is the graph of y=|x| shifted k units to the right and h units up. See worked examples practicing this relationship.

title: Absolute value & piecewise functions
translated_description: The graph of y=k|x| is the graph of y=|x| scaled by a factor of |k|. If k<0  it's also reflected (or "flipped") across the x-axis. In this worked example  we find the equation of an absolute value function from a description of the transformation performed on y=|x|.

title: Absolute value & piecewise functions
translated_description: The graph of y=k|x| is the graph of y=|x| scaled by a factor of |k|. If k<0  it's also reflected (or "flipped") across the x-axis. In this worked example  we find the equation of an absolute value function from its graph.

title: Absolute value & piecewise functions
translated_description: We can graph any equation of the form y=k|x-a|+h by thinking about function transformations (shifts  reflections  and scalings).

title: Absolute value & piecewise functions
translated_description: Functions assign outputs to inputs. Some functions have simple rules  like "for every x  return x²." However  there can be other rules that are more elaborate. For example  "If x<0  return 2x  and if x≥0  return 3x." These are called *piecewise functions*  because their rules aren't uniform  but consist of multiple pieces

title: Absolute value & piecewise functions
translated_description: Evaluating piecewise functions at given inputs  both from a formula and from a graph.

title: Absolute value & piecewise functions
translated_description: Graphing a piecewise function given its formula. In this case  the function consists of three separate lines.

title: Absolute value & piecewise functions
translated_description: Finding the domain and range of a piecewise function that is constant in each segment. Such functions are called "step functions."

title: Absolute value & piecewise functions
translated_description: Finding the domain and range of a piecewise function where each segment is linear.

title: Expressions with rational exponents and radicals
translated_description: For any base a and for any exponents n and m  aⁿ⋅aᵐ=aⁿ⁺ᵐ and aⁿ/aᵐ=aⁿ⁻ᵐ. These are worked examples for using these properties with integer exponents.

title: Expressions with rational exponents and radicals
translated_description: For any integers a and b and for any exponents n  (a⋅b)ⁿ=aⁿ⋅bⁿ and (a/b)ⁿ=aⁿ/bⁿ. These are worked examples for using these properties with integer exponents.

title: Expressions with rational exponents and radicals
translated_description: Learn about the square root symbol (the principal root) and what it means to find a square root. Also learn how to solve simple square root equations.

title: Expressions with rational exponents and radicals
translated_description: Learn how square root means what number multiplied by itself will result in the given number.

title: Expressions with rational exponents and radicals
translated_description: Learn the meaning of cube roots and how to find them. Also learn how to find the cube root of a negative number.

title: Expressions with rational exponents and radicals
translated_description: Learn how to find the square root of a decimal number. The problem solved in this video is p^2 = 0.81.

title: Expressions with rational exponents and radicals
translated_description: 5th roots

title: Expressions with rational exponents and radicals
translated_description: What does it mean to take a number by a power which is a unit fraction? For example  what is the result of 3 raised to ½?

title: Expressions with rational exponents and radicals
translated_description: Sal solves several problems about the equivalence of expressions with roots and rational exponents. For example  rewrite ⁶√(g⁵) as g^⅚.

title: Expressions with rational exponents and radicals
translated_description: A worked example of rewriting a radical as an exponent. In this example  we solve for the unknown in 3ᵃ = ⁵√(3²).

title: Expressions with rational exponents and radicals
translated_description: Sal simplifies the expression m^(7/9) / m^(1/3) as a single exponential term m^(4/9).

title: Expressions with rational exponents and radicals
translated_description: Sal rewrites (r^(2/3)s^3)^2*√(20r^4s^5)  once as an exponential expression and once as a radical expression.

title: Expressions with rational exponents and radicals
translated_description: Sal shows how to evaluate 64^(2/3) and (8/27)^(-2/3).

title: Expressions with rational exponents and radicals
translated_description: How to evaluate powers that are negative unit fractions  like 9 raised to -½ and 27 raised to -⅓.

title: Expressions with rational exponents and radicals
translated_description: Sal shows how to evaluate (25/9)^(1/2) and (81/256)^(-1/4).

title: Expressions with rational exponents and radicals
translated_description: Sal simplifies the complicated expression 256^(4/7) / 2^(4/7)  until he finds that the expression is equal to 16.

title: Expressions with rational exponents and radicals
translated_description: A worked example of calculating an expression that has both a radical and an exponent. In this example  we evaluate 6^(1/2)⋅(⁵√6)³.

title: Expressions with rational exponents and radicals
translated_description: Roots are nice  but we prefer dealing with regular numbers as much as possible. So  for example  instead of √4 we prefer dealing with 2. What about roots that aren't equal to an integer  like √20? Still  we can write 20 as 4⋅5 and then use known properties to write √(4⋅5) as √4⋅√5  which is 2√5. We *simplified* √20.

title: Expressions with rational exponents and radicals
translated_description: A worked example of simplifying radical with a variable in it. In this example  we simplify 3√(500x³).

title: Expressions with rational exponents and radicals
translated_description: Worked examples of taking expressions with square roots and taking all of the perfect squares out of the square roots. For example  2√(7x)⋅3√(14x²) can be written as 42x√(2x).

title: Expressions with rational exponents and radicals
translated_description: Multiple examples of simplifications of higher-index radicals. For example  simplifying ⁵√96 as 2⁵√3.

title: Expressions with rational exponents and radicals
translated_description: A worked example of simplifying elaborate expressions that contain radicals. In this example  we simplify 5∛(2x²)⋅3∛(4x⁴).

title: Expressions with rational exponents and radicals
translated_description: Sal simplifies ∛(125x⁶y³) as 5x²y.

title: Expressions with rational exponents and radicals
translated_description: How to rewrite a radical with variables in it as an exponent and then simplify it using exponent properties. In this example  we simplify ∜(5a⁴b¹²).

title: Introduction to exponential functions
translated_description: In exponential functions the variable is in the exponent  like y=3ˣ. Here we introduce this concept with a few examples.

title: Introduction to exponential functions
translated_description: For constant increments in x  a linear growth would increase by a constant difference  and an exponential growth would increase by a constant ratio.

title: Introduction to exponential functions
translated_description: Sal sorts various descriptions of real-world situation according to the type of growth they describe: linear or exponential.

title: Introduction to exponential functions
translated_description: Determining whether real world model is linear or exponential  where the model is given as a table.

title: Introduction to exponential functions
translated_description: Given the description of a real-world context  we write a calculation of a certain measure. The expression is exponential because it involves repeated multiplication.

title: Introduction to exponential functions
translated_description: Get comfortable with the basic ingredients of exponential functions: the Initial value and the common ratio.

title: Introduction to exponential functions
translated_description: Given a a real-world context that involves repeated multiplication  we model it with an exponential function.

title: Introduction to exponential functions
translated_description: Given an exponential function that models a real-world context  we interpret it to see what each part of the function represents in the real world.

title: Introduction to exponential functions
translated_description: Analyzing the features of exponential graphs through the example of y=5ˣ.

title: Introduction to exponential functions
translated_description: Identifying which graph represents a given exponential function.

title: Introduction to exponential functions
translated_description: If we compare linear and exponential growth  we will see that over time  *any* exponential growth will surpass *any* linear growth  no matter how steep it is.

title: Introduction to exponential functions
translated_description: An exponential function a⋅rˣ is growing (increasing) if r>1 and decaying (decreasing) if 0

title: Introduction to exponential functions
translated_description: Graphing the exponential functions y=27⋅(⅓)ˣ and y=-30⋅2ˣ.

title: Introduction to exponential functions
translated_description: Two word problem examples: one about a radioactive decay  and the other the exponential growth of a fast-food chain.

title: Introduction to exponential functions
translated_description: Writing the exponential function whose initial value is -2 and common ratio is 1/7.

title: Introduction to exponential functions
translated_description: Writing a linear function of the form f(x)=mx+b and an exponential function of the form g(x)=a⋅rˣ  given a table of values of those functions.

title: Introduction to exponential functions
translated_description: Writing a linear function of the form f(x)=mx+b and an exponential function of the form g(x)=a⋅rˣ  given the graphs of those functions.

title: Introduction to exponential functions
translated_description: Sal is given a table of values of an exponential function and he analyzes it in order to find the common ratio and the initial value.

title: Introduction to exponential functions
translated_description: Given the graph of an exponential function  Sal finds the formula of the function and a value that is outside the graph.

title: Introduction to exponential functions
translated_description: Given the graph of an exponential function with a negative initial value  Sal finds the formula of the function and solves an equation.

title: Introduction to exponential functions
translated_description: Sal solves a word problem where he models the growth of a speeding ticket fine over time as an exponential function  and then interprets this model.

title: Introduction to polynomials
translated_description: Polynomials are sums of terms of the form k⋅xⁿ  where k is any number and n is a positive integer. For example  3x+2x-5 is a polynomial. Introduction to polynomials. This video covers common terminology like terms  degree  standard form  monomial  binomial and trinomial.

title: Introduction to polynomials
translated_description: Learn about the parts of polynomial expressions (including terms  coefficients  and exponents).

title: Introduction to polynomials
translated_description: Evaluating 3x²-8x+7 when x=-2.

title: Introduction to polynomials
translated_description: Simplifying the polynomial 3x²-8x+7+2x³-x²+8x-3 by combining like terms.

title: Introduction to polynomials
translated_description: Sal simplifies (5x² + 8x - 3) + (2x² - 7x + 13x).

title: Introduction to polynomials
translated_description: Sal simplifies (16x+14) - (3x² + x - 9).

title: Introduction to polynomials
translated_description: Sal subtracts (-2x²+4x-1) from (6x²+3x-9) and shows that the set of polynomials is closed under addition and subtraction.

title: Introduction to polynomials
translated_description: Sal simplifies (x³ + 3x - 6) + (-2x² + x - 2) - (3x - 4).

title: Introduction to polynomials
translated_description: Sal simplifies (4x²y - 3x² - 2y) + (8xy - 3x² + 2x²y + 4).

title: Introduction to polynomials
translated_description: Sal simplifies (4x²y - 3xy + 25) - (9y²x + 7xy - 20).

title: Introduction to polynomials
translated_description: Sal subtracts -6x⁴-3x²y²+5y⁴ from 2x⁴-8x²y²-y⁴.

title: Introduction to polynomials
translated_description: Sal analyzes a polynomial subtraction process to find the step that has an error.

title: Introduction to polynomials
translated_description: If you can't get enough of Sal adding and subtracting polynomials  here's a bunch of many more examples.

title: Introduction to polynomials
translated_description: Learn how to multiply monomials like 5x² * 4x⁶ or 4p³ * p.

title: Introduction to polynomials
translated_description: Sal expresses the area of a rectangle with length 4xy and width 2y as a monomial.

title: Introduction to polynomials
translated_description: Learn to express the area of a rectangle with length 4y and width 2y as a monomial.

title: Introduction to polynomials
translated_description: Sal finds the values of coefficients a and b that make (3x^a)(bx^4)=-24x^6 true for all x-values.

title: Introduction to polynomials
translated_description: Sal expresses the area of a rectangle whose height is 4 and width is x²+3x+2.

title: Introduction to polynomials
translated_description: Sal multiplies -4x² by (3x² + 25x - 7).

title: Introduction to polynomials
translated_description: Sal finds the values of coefficients c  d  and f that make -2y(y²+cy-3)=dy³+12y²+fy true for all y-values.

title: Introduction to polynomials
translated_description: Sal expresses the area of a rectangle whose height is x+2 and width is x+3.

title: Introduction to polynomials
translated_description: Sal expresses (x-4)(x+7) as the standard trinomial x²+3x-28 and discusses how the general product (x+a)(x+b) can be written as x²+(a+b)x+a*b.

title: Introduction to polynomials
translated_description: Sal expresses the product (3x+2)(5x-7) as 15x²-11x-14.

title: Introduction to polynomials
translated_description: Sal introduces difference of squares expressions. For example  (x+3)(x-3) is expanded as x²-9.

title: Introduction to polynomials
translated_description: Sal introduces perfect square expressions. For example  (x+7)² is expanded as x²+14x+49.

title: Introduction to polynomials
translated_description: Sal expand the difference of squares (2x+8)(2x-8) as 4x²-64.

title: Introduction to polynomials
translated_description: Sal expands the perfect square (7x+10)² as 49x^2+140x+100.

title: Introduction to polynomials
translated_description: Sal finds the area of a square with side (6x-5y).

title: Introduction to polynomials
translated_description: Sal gives numerous examples of the two special binomial product forms: perfect squares and the difference of two squares.

title: Introduction to polynomials
translated_description: Sal expresses the product (10a-3)(5a² + 7a - 1) as 50a³+55a²-31a+3.

title: Introduction to polynomials
translated_description: Sal expresses the area of a rectangle whose height is y²-6y and width is 3y²-2y+1.

title: Introduction to polynomials
translated_description: Sal finds the values of coefficients a and b that make (2x+4)(5x-9)=ax²+bx-46 true for all x-values.

title: Introduction to polynomials
translated_description: Sal finds the volume of a tank whose base has an area of 3x² + 30x + 5 square feet and whose height is 8x - 5 feet.

title: Introduction to polynomials
translated_description: Sal writes a binomial to express the difference between the area of a rectangle and the area of a circle.

title: Introduction to polynomials
translated_description: Sal writes a polynomial to express the total value of p twenty dollar bills  q ten dollar bills  and r five dollar bills.

title: Introduction to polynomials
translated_description: Sal writes a polynomial expression that represents the total area of a window made of wood and glass.

title: Polynomial factorization
translated_description: Sal explains what it means for a polynomial to be a factor of another polynomial  and what it means for a polynomial to be divisible by another polynomial.

title: Polynomial factorization
translated_description: Sal analyzes two different factorizations of 24x^5 and determines whether they are correct.

title: Polynomial factorization
translated_description: Sal finds the missing factor F in the factorization of -30x^5 as (-10x^3)(F).

title: Polynomial factorization
translated_description: Sal finds the length of a rectangle whose area is 42xy^3 and whose height is 14xy.

title: Polynomial factorization
translated_description: Sal finds the greatest common factor of 10cd^2 and 25c^3d^2.

title: Polynomial factorization
translated_description: Sal shows how to factor the expression 4x+18 into the expression 2(2x+9).

title: Polynomial factorization
translated_description: Sal factors 8x²y+12xy² as (4xy)(2x+3y) by taking out the greatest common factor.

title: Polynomial factorization
translated_description: Sal factors 4x⁴y-8x³y-2x² as 2x²(2x²y-4xy-1) by taking the greatest common factor.

title: Polynomial factorization
translated_description: Sal finds the measures of a rectangle whose area is 12x⁴+6x³+15x² by taking the greatest common factor.

title: Polynomial factorization
translated_description: Sal factors n(n-1)+3(n-1) as (n+3)(n-1) by noticing that (n-1) is a common factor.

title: Polynomial factorization
translated_description: Sal solved a few examples where we need to evaluate an expression  but we don't know the individual variable values.

title: Polynomial factorization
translated_description: A few more examples where Sal evaluates expressions with multiple unknown variables.

title: Polynomial factorization
translated_description: Sal factors x²-3x-10 as (x+2)(x-5) using the sum-product form: (x+a)(x+b)=x²+(a+b)x+a*b.

title: Polynomial factorization
translated_description: Sal factors x^2-14x+40 as (x-4)(x-10) and x^2-x-12 as (x+3)(x-4).

title: Polynomial factorization
translated_description: Can't get enough of Sal factoring simple quadratics? Here's a handful of examples just for you!

title: Polynomial factorization
translated_description: Sal introduces the method of grouping  which is very useful in factoring quadratics whose leading coefficient is not 1.

title: Polynomial factorization
translated_description: Sal factors 4y^2+4y-15 as (2y-3)(2y+5) by grouping.

title: Polynomial factorization
translated_description: Sal factors 35k^2+100k-15 as 5(k+3)(7k-1).

title: Polynomial factorization
translated_description: Sal factors x^2+4xy-5y^2 as (x-y)(x+5y).

title: Polynomial factorization
translated_description: Sal rearranges 30x^2+11xy+y^2 as y^2+11xy+30x^2 and then factors it as (y+5x)(y+6x).

title: Polynomial factorization
translated_description: Sal factors 5rs+25r-3s-15 as (s+5)(5r-3).

title: Polynomial factorization
translated_description: When an expression can be viewed as the difference of two perfect squares  i.e. a²-b²  then we can factor it as (a+b)(a-b). For example  x²-25 can be factored as (x+5)(x-5). This method is based on the pattern (a+b)(a-b)=a²-b²  which can be verified by expanding the parentheses in (a+b)(a-b).

title: Polynomial factorization
translated_description: Sal factors 45x^2-125 as 5(3x+5)(3x-5).

title: Polynomial factorization
translated_description: Sal analyzes two different factorizations of 16x^2-64 and determines whether they are correct.

title: Polynomial factorization
translated_description: Sal analyzes the factorization of 3y^3-100y as 4y(My+g)(My-g) to find the possible values for the missing coefficient g.

title: Polynomial factorization
translated_description: Sal finds the binomial factor shared by m^2-4m-45 and 6m^2-150.

title: Polynomial factorization
translated_description: When an expression has the general form a²+2ab+b²  then we can factor it as (a+b)². For example  x²+10x+25 can be factored as (x+5)². This method is based on the pattern (a+b)²=a²+2ab+b²  which can be verified by expanding the parentheses in (a+b)(a+b).

title: Polynomial factorization
translated_description: Sal factors 25x^2-30x+9 as (5x-3)^2 or as (-5x+3)^2.

title: Polynomial factorization
translated_description: Sal shows how we can identify that a trinomial has the "perfect square" form.

title: Polynomial factorization
translated_description: Sal factors 16x^3+24x^2+9x as (x)(4x+3)^2.

title: Polynomial factorization
translated_description: Sal factors -4t^2-12t-9 as -1(2t+3)^2.

title: Polynomial factorization
translated_description: Sal analyzes the factorization of x^2+5x+c as (x+d)^2 to find the values of the missing coefficients c and d.

title: Polynomial factorization
translated_description: Sal finds the binomial factor shared by 4x^2+12x+9 and 4x^2-9.

title: Polynomial factorization
translated_description: There are a lot of methods to factor quadratics  which apply on different occasions and conditions. After learning all of them in separate  let's think strategically about which method is useful for a given quadratic expression we want to factor.

title: Polynomial factorization
translated_description: There are a lot of methods to factor quadratics  which apply on different occasions and conditions. After learning all of them in separate  let's think strategically about which method is useful for a given quadratic expression we want to factor.

title: Polynomial factorization
translated_description: Sal factors 25x^4-30x^2+9 as (5x^2-3)^2.

title: Polynomial factorization
translated_description: If we expand (a+b)(a-b) we will get a²-b². Factorization goes the other way: suppose we have an expression that is the difference of two squares  like x²-25 or 49x²-y²  then we can factor is using the roots of those squares. For example  x²-25 can be factored as (x+5)(x-5). This is an extremely useful method that is used throughout math.

title: Polynomial factorization
translated_description: Sal factors 49x^2-49y^2 as (7x+7y)(7x-7y) or as 49(x+y)(x-y).

title: Quadratic equations and functions
translated_description: Graphs of quadratic functions all have the same shape which we call "parabola." All parabolas have shared characteristics. For example  they are all symmetric about a line that passes through their vertex. This video covers this and other basic facts about parabolas.

title: Quadratic equations and functions
translated_description: The zero product property states that if a⋅b=0 then either a or b equal zero. This basic property helps us solve equations like (x+2)(x-5)=0.

title: Quadratic equations and functions
translated_description: An example for a quadratic function in factored form is y=½(x-6)(x+2). We can analyze this form to find the x-intercepts of the graph  as well as find the vertex.

title: Quadratic equations and functions
translated_description: Sal analyzes the conditions for the maximum possible number of mosquitoes in New York City  which is given as a quadratic function.

title: Quadratic equations and functions
translated_description: Sal solves the equation 2x^2+3=75 by isolating x^2 and taking the square root of both sides.

title: Quadratic equations and functions
translated_description: Sal solves the equation (x+3)²-4=0 and finds the x-intercepts of f(x)=(x-2)²-9.

title: Quadratic equations and functions
translated_description: Sal discusses the exact order of steps in the process of solving the equation 3(x+6)^2=75.

title: Quadratic equations and functions
translated_description: Sal analyzes a given solution of a quadratic equation  and finds where and what was the error in that process.

title: Quadratic equations and functions
translated_description: Sal rewrites a quadratic equation in vertex form and shows how it reveals the vertex of the corresponding parabola.

title: Quadratic equations and functions
translated_description: Learn how to graph any quadratic function that is given in vertex form. Here  Sal graphs y=-2(x-2)²+5.

title: Quadratic equations and functions
translated_description: Given a quadratic function that models the height of an object being launched from a platform  we analyze the function to answer questions like "what is the height of the platform?" or "when does the object reach its maximum height?"

title: Quadratic equations and functions
translated_description: Sal solves the equation s^2-2s-35=0 by factoring the expression on the left as (s+5)(s-7) and finding the s-values that make each factor equal to zero.

title: Quadratic equations and functions
translated_description: Sal solves 6x²-120x+600=0 by first dividing by 6 and then factoring.

title: Quadratic equations and functions
translated_description: Sal solves (2x-3)^2=4x-6 by substituting p for 2x-3 and obtaining the simpler equation p^2=2p.

title: Quadratic equations and functions
translated_description: Sal solves a geometry problem using a quadratic equation.

title: Quadratic equations and functions
translated_description: Sal solves a volume problem using a quadratic equation.

title: Quadratic equations and functions
translated_description: Some quadratic expressions can be factored as perfect squares. For example  x²+6x+9=(x+3)². However  even if an expression isn't a perfect square  we can turn it into one by adding a constant number. For example  x²+6x+5 isn't a perfect square  but if we add 4 we get (x+3)². This  in essence  is the method of *completing the square*

title: Quadratic equations and functions
translated_description: Sal completes x²-44x into a perfect square.

title: Quadratic equations and functions
translated_description: Sal rewrites x²+16x+9 as (x+8)²-55 by completing the square.

title: Quadratic equations and functions
translated_description: Sal solves x²-2x-8=0 by rewriting the equation as (x-1)²-9=0 (which is done by completing the square!).

title: Quadratic equations and functions
translated_description: Sal solves the equation 4x^2+40x-300=0 by completing the square.

title: Quadratic equations and functions
translated_description: Sal solves the equation 4x^2+40x+280=0 by completing the square  only to find there's no solution for this equation.

title: Quadratic equations and functions
translated_description: With the quadratic formula  we can solve any quadratic equation! Learn how to use it with an example.

title: Quadratic equations and functions
translated_description: Sal solves the equation -7q^2+2q+9=0 by using the quadratic formula.

title: Quadratic equations and functions
translated_description: Solving 6x²+3=2x-6 by rewriting in standard form and identifying the parameters a  b  and c  that can be used within the quadratic formula.

title: Quadratic equations and functions
translated_description: Sal solves the equation -x^2+8x=1 by first bringing it to standard form and then using the quadratic formula.

title: Quadratic equations and functions
translated_description: Sal solves -3x^2+10x-3=0 by plugging a=-3  b=10  c=-3 in the quadratic formula. Then he multiplies everything by -1 and solves again. The results are the same!

title: Quadratic equations and functions
translated_description: Sal determines how many solutions the equation x²+14x+49=0 has by considering its quadratic formula  and more specifically  its discriminant.

title: Quadratic equations and functions
translated_description: Sal proves the quadratic formula using the method of completing the square.

title: Quadratic equations and functions
translated_description: Sal rewrites the equation y=-5x^2-20x+15 in vertex form (by completing the square) in order to identify the vertex of the corresponding parabola.

title: Quadratic equations and functions
translated_description: Learn how to graph any quadratic function that is given in standard form. Here  Sal graphs y=5x²-20x+15.

title: Quadratic equations and functions
translated_description: Sal solves a word problem about a ball being shot in the air. The equation for the height of the ball as a function of time is quadratic.

title: Quadratic equations and functions
translated_description: Different forms of quadratic functions reveal different features of those functions. Here  Sal rewrites f(x)=x²-5x+6 in factored form to reveal its zeros and in vertex form to reveal its vertex.

title: Quadratic equations and functions
translated_description: Choosing whether factored form  vertex form or standard form of a quadratic is best in different situations.

title: Quadratic equations and functions
translated_description: Sal finds the zeros  the vertex  & the line of symmetry of quadratic functions given in vertex form  factored form  & standard form.

title: Quadratic equations and functions
translated_description: Sal compares the y-intercepts  the zeros  and the concavity of quadratic functions given graphically and algebraically.

title: Quadratic equations and functions
translated_description: Given several quadratic functions represented in different forms  Sal finds the one with the lowest maximum value.

title: Quadratic equations and functions
translated_description: Sal discusses how we can shift and scale the graph of a parabola to obtain any other parabola  and how this affects the equation of the parabola.

title: Quadratic equations and functions
translated_description: The graph of y=(x-k)²+h is the resulting of shifting (or translating) the graph of y=x²  k units to the right and h units up. For example  y=(x-3)²-4 is the result of shifting y=x² 3 units to the right and -4 units up  which is the same as 4 units down.

title: Quadratic equations and functions
translated_description: The graph of y=k⋅x² is the graph of y=x² scaled by a factor of |k|. If k<0  it's also reflected (or "flipped") across the x-axis. In this worked example  we find the equation of a parabola from its graph.

title: Rational and irrational numbers
translated_description: Learn what rational and irrational numbers are and how to tell them apart.

title: Rational and irrational numbers
translated_description: Given a bunch of numbers  learn how to tell which are rational and which are irrational.

title: Rational and irrational numbers
translated_description: Sal proves that the sum  or the product  of any two rational numbers will always be a rational number.

title: Rational and irrational numbers
translated_description: The product of any rational number and any irrational number will always be an irrational number. This allows us to quickly conclude that 3π is irrational.

title: Rational and irrational numbers
translated_description: The sum of any rational number and any irrational number will always be an irrational number. This allows us to quickly conclude that ½+√2 is irrational.

title: Rational and irrational numbers
translated_description: The sum of two irrational numbers can be rational and it can be irrational. It depends on which irrational numbers we're talking about exactly. The same goes for products for two irrational numbers. This video covers this fact with various examples.

title: Rational and irrational numbers
translated_description: Sal shows how to determine whether the following expressions are rational or irrational: 9 + √(45)  √(45)/ (3*√(5))  and 3*√(9).

title: Rational and irrational numbers
translated_description: Sal determines whether expressions with unknown rational/irrational numbers are rational or irrational.

title: Rational and irrational numbers
translated_description: Sal proves that the square root of 2 is an irrational number  i.e. it cannot be given as the ratio of two integers.

title: Rational and irrational numbers
translated_description: Sal proves that the square root of any prime number must be an irrational number. For example  because of this proof we can quickly determine that √3  √5  √7  or √11 are irrational numbers.

title: Rational and irrational numbers
translated_description: Sal proves that when given any two rational numbers  no matter how close  we can find an irrational number that lies between them.

title: Geometry foundations
translated_description: Euclid was a great mathematician and often called the father of geometry.  Learn more about Euclid and how some of our math concepts came about and how influential they have become.

title: Geometry foundations
translated_description: Learn about geometry terms like point  line  and ray.  We will also learn how to label them.

title: Geometry foundations
translated_description: Learn the difference between lines  line segments  and rays.

title: Geometry foundations
translated_description: In a three-dimensional space  a plane can be defined by three points it contains  as long as those points are not on the same line. Learn more about it in this video.

title: Geometry foundations
translated_description: Watch Sal solve a problem where he matches three students definition of parallel lines to a teacher's comments.

title: Geometry foundations
translated_description: Learn how to measure an angle with a protractor.

title: Geometry foundations
translated_description: Learn to use a virtual protractor to measure angles.

title: Geometry foundations
translated_description: Sal measures several angles with a protractor.

title: Geometry foundations
translated_description: Acute angles measure less than 90 degrees.  Right angles measure 90 degrees.  Obtuse angles measure more than 90 degrees.  Learn about angles types and see examples of each.

title: Geometry foundations
translated_description: By using our knowledge of supplementary  adjacent  and vertical angles  we can solve problems involving the intersection of two lines. Including this one!

title: Geometry foundations
translated_description: Given algebraic expressions that represent a pair of two vertical angles  Sal forms and solves an equation.

title: Geometry foundations
translated_description: Learn about complementary and supplementary angles  as well as the definitions of adjacent and straight angles.

title: Geometry foundations
translated_description: Given the algebraic expressions that represent a pair of complementary angles  learn how to form and solve an equation to find an unknown angle.

title: Geometry foundations
translated_description: Given the algebraic expressions that represent a pair of supplementary angles  Sal forms and solves an equation.

title: Geometry foundations
translated_description: Learn about parallel lines  transversals  and the angles they form.

title: Geometry foundations
translated_description: Parallel lines are lines in a plane that are always the same distance apart. Parallel lines never intersect. Perpendicular lines are lines that intersect at a right (90 degrees) angle.

title: Geometry foundations
translated_description: Learn how to find missing angle measurements in a figure with two parallel lines and a transversal.

title: Geometry foundations
translated_description: Sal solves an equation to find missing angles given two parallel lines and a transversal.

title: Geometry foundations
translated_description: Sal proves that two angles are congruent in a really interesting triangle like figure.

title: Geometry foundations
translated_description: Learn the formal proof that shows the measures of interior angles of a triangle sum to 180°.

title: Geometry foundations
translated_description: Learn about the angles in a triangle and a little about exterior angles being the sum of the remote interior angles.

title: Geometry foundations
translated_description: Worked examples finding angles in triangles formed by intersecting lines

title: Geometry foundations
translated_description: Worked examples finding angles in triangles that are part of diagrams

title: Geometry foundations
translated_description: Example of angle hunting!

title: Geometry foundations
translated_description: Learn how to find the sum of the interior angles of any polygon.

title: Geometry foundations
translated_description: Sal demonstrates how the the sum of the exterior angles of a convex polygon is 360 degrees.

title: Geometry foundations
translated_description: Intuition behind the triangle inequality theorem

title: Geometry foundations
translated_description: Learn the term quadrilateral as well as trapezoid  parallelogram  rectangle  rhombus  and square.

title: Geometry foundations
translated_description: Learn about the properties of quadrilaterals  parallelograms  trapezoids  rhombuses  rectangles  and squares.

title: Geometry foundations
translated_description: Sal discusses a special type of quadrilateral  the kite.

title: Geometry foundations
translated_description: Learn to identify quadrilaterals such as kites  trapezoids  parallelograms  rhombuses  rectangles  and squares by line and angle type.

title: Geometry foundations
translated_description: Sal proves that a figure is a parallelogram if and only if opposite sides are congruent.

title: Geometry foundations
translated_description: Sal proves that opposite angles of a parallelogram are congruent.

title: Geometry foundations
translated_description: Perimeter is the distance around the outside of a shape. Area measures the space inside a shape. Learn how to calculate perimeter and area for various shapes.

title: Geometry foundations
translated_description: Understand why the formula for the area of a triangle is one half base times height  which is half of the area of a parallelogram.

title: Geometry foundations
translated_description: Understand why the formula for the area of a parallelogram is base times height  just like the formula for the area of a rectangle.

title: Geometry foundations
translated_description: Area of a trapezoid is found with the formula  A=(a+b)/2 x h.  Learn how to use the formula to find area of trapezoids.

title: Geometry foundations
translated_description: Learn how to find the area of a kite. A kite is a type of quadrilateral that is symmetric around one of its diagonals.

title: Geometry foundations
translated_description: Learn how to calculate the area of a triangle on a grid.

title: Geometry foundations
translated_description: Learn to break up oddly shaped quadrilaterals into shapes where finding the area is more easily determined.

title: Geometry foundations
translated_description: Learn to break up irregular shapes into smaller geometric shapes to determine area.

title: Geometry foundations
translated_description: Sal finds perimeter and area of a non-standard polygon.

title: Geometry foundations
translated_description: Three example problems involving perimeter and area.

title: Geometry foundations
translated_description: Learn how the number Pi allows us to relate the radius  diameter  and circumference of a circle.

title: Geometry foundations
translated_description: The area of a circle is pi times the radius squared (A = π r²). Learn how to use this formula to find the area of a circle when given the diameter.

title: Geometry foundations
translated_description: Sal finds the radius and diameter of a circle given the circumference.

title: Geometry foundations
translated_description: Using triangles to create an informal argument for the area of a circle formula.

title: Geometry foundations
translated_description: Admittedly  "nets of polyhedra" sounds like the title of a bad sci-fi movie about man-eating  multi-headed fish. But in reality  nets of polyhedra are just 2D objects that wrap around 3D objects  like wrapping paper around presents.

title: Geometry foundations
translated_description: A polyhedron is a three-dimensional shape that has flat surfaces and straight edges.  Learn whether or not a certain net could be folded up into a certain rectangular prism.

title: Transformations
translated_description: Learn what the "image" of a transformations is  what are the rigid transformations  and which transformations are not rigid.

title: Transformations
translated_description: Sal shows how to perform a translation on a triangle using our interactive widget!

title: Transformations
translated_description: Sal shows how to perform a rotation on a pentagon using our interactive widget!

title: Transformations
translated_description: Sal shows how to perform a reflection on a quadrilateral using our interactive widget!

title: Transformations
translated_description: Sal is given a triangle on the coordinate plane and the definition of a translation  and he draws the image of the triangle under that translation.

title: Transformations
translated_description: Sal is given two triangles on the coordinate plane  and determines the translation that maps one of them into the other.

title: Transformations
translated_description: A translation acting on the coordinate plane takes the point (-169 434) to point (-203  -68). What are the coordinates of the image of point (31  -529) under this translation?

title: Transformations
translated_description: Sal is given two pairs of line segments and a center of a dilation. He finds the angle for the rotation that maps one pair of segments to another.

title: Transformations
translated_description: Sal is given a triangle on the coordinate plane and the definition of a rotation about the origin  and he manually draws the image of that rotation.

title: Transformations
translated_description: Sal is given two line segments on the coordinate plane and the definition of a translation  and he draws the image of the segments under that reflection.

title: Transformations
translated_description: Sal is given two line segments on the coordinate plane  and determines the reflection that maps one of them into the other.

title: Transformations
translated_description: Sal shows how to perform a dilation on a hexagon using our interactive widget!

title: Transformations
translated_description: Sal is given a triangle on the coordinate plane and he draws the image of the triangle under a dilation with scale factor 1/2 about the origin.

title: Transformations
translated_description: Sal is given a rectangle on the coordinate plane and he draws the image of the rectangle under a dilation with scale factor 1 2/3 about an arbitrary point.

title: Transformations
translated_description: Sal shows how we can use dilations to map a line into another  parallel  line.

title: Transformations
translated_description: Sal is given information about a transformation in terms of a few pairs of points and their corresponding images  and he determines what kind of transformation it can be.

title: Transformations
translated_description: Introduction to the concept of an "axis of symmetry"

title: Transformations
translated_description: Sal checks whether various figure are symmetrical under a 180 degrees rotation.

title: Transformations
translated_description: Two of the points that define a certain quadrilateral are (0 9) and (3 4). The quadrilateral has reflective symmetry over the line y=3-x. Draw and classify the quadrilateral.

title: Transformations
translated_description: Two of the points that define a certain quadrilateral are (-4 -2) and (0 5). The quadrilateral has a reflective symmetry over the lines y=x/2 and y=-2x+5. Draw and classify the quadrilateral.

title: Congruence
translated_description: Sal shows that a given pair of pentagons are congruent by mapping one onto the other using rigid transformations.

title: Congruence
translated_description: Sal shows that a given pair of pentagons are not congruent by showing it's not possible to map one onto the other using rigid transformations.

title: Congruence
translated_description: Sal reflects and then translates a given pentagon  and determines whether the resulting figure is congruent to the source figure.

title: Congruence
translated_description: Sal maps a given quadrilateral onto another using a translation  a dilation  and a reflection. The quadrilaterals are not congruent because a dilation was used.

title: Congruence
translated_description: Sal explains what it means for triangles to be congruent and what is a postulate/axiom. He also presents the SSS congruence postulate/criterion and its justification.

title: Congruence
translated_description: Sal introduces and justifies the SSS  SAS  ASA and AAS postulates for congruent triangles. He also shows that AAA is only good for similarity. For SSA  better to watch next video.

title: Congruence
translated_description: There are some cases when SSA can imply triangle congruence  but not always. This is why it's not like the other triangle congruence postulates/criteria.

title: Congruence
translated_description: Sal uses the SSS  ASA  SAS  and AAS postulates to find congruent triangles.

title: Congruence
translated_description: Learn the formal proof that shows the measures of interior angles of a triangle sum to 180°.

title: Congruence
translated_description: Sal proves that the base angles in isosceles triangles are congruent  and conversely  that triangles with congruent base angles are isosceles. He also proves that the perpendicular to the base of an isosceles triangle bisects it.

title: Congruence
translated_description: Sal proves that the angles of an equilateral triangle are all congruent (and therefore they all measure 60°)  and conversely  that triangles with all congruent angles are equilateral.

title: Congruence
translated_description: We write the letters of congruent triangles so their order tells us which parts of corresponding. In this video  Sal uses this notation to solve some angles.

title: Congruence
translated_description: Three example problems involving isosceles and equilateral triangles (partly taken from Art of Problem Solving  by Richard Rusczyk).

title: Congruence
translated_description: The measures of two angles of an isosceles triangle are 3x+5 and x+16. Find all possible values of x.

title: Congruence
translated_description: Sal combines what we know about isosceles triangles and parallel lines with the power of algebra to solve the angles of an isosceles triangle.

title: Congruence
translated_description: Sal proves that a figure is a parallelogram if and only if opposite sides are congruent.

title: Congruence
translated_description: Sal proves that a quadrilateral is a parallelogram if and only if its diagonals bisect each other.

title: Congruence
translated_description: Sal proves that opposite angles of a parallelogram are congruent.

title: Congruence
translated_description: Sal proves that the diagonals of a kite are perpendicular  by using the SSS and SAS triangle congruence criteria.

title: Congruence
translated_description: Sal proves that the diagonals of a rhombus are perpendicular  and that they intersect at the midpoints of both.

title: Congruence
translated_description: Sal proves that we can find the area of a rhombus by taking half the product of the lengths of the diagonals.

title: Congruence
translated_description: Sal proves that a point is the midpoint of a segment using triangle congruence.

title: Congruence
translated_description: Sal proves that two pairs of segments are congruent using the ASA and AAS congruence criteria.

title: Congruence
translated_description: Sal finds a missing angle using triangle congruence in a diagram that contains sector of a circle inscribed within a square.

title: Congruence
translated_description: Sal constructs a perpendicular bisector to a given line segment using compass and straightedge.

title: Congruence
translated_description: Sal constructs a line perpendicular to a given line using compass and straightedge.

title: Congruence
translated_description: Sal constructs a line that bisects a given angle using compass and straightedge.

title: Similarity
translated_description: Sal is given pairs of polygons  and then he determines whether they are similar by trying to map one onto the other using angle-preserving transformations.

title: Similarity
translated_description: Sal solves a problem about the conditions for two quadrilaterals to be similar  based on the definition that two polygons are similar if all their angles are congruent.

title: Similarity
translated_description: Sal explains what it means for triangles to be similar  and how this follows from the definition of similarity.

title: Similarity
translated_description: Sal reviews all the different ways we can determine that two triangles are similar. This is similar to the congruence criteria  only for similarity!

title: Similarity
translated_description: Multiple examples where Sal analyzes the similarity of triangles.

title: Similarity
translated_description: Sal uses a clever proof involving similar triangles to show that slope is constant for a line.

title: Similarity
translated_description: Sal solves two problems where a missing side length is found by proving that triangles are similar and using this to find the measure.

title: Similarity
translated_description: Sal finds a missing side length in a problem where the same side plays different roles in two similar triangles.

title: Similarity
translated_description: Sal introduces the angle-bisector theorem and proves it.

title: Similarity
translated_description: Sal uses the angle bisector theorem to solve for sides of a triangle.

title: Similarity
translated_description: Sal uses the similarity of triangles and the congruence of others in this multi-step problem to find the area of a polygon.

title: Similarity
translated_description: Interesting similarity problem where we don't have a lot of information to work with

title: Similarity
translated_description: Triangle similarity  the Golden ratio  and art  all converge in this inspiring video!

title: Similarity
translated_description: Similarity and the Golden ratio join forces again  this time to save the Earth! (Or maybe just finding its radius)

title: Similarity
translated_description: Sal uses triangle similarity to plan the perfect shot in a pool game.

title: Right triangles & trigonometry
translated_description: Sal introduces the famous and super important Pythagorean theorem!

title: Right triangles & trigonometry
translated_description: Sal introduces the famous and super important Pythagorean theorem!

title: Right triangles & trigonometry
translated_description: Sal uses the Pythagorean theorem to solve a word problem about a fishing boat.

title: Right triangles & trigonometry
translated_description: Sal uses the Pythagorean theorem to find the height of a right triangle with a base of 9 and a hypotenuse of 14.

title: Right triangles & trigonometry
translated_description: Sal uses the Pythagorean theorem to find the width of some carpet.

title: Right triangles & trigonometry
translated_description: Sal uses the Pythagorean theorem to find a missing side length in an isosceles triangle.

title: Right triangles & trigonometry
translated_description: Right triangles and the Pythagorean Theorem

title: Right triangles & trigonometry
translated_description: More Pythagorean Theorem examples. Introduction to 45-45-90 triangles.

title: Right triangles & trigonometry
translated_description: James Garfield's proof of the Pythagorean Theorem.

title: Right triangles & trigonometry
translated_description: An elegant visual proof of the Pythagorean Theorem developed by the 12th century Indian mathematician Bhaskara.

title: Right triangles & trigonometry
translated_description: Proof of the Pythagorean Theorem using similarity

title: Right triangles & trigonometry
translated_description: Visually proving the Pythagorean Theorem

title: Right triangles & trigonometry
translated_description: Introduction to 45-45-90 Triangles

title: Right triangles & trigonometry
translated_description: A few more 45-45-90 triangle examples and an introduction to 30-60-90 triangles.

title: Right triangles & trigonometry
translated_description: Using what we know about 30-60-90 triangles to solve what at first seems to be a challenging problem

title: Right triangles & trigonometry
translated_description: Learn how to prove the ratios between the sides of a 30-60-90 triangle.

title: Right triangles & trigonometry
translated_description: Showing the ratios of the sides of a 45-45-90 triangle are 1:1:sqrt(2)

title: Right triangles & trigonometry
translated_description: Using what we know about triangles to find the area of a regular hexagon

title: Right triangles & trigonometry
translated_description: Sal introduces sine  cosine  and tangent  and gives an example of finding them for a given right triangle.

title: Right triangles & trigonometry
translated_description: Sal shows a few examples where he starts with the two legs of a right triangle and he finds the trig ratios of one of the acute angles.

title: Right triangles & trigonometry
translated_description: Sal is given a right triangle with an acute angle of 65° and a leg of 5 units  and he uses trigonometry to find the two missing sides.

title: Right triangles & trigonometry
translated_description: Sal solves a modeling problem where he finds the necessary angle to shoot at a vicious alien.

title: Right triangles & trigonometry
translated_description: Sal explains how the trigonometric ratios are derived from triangle similarity considerations.

title: Right triangles & trigonometry
translated_description: Sal is given a diagram with multiple right triangles and is asked to verify identities relating to trig ratios in those triangles.

title: Right triangles & trigonometry
translated_description: Sal is given a diagram with multiple right triangles and is asked to match different expressions with different trig values.

title: Right triangles & trigonometry
translated_description: Sal shows that the sine of any angle is equal to the cosine of its complementary angle.

title: Right triangles & trigonometry
translated_description: Sal solved the following problem: Given that cos(58°)=0.53  find sin(32°).

title: Right triangles & trigonometry
translated_description: Sal solves a problem about a submerged pyramid using the fact that the sine of an angle is equal to the cosine of its complementary angle.

title: Right triangles & trigonometry
translated_description: Sal is given a triangle with two angle measures and one side length  and he finds all the missing side lengths and angle measures using the law of sines.

title: Right triangles & trigonometry
translated_description: Sal is given a triangle with two side lengths and one angle measure  and he finds all the missing angle measures using the law of sines.

title: Right triangles & trigonometry
translated_description: Sal gives a simple proof of the Law of sines.

title: Right triangles & trigonometry
translated_description: Learn how to use the law of cosines to find the missing side length of a triangle when given two side lengths and the contained angle measure.

title: Right triangles & trigonometry
translated_description: Sal is given a triangle with all side lengths but no angle measure  and he finds one of the angle measures using the law of cosines.

title: Right triangles & trigonometry
translated_description: Sal gives a simple proof of the Law of cosines.

title: Right triangles & trigonometry
translated_description: Sal solves a word problem about the distance between stars using the law of cosines.

title: Solid geometry
translated_description: Using the formulas for the volume of triangular prism and cube to solve some solid geometry problems.

title: Solid geometry
translated_description: The formula for the volume of a cone is V=1/3hπr². Learn how to use this formula to solve an example problem.

title: Solid geometry
translated_description: A cylinder's volume is π r² h  and its surface area is 2π r h + 2π r². Learn how to use these formulas to solve an example problem.

title: Solid geometry
translated_description: The formula for the volume of a sphere is V = 4/3 πr³. See the formula used in an example where we are given the diameter of the sphere.

title: Solid geometry
translated_description: Sal solves a word problem about the number of passengers a blimp can carry  using his knowledge of volume and density.

title: Solid geometry
translated_description: What happens when you slice vertically into a rectangular pyramid? What kind of geometric shape results?

title: Solid geometry
translated_description: Learn about all the different ways we can obtain cross-sections of a cube.

title: Solid geometry
translated_description: If you rotate a 2D shape about an axis  the shape will define a 3D object. Watch Sal rotating various 2D shapes and see what 3D objects he gets!

title: Analytic geometry
translated_description: Learn how to find the distance between two points by using the distance formula  which is an application of the Pythagorean theorem.

title: Analytic geometry
translated_description: Learn how to use the midpoint formula to find the midpoint of a line segment on the coordinate plane  or find the endpoint of a line segment given one point and the midpoint.

title: Analytic geometry
translated_description: Sal finds the area of a trapezoid using the distance formula and the trapezoid area formula.

title: Analytic geometry
translated_description: Sal uses the distance formula to determine whether the point (-6 -6) is inside  outside  or on the circle centered at (-1 -3) with radius 6.

title: Analytic geometry
translated_description: Watch Sal solve a challenging problem where he has to determine if points are on both  one  or neither of two circles.

title: Analytic geometry
translated_description: Watch Sal solve an example where has to determine which of the Minions a wizard can reach using the coordinate plane.

title: Analytic geometry
translated_description: Watch Sal figure out the coordinates of a point between two other points that give a certain ratio. A graph is given to make it easier to visualize the problem.

title: Analytic geometry
translated_description: Watch Sal figure out the coordinates of a point between two other points that give a certain ratio.

title: Analytic geometry
translated_description: Parallel lines never intersect  and perpendicular lines intersect at a 90 degree angle. Learn how to identify parallel and perpendicular lines.

title: Analytic geometry
translated_description: The slopes of parallel lines are equal  and the slopes of perpendicular lines are opposite reciprocals. This is a worked example of determining whether given lines are parallel or perpendicular.

title: Analytic geometry
translated_description: Sal determines which pairs out of a few given linear equations are parallel.

title: Analytic geometry
translated_description: Sal determines which pairs out of a few given linear equations are parallel.

title: Analytic geometry
translated_description: Sal determines which pairs out of a few given linear equations are parallel.

title: Analytic geometry
translated_description: Sal determines which pairs out of a few given linear equations are perpendicular.

title: Analytic geometry
translated_description: Given line A and point P  Sal finds the equation of the line perpendicular to A that passes through P.

title: Analytic geometry
translated_description: Sal finds the equation of a line perpendicular to a line given in slope-intercept form that passes through a specific point.

title: Analytic geometry
translated_description: Sal proves that parallel lines have the same slope using triangle similarity.

title: Analytic geometry
translated_description: Sal proves that perpendicular lines have negative reciprocal slope using triangle similarity.

title: Analytic geometry
translated_description: Watch Sal classify a quadrilateral as a square  rhombus  rectangle  parallelogram  or trapezoid given its four vertices.

title: Circles
translated_description: Formal definition of a circle. Tangent and secant lines. Diameters and radii. major and minor arcs

title: Circles
translated_description: Learn how the number Pi allows us to relate the radius  diameter  and circumference of a circle.

title: Circles
translated_description: Watch Sal informally prove that all circles are similar by showing how we can translate then dilate any circle onto another.

title: Circles
translated_description: Sal introduces arc measure including that they must sum to 360  conventions of minor and major arcs  and a comparison to arc length.

title: Circles
translated_description: Watch Sal solve a few problems where he finds a missing arc measure.

title: Circles
translated_description: Sal solves a few items where arc measures are given in equations  we have to find a variable  then use it to find an arc measure.

title: Circles
translated_description: Finding the length of an arc using the degree of the angle subtended by the arc and the perimeter of the circle.

title: Circles
translated_description: Watch Sal solve an example where he finds the central angle given arc length.

title: Circles
translated_description: Sal explains the definition and motivation for radians and the relationship between radians and degrees.

title: Circles
translated_description: Sal discusses the general approach to converting between radians and degrees and vice versa.

title: Circles
translated_description: Sal converts the degree measures 150° and -45° to radians.

title: Circles
translated_description: Sal converts the radian measures π and -π/3 to degrees.

title: Circles
translated_description: Sal finds the fraction of an arc length out of the entire circumference using the radian measure of the central angle subtended by the arc.

title: Circles
translated_description: Sal finds the length of an arc using the radius and the radian measure of the angle subtended by the arc.

title: Circles
translated_description: A worked example of finding the area of a circle's sector using the area of the circle and the central angle of the sector.

title: Circles
translated_description: Sal finds a missing inscribed angle using the inscribed angle theorem.

title: Circles
translated_description: Proving that an inscribed angle is half of a central angle that subtends the same arc.

title: Circles
translated_description: Proof showing that a triangle inscribed in a circle having a diameter as one side is a right triangle

title: Circles
translated_description: Find the diameter of a circle using an inscribed right triangle.

title: Circles
translated_description: One method using an inscribed angle intercepting a diameter of a circle.

title: Circles
translated_description: Using either the inscribed angle theorem or the fact that two inscribed angles that intercept the same arc must be congruent.

title: Circles
translated_description: Sal uses the inscribed angle theorem and some algebra to prove that opposite angles of an inscribed quadrilateral are supplementary.

title: Circles
translated_description: Example showing supplementary oppositie angles in inscribed quadrilateral.

title: Circles
translated_description: Sal proves that the radius that connects the intersection point of a tangent line with the circle is perpendicular to the tangent line.

title: Circles
translated_description: Sal proves that two tangent segments to a circle that are drawn from the same outside point are congruent.

title: Circles
translated_description: Sal finds missing angles using the property that tangents are perpendicular to the radius.

title: Circles
translated_description: Sal finds a missing angle using the property that tangents are perpendicular to the radius.

title: Circles
translated_description: Sal finds a missing length using the property that tangents are perpendicular to the radius.

title: Circles
translated_description: Sal proves that if a radius in a circle is drawn so it bisects a chord  then the radius is also perpendicular to that chord. The proof uses SSS congruence.

title: Circles
translated_description: Simple proof using RSH postulate to show that a radius perpendicular to a chord bisects it

title: Circles
translated_description: A worked example of finding the area of an equilateral triangle inscribed within a circle who's area is known. This video uses Heron's formula and some trigonometry.

title: Circles
translated_description: Sal finds the center and the radius of the circle whose equation is (x+3)^2+(y-4)^2=49.

title: Circles
translated_description: Sal graphs the circle whose equation is (x+5)²+(y-5)²=4.

title: Circles
translated_description: Given a circle on the coordinate plane  Sal finds its standard equation  which is an equation in the form (x-a)²+(y-b)²=r².

title: Circles
translated_description: Sal finds the center and the radius of a circle whose equation is x^2+y^2+4x-4y-17=0  and then he graphs the circle.

title: Circles
translated_description: Sal constructs a square that is inscribed inside a given circle using compass and straightedge.

title: Circles
translated_description: Sal constructs an equilateral triangle that is inscribed inside a given circle using compass and straightedge.

title: Circles
translated_description: Sal constructs a regular hexagon that is inscribed inside a given circle using compass and straightedge.

title: Circles
translated_description: Sal constructs a circle that inscribes a given triangle using compass and straightedge.

title: Circles
translated_description: Sal constructs a circle that circumscribes a given triangle using compass and straightedge.

title: Circles
translated_description: Sal constructs a line tangent to a circle using compass and straightedge.

title: Circles
translated_description: Sal constructs a line tangent to a circle using compass and straightedge.

title: Trigonometry with right triangles
translated_description: Sal introduces sine  cosine  and tangent  and gives an example of finding them for a given right triangle.

title: Trigonometry with right triangles
translated_description: Sal shows a few examples where he starts with the two legs of a right triangle and he finds the trig ratios of one of the acute angles.

title: Trigonometry with right triangles
translated_description: Sal is given a right triangle with an acute angle of 65° and a leg of 5 units  and he uses trigonometry to find the two missing sides.

title: Trigonometry with right triangles
translated_description: Sal solves a modeling problem where he finds the necessary angle to shoot at a vicious alien.

title: Trigonometry with right triangles
translated_description: Sal explains how the trigonometric ratios are derived from triangle similarity considerations.

title: Trigonometry with right triangles
translated_description: Sal is given a diagram with multiple right triangles and is asked to verify identities relating to trig ratios in those triangles.

title: Trigonometry with right triangles
translated_description: Sal is given a diagram with multiple right triangles and is asked to match different expressions with different trig values.

title: Trigonometry with right triangles
translated_description: Sal shows that the sine of any angle is equal to the cosine of its complementary angle.

title: Trigonometry with right triangles
translated_description: Sal solved the following problem: Given that cos(58°)=0.53  find sin(32°).

title: Trigonometry with right triangles
translated_description: Sal solves a problem about a submerged pyramid using the fact that the sine of an angle is equal to the cosine of its complementary angle.

title: Trigonometry with right triangles
translated_description: Sal introduces and proves the identity (sinθ)^2+(cosθ)^2=1  which arises from the Pythagorean theorem!

title: Trigonometry with right triangles
translated_description: Sal finds all six trigonometric ratios (sine  cosine  tangent  secant  cosecant  and cotangent) of an angle in a given right triangle.

title: Trigonometry with right triangles
translated_description: Sal is given two sides in a right triangle and the cotangent of one of the angles  and he uses this information to find the missing side.

title: Trigonometry with general triangles
translated_description: Sal is given a triangle with two angle measures and one side length  and he finds all the missing side lengths and angle measures using the law of sines.

title: Trigonometry with general triangles
translated_description: Sal is given a triangle with two side lengths and one angle measure  and he finds all the missing angle measures using the law of sines.

title: Trigonometry with general triangles
translated_description: Sal gives a simple proof of the Law of sines.

title: Trigonometry with general triangles
translated_description: Learn how to use the law of cosines to find the missing side length of a triangle when given two side lengths and the contained angle measure.

title: Trigonometry with general triangles
translated_description: Sal is given a triangle with all side lengths but no angle measure  and he finds one of the angle measures using the law of cosines.

title: Trigonometry with general triangles
translated_description: Sal gives a simple proof of the Law of cosines.

title: Trigonometry with general triangles
translated_description: Sal solves a word problem about the distance between stars using the law of cosines.

title: The unit circle definition of sine cosine and tangent
translated_description: Sal explains the definition and motivation for radians and the relationship between radians and degrees.

title: The unit circle definition of sine cosine and tangent
translated_description: Sal discusses the general approach to converting between radians and degrees and vice versa.

title: The unit circle definition of sine cosine and tangent
translated_description: Sal converts the degree measures 150° and -45° to radians.

title: The unit circle definition of sine cosine and tangent
translated_description: Sal converts the radian measures π and -π/3 to degrees.

title: The unit circle definition of sine cosine and tangent
translated_description: Sal determines the quadrant at which a ray falls after a rotation by a certain measure of radians.

title: The unit circle definition of sine cosine and tangent
translated_description: Learn how to use the unit circle to define sine  cosine  and tangent for all real numbers.

title: The unit circle definition of sine cosine and tangent
translated_description: Sal shows how  for acute angles  the two different definitions of the trigonometric values (SOH CAH TOA and the unit circle definition) result in the same values.

title: The unit circle definition of sine cosine and tangent
translated_description: The graph of y=sin(x) is like a wave that forever oscillates between -1 and 1  in a shape that repeats itself every 2π units. Specifically  this means that the domain of sin(x) is all real numbers  and the range is [-1 1]. See how we find the graph of y=sin(x) using the ​unit-circle definition of sin(x).

title: The unit circle definition of sine cosine and tangent
translated_description: Sal draws the graph of the tangent function based on the unit circle definition of the function.

title: The unit circle definition of sine cosine and tangent
translated_description: Sal draws the graphs of the sine and the cosine functions and analyzes their intersection points.

title: The unit circle definition of sine cosine and tangent
translated_description: Sal finds several trigonometric identities for sine and cosine by considering horizontal and vertical symmetries of the unit circle.

title: The unit circle definition of sine cosine and tangent
translated_description: Sal finds several trigonometric identities for tangent by considering horizontal and vertical symmetries of the unit circle.

title: The unit circle definition of sine cosine and tangent
translated_description: Sal finds trigonometric identities for sine and cosine by considering angle rotations on the unit circle.

title: The unit circle definition of sine cosine and tangent
translated_description: Sal solves a problem by considering the periodicity of the tangent function.

title: The unit circle definition of sine cosine and tangent
translated_description: Sal finds the trigonometric values of π/4 using the unit-circle definition.

title: The unit circle definition of sine cosine and tangent
translated_description: Sal proves the Pythagorean identity (sinθ)^2+(cosθ)^2=1 for all real numbers.

title: The unit circle definition of sine cosine and tangent
translated_description: Given that sin(θ)=1/2 and that θ is in the second quadrant  Sal finds tan(θ) using the Pythagorean identity.

title: The unit circle definition of sine cosine and tangent
translated_description: Why Tau might be a better number to look at than Pi
