title: The unit circle definition of sine cosine and tangent
translated_description: Please excuse the simple math and spelling errors. You shouldn't believe anything I say without double-checking even at the best of times. Go here: http://tauday.com/ and here: http://www.math.utah.edu/~palais/pi.html Me: http://vihart.com

title: Graphs of trigonometric functions
translated_description: The graph of y=sin(x) is like a wave that forever oscillates between -1 and 1  in a shape that repeats itself every 2π units. Specifically  this means that the domain of sin(x) is all real numbers  and the range is [-1 1]. See how we find the graph of y=sin(x) using the ​unit-circle definition of sin(x).

title: Graphs of trigonometric functions
translated_description: Sal draws the graph of the tangent function based on the unit circle definition of the function.

title: Graphs of trigonometric functions
translated_description: Sal draws the graphs of the sine and the cosine functions and analyzes their intersection points.

title: Graphs of trigonometric functions
translated_description: Sal introduces the main features of sinusoidal functions: midline  amplitude  & period. He shows how these can be found from a sinusoidal function's graph.

title: Graphs of trigonometric functions
translated_description: Sal finds the amplitude and the period of y=-0.5cos(3x).

title: Graphs of trigonometric functions
translated_description: Sal finds the amplitude and the period of y=-0.5cos(3x).

title: Graphs of trigonometric functions
translated_description: Sal graphs y=2*sin(-x) by considering it as a vertical stretch and a horizontal reflection of y=sin(x).

title: Graphs of trigonometric functions
translated_description: Sal graphs y=-2.5*cos(1/3*x) by considering it as a vertical stretch and reflection  and a horizontal stretch  of y=cos(x).

title: Graphs of trigonometric functions
translated_description: Sal finds the equation of a sinusoidal function from its graph where the minimum point (-2 -5) and the maximum point (2 1) are highlighted.

title: Graphs of trigonometric functions
translated_description: Sal solves a word problem about the daily change in temperature by modeling it with a sinusoidal function.

title: Graphs of trigonometric functions
translated_description: Sal solves a word problem about the annual change in temperature by modeling it with a sinusoidal function.

title: Graphs of trigonometric functions
translated_description: Sal solves a word problem about the annual change in the length of day by modeling it with a sinusoidal function that has a phase shift.

title: Trigonometric equations and identities
translated_description: Sal introduces arcsine  which is the inverse function of sine  and discusses its principal range.

title: Trigonometric equations and identities
translated_description: Sal introduces arctangent  which is the inverse function of tangent  and discusses its principal range.

title: Trigonometric equations and identities
translated_description: Sal introduces arccosine  which is the inverse function of cosine  and discusses its principal range.

title: Trigonometric equations and identities
translated_description: Sal is given the graph of a trigonometric function  and he discusses ways in which he can change the function to make it invertible.

title: Trigonometric equations and identities
translated_description: Sal find the formula for the inverse function of g(x)=tan(x-3π/2)+6  and then determines the domain of that inverse function.

title: Trigonometric equations and identities
translated_description: Sal discusses the appropriate way to use the calculator in order to find an angle when its tangent value is given.

title: Trigonometric equations and identities
translated_description: Sal finds the expressions that together represent all possible solutions to the equation sin(x)=1/3.

title: Trigonometric equations and identities
translated_description: Sal solves the equations cos(θ)=1 and cos(θ)=-1 using the graph of y=cos(θ).

title: Trigonometric equations and identities
translated_description: Sal solves a word problem about the annual change in temperature by solving a sinusoidal equation.

title: Trigonometric equations and identities
translated_description: Sal reviews all the different trigonometric angle addition identities: sin(a+b)  sin(a-c)  cos(a+b)  cos(a-b)  cos(2a)  and sin(2a).

title: Trigonometric equations and identities
translated_description: Sal evaluates the cosine of the sum of 60° and another angle whose right triangle is given. To do this  he must use the cosine angle addition formula.

title: Trigonometric equations and identities
translated_description: Sal evaluates the cosine of twice an angle whose right triangle is given. To do this  he must use the cosine double-angle formula.

title: Trigonometric equations and identities
translated_description: Sal proves the identity sin(x+y) = sin(x)*cos(y) + cos(x)*sin(y).

title: Trigonometric equations and identities
translated_description: Sal proves the identity cos(x+y) = cos(x)*cos(y) - sin(x)*sin(y).

title: Trigonometric equations and identities
translated_description: Sal finds the value of sin(7π/12) by rewriting it as sin(π/3+π/4) and then using the sine angle addition formula.

title: Trigonometric equations and identities
translated_description: Sal is given a drawing with two triangles and some side lengths  and he uses the sine angle addition identity in order to find a missing side length.

title: Trigonometric equations and identities
translated_description: Sal is given that cos(2θ)=C and he uses the cosine double-angle identity in order to find an expression for sin(θ).

title: Trigonometric equations and identities
translated_description: Rewrite trigonometric expressions using the Pythagorean identity and other trigonometric identities.

title: Trigonometric equations and identities
translated_description: Sal solves a very complicated geometrical trig problem that appeared as problem 11 in the 2003 AIME II exam.

title: Trigonometric equations and identities
translated_description: Sal solves a very complicated geometrical trig problem that appeared as problem 14 in the 2003 AIME II exam.

title: Trigonometric equations and identities
translated_description: Sal is given cos(θ) and cos(φ) and he finds cos(θ+φ). To do that  he must first find sin(θ) and sin(φ) using the Pythagorean identity.

title: Trigonometric equations and identities
translated_description: Sal solves a very complicated algebraic trig problem that appeared as problem 29 in the 2010 IIT JEE Paper I exam.

title: Trigonometric equations and identities
translated_description: Sal solves a very complicated algebraic trig problem that appeared as problem 48 in the 2010 IIT JEE Paper I exam.

title: Trigonometric equations and identities
translated_description: Sal solves a very complicated algebraic trig problem that appeared as problem 47 in the 2010 IIT JEE Paper I exam.

title: Trigonometric equations and identities
translated_description: Sal solves a very complicated algebraic trig problem that appeared as problem 55 in the 2010 IIT JEE Paper I exam.

title: Trigonometric equations and identities
translated_description: Sal introduces arcsine  which is the inverse function of sine  and discusses its principal range.

title: Trigonometric equations and identities
translated_description: Sal introduces arctangent  which is the inverse function of tangent  and discusses its principal range.

title: Trigonometric equations and identities
translated_description: Sal introduces arccosine  which is the inverse function of cosine  and discusses its principal range.

title: Trigonometric equations and identities
translated_description: Sal is given the graph of a trigonometric function  and he discusses ways in which he can change the function to make it invertible.

title: Trigonometric equations and identities
translated_description: Sal find the formula for the inverse function of g(x)=tan(x-3π/2)+6  and then determines the domain of that inverse function.

title: Trigonometric equations and identities
translated_description: Sal discusses the appropriate way to use the calculator in order to find an angle when its tangent value is given.

title: Trigonometric equations and identities
translated_description: Sal finds the expressions that together represent all possible solutions to the equation sin(x)=1/3.

title: Trigonometric equations and identities
translated_description: Sal solves the equations cos(θ)=1 and cos(θ)=-1 using the graph of y=cos(θ).

title: Trigonometric equations and identities
translated_description: Sal solves a word problem about the annual change in temperature by solving a sinusoidal equation.

title: Trigonometric equations and identities
translated_description: Sal reviews all the different trigonometric angle addition identities: sin(a+b)  sin(a-c)  cos(a+b)  cos(a-b)  cos(2a)  and sin(2a).

title: Trigonometric equations and identities
translated_description: Sal evaluates the cosine of the sum of 60° and another angle whose right triangle is given. To do this  he must use the cosine angle addition formula.

title: Trigonometric equations and identities
translated_description: Sal evaluates the cosine of twice an angle whose right triangle is given. To do this  he must use the cosine double-angle formula.

title: Trigonometric equations and identities
translated_description: Sal proves the identity sin(x+y) = sin(x)*cos(y) + cos(x)*sin(y).

title: Trigonometric equations and identities
translated_description: Sal proves the identity cos(x+y) = cos(x)*cos(y) - sin(x)*sin(y).

title: Trigonometric equations and identities
translated_description: Sal finds the value of sin(7π/12) by rewriting it as sin(π/3+π/4) and then using the sine angle addition formula.

title: Trigonometric equations and identities
translated_description: Sal is given a drawing with two triangles and some side lengths  and he uses the sine angle addition identity in order to find a missing side length.

title: Trigonometric equations and identities
translated_description: Sal is given that cos(2θ)=C and he uses the cosine double-angle identity in order to find an expression for sin(θ).

title: Trigonometric equations and identities
translated_description: Rewrite trigonometric expressions using the Pythagorean identity and other trigonometric identities.

title: Conic sections
translated_description: Sal introduces the four conic sections and shows how they are derived by intersecting planes with cones in certain ways.

title: Conic sections
translated_description: Sal graphs a circle centered at (3 -2) with a radius of 5 units in our interactive widget.

title: Conic sections
translated_description: Given a circle on the coordinate plane  Sal finds its center and its radius.

title: Conic sections
translated_description: Sal finds the center and the radius of the circle whose equation is (x+3)^2+(y-4)^2=49.

title: Conic sections
translated_description: Sal graphs the circle whose equation is (x+5)²+(y-5)²=4.

title: Conic sections
translated_description: Given a circle on the coordinate plane  Sal finds its standard equation  which is an equation in the form (x-a)²+(y-b)²=r².

title: Conic sections
translated_description: Sal finds the center and the radius of a circle whose equation is x^2+y^2+4x-4y-17=0  and then he graphs the circle.

title: Conic sections
translated_description: Sal introduces ellipses and shows how their standard equation relates to their center and radii (ellipses have two radii: major and minor).

title: Conic sections
translated_description: Given an ellipse on the coordinate plane  Sal finds its standard equation  which is an equation in the form (x-h)²/a²+(y-k)²/b²=1.

title: Conic sections
translated_description: Given the standard equation of an ellipse  Sal finds the graph of the ellipse.

title: Conic sections
translated_description: Sal explains how the radii and the foci of an ellipse relate to each other  and how we can use this relationship in order to find the foci from the equation of an ellipse.

title: Conic sections
translated_description: A parabola is the set of all points equidistant from a point (called the "focus") and a line (called the "directrix"). See this video to learn more about this.

title: Conic sections
translated_description: The equation of a parabola is derived from the focus and directrix  and then the general formula is used to solve an example.

title: Conic sections
translated_description: Given the parabola equation y-23/4=-1/3(x-1)^2  Sal finds the parabola's focus and directrix using the general formula for a parabola whose focus is (a b) and directrix is y=k.

title: Conic sections
translated_description: Sal introduces the standard equation for hyperbolas  and how it can be used in order to determine the direction of the hyperbola and its vertices.

title: Conic sections
translated_description: Sal picks the graph of y²/9-x²/4=1 based on the hyperbola's center  direction  & vertices.

title: Conic sections
translated_description: Sal matches an equation to a given graph of a hyperbola  based on the hyperbola's direction & vertices.

title: Conic sections
translated_description: Given the hyperbola equation y^2/4-x^2/9=1  Sal determines the direction to which it opens and its vertices in order to draw its graph.

title: Conic sections
translated_description: Sal discusses the foci of hyperbolas and shows how they relate to hyperbola equations.

title: Conic sections
translated_description: Sal proves why  for the general hyperbola equation x^2/a^2-y^2/b^2=1  the focal length f forms the equation f^2=a^2+b^2 with the parameters a and b.

title: Conic sections
translated_description: Sal analyzes the hyperbola whose equation is (x-1)^2/16-(y+1)^2/4=1  and graphs it.

title: Conic sections
translated_description: Sal manipulates the equation x^2+y^2-3x+4y=4 in order to find that it represents a circle  and the equation 2x^2+y+12x+16=0 in order to find it represents a parabola.

title: Conic sections
translated_description: Sal manipulates the equation 9x^2+4y^2+54x-8y+49=0 in order to find that it represents an ellipse.

title: Conic sections
translated_description: Sal manipulates the equation 4y^2-50x=25x^2+16y+109 in order to find that it represents a hyperbola.

title: Conic sections
translated_description: How a tangent line relates to a hyperbola. Might be useful for some competitive exams where there isn't time to derive (like we are doing in this video).

title: Conic sections
translated_description: 2010 IIT JEE Paper 1 Problem 45: Find the equation of a tangent common a given circle and a given hyperbola.

title: Conic sections
translated_description: 2010 IIT JEE Paper 1 Problem 45 Circle Hyperbola Common Tangent Part 2

title: Conic sections
translated_description: 2010 IIT JEE Paper 1 Problem 45 Circle Hyperbola Common Tangent Part 3

title: Conic sections
translated_description: 2010 IIT JEE Paper 1 Problem 45 Circle Hyperbola Common Tangent Part 4

title: Conic sections
translated_description: 2010 IIT JEE Paper 1 Problem 45 Circle Hyperbola Common Tangent Part 5

title: Conic sections
translated_description: 2010 IIT JEE Paper 1 Problem 46: Find the equation of a circle whose diameter is defined by the two intersection points of given circle and hyperbola.

title: Vectors
translated_description: Distance  displacement  speed and velocity. Difference between vectors and scalars.

title: Vectors
translated_description: Watch Sal figure out which of a few options could be represented by a vector. Remember that vectors have both magnitude and direction!

title: Vectors
translated_description: Sal determines if two vectors shown on a graph are equivalent by seeing if they have the same magnitude and direction.

title: Vectors
translated_description: Sal finds the x and y-components of a vector given its graph.

title: Vectors
translated_description: Sal figures out which vectors have the same x-component given the graphs of 4 different vectors.

title: Vectors
translated_description: Sal finds the magnitude of a vector given its graph.

title: Vectors
translated_description: Sal finds the magnitude of a vector given its components of (5  -3).

title: Vectors
translated_description: Sal finds the magnitude of the vector with initial point (-7  3) and terminal point (2  -1).

title: Vectors
translated_description: Sal explains what happens graphically and to the components of a vector when we multiply it by a scalar.

title: Vectors
translated_description: Sal analyzes the magnitude and direction of vectors that are a result of scalar multiplication of a vector whose magnitude is given.

title: Vectors
translated_description: Sal shows how to add vectors by adding their components  then explains the intuition behind adding vectors using a graph.

title: Vectors
translated_description: Build intuition behind adding and subtracting vectors visually and the "head-to-tail" method.

title: Vectors
translated_description: Watch Sal determine which diagram represents vector subtraction graphically.

title: Vectors
translated_description: To add the vectors (x₁ y₁) and (x₂ y₂)  we add the corresponding components from each vector: (x₁+x₂ y₁+y₂). Here's a concrete example: the sum of (2 4) and (1 5) is (2+1 4+5)  which is (3 9). There's also a nice graphical way to add vectors  and the two ways will always result in the same vector.​​

title: Vectors
translated_description: Watch Sal find new vector 3u + 1/5w when u = (2  -1) and w = (-5  5).

title: Vectors
translated_description: Unit vectors are vectors whose magnitude is exactly 1 unit. They are very useful for different reasons. Specifically  the unit vectors [0 1] and [1 0] can form together any other vector.

title: Vectors
translated_description: Learn what a unit vector is and how to find a unit vector in the direction of a given vector.

title: Vectors
translated_description: Watch Sal scale up a unit vector to have a magnitude greater than 1.

title: Vectors
translated_description: Sal first finds the direction angle of a vector in the first quadrant  then moves onto a trickier one in the second quadrant.

title: Vectors
translated_description: Sal finds the direction angle of a vector in the third quadrant and a vector in the fourth quadrant.

title: Vectors
translated_description: Sal finds the components of a couple of vectors given in magnitude and direction form.

title: Vectors
translated_description: Watch Sal add two vectors given in magnitude and direction form by breaking them down into components first.

title: Vectors
translated_description: Watch Sal finish the problem he started in part 1 by converting the sum back to magnitude and direction form.

title: Vectors
translated_description: Sal explains some interesting properties of the magnitude of vector sums.

title: Vectors
translated_description: Sal solves a word problem where three vector forces act upon a ring in different magnitudes & directions.

title: Vectors
translated_description: Sal solves a word problem with vectors where he finds the total straight-line distance traveled over a few days.

title: Matrices
translated_description: Take the red pill and enter the Matrix!

title: Matrices
translated_description: Sal solves a linear system with 3 variables by representing it with an augmented matrix and bringing the matrix to reduced row-echelon form.

title: Matrices
translated_description: Sal defines what it means to add or subtract matrices. He shows a few examples and discusses some important properties of matrix addition and subtraction.

title: Matrices
translated_description: Sal defines what it means to multiply a matrix by a scalar (in the world of matrices  a scalar is simply a regular number).

title: Matrices
translated_description: Sal explains what it means to multiply two matrices  and gives an example.

title: Matrices
translated_description: Sal gives an example of a multiplication of two matrices that don't have the same dimensions.

title: Matrices
translated_description: Sal discusses the conditions of matrix dimensions for which addition or multiplication are defined.

title: Matrices
translated_description: Just as any number remains the same when multiplied by 1  any matrix remains the same when multiplied by the identity matrix. Learn more from Sal.

title: Matrices
translated_description: Sal explains why the identity matrix is always a square matrix  even though it works with non-square matrices.

title: Matrices
translated_description: Sal checks whether the commutative property applies for matrix multiplication. In other words  he checks whether for any two matrices A and B  A*B=B*A (the answer is NO  by the way).

title: Matrices
translated_description: Sal shows that matrix multiplication is associative. Mathematically  this means that for any three matrices A  B  and C  (A*B)*C=A*(B*C).

title: Matrices
translated_description: Just as any number multiplied by zero is zero  there is a zero matrix such that any matrix multiplied by it results in that zero matrix. Learn more from Sal.

title: Matrices
translated_description: Sal determines which of a few optional matrix expressions is equivalent to the matrix expression A*B*C. This is done using what we know about the properties of matrix addition and multiplication.

title: Matrices
translated_description: Sal solves a problem where he has to determine whether unknown matrices are zero or identity to make an equation true.

title: Matrices
translated_description: Sal transforms a 2-dimensional vector using a 2x2 matrix  and draws the original vector and its image on the plane.

title: Matrices
translated_description: Sal transforms a triangle using a 2x2 matrix.

title: Matrices
translated_description: Sal finds the drawing that appropriately represents the effect of a given 2x2 transformation matrix on the plane.

title: Matrices
translated_description: Sal shows how to find the determinant of a 2x2 matrix.

title: Matrices
translated_description: Sal introduces the concept of an inverse matrix.

title: Matrices
translated_description: Sal shows why a matrix is invertible if and only if its determinant is not 0.

title: Matrices
translated_description: Sal gives an example of how to find the inverse of a given 2x2 matrix.

title: Matrices
translated_description: Sal shows how a system of two linear equations can be represented with the equation A*x=b where A is the coefficient matrix  x is the variable vector  and b is the constant vector.

title: Matrices
translated_description: After he represented a system of equations with a single matrix equation  Sal solves that matrix equation using the inverse of the coefficient matrix.

title: Matrices
translated_description: Sal finds the appropriate combination of two given vectors in order to obtain a third given vector. This is done by representing the problem with a single matrix equation and solving that equation.

title: Matrices
translated_description: Sal shows how matrices can be used to efficiently represent data about the prices of toilet paper and toothpaste in two different cities.

title: Imaginary and complex numbers
translated_description: Sal introduces the imaginary unit i  which is defined by the equation i^2=-1. He then gets to know this special number better by thinking about its powers.

title: Imaginary and complex numbers
translated_description: The imaginary unit i is defined such that i²=-1. So what's i³? i³=i²⋅i=-i. What's i⁴? i⁴=i²⋅i²=(-1)²=1. What's i⁵? i⁵=i⁴⋅i=1⋅i=i. This pattern repeats itself all the time  so we can quickly tell what iⁿ for any positive integer n.

title: Imaginary and complex numbers
translated_description: Sal simplifies √(-52) as 2i√(13).

title: Imaginary and complex numbers
translated_description: The formal definition of i is i^2=-1 and not √-1=i  and there's a good reason for this (although it's a bit technical). See Sal explain why.

title: Imaginary and complex numbers
translated_description: Sal explains how we obtain complex numbers by adding real numbers and imaginary numbers.

title: Imaginary and complex numbers
translated_description: Sal first simplifies complex expressions  and then explains how to classify numbers as real  pure imaginary  or complex.

title: Imaginary and complex numbers
translated_description: Sal shows how to plot various numbers on the complex plane.

title: Imaginary and complex numbers
translated_description: Sal adds (5+2i) and (3-7i) .

title: Imaginary and complex numbers
translated_description: Sal subtracts (6-18i) from (2-3i).

title: Imaginary and complex numbers
translated_description: Sal multiplies (1-3i) by (2+5i).

title: Imaginary and complex numbers
translated_description: Sal explains what is the conjugate of a complex number  and shows how the product of a complex number and its conjugate is always a real number.

title: Imaginary and complex numbers
translated_description: Sal finds the conjugate of (7-5i).

title: Imaginary and complex numbers
translated_description: Sal divides (6+3i) by (7-5i).

title: Imaginary and complex numbers
translated_description: Sal finds the absolute value of (3-4i).

title: Imaginary and complex numbers
translated_description: Sal finds the modulus (which is the absolute value) and the argument (which is the angle) of √3/2+1/2*i.

title: Imaginary and complex numbers
translated_description: Sal finds the distance between (2+3i) and (-5-i) and then he finds their midpoint on the complex plane.

title: Imaginary and complex numbers
translated_description: Sal rewrites the complex number -3+2i (which is given in rectangular form) in its polar form.

title: Imaginary and complex numbers
translated_description: Sal shows how complex division affects the modulus and the argument of the divisor and the dividend.

title: Imaginary and complex numbers
translated_description: Sal simplifies the 20th power of a complex number given in polar form.

title: Imaginary and complex numbers
translated_description: Sal finds all complex solutions to the equation x^3=1.

title: Imaginary and complex numbers
translated_description: Paper 1 Problem 39 from the challenging 2010 IIT JEE exam  about complex numbers.

title: Imaginary and complex numbers
translated_description: Paper 1 Problem 39 from the challenging 2010 IIT JEE exam  about complex numbers.

title: Imaginary and complex numbers
translated_description: Paper 1 Problem 39 from the challenging 2010 IIT JEE exam  about complex numbers.

title: Imaginary and complex numbers
translated_description: Paper 1 Problem 53 from the challenging 2010 IIT JEE exam  about determinant of a complex numbers matrix.

title: Probability and combinatorics
translated_description: We give you an introduction to probability through the example of flipping a quarter and rolling a die.

title: Probability and combinatorics
translated_description: In order to find the probability of picking a yellow marble from a bag  we have to first determine the number of possible outcomes  and then how many of them meet our constraints.

title: Probability and combinatorics
translated_description: In this example we are figuring out the probability of randomly picking a non-blue marble from a bag. Again  we'll have to think about the possible outcomes first.

title: Probability and combinatorics
translated_description: Probability of compound events. The Addition Rule.

title: Probability and combinatorics
translated_description: Venn diagrams and the addition rule for probability

title: Probability and combinatorics
translated_description: We're thinking about the probability of rolling doubles on a pair of dice. Let's create a grid of all possible outcomes.

title: Probability and combinatorics
translated_description: The probability of getting exactly 2 heads when flipping three coins. Thinking about this by visualy depicting all of the outcomes.

title: Probability and combinatorics
translated_description: Sal figures out the probability of flipping three coins and getting at least two tails.

title: Probability and combinatorics
translated_description: You'll become familiar with the concept of independent events  or that one event in no way affects what happens in the second event. Keep in mind  too  that the sum of the probabilities of all the possible events should equal 1.

title: Probability and combinatorics
translated_description: Up until now  we've looked at probabilities surrounding only equally likely events. What about probabilities when we don't have equally likely events? Say  we have unfair coins?

title: Probability and combinatorics
translated_description: Have you ever taken a test and discovered you have no choice but to guess on a couple of problems? In this example problem  we are considering the probability of two independent events occurring.

title: Probability and combinatorics
translated_description: We hope you're not a gambler  but if you had to bet on whether you can roll even numbers three times in a row  you might want to figure this probability first.

title: Probability and combinatorics
translated_description: In this video  we 'll explore the probability of getting at least one heads in multiple flips of a fair coin.

title: Probability and combinatorics
translated_description: Our friend and Cleveland Cavalier  LeBron James  asks Sal how to determine the probability of making 10 free throws in a row. Hint: the answer is surprising!

title: Probability and combinatorics
translated_description: Our friend and Cleveland Cavalier  LeBron James  asks Sal if there's a high probability of making three free throws in a row or one three-pointer. Before solving the problem  jot down what you think the answer will be!

title: Probability and combinatorics
translated_description: Let's get you started with a great explanation of dependent probability using a scenario involving a casino game.

title: Probability and combinatorics
translated_description: We're thinking about how the probability of an event can be dependent on another event occuring in this example problem.

title: Probability and combinatorics
translated_description: It's important to practice these probability problems as they get more complex eventually. Take a stab on this one...with our help  of course.

title: Probability and combinatorics
translated_description: This time around we're not going to tell you whether we're working on a dependent or independent probability event problem. You tell us!

title: Probability and combinatorics
translated_description: Here we have a presentation and analysis of the famous thought experiment: the "Monty Hall" problem! This is fun.

title: Probability and combinatorics
translated_description: Sal explains a tricky factorial problem about counting seat arrangements.

title: Probability and combinatorics
translated_description: Sal explains the permutation formula and how to use it.

title: Probability and combinatorics
translated_description: Sal explains how to find all of the possible three letter words when we can use each letter as many times as we want  and when each letter can only be used once.

title: Probability and combinatorics
translated_description: Sal explains the intuition behind zero factorial.

title: Probability and combinatorics
translated_description: Thinking about how many ways you can pick four colors from a group of 6

title: Probability and combinatorics
translated_description: How many ways can we pick officers for our organization?

title: Probability and combinatorics
translated_description: Sal introduces the basic idea of combinations.

title: Probability and combinatorics
translated_description: Sal explains the combination formula.

title: Probability and combinatorics
translated_description: Sal figures out how different combinations of people can shake hands.

title: Probability and combinatorics
translated_description: Thinking about how many ways we can construct a hand of 9 cards

title: Probability and combinatorics
translated_description: Probability of getting exactly 3 heads in 8 flips of a fair coin.

title: Probability and combinatorics
translated_description: Making at least 3 out of 5 free throws.

title: Probability and combinatorics
translated_description: The probability of getting exactly 2 heads when flipping three coins. Thinking about this by visualy depicting all of the outcomes.

title: Probability and combinatorics
translated_description: A different way to think about the probability of getting 2 heads in 4 flips

title: Probability and combinatorics
translated_description: Probability of exactly 3 heads in 5 flips using combinations

title: Probability and combinatorics
translated_description: Conceptual understanding of where the formula for binomial coefficients come from

title: Probability and combinatorics
translated_description: Thinking about the different ways we can pick officers in order to find the probability of one situation in particular.

title: Probability and combinatorics
translated_description: Probability of getting a set of cards

title: Probability and combinatorics
translated_description: What is the probability of winning a 4-number lottery?

title: Probability and combinatorics
translated_description: Probability of winning the Mega Millions jackpot

title: Probability and combinatorics
translated_description: The probability that at least 2 people in a room of 30 share the same birthday.

title: Sequences series and induction
translated_description: Sequences are ordered lists of numbers (called "terms")  like 2 5 8. Some sequences follow a specific pattern that can be used to extend them indefinitely. For example  2 5 8 follows the pattern "add 3 " and now we can continue the sequence. Sequences can have formulas that tell us how to find any term in the sequence. For example  2 5 8 ... can be represented by the formula 2+3(n-1).

title: Sequences series and induction
translated_description: Sal introduces arithmetic sequences and their main features  the initial term and the common difference. He gives various examples of such sequences  defined explicitly and recursively.

title: Sequences series and induction
translated_description: Sal finds the equation that describes a growth pattern of shapes made of squares.

title: Sequences series and induction
translated_description: Sal finds explicit formulas of arithmetic sequences given the first few terms of those sequences. He also explores equivalent forms of such formulas.

title: Sequences series and induction
translated_description: Sigma  Σ  is the standard notation for writing long sums. Learn how it is used in this video.

title: Sequences series and induction
translated_description: Sal explains the formula for the sum of a finite arithmetic series

title: Sequences series and induction
translated_description: Sal evaluates the arithmetic series Σ(2k+50) for k=1 to 550. He does that using the arithmetic series formula (a₁+aₙ)*n/2.

title: Sequences series and induction
translated_description: Sal evaluates the arithmetic sum (-50)+(-44)+(-38)+...+2044. He does that by finding the number of terms and using the arithmetic series formula (a₁+aₙ)*n/2.

title: Sequences series and induction
translated_description: Sal evaluates the sum of the first 650 terms in the sequence defined recursively as {aᵢ=aᵢ₋₁+11  a₁=4}. He does that by finding the 650th term and using the arithmetic series formula (a₁+aₙ)*n/2.

title: Sequences series and induction
translated_description: Watch Sal prove the expression for the sum of all positive integers up to and including n.

title: Sequences series and induction
translated_description: Sal introduces geometric sequences and their main features  the initial term and the common ratio.

title: Sequences series and induction
translated_description: Sal introduces geometric sequences and gives a few examples. Notation used in this video is relatively advanced.

title: Sequences series and induction
translated_description: Sal finds an explicit formula of a geometric sequence given the first few terms of the sequences. Then he explores equivalent forms the explicit formula and finds the corresponding recursive formula.

title: Sequences series and induction
translated_description: Sal solves the following problem: The explicit formula of a geometric sequence is g(x)=9*8^(x-1). Find the recursive formula of the sequence.

title: Sequences series and induction
translated_description: A geometric series is the sum of the terms of a geometric sequence. Learn more about it here.

title: Sequences series and induction
translated_description: A geometric series is the sum of the terms of a geometric sequence. Learn about geometric series and how they can be written in general terms and using sigma notation.

title: Sequences series and induction
translated_description: Sal evaluates the geometric series Σ2(3ᵏ) for k=0 to 99 using the finite geometric series formula a(1-rⁿ)/(1-r).

title: Sequences series and induction
translated_description: Sal evaluates three geometric series (defined in various ways) using the finite geometric series formula a(1-rⁿ)/(1-r).

title: Sequences series and induction
translated_description: The finite geometric series formula is a(1-rⁿ)/(1-r). In this video  Sal gives a pretty neat justification as to why the formula works.

title: Sequences series and induction
translated_description: Watch Sal solve an example of using a geometric series to answer a fun word problem.

title: Sequences series and induction
translated_description: Figuring out the formula for fixed mortgage payments using the sum of a geometric series

title: Displaying and describing data
translated_description: What makes a question a "statistical question"?

title: Displaying and describing data
translated_description: A statistical question is one that can be answered by collecting data and where there will be variability in that data. For example  there will likely be variability in the data collected to answer the question  "How much do the animals at Fancy Farm weigh?" but not to answer  "What color hat is Sara wearing?".

title: Displaying and describing data
translated_description: Common sense tells you that a pictograph must be some kind of....picture. Yes! A pictograph is basically a way to represent data with pictures that relate to the data. Let's look at this word problem that asks to interpret a pictograph.

title: Displaying and describing data
translated_description: Reading Bar Graphs.

title: Displaying and describing data
translated_description: Sal interprets a bar graph.

title: Displaying and describing data
translated_description: Sal creates a bar chart using data from a survey.

title: Displaying and describing data
translated_description: A bar chart is especially useful with comparing two sets of data. The difference in the bars give us a quick snapshot that allows us to draw some conclusions.

title: Displaying and describing data
translated_description: Let's combine some learning! Here we looking at bar charts and using the information to determine the measures of central tendency.

title: Displaying and describing data
translated_description: Reading Pie Graphs (Circle Graphs)

title: Displaying and describing data
translated_description: Sal uses a Venn diagram to introduce two-way frequency tables.

title: Displaying and describing data
translated_description: Worked example video where we are asked to find a two-way table of column relative frequencies.

title: Displaying and describing data
translated_description: Learn how to read two-way tables.

title: Displaying and describing data
translated_description: Sal breaks down some categorical data on video games and violence.

title: Displaying and describing data
translated_description: Sal solves an example where he is asked to calculate relative frequencies and analyze trends in categorical data.

title: Displaying and describing data
translated_description: Here are a few of the many ways to look at data. Which is your favorite?

title: Displaying and describing data
translated_description: Learn to organize data into frequency tables and dot plots (sometimes called line plots).

title: Displaying and describing data
translated_description: A histogram is a graphical display of data using bars of different heights. In a histogram  each bar groups numbers into ranges. Taller bars show that more data falls in that range. A histogram displays the shape and spread of continuous sample data.

title: Displaying and describing data
translated_description: Learn how to read and interpret histograms  which summarize data by sorting it into buckets.

title: Displaying and describing data
translated_description: Some distributions are symmetrical  with data evenly distributed about the mean. Other distributions are "skewed " with data tending to the left or right of the mean. We sometimes say that skewed distributions have "tails."

title: Displaying and describing data
translated_description: Examples looking at different features of distributions  such as clusters  gaps  peaks  and outliers for distributions

title: Displaying and describing data
translated_description: Sal examines two distributions in dot plots to draw conclusions about the times of Olympic swimmers.

title: Displaying and describing data
translated_description: Sal solves practice problems where he thinks about which data displays would be helpful in which situations.

title: Displaying and describing data
translated_description: A stem and leaf is a table used to display data. The 'stem' is on the left displays the first digit or digits. The 'leaf' is on the right and displays the last digit. For example  543 and 548 can be displayed together on a stem and leaf as 54 | 3 8.

title: Displaying and describing data
translated_description: A line graph is way to visually represent data  especially data that changes over time.  Let's take a look at an example.

title: Displaying and describing data
translated_description: Misleading Line Graphs

title: Displaying and describing data
translated_description: Introduction to descriptive statistics and central tendency. Ways to measure the average of a set: median  mean  mode

title: Displaying and describing data
translated_description: The mean (average) of a data set is found by adding all numbers in the data set and then dividing by the number of values in the set. The median is the middle value when a data set is ordered from least to greatest. The mode is the number that occurs most often in a data set.

title: Displaying and describing data
translated_description: Here we give you a set of numbers and then ask you to find the mean  median  and mode. It's your first opportunity to practice with us!

title: Displaying and describing data
translated_description: Sal compares the means of two different distributions given as dot plots.

title: Displaying and describing data
translated_description: Sal compares the mean and median based on a few different distributions.

title: Displaying and describing data
translated_description: Sal thinks through the effects of removing a low outlier from a data set. What will happen to the mean and median?

title: Displaying and describing data
translated_description: Sal thinks through the effects of modifying a value in a data set. What will happen to the mean and median?

title: Displaying and describing data
translated_description: Learn how to find the value of a missing piece of data if you know the mean of the data set.

title: Displaying and describing data
translated_description: Sal solves an interesting median and range challenge problem.

title: Displaying and describing data
translated_description: The range is the difference between the largest and smallest numbers. The midrange is the average of the largest and smallest number. Practice with this problem.

title: Displaying and describing data
translated_description: The IQR describes the middle 50% of values when ordered from lowest to highest. To find the interquartile range (IQR)  ​first find the median (middle value) of the lower and upper half of the data. These values are quartile 1 (Q1) and quartile 3 (Q3). The IQR is the difference between Q3 and Q1.

title: Displaying and describing data
translated_description: Mean absolute deviation (MAD) of a data set is the average distance between each data value and the mean. Mean absolute deviation is a way to describe variation in a data set. Mean absolute deviation helps us get a sense of how "spread out" the values in a data set are.

title: Displaying and describing data
translated_description: Sal finds the mean absolute deviation of a data set that's given in a bar chart.

title: Displaying and describing data
translated_description: Learn how to create a box plot. The data set used in this example has 11 data points.

title: Displaying and describing data
translated_description: Learn how to create a box plot. The data set used in this example has 14 data points.

title: Displaying and describing data
translated_description: Here's a word problem that's perfectly suited for a box and whiskers plot to help analyze data. Let's construct one together  shall we?

title: Displaying and describing data
translated_description: Is this some kind of cute cat video? No! Box and whisker plots seek to explain data by showing a spread of all the data points in a sample. The "whiskers" are the two opposite ends of the data. This video is more fun than a handful of catnip.

title: Displaying and describing data
translated_description: Sal discusses the three most common measures of spread!

title: Displaying and describing data
translated_description: Variance as a measure of  on average  how far the data points in a population are from the population mean

title: Displaying and describing data
translated_description: Variance of a population.

title: Displaying and describing data
translated_description: Sal explains a different variance formula and why it works!

title: Displaying and describing data
translated_description: Thinking about how we can estimate the variance of a population by looking at the data in a sample.

title: Displaying and describing data
translated_description: Reviewing the population mean  sample mean  population variance  sample variance and building an intuition for why we divide by n-1 for the unbiased sample variance

title: Displaying and describing data
translated_description: Sal shows an example of calculating standard deviation and bias.

title: Displaying and describing data
translated_description: Another visualization providing evidence that dividing by n-1 truly gives an unbiased estimate of population variance. Simulation at: http://www.khanacademy.org/cs/unbiased-variance-visualization/1167453164

title: Displaying and describing data
translated_description: Simulation by Peter Collingridge giving us a better understanding of why we divide by (n-1) when calculating the unbiased sample variance. Simulation available at: http://www.khanacademy.org/cs/challenge-unbiased-estimate-of-population-variance/1169428428

title: Displaying and describing data
translated_description: Simulation by KA user tetef showing that dividing by (n-1) gives us an unbiased estimate of population variance. Simulation at: http://www.khanacademy.org/cs/will-it-converge-towards-1/1167579097

title: Displaying and describing data
translated_description: Using the variance of a sample to estimate the variance of a population

title: Displaying and describing data
translated_description: Learn how to calculate standard deviation  how it relates to variance and mean  and the difference between population and sample standard deviation

title: Modeling distributions of data
translated_description: Z-score practice

title: Modeling distributions of data
translated_description: Discussion of how "normal" a distribution might be

title: Modeling distributions of data
translated_description: Using the empirical rule (or 68-95-99.7 rule) to estimate probabilities for normal distributions

title: Modeling distributions of data
translated_description: Using the Empirical Rule with a standard normal distribution

title: Modeling distributions of data
translated_description: More Empirical Rule and Z-score practice

title: Modeling distributions of data
translated_description: Exploring the normal distribution

title: Modeling distributions of data
translated_description: (Long-26 minutes) Presentation on spreadsheet to show that the normal distribution approximates the binomial distribution for a large number of trials.

title: Describing relationships in quantitative data
translated_description: Sal shows how to construct a scatter plot.

title: Describing relationships in quantitative data
translated_description: Sal answers a question about scatter plots that show the relationship between study time  shoe size  and test score.

title: Describing relationships in quantitative data
translated_description: Sal chooses the scatter plot that shows that smoking rate drops by 0.5 point each year.

title: Describing relationships in quantitative data
translated_description: Sal explains the intuition behind correlation coefficients and does a problem where he matches correlation coefficients to scatter plots.

title: Describing relationships in quantitative data
translated_description: Sal creates a scatter plot and then fits a line to data on the median California family income.

title: Describing relationships in quantitative data
translated_description: Sal solves a problem where he has to estimate the line of best fit for a scatter plot.

title: Describing relationships in quantitative data
translated_description: Sal estimates the percentage of American adults who smoked in 1945 using a scatter plot.

title: Describing relationships in quantitative data
translated_description: Sal interprets a trend line that shows the relationship between study time and math test score for Shira.

title: Describing relationships in quantitative data
translated_description: Introduction to the idea that one can find a line that minimizes the squared distances to the points

title: Describing relationships in quantitative data
translated_description: Proof (Part 1) Minimizing Squared Error to Regression Line

title: Describing relationships in quantitative data
translated_description: Proof Part 2 Minimizing Squared Error to Line

title: Describing relationships in quantitative data
translated_description: Proof (Part 3) Minimizing Squared Error to Regression Line

title: Describing relationships in quantitative data
translated_description: Proof (Part 4) Minimizing Squared Error to Regression Line

title: Describing relationships in quantitative data
translated_description: Regression Line Example

title: Describing relationships in quantitative data
translated_description: Second Regression Example

title: Describing relationships in quantitative data
translated_description: R-Squared or Coefficient of Determination

title: Describing relationships in quantitative data
translated_description: Calculating R-Squared to see how well a regression line fits data

title: Describing relationships in quantitative data
translated_description: Covariance  Variance and the Slope of the Regression Line

title: Designing studies
translated_description: To make a valid conclusion  you'll need a representaive  not skewed  sample.

title: Designing studies
translated_description: Sal determines if a few different methods of a magician choosing a volunteer are fair.

title: Designing studies
translated_description: Much of statistics is based upon using data from a random sample that is representative of the population at large. From that sample mean  we can infer things about the greater population mean. We'll explain.

title: Designing studies
translated_description: Understanding why correlation does not imply causality (even though many in the press and some researchers often imply otherwise)

title: Designing studies
translated_description: Sal determines if a statistical study was a sample study  an experiment  or an observational study.

title: Probability
translated_description: We give you an introduction to probability through the example of flipping a quarter and rolling a die.

title: Probability
translated_description: In order to find the probability of picking a yellow marble from a bag  we have to first determine the number of possible outcomes  and then how many of them meet our constraints.

title: Probability
translated_description: In this example we are figuring out the probability of randomly picking a non-blue marble from a bag. Again  we'll have to think about the possible outcomes first.

title: Probability
translated_description: Think about what probabilities really mean. What does a probability of 0 mean? How about 1?

title: Probability
translated_description: Here we have a presentation and analysis of the famous thought experiment: the "Monty Hall" problem! This is fun.

title: Probability
translated_description: The probability of getting exactly 2 heads when flipping three coins. Thinking about this by visualy depicting all of the outcomes.

title: Probability
translated_description: Manually going through the combinatorics to determine the probability of an event occuring

title: Probability
translated_description: We're thinking about the probability of rolling doubles on a pair of dice. Let's create a grid of all possible outcomes.

title: Probability
translated_description: Sal solves an example about subsets.

title: Probability
translated_description: Based on past experience  we can make reasonable estimates of the likelihood of future events.

title: Probability
translated_description: Compare expected probabilities to what really happens when we run experiments.

title: Probability
translated_description: Predict the number of times a spinner will land on an elephant.

title: Probability
translated_description: Sal shows examples of intersection and union of sets and introduces some set notation.

title: Probability
translated_description: Sal shows an example finding the relative complement or difference of two sets A and B.

title: Probability
translated_description: Sal moves onto more challenging set ideas and notation like the universal set and absolute complement.

title: Probability
translated_description: Sal explains the difference between a subset  a strict subset  and a superset. He also explains the notation behind these ideas.

title: Probability
translated_description: Sal summarizes the set operations that he has discussed in the previous videos.

title: Probability
translated_description: Probability of compound events. The Addition Rule.

title: Probability
translated_description: Venn diagrams and the addition rule for probability

title: Probability
translated_description: Explore the notion of a "sample space". See a sample space represented as a tree diagram  table  and list.

title: Probability
translated_description: You'll become familiar with the concept of independent events  or that one event in no way affects what happens in the second event. Keep in mind  too  that the sum of the probabilities of all the possible events should equal 1.

title: Probability
translated_description: Learn how to use sample space diagrams to find probabilities.

title: Probability
translated_description: In this video  we 'll explore the probability of getting at least one heads in multiple flips of a fair coin.

title: Probability
translated_description: Our friend and Cleveland Cavalier  LeBron James  asks Sal how to determine the probability of making 10 free throws in a row. Hint: the answer is surprising!

title: Probability
translated_description: Our friend and Cleveland Cavalier  LeBron James  asks Sal if there's a high probability of making three free throws in a row or one three-pointer. Before solving the problem  jot down what you think the answer will be!

title: Probability
translated_description: Up until now  we've looked at probabilities surrounding only equally likely events. What about probabilities when we don't have equally likely events? Say  we have unfair coins?

title: Probability
translated_description: Have you ever taken a test and discovered you have no choice but to guess on a couple of problems? In this example problem  we are considering the probability of two independent events occurring.

title: Probability
translated_description: We hope you're not a gambler  but if you had to bet on whether you can roll even numbers three times in a row  you might want to figure this probability first.

title: Probability
translated_description: Let's get you started with a great explanation of dependent probability using a scenario involving a casino game.

title: Probability
translated_description: We're thinking about how the probability of an event can be dependent on another event occuring in this example problem.

title: Probability
translated_description: It's important to practice these probability problems as they get more complex eventually. Take a stab on this one...with our help  of course.

title: Probability
translated_description: This time around we're not going to tell you whether we're working on a dependent or independent probability event problem. You tell us!

title: Probability
translated_description: Sal finds dependent probabilities like P(A | B) using an example rolling die.

title: Probability
translated_description: Sal solves a conditional probability example where he thinks about probabilities like P(A | B) where the events are about lunch and breakfast!

title: Probability
translated_description: Sal uses an example about shirts  scarves  hats  and pants to explain how to use probabilities to figure out if two events are independent.

title: Probability
translated_description: Tree diagrams display all the possible outcomes of an event. Each branch in a tree diagram represents a possible outcome. Tree diagrams can be used to find the number of possible outcomes and calculate the probability of possible outcomes.

title: Probability
translated_description: Find the number of ways you can put four types of flowers into three types of pots.

title: Probability
translated_description: A different way to think about the probability of getting 2 heads in 4 flips

title: Probability
translated_description: Sal explains the permutation formula and how to use it.

title: Probability
translated_description: Sal explains the intuition behind zero factorial.

title: Probability
translated_description: Sal explains a tricky factorial problem about counting seat arrangements.

title: Probability
translated_description: Sal explains how to find all of the possible three letter words when we can use each letter as many times as we want  and when each letter can only be used once.

title: Probability
translated_description: Thinking about how many ways you can pick four colors from a group of 6

title: Probability
translated_description: How many ways can we pick officers for our organization?

title: Probability
translated_description: Sal introduces the basic idea of combinations.

title: Probability
translated_description: Sal explains the combination formula.

title: Probability
translated_description: Sal figures out how different combinations of people can shake hands.

title: Probability
translated_description: Thinking about how many ways we can construct a hand of 9 cards

title: Probability
translated_description: Probability of getting exactly 3 heads in 8 flips of a fair coin.

title: Probability
translated_description: Making at least 3 out of 5 free throws.

title: Probability
translated_description: Thinking about the different ways we can pick officers in order to find the probability of one situation in particular.

title: Probability
translated_description: Probability of getting a set of cards

title: Probability
translated_description: Probability of exactly 3 heads in 5 flips using combinations

title: Probability
translated_description: Conceptual understanding of where the formula for binomial coefficients come from

title: Probability
translated_description: What is the probability of winning a 4-number lottery?

title: Probability
translated_description: Probability that I picked a fair coin given that I flipped 4 heads out of 6 tosses.

title: Probability
translated_description: Probability of winning the Mega Millions jackpot

title: Probability
translated_description: The probability that at least 2 people in a room of 30 share the same birthday.

title: Random variables
translated_description: Basic idea and definitions of random variables

title: Random variables
translated_description: Defining discrete and continuous random variables. Working through examples of both discrete and continuous random variables.

title: Random variables
translated_description: Sal breaks down how to create the probability distribution of the number of "heads" after 3 flips of a fair coin.

title: Random variables
translated_description: Model the probability of a frozen yogurt line having 0  1  or 2 people in it.

title: Random variables
translated_description: Probability density functions for continuous random variables.

title: Random variables
translated_description: Understanding an insurance company's sense of my chances of dying.

title: Random variables
translated_description: Sal finds two missing frequencies given the total frequency and the expected value.

title: Random variables
translated_description: Sal multiplies outcomes by probabilities to find the expected value of a lottery ticket.

title: Random variables
translated_description: Sal walks through an example where he multiplies probability by values and sums to find expected value.

title: Random variables
translated_description: Sal uses expected value to compare a couple of different insurance policies.

title: Random variables
translated_description: Sal introduces the magic behind the law of large numbers.

title: Random variables
translated_description: Sal derives the variance of the difference of random variables

title: Random variables
translated_description: Sal introduces the binomial distribution with an example.

title: Random variables
translated_description: Sal walks through graphing a binomial distribution and connects it back to how to calculate binomial probabilities.

title: Random variables
translated_description: Sal calculates the probability of making 2 shots out of 6 using the binomial distribution.

title: Random variables
translated_description: Sal generalizes 2 scores in 6 attempts to k scores in n attempts.

title: Random variables
translated_description: Sal uses the binomial distribution to calculate the probability of making different number of free throws.

title: Random variables
translated_description: Sal graphs the results of using the binomial distribution to find the probabilities of making different numbers of free throws.

title: Random variables
translated_description: Expected value of a binomial distributed random variable

title: Random variables
translated_description: Introduction to Poisson Processes and the Poisson Distribution.

title: Random variables
translated_description: More of the derivation of the Poisson Distribution.

title: Sampling distributions
translated_description: Sal calculates the mean and variance of a Bernoulli distribution (in this example the responses are either favorable or unfavorable).

title: Sampling distributions
translated_description: Sal continues on from the previous video to derive the mean and variance formulas for the Bernoulli distribution.

title: Sampling distributions
translated_description: Introduction to the central limit theorem and the sampling distribution of the mean

title: Sampling distributions
translated_description: The central limit theorem and the sampling distribution of the sample mean

title: Sampling distributions
translated_description: More on the Central Limit Theorem and the Sampling Distribution of the Sample Mean

title: Sampling distributions
translated_description: Standard Error of the Mean (a.k.a. the standard deviation of the sampling distribution of the sample mean!)

title: Sampling distributions
translated_description: Figuring out the probability of running out of water on a camping trip

title: Sampling distributions
translated_description: Estimating the probability that the true population mean lies within a range around a sample mean.

title: Sampling distributions
translated_description: Sal walks through the difference of sample means distribution.

title: Confidence intervals (one sample)
translated_description: Sal calculates a 99% confidence interval for the proportion of teachers who felt computers are an essential tool.

title: Confidence intervals (one sample)
translated_description: Finding the 95% confidence interval for the proportion of a population voting for a candidate.

title: Confidence intervals (one sample)
translated_description: Finding the 95% confidence interval for the proportion of a population voting for a candidate.

title: Confidence intervals (one sample)
translated_description: Estimating the probability that the true population mean lies within a range around a sample mean.

title: Confidence intervals (one sample)
translated_description: Constructing small sample size confidence intervals using t-distributions

title: Confidence intervals (one sample)
translated_description: Sal computes a confidence interval for the emission from an engine with a new design.

title: Significance tests (one sample)
translated_description: Sal walks through an example about who should do the dishes that gets at the idea behind hypothesis testing.

title: Significance tests (one sample)
translated_description: Sal gives the definition of type 1 error and builds some intuition behind it.

title: Significance tests (one sample)
translated_description: Sal uses a large sample to test if more than 30% of US households have internet access.

title: Significance tests (one sample)
translated_description: Sal walks through an example about a neurologist testing the effect of a drug to discuss hypothesis testing and p-values.

title: Significance tests (one sample)
translated_description: Sal continues his discussion of the effect of a drug to one-tailed and two-tailed hypothesis tests.

title: Significance tests (one sample)
translated_description: Sal breaks down the difference between Z-statistics and T-statistics.

title: Significance tests (one sample)
translated_description: Sal walks through an example of a hypothesis test where he determines if there is sufficient evidence to conclude that a new type of engine meets emission requirements.

title: Significance tests and confidence intervals (two samples)
translated_description: Sal uses an election example to compare population proportions.

title: Significance tests and confidence intervals (two samples)
translated_description: Sal continues the election example for population proportions.

title: Significance tests and confidence intervals (two samples)
translated_description: Once again  Sal continues the discussion of election results to run a hypothesis test comparing population proportions.

title: Significance tests and confidence intervals (two samples)
translated_description: Sal determines if the results of an experiment about advertising are statistically significant.

title: Significance tests and confidence intervals (two samples)
translated_description: Sal determines if the results of an experiment about bus speeds are statistically significant.

title: Significance tests and confidence intervals (two samples)
translated_description: Sal walks through the difference of sample means distribution.

title: Significance tests and confidence intervals (two samples)
translated_description: Sal uses a confidence interval to help figure out if a low-fat diet helps obese people lose weight.

title: Significance tests and confidence intervals (two samples)
translated_description: Clarification of Confidence Interval of Difference of Means

title: Significance tests and confidence intervals (two samples)
translated_description: Hypothesis Test for Difference of Means

title: Inference for categorical data (chi-square tests)
translated_description: Chi-Square Distribution Introduction

title: Inference for categorical data (chi-square tests)
translated_description: Sal uses the chi square test to the hypothesis that the owner's distribution is correct.

title: Inference for categorical data (chi-square tests)
translated_description: Give the row and column totals  Sal fills in the cells of a frequency table so that the events are independent.

title: Inference for categorical data (chi-square tests)
translated_description: Sal uses the contingency table chi-square test to see if a couple of different herbs prevent people from getting sick.

title: Advanced regression (inference and transforming)
translated_description: Sal determines if a quadratic or exponential model fits the data better  then uses the model to make a prediction.

title: Analysis of variance (ANOVA)
translated_description: Analysis of Variance 1 - Calculating SST (Total Sum of Squares)

title: Analysis of variance (ANOVA)
translated_description: Analysis of Variance 2 - Calculating SSW and SSB (Total Sum of Squares Within and Between)

title: Analysis of variance (ANOVA)
translated_description: Analysis of Variance 3 -Hypothesis Test with F-Statistic

title: Limits basics
translated_description: Why we study differential calculus.

title: Limits basics
translated_description: A limit tells us the value that a function approaches as that function’s inputs get closer and closer to some number. The idea of a limit is the basis of all calculus.

title: Limits basics
translated_description: Sal finds the limit of 3sin(5x)/sin(2x) at x=0 using a table of values.

title: Limits basics
translated_description: Sal finds the limit of a function given its graph. The function isn't defined at the limiting value but that doesn't mean the limit doesn't exist!

title: Limits basics
translated_description: Sal finds the limit of a function given its graph. The function's value at the limit is different from the limit's value  but that doesn't mean the limit doesn't exist!

title: Limits basics
translated_description: Sal finds the limit of a function given its graph. The function has an asymptote at the limiting value. This means the limit doesn't exist.

title: Limits basics
translated_description: A one-sided limit is the value the function approaches as the x-values approach the limit from *one side only*. For example  f(x)=|x|/x returns -1 for negative numbers  1 for positive numbers  and isn't defined for 0. The one-sided *right* limit of f at x=0 is 1  and the one-sided *left* limit at x=0 is -1.

title: Limits basics
translated_description: Sal analyzes the left-sided limit of a function given its graph. It turns out the function has an asymptote  so the limit doesn't exist.

title: Limits basics
translated_description: Sal finds the one-sided limit of x²/(1-cosx) as x approaches zero from the right  using a table of values.

title: Limits basics
translated_description: Sal explains the relationship between the 1-sided limits and the 2-sided limit of a function at a point  using a graphical example where the 1-sided limits exist but the 2-sided limit doesn't.

title: Limits basics
translated_description: Sal explains the relationship between the 1-sided limits and the 2-sided limit of a function at a point  using an algebraic example where the 1-sided limits exist but the 2-sided limit doesn't.

title: Limits basics
translated_description: Sal analyzes various 1- and 2-sided limits of a function given graphically.

title: Limits basics
translated_description: A quick reminder of what limits are  to set up for the formal definition of a limit.

title: Limits basics
translated_description: Some background intuition to make the formal definition of a limit make intuitive sense.

title: Limits basics
translated_description: The epsilon-delta defintion of limits says that the limit of f(x) at x=c is L if for any ε>0 there's a δ>0 such that if the distance of x from c is les than δ  then the distance of f(x) from L is less than ε. This is a formulation of the intuitive notion that we can get as close as we want to L.

title: Limits basics
translated_description: Watch the definition of a limit in action.

title: Continuity
translated_description: Sal introduces a formal definition of continuity at a point using limits.

title: Continuity
translated_description: Sal gives two examples where he analyzes the conditions for continuity at a point given a function's graph.

title: Continuity
translated_description: What is the limit of the sum of two functions?  What about the product?

title: Continuity
translated_description: Sal solves a few examples where the graphs of two functions are given and we're asked to find the limit of an expression that combines the two functions. For example  the limit at 0 of the product of the functions.

title: Continuity
translated_description: Sal solves a few examples where the graphs of two functions are given and we're asked to find the limit of a function that is a composition of the two functions.

title: Continuity
translated_description: Sal is asked which of the following two functions is continuous on all real numbers: eˣ and/or √x. In general  the common functions are continuous on all the numbers in their domain.

title: Continuity
translated_description: Sal is asked which of the following two functions is continuous at x=3: ln(x-3) and/or eˣ⁻³. In general  the common functions are continuous on all the numbers in their domain.

title: Continuity
translated_description: Introduction to the Intermediate value theorem. If f is a continuous function over [a b]  then it takes on every value between f(a) and f(b) over that interval.

title: Continuity
translated_description: Given that a continuous function f obtains f(-2)=3 and f(1)=6  Sal picks the statement that is guaranteed by the Intermediate value theorem.

title: Limits from equations
translated_description: Sal explains how you can easily find limits of functions at points where the functions are continuous: simply plug in the x-value into the function! Later we will learn how to find limits even when the function isn't continuous.

title: Limits from equations
translated_description: Sal gives an example of a limit where direct substitution ends in a quotient with 0 in the denominator and non-0 in the numerator. Such limits are undefined. What about limits where substitution ends in 0/0? Keep going and you'll see!

title: Limits from equations
translated_description: Sal finds the limit of (x²+x-6)/(x-2) at x=2 by factoring and simplifying the expression.

title: Limits from equations
translated_description: Sal finds the limits of (x+1)/(√(x+5)-2) by "rationalizing the denominator" of the expression.

title: Limits from equations
translated_description: The squeeze (or sandwich) theorem states that if f(x)≤g(x)≤h(x) for all numbers  and at some point x=k we have f(k)=h(k)  then g(k) must also be equal to them. We can use the theorem to find tricky limits like sin(x)/x at x=0  by "squeezing" sin(x)/x between two nicer functions and ​using them to find the limit at x=0.

title: Limits from equations
translated_description: An example applying the squeeze theorem.

title: Limits from equations
translated_description: Using the squeeze theorem to prove that the limit as x approaches 0 of (sin x)/x =1

title: Limits from equations
translated_description: Sal finds the limit at θ=0 of (1-cosθ)/(2sin²θ) by rewriting the expression using the Pythagorean identity.

title: Limits from equations
translated_description: Sal finds the limit at θ=-π/4 of (1+√2sinθ)/(cos2θ) by rewriting the expression using the cosine double angle identity.

title: Limits from equations
translated_description: Sal finds the limit of a piecewise function at the point between two different cases of the function. In this case  the two one-sided limits are equal  so the limit exists.

title: Limits from equations
translated_description: Sal finds the limit of a piecewise function at the point between two different cases of the function. In this case  the two one-sided limits aren't equal  so the limit doesn't exist.

title: Limits from equations
translated_description: Sal finds the value the function f(x)=(6x²+18x+12)/(x²-4) should have at x=-2 so it's continuous at that point.

title: Limits from equations
translated_description: Sal finds the value the function f(x)=(√(x+4)-3)/(x-5) should have at x=5 so it's continuous at that point.

title: Infinite limits
translated_description: Here we consider the limit of the function f(x)=1/x as x approaches 0  and as x approaches infinity.

title: Infinite limits
translated_description: Sal analyzes a function with an asymptote and finds the correct description of the two one-sided limits of the function at that asymptote.

title: Infinite limits
translated_description: Sal analyzes the behavior of f(x)=-1/(x-1)² around its asymptote at x=1.

title: Infinite limits
translated_description: Sal analyzes the behavior of f(x)=x/[1-cos(x-2)] around its asymptote at x=2.

title: Infinite limits
translated_description: Here we consider the limit of the function f(x)=1/x as x approaches 0  and as x approaches infinity.

title: Infinite limits
translated_description: Sal analyzes the limits at infinity of three different rational functions. He finds there are three general cases of how the limits behave.

title: Infinite limits
translated_description: Sal finds the limits at positive and negative infinity of (4x⁵-3x²+3)/(6x⁵-100x²-10).

title: Infinite limits
translated_description: Sal finds the limits at positive and negative infinity of x/√(x²+1). Since the leading term is raised to an odd power (1)  the limits at positive and negative infinity are different.

title: Infinite limits
translated_description: Limit at infinity of rational expression with radical

title: Infinite limits
translated_description: Sal finds the limit of cosx/(x²-1) at infinity  by putting it between two limits of rational functions  1/(x²-1) and -1/(x²-1).

title: Infinite limits
translated_description: Sal analyzes the limit of (x²+1)/sin(x) at infinity. It turns out this limit doesn't exist  as the function keeps oscillating between positive and negative infinity.

title: Infinite limits
translated_description: Sal finds the limit at infinity of √(100+x)-√(x).

title: Derivative introduction
translated_description: Why we study differential calculus.

title: Derivative introduction
translated_description: Sal solves a couple of problems where he interprets the derivative of a function at a point as the slope of the curve  or of the line tangent to the curve  at that point.

title: Derivative introduction
translated_description: Sal analyzes various graphs to find intervals where the derivative of the graphed function is positive or negative.

title: Derivative introduction
translated_description: Sal solves a couple of problems where the key to the solution is using the derivative of a function at a point as the slope of the line tangent to the function's graph at that point.

title: Derivative introduction
translated_description: Given that f(-2)=3 and f'(x)≤7  Sal finds the largest possible value of f(10).

title: Derivative introduction
