translated_description: Sal finds the average rate of change of a curve over several intervals  and uses one of them to approximate the slope of a line tangent to the curve.

title: Derivative introduction
translated_description: Sal approximates the instantaneous rate of change of stores per year in a popular coffee chain.

title: Derivative introduction
translated_description: Sal approximates the instantaneous velocity of a motorcyclist.

title: Derivative introduction
translated_description: What is the slope of a line between two points on a curve?  This is called a "secant" line.

title: Derivative introduction
translated_description: Sal finds the slope of the secant line on the graph of ln(x) between the points (2 ln2) and (2+h ln(2+h)).

title: Derivative introduction
translated_description: Sal finds the slope of the secant line on the graph of ln(x) between the points (e 1) and (x lnx).

title: Derivative introduction
translated_description: Sal finds and simplifies the expression for the slope of the secant line between x=4 and x=4+h on the graph of y=2x²+1.

title: Derivative introduction
translated_description: Sal finds and simplifies the expression for the slope of the secant line between x=3 and x=t on the graph of y=2x²+5x.

title: Derivative introduction
translated_description: Sal solves a challenging problem involving slopes of secant lines to a curve.

title: Derivative introduction
translated_description: Sal interprets an expression as the slope of a secant line between a specific point on a graph and any other point on that graph.

title: Derivative introduction
translated_description: Sal arrives at a formal definition for the derivative by considering it as a limit of the slopes of secant lines that approach a tangent line.

title: Derivative introduction
translated_description: Sal relates the derivative of a function and the average rate of change of the function over intervals that become infinitely small.

title: Derivative introduction
translated_description: Sal introduces two ways of writing the limit expression for the derivative of a function at a point.

title: Derivative introduction
translated_description: Enough abstract stuff already  let's see what the formal and alternative forms of the derivative look like in practice.

title: Derivative introduction
translated_description: Sal interprets a limit expression to find that it describes the derivative of f(x)=x³ at the point x=5.

title: Derivative introduction
translated_description: Sal finds the limit expression for the derivative of f(x)=x² at the point x=3 and evaluates it.

title: Derivative introduction
translated_description: Sal finds the limit expression for the derivative of f(x)=x² at any point x and simplifies it into a simpler expression (spoiler: it's 2x).

title: Derivative introduction
translated_description: Sal interprets a limit expression as the derivative of a linear function at a point  and evaluates it.

title: Derivative introduction
translated_description: Sal interprets a limit expression as the derivative of cos(x) at x=π  and evaluates it.

title: Derivative introduction
translated_description: Sal interprets limit expressions as the derivatives of a function given graphically  and evaluates them.

title: Derivative introduction
translated_description: Sal gives a couple of examples where he finds the points on the graphs of a functions where the functions aren't differentiable.

title: Derivative introduction
translated_description: Sal analyzes a piecewise function to see if it's differentiable or continuous at the edge point. In this case  the function is both continuous and differentiable.

title: Derivative introduction
translated_description: Sal analyzes a piecewise function to see if it's differentiable or continuous at the edge point. In this case  the function is continuous but not differentiable.

title: Derivative introduction
translated_description: Given the graph of a function  Sal sketches the graph of its derivative.

title: Derivative introduction
translated_description: Given the graph of a function  Sal sketches the graph of its antiderivative. In other words  he sketches the graph of the function whose derivative is the given function.

title: Derivative introduction
translated_description: Given the graph of a function  we are asked to recognize the graph of its derivative.

title: Derivative introduction
translated_description: More practice with the relationship between the graph of a function and the graph of its derivative.

title: Basic differentiation
translated_description: Sal introduces the Constant rule  which says that the derivative of f(x)=k (for any constant k) is f'(x)=0. He also justifies this rule algebraically.

title: Basic differentiation
translated_description: Constant multiple rule says that the derivative of f(x)=kg(x) is f'(x)=kg'(x). Sum/Difference rule says that the derivative of f(x)=g(x)±h(x) is f'(x)=g'(x)±h'(x). Sal introduces and justifies these rules.

title: Basic differentiation
translated_description: Sal analyzes two attempts of students to differentiate linear functions.

title: Basic differentiation
translated_description: Given some values of the derivative of a function f  and the full definition of another function g  find the derivative of 3f(x)+2g(x)

title: Basic differentiation
translated_description: Sal introduces the power rule  which tells us how to find the derivative of xⁿ.

title: Basic differentiation
translated_description: Before actually proving the power rule  Sal shows why the power rule makes sense by considering the derivatives of x¹ and x².

title: Basic differentiation
translated_description: Here Sal prooves the formula for the derivative of x^n using the binomial theorem.

title: Basic differentiation
translated_description: Sal gives a proof of the power rule for the specific case where n=½ (i.e. for the derivative of √x).

title: Basic differentiation
translated_description: Once you know how to take the derivative of x^n  it turns out you can take the derivative of any polynomial.  Let's see why...

title: Basic differentiation
translated_description: Sal differentiates f(x)=x⁵+2x³-x²  and evaluates the derivative at x=2.

title: Basic differentiation
translated_description: Sal finds the equation of the line tangent to the graph of f(x)=x³-6x²+x-5 at x=1.

title: Basic differentiation
translated_description: Sal differentiates g(x)=2/(x³)-1/(x²)  and evaluates the derivative at x=2. This can actually be done quite easily using the Power rule!

title: Basic differentiation
translated_description: A practice problem for finding the y-intercept of a tangent line to f(x) = 1/x

title: Basic differentiation
translated_description: Sal differentiates h(x)=5x^¼+7  and evaluates the derivative at x=16. This can actually be done quite easily using the Power rule!

title: Basic differentiation
translated_description: Sal differentiates f(x)=-4∛x  and evaluates the derivative at x=8. This can actually be done quite easily using the Power rule!

title: Basic differentiation
translated_description: Learn the derivatives of several common functions.

title: Basic differentiation
translated_description: Sal differentiates g(x)=7sin(x)-3cos(x)-(π/∛x)². This can be done using the derivatives of sine and cosine  and the Power rule.

title: Basic differentiation
translated_description: Learn the derivatives of several common functions.

title: Product quotient & chain rules
translated_description: Sal differentiates x²sin(x) using the product rule.

title: Product quotient & chain rules
translated_description: Sal differentiates eˣcos(x) using the product rule.

title: Product quotient & chain rules
translated_description: Given the values of f and h (and their derivatives) at x=3  Sal evaluates the derivative of f(x)⋅h(x) at x=3.

title: Product quotient & chain rules
translated_description: Given the values of f and f' at x=-1 and that g(x)=1/x  Sal evaluates the derivative of F(x)=f(x)⋅g(x) at x=-1.

title: Product quotient & chain rules
translated_description: Sal differentiates the product of three different functions  and generalizes for the derivative of the product of any number of functions.

title: Product quotient & chain rules
translated_description: Why does the product rule work?

title: Product quotient & chain rules
translated_description: The chain rule states that the derivative of f(g(x)) is f'(g(x))⋅g'(x). In other words  it helps us differentiate *composite functions*. For example  sin(x²) is a composite function because it can be constructed as f(g(x)) for f(x)=sin(x) and g(x)=x². Using the chain rule and the derivatives of sin(x) and x²  we can then find the derivative of sin(x²).

title: Product quotient & chain rules
translated_description: Sal differentiates the composite function f(x)=cos³x using the chain rule.

title: Product quotient & chain rules
translated_description: Sal differentiates the composite function f(x)=ln(√x) using the chain rule.

title: Product quotient & chain rules
translated_description: Sal differentiates the composite function f(x)=√(3x²-x) using the chain rule.

title: Product quotient & chain rules
translated_description: Given the values of f and g (and their derivatives) at some x-values  Sal evaluates the derivative of F(x)=f(g(x)) at a specific x-value.

title: Product quotient & chain rules
translated_description: Sal shows that if a function is differentiable at a point  it is also continuous at that point.

title: Product quotient & chain rules
translated_description: Sal shows that if a function is continuous  the difference in the function's values approaches 0 as the difference in the x-values approaches 0. This is simply another way to define continuity.

title: Product quotient & chain rules
translated_description: Here we use the formal properties of continuity and differentiability to see why the chain rule is true.

title: Product quotient & chain rules
translated_description: Sal shows how you can derive the quotient rule using the product rule and the chain rule (one less rule to memorize!)

title: Product quotient & chain rules
translated_description: Given the values of f and f' at x=-1 and that g(x)=2x³  Sal evaluates the derivative of F(x)=f(x)/g(x) at x=-1.

title: Product quotient & chain rules
translated_description: Sal finds the equation of the line tangent to the curve y=eˣ/(2+x³) at the point (1 e/3).

title: Product quotient & chain rules
translated_description: Sal finds the equation of the line normal to the curve y=eˣ/x² at the point (1 e).

title: Differentiating common functions
translated_description: Sal differentiates the rational function (5-3x)/(x²+3x). This function (and any other rational function) can be differentiated using the Quotient rule!

title: Differentiating common functions
translated_description: Sal differentiates ∜(x³+4x²+7) and evaluates the derivative at x=-3.

title: Differentiating common functions
translated_description: Sal finds the derivatives of tan(x) and cot(x) by writing them as quotients of sin(x) and cos(x) and using quotient rule.

title: Differentiating common functions
translated_description: Sal finds the derivatives of sec(x) and csc(x) by writing them as 1/sin(x) or 1/cos(x) and using quotient rule.

title: Differentiating common functions
translated_description: Sal differentiates sec(3π/2-x) and evaluates the derivative at x=π/4.

title: Differentiating common functions
translated_description: Learn the derivatives of several common functions.

title: Differentiating common functions
translated_description: Sal finds the derivative of aˣ (for any positive base a) using the derivative of eˣ and the chain rule. He then differentiates 8⋅3ˣ.

title: Differentiating common functions
translated_description: Sal differentiates the exponential function 7^(x²-x) using our knowledge of the derivative of aˣ and the chain rule.

title: Differentiating common functions
translated_description: Learn the derivatives of several common functions.

title: Differentiating common functions
translated_description: Sal finds the derivative of logₐx (for any positive base a≠1) using the derivative of ln(x) and the logarithm change of base rule. He then differentiates log₇x and -3log_π(x).

title: Differentiating common functions
translated_description: Sal differentiates the logarithmic function log₄(x²+x) using our knowledge of the derivative of logₐ(x) and the chain rule.

title: Differentiating common functions
translated_description: By exploiting our knowledge of logarithms  we can make certain derivatives much smoother to compute.

title: Differentiating common functions
translated_description: Sal differentiates eᶜᵒˢˣ⋅cos(eˣ) by applying both the product rule and the chain rule.

title: Differentiating common functions
translated_description: Sal differentiates sin(ln(x²)) by applying the chain rule twice.

title: Advanced differentiation
translated_description: Some relationships cannot be represented by an explicit function. For example  x²+y²=1. Implicit differentiation helps us find ​dy/dx even for relationships like that. This is done using the chain ​rule  and viewing y as an implicit function of x. For example  according to the chain rule  the derivative of y² would be 2y⋅(dy/dx).

title: Advanced differentiation
translated_description: Implicit differentiation of (x-y)²=x+y-1

title: Advanced differentiation
translated_description: Sal finds the slope of the tangent line to the curve x²+(y-x)³=28 at x=1 using implicit differentiation.

title: Advanced differentiation
translated_description: Sal gives an example of how implicit differentiation results in the same derivative expression as direct differentiation.

title: Advanced differentiation
translated_description: Implicit differentiation of y = cos(5x - 3y)

title: Advanced differentiation
translated_description: Implicit derivative of (x²+y²)³=5x²y².

title: Advanced differentiation
translated_description: Sal finds dy/dx for e^(xy²)=x-y using implicit differentiation.

title: Advanced differentiation
translated_description: How can you find the derivative of ln(x) by viewing it as the inverse of e^x?

title: Advanced differentiation
translated_description: Derivative of inverse sine

title: Advanced differentiation
translated_description: Derivative of inverse cosine.

title: Advanced differentiation
translated_description: More inverses!  Inverse of tangent this time.

title: Advanced differentiation
translated_description: Given that f(x)=½x³+3x-4  Sal evaluates the derivative of the inverse of f at x=-14.

title: Advanced differentiation
translated_description: Given a table of values of g  its inverse h  and its derivative g'  Sal evaluates the derivative of the inverse  h'  at a given x-value.

title: Advanced differentiation
translated_description: Sal interprets an elaborate limit expression as 5 times the derivative of log(x) at x=2. This way  he can evaluate the limit using differentiation rules instead of directly analyzing the limit (which is hard!).

title: Advanced differentiation
translated_description: Taking the derivative of ln x

title: Advanced differentiation
translated_description: Proof that the derivative of eˣ is eˣ.

title: Advanced differentiation
translated_description: Doing both proofs in the same video to clarify any misconceptions that the original proof was "circular".

title: Advanced differentiation
translated_description: Sal finds the derivatives of xˣ and x^(xˣ). They are surprisingly fun to do!

title: Advanced differentiation
translated_description: Sal differentiates the composite exponential function [ln(x)]ˣ and evaluates the derivative at x=e. Composite exponential functions are functions where the variable is in both the base and the exponent.

title: Advanced differentiation
translated_description: Sal finds the second derivative of y=6/x². Second derivative is the derivative of the derivative of y.

title: Analyzing functions with calculus
translated_description: Sal explains all about minimum and maximum points  both absolute and relative.

title: Analyzing functions with calculus
translated_description: Sal analyzes graphs of functions to find relative extremum points.

title: Analyzing functions with calculus
translated_description: Sal introduces the "critical points" of a function and discusses their relationship with the extremum points of the function.

title: Analyzing functions with calculus
translated_description: Sal finds the critical points of f(x)=xe^(-2x²).

title: Analyzing functions with calculus
translated_description: Sal finds the intervals where the function f(x)=x⁶-3x⁵ is decreasing by finding where f' is negative.

title: Analyzing functions with calculus
translated_description: Sal is given that the derivative of function g  is g'(x)=x²/(x-2)³. He uses that to find the intervals where g is increasing  by looking for the intervals where g' is positive.

title: Analyzing functions with calculus
translated_description: Once you find a critical point  how can you tell if it is a minimum  maximum or neither?

title: Analyzing functions with calculus
translated_description: Sal finds the extremum points of f(x)=x³-12x+2.

title: Analyzing functions with calculus
translated_description: Sal finds the relative maximum point of g(x)=x⁴-x⁵ by analyzing the intervals where its derivative  g'  is negative or positive.

title: Analyzing functions with calculus
translated_description: The Extreme Value Theorem states that if a function in continuous on a closed interval [a b]  then the function must have a maximum and a minimum on the interval. This makes sense: when a function is continuous you can draw its graph without lifting the pencil  so you must hit a high point and a low point on that interval.

title: Analyzing functions with calculus
translated_description: Sal finds the absolute maximum value of f(x)=8ln(x)-x² over the interval [1 4].

title: Analyzing functions with calculus
translated_description: Sal analyzes the absolute minimum and maximum points of g(x)=x²ln(x) over its entire domain.

title: Analyzing functions with calculus
translated_description: Sal introduces the concept of concavity  what it means for a graph to be "concave up" or "concave down " and how this relates to the second derivative of a function.

title: Analyzing functions with calculus
translated_description: Sal walks through an exercise where you are asked to recognize the concavity of a function in certain regions.

title: Analyzing functions with calculus
translated_description: Sal finds the intervals where g(x)=-x⁴+6x²-2x-3 is concave down/up by finding where its second derivative  g''  is positive/negative.

title: Analyzing functions with calculus
translated_description: Sal justifies the second derivative test  which is a way of determining relative minima & maxima  and gives an example.

title: Analyzing functions with calculus
translated_description: Inflection points are points where the function changes concavity  i.e. from being "concave up" to being "concave down" or vice versa. They can be found by considering where the second derivative changes signs. In similar to critical points in the first derivative  inflection points will occur when the second derivative is either zero or undefined.

title: Analyzing functions with calculus
translated_description: Sal analyzes the graph of a function g to find all the inflection points of g.

title: Analyzing functions with calculus
translated_description: Sal analyzes the graph of a the derivative g' of function g to find all the inflection points of g.

title: Analyzing functions with calculus
translated_description: Sal analyzes the points of inflection of g(x)=¼x⁴-4x³+24x² by looking for values where the second derivative g'' changes signs.

title: Analyzing functions with calculus
translated_description: Sal sketches a graph of f(x)=3x⁴-4x³+2 including extremum and inflection points.

title: Analyzing functions with calculus
translated_description: Sal sketches a graph of f(x)=ln(x⁴+27) including extremum and inflection points.

title: Derivative applications
translated_description: Sal introduces the idea of approximating curves using their tangent line equations. This is also called "local linearization."

title: Derivative applications
translated_description: Sal finds a linear expression that approximates y=1/(x-1) around x=-1. This is done by finding the equation of the line tangent to the graph at x=-1  a process called "linear approximation."

title: Derivative applications
translated_description: The position of a particle moving along the x-axis is given by s(t)=t³-6t²+9t. Sal analyzes it to find the times when the particle is "speeding up."

title: Derivative applications
translated_description: The speed of a particle moving along the x-axis is given by v(t)=-t³+6t²+2t. Sal analyzes it to find the time when the particle's acceleration attains its maximum value.

title: Derivative applications
translated_description: Learn how to analyze a particles motion given the graph of its position over time.

title: Derivative applications
translated_description: Given a function representing the position of a function over time  how can you find the total distance traveled?

title: Derivative applications
translated_description: What's the relationship between how fast a circle's radius changes  and how fast its area changes?

title: Derivative applications
translated_description: As two cars approach the same intersection from different roads  how does the rate of change of the distance between them change?

title: Derivative applications
translated_description: You're on a ladder.  The bottom of the ladder starts slipping away from the wall.  Amidst your fright  you realize this would make a great related rates problem...

title: Derivative applications
translated_description: As you pour water into a cone  how does the rate of change of the depth of the water relate to the rate of change in volume.

title: Derivative applications
translated_description: Sal solves a related rates problem about the shadow an owl casts as it's hunting a mouse.

title: Derivative applications
translated_description: In this example  you are analyzing the rate of change of a balloon's altitude based on the angle you have to crane your neck to look at it.

title: Derivative applications
translated_description: What is the minimum possible value of x^2+y^2 given that their product has to be fixed at xy = -16

title: Derivative applications
translated_description: If you are making a box out of a flat piece of cardboard  how do you maximize the volume of that box?

title: Derivative applications
translated_description: Finishing up the last video by working through the formulas.

title: Derivative applications
translated_description: Who knows  you may end up running a shoe factory one day.  So it might not be a bad idea to know how to maximize profits.

title: Derivative applications
translated_description: With all the storage you might have to handle for your shoe factory  I bet you'd also like to be able to minize the cost of storage.

title: Derivative applications
translated_description: Sal constructs an equilateral triangle & a square whose bases are 100m together  such that their area is the smallest possible.

title: Derivative applications
translated_description: Sal constructs an equilateral triangle & a square whose bases are 100m together  such that their area is the smallest possible.

title: Derivative applications
translated_description: A difficult but interesting derivative word problem

title: Derivative applications
translated_description: Let's face it  sometimes it feels like we forget much of what we learn.  In this example we model that forgetful phenomenon.

title: Derivative applications
translated_description: Sal solves a problem involving the modeling of cost with a function  which means the function's derivative models the marginal cost.

title: Derivative applications
translated_description: In economics  the idea of marginal cost can be nicely captured with the derivative.

title: Derivative applications
translated_description: The Mean Value Theorem states that if a function f is continuous on the closed interval [a b] and differentiable on the open interval (a b)  then there exists a point c in the interval (a b) such that f'(c) is equal to the function's average rate of change over [a b]. In other words  the graph has a tangent somewhere in (a b) that is parallel to the secant line over [a b].

title: Derivative applications
translated_description: Sal finds the number that satisfies the Mean value theorem for f(x)=x²-6x+8 over the interval [2 5].

title: Derivative applications
translated_description: Sal finds the number that satisfies the Mean value theorem for f(x)=√(4x-3) over the interval [1 3].

title: Derivative applications
translated_description: Even if a cop never spots you while you are speeding  he can still infer when you must have been speeding...

title: Derivative applications
translated_description: When you are solving a limit  and get 0/0 or ∞/∞  L'Hôpital's rule is the tool you need.

title: Derivative applications
translated_description: Sal uses L'Hôpital's rule to find the limit at 0 of (2sinx-sin2x)/(x-sinx).

title: Derivative applications
translated_description: Sal uses L'Hôpital's rule to find the limit at 1 of x/(x-1)-1/lnx.

title: Derivative applications
translated_description: Sal uses L'Hôpital's rule to find the limit at infinity of (4x²-5x)/(1-3x²).

title: Derivative applications
translated_description: Sal uses L'Hôpital's rule to find the value of a in (√(4+a)-√(4-ax))/x so the expression's limit at 0 is ¾.

title: Derivative applications
translated_description: Sal uses L'Hôpital's rule to find the limit at 0 of (sinx)^(1/lnx).

title: Derivative applications
translated_description: This isn't a full proof of L'Hopital's rule  but it should give some intuition for why it works.

title: Indefinite integrals
translated_description: What's the opposite of a derivative?  It's something called the "indefinite integral".

title: Indefinite integrals
translated_description: Can you find a function whose derivative is x^n?

title: Indefinite integrals
translated_description: In this example  we find the antiderivative an expression which is not so simple.

title: Indefinite integrals
translated_description: Given the graph of a function  can you identify the graph of its antiderivative?

title: Indefinite integrals
translated_description: More practice identifying the graph of the antiderivative of a function.

title: Indefinite integrals
translated_description: What are the antiderivatives of sin(x)  cos(x) and e^x?

title: Indefinite integrals
translated_description: In differential ​calculus we learned that the derivative of ln(x) is 1/x. Integration goes the other way: the integral (or antiderivative) of 1/x should be a function whose derivative is 1/x. As we just saw  this is ln(x). However  if x is negative then ln(x) is undefined! The solution is quite simple: the antiderivative of 1/x is ln(|x|).

title: Indefinite integrals
translated_description: Sal finds f(-1) given that f'(x)=24/x³ and f(2)=12.

title: Indefinite integrals
translated_description: Sal finds f(0) given that f'(x)=5eˣ and f(7)=40+5e⁷.

title: Definite integrals introduction
translated_description: If you already know the area under a curve  you can use it to compute an integral.

title: Definite integrals introduction
translated_description: Sal uses a graph to explain why we can take a constant out of a definite integral.

title: Definite integrals introduction
translated_description: If you know the integrals of two functions  what is the integral of their sum?

title: Definite integrals introduction
translated_description: What happens when the bounds of your integral are the same?

title: Definite integrals introduction
translated_description: By subdividing the stretch of numbers where you are integrating  you can break up an integral.

title: Definite integrals introduction
translated_description: When you shift a function  what happens to its integral?

title: Definite integrals introduction
translated_description: What happens when you swap the bounds on an integral?

title: Definite integrals introduction
translated_description: Sal evaluates definite integrals of functions given their graphs. He does so using various properties of integrals.

title: Definite integrals introduction
translated_description: Sal evaluates definite integrals of functions given their graphs. He does so using various properties of integrals.

title: Definite integrals introduction
translated_description: Given the definite integrals of f and g over a specific interval  Sal finds the definite integral (on that interval) of a combination of f and g.

title: Definite integrals introduction
translated_description: Given the definite integral of f over two intervals  Sal finds the definite integral of f over another  related  interval.

title: Definite integrals introduction
translated_description: Watch how some integral properties can actually be used.

title: Riemann sums
translated_description: Approximating the area under a curve using some rectangles.  This is called a "Riemann sum".

title: Riemann sums
translated_description: Generalizing the technique of approximating area under a curve with rectangles.

title: Riemann sums
translated_description: Here we see how estimating the area under a curve representing velocity estimates distance traveled.

title: Riemann sums
translated_description: Here we express the approximation of the area under a curve in sigma notation.

title: Riemann sums
translated_description: When a function is negative  Riemann sums seem to treat it as having "negative area".

title: Riemann sums
translated_description: Estimating the area under a curve with trapazoids instead of rectangles can give a closer approximation.

title: Riemann sums
translated_description: Another example of trapazoidal approximation

title: Riemann sums
translated_description: The moment you've been waiting for.  Here we connect the idea of Riemann sums with integrals.

title: Riemann sums
translated_description: A good way to test your understanding of Riemann sums is to rank the values of various different sums.

title: Fundamental theorem of calculus
translated_description: Sal explains how to use a graph to evaluate a function defined by an integral.

title: Fundamental theorem of calculus
translated_description: Sal evaluates a function defined by the integral of a graphed function. In order to evaluate he must switch the sides of the interval.

title: Fundamental theorem of calculus
translated_description: Solving for where a function defined by an integral equals 0.

title: Fundamental theorem of calculus
translated_description: The fundamental theorem of calculus shows how  in some sense  integration is the opposite of differentiation.

title: Fundamental theorem of calculus
translated_description: See what the fundamental theorem of calculus looks like in action.

title: Fundamental theorem of calculus
translated_description: How do you apply the fundamental theorem of calculus when both integral bounds are a function of x.

title: Fundamental theorem of calculus
translated_description: See why this surpising result is true.

title: Fundamental theorem of calculus
translated_description: See what the fundamental theorem of calculus looks like in action.

title: Fundamental theorem of calculus
translated_description: Sometimes you need to swap the bounds of integration before applying the fundamental theorem of calculus.

title: Definite integral evaluation
translated_description: There are really two versions of the fundamental theorem of calculus  and we go through the connection here.

title: Definite integral evaluation
translated_description: Why should taking the integral of an derivative bring you back to the function where you started?

title: Definite integral evaluation
translated_description: Based on the fundamental theorem of calculus  we can use antiderivatives to compute integrals.

title: Definite integral evaluation
translated_description: With integrals  it can be helpful to introduce the notion of "negative area".  See why!

title: Definite integral evaluation
translated_description: Sal finds the definite integral of (16-x³)/x³ between -1 and -2 using the reverse power rule.

title: Definite integral evaluation
translated_description: Sal finds the definite integral of 12∛x between -1 and 8 using the reverse power rule.

title: Definite integral evaluation
translated_description: Sal finds the definite integral of 9sin(x) between 11π/2 and 6π.

title: Definite integral evaluation
translated_description: Sal finds the definite integral of (6+x²)/x³ between 2 and 4. To do that  he has to use the integral of 1/x  which is ln(x).

title: Definite integral evaluation
translated_description: Sal evaluates definite integral of a piecewise function over an interval that goes through the two cases of the function.

title: Definite integral evaluation
translated_description: Sal evaluates the definite integral of f(x)=|x+2| between -4 and 0.

title: Integration techniques
translated_description: Using u-substitution to find the anti-derivative of a function. Seeing that u-substitution is the inverse of the chain rule.

title: Integration techniques
translated_description: Another example of using u-subsitution

title: Integration techniques
translated_description: Manipulating the expression to make u-substitution a little more obvious.

title: Integration techniques
translated_description: Doing u-substitution with ln(x)

title: Integration techniques
translated_description: Finding  ∫(2^ln x)/x dx

title: Integration techniques
translated_description: Using u-substitution and "back substituting" for x to simplify an expression

title: Integration techniques
translated_description: You can never get too much u-substitution practice

title: Integration techniques
translated_description: We do substitution two times to get the integral into a reasonable form

title: Integration techniques
translated_description: What is the "reverse chain rule"  and why it does the same thing as u-substitution.

title: Integration techniques
translated_description: Using the reverse chain for (x/2)sin(2x^2 + 2)

title: Integration techniques
translated_description: It might not look like it at first  but the reverse chain rule let's us find the integral of tan(x)

title: Area & arc length using calculus
translated_description: Based on the fundamental theorem of calculus  we can use antiderivatives to compute integrals.

title: Area & arc length using calculus
translated_description: By integrating the difference of two functions  you can find the area between them.

title: Area & arc length using calculus
translated_description: Here we go through a slightly more involved problem finding the area between different functions.

title: Area & arc length using calculus
translated_description: A non-rigorous justification of the arc length formula

title: Area & arc length using calculus
translated_description: A finely tuned example demonstrating how the arc length formula works.

title: Area & arc length using calculus
translated_description: More arc length practice.

title: Integration applications
translated_description: An example relating rates of change with a leaky bathtub.

title: Integration applications
translated_description: If you have a function representing rate  what does the area under its curve represent?

title: Integration applications
translated_description: What can you say about the velocity and position of a particle given its acceleration.

title: Integration applications
translated_description: Average value of a function over a closed interval

title: Integration applications
translated_description: Here we find the average value of x^2+1 on the interval between 0 and 3.

title: Integration applications
translated_description: As an example of finding a mean value  we find an average acceleration.

title: Integration applications
translated_description: Here Sal goes through the connection between the mean value theorem and integration.

title: Volume using calculus
translated_description: The volume of a solid with semi-circular cross sections and a triangular base.

title: Volume using calculus
translated_description: This time  the cross section of our solid is given as the area between two curves.

title: Volume using calculus
translated_description: Finding the solid of revolution (constructed by revolving around the x-axis) using the disk method.

title: Volume using calculus
translated_description: Generalizing what we did in the last video for f(x) to get the "formula" for using the disk method around the x-axis

title: Volume using calculus
translated_description: Finding the volume of a figure that is rotated around the y-axis using the disk method

title: Volume using calculus
translated_description: Solid of revolution constructing by rotating around line that is not an axis

title: Volume using calculus
translated_description: Volume of solid created by rotating around vertical line that is not the y-axis using the disk method.

title: Volume using calculus
translated_description: Calculate the integral from the last video.

title: Volume using calculus
translated_description: Finding the volume of a solid of revolution that is defined between two functions

title: Volume using calculus
translated_description: Looking at the example from the last video in a more generalized way

title: Volume using calculus
translated_description: Washer method when rotating around a horizontal line that is not the x-axis

title: Volume using calculus
translated_description: Doing some hairy algebra and arithmetic to evaluate the definite integral from the last video

title: Volume using calculus
translated_description: Setting up the definite integral for the volume of a solid of revolution around a vertical line using the "washer" or "ring" method.

title: Volume using calculus
translated_description: Evaluating the integral set up in the last video using washer method.

title: Volume using calculus
translated_description: Introducing the shell method for rotation around a vertical line.

title: Volume using calculus
translated_description: Evaluating the definite integral set up using the shell method

title: Volume using calculus
translated_description: Find the volume of a solid of revolution by rotating around the x-axis using the shell method

title: Volume using calculus
translated_description: Using the shell method to rotate around a vertical line.

title: Volume using calculus
translated_description: Evaluating integral set up with shell method for two functions.

title: Volume using calculus
translated_description: Stepping it up a notch  our solid is now defined in terms of two separate functions.

title: Differential equations
translated_description: Differential equations are equations that relate a function with one or more of its derivatives. This means their solution is a function! Learn more in this video.

title: Differential equations
translated_description: If a particular solution to a differential equation is linear  y=mx+b  we can set up a system of equations to find m and b. See how it works in this video.

title: Differential equations
translated_description: Differential equations describe relationships that involve quantities and their rates of change. See how we write the equation for such a relationship.

title: Differential equations
translated_description: Slope fields allow us to analyze differential equations graphically. Learn how to draw them and use them to find particular solutions.

title: Differential equations
translated_description: Given a slope field and a few differential equations  we can determine which equation corresponds to the slope field by considering specific slopes.

title: Differential equations
translated_description: Given a differential equation in x and y  we can draw a segment with dy/dx as slope at any point (x y). That's the slope field of the equation. See how we match an equation to its slope field by considering the various slopes in the diagram.

title: Differential equations
translated_description: Given a differential equation in x and y  we can draw a segment with dy/dx as slope at any point (x y). That's the slope field of the equation. See how we determine the slopes of a few segments in the slope field of an equation.

title: Differential equations
translated_description: Given the slope field of a differential equation  we can sketch various solutions to the equation.

title: Differential equations
translated_description: Given the slope field of a differential equation  we can sketch various solutions to the equation. In this example  we analyze the range of a specific solution.

title: Differential equations
translated_description: Separation of variables allows us to rewrite differential equations so we obtain an equality between two integrals we can evaluate. Separable equations are the class of differential equations that can be solved using this method.

title: Differential equations
translated_description: Addressing treating differentials algebraically

title: Differential equations
translated_description: Separable equations can be written in the form dy/dx=f(x)g(y). See how we analyze various differential equations to see if they are separable.

title: Differential equations
translated_description: Solving a separable differential equation given initial conditions. In this video  the equation is dy/dx=2y² with y(1)=1.

title: Differential equations
translated_description: Sometimes the solution of a separable differential equation can't be written as an explicit function. This doesn't mean we can't use it!

title: Differential equations
translated_description: Assuming a quantity grows proportionally to its size results in the general equation dy/dx=ky. Solving it with separation of variables results in the general exponential function y=Ceᵏˣ.

title: Differential equations
translated_description: Given the general solution P=Ceᵏᵗ and the conditions P(0)=100 and P(50)=200  we find the solution to an exponential modeling problem.

title: Differential equations
translated_description: The solution of the general differential equation dy/dx=ky (for some k) is C⋅eᵏˣ (for some C). See how this is derived and used for finding a particular solution to a differential equation.

title: Differential equations
translated_description: Newton's law of cooling can be modeled with the general equation dT/dt=-k(T-Tₐ)  whose solutions are T=Ce⁻ᵏᵗ+Tₐ (for cooling) and T=Tₐ-Ce⁻ᵏᵗ (for heating).

title: Differential equations
translated_description: The general function for Newton's law of cooling is T=Ce⁻ᵏᵗ+Tₐ. In this video  we solve a word problem that involves the cooling of a freshly baked cookie!

title: AP Calculus AB questions
translated_description: AP Calculus lead  Ben Hedrick  talks about the design and tips for the AP Calculus exams.

translated_description: Water in a pipe

translated_description: Minimum water in the pipe

translated_description: When the pipe overflows

translated_description: Areas between curves

translated_description: Volume of solid

translated_description: Rate of change of difference between functions

translated_description: Estimating acceleration

translated_description: Riemann sum to estimate distance

translated_description: Accelerations and average velocity from velocity function

translated_description: Slope field for differential equation

translated_description: Solutions for the differential equation

translated_description: Maxima for f from graph of f'

translated_description: Intervals where f is concave downwards and decreasing.

translated_description: Inflection points for a function

translated_description: Constructing expression for f with integral.

title: AP Calculus AB questions
translated_description: Equation for tangent line

translated_description: Point on curve where tangent is vertical

translated_description: Finding second derivative through implicit differentiation

title: AP Calculus AB questions
translated_description: Determining whether speed is increasing. Difference between speed and acceleration

title: AP Calculus AB questions
translated_description: Integration to find average value of a function.  Using a graphing calculator to calculate definite integrals.

title: AP Calculus AB questions
translated_description: Approximating rate of change and total area under a curve.  Trapezoidal sums to approximate integrals

title: AP Calculus AB questions
translated_description: Second fundamental theorem of calculus application

title: AP Calculus AB questions
translated_description: Equation of a tangent line and area between curves

title: AP Calculus AB questions
translated_description: Disk method to find the volume of a solid generated by rotation of a function

title: AP Calculus AB questions
translated_description: Taking derivatives and integrals of strangely defined functions

title: AP Calculus AB questions
translated_description: Absolute maximum over an interval.  Critical points and differentiability.

title: AP Calculus AB questions
translated_description: Finding the points of inflection for a strangely defined function

title: AP Calculus AB questions
translated_description: Mean Value Theorem and differentiability

title: AP Calculus AB questions
translated_description: Using a tangent line to extrapolate a function from a known initial condition

title: AP Calculus AB questions
translated_description: Using the second derivative to judge whether an approximation with the tangent line is an overestimate or underestimate

title: AP Calculus AB questions
translated_description: Solving a differential equation using separation of variables

title: AP Calculus AB questions
translated_description: Continuity of piecewise-defined functions

title: AP Calculus AB questions
translated_description: Derivative of a piecewise-defined function

title: AP Calculus AB questions
translated_description: Average value of a piecewise-defined function on an interval

title: Limits basics
translated_description: Why we study differential calculus.

title: Limits basics
translated_description: A limit tells us the value that a function approaches as that function’s inputs get closer and closer to some number. The idea of a limit is the basis of all calculus.

title: Limits basics
translated_description: Sal finds the limit of 3sin(5x)/sin(2x) at x=0 using a table of values.

title: Limits basics
translated_description: Sal finds the limit of a function given its graph. The function isn't defined at the limiting value but that doesn't mean the limit doesn't exist!

title: Limits basics
translated_description: Sal finds the limit of a function given its graph. The function's value at the limit is different from the limit's value  but that doesn't mean the limit doesn't exist!

title: Limits basics
translated_description: Sal finds the limit of a function given its graph. The function has an asymptote at the limiting value. This means the limit doesn't exist.

title: Limits basics
translated_description: A one-sided limit is the value the function approaches as the x-values approach the limit from *one side only*. For example  f(x)=|x|/x returns -1 for negative numbers  1 for positive numbers  and isn't defined for 0. The one-sided *right* limit of f at x=0 is 1  and the one-sided *left* limit at x=0 is -1.

title: Limits basics
translated_description: Sal analyzes the left-sided limit of a function given its graph. It turns out the function has an asymptote  so the limit doesn't exist.

title: Limits basics
translated_description: Sal finds the one-sided limit of x²/(1-cosx) as x approaches zero from the right  using a table of values.

title: Limits basics
translated_description: Sal explains the relationship between the 1-sided limits and the 2-sided limit of a function at a point  using a graphical example where the 1-sided limits exist but the 2-sided limit doesn't.

title: Limits basics
translated_description: Sal explains the relationship between the 1-sided limits and the 2-sided limit of a function at a point  using an algebraic example where the 1-sided limits exist but the 2-sided limit doesn't.

title: Limits basics
translated_description: Sal analyzes various 1- and 2-sided limits of a function given graphically.

title: Limits basics
translated_description: A quick reminder of what limits are  to set up for the formal definition of a limit.

title: Limits basics
translated_description: Some background intuition to make the formal definition of a limit make intuitive sense.

title: Limits basics
translated_description: The epsilon-delta defintion of limits says that the limit of f(x) at x=c is L if for any ε>0 there's a δ>0 such that if the distance of x from c is les than δ  then the distance of f(x) from L is less than ε. This is a formulation of the intuitive notion that we can get as close as we want to L.

title: Limits basics
translated_description: Watch the definition of a limit in action.

title: Continuity
translated_description: Sal introduces a formal definition of continuity at a point using limits.

title: Continuity
translated_description: Sal gives two examples where he analyzes the conditions for continuity at a point given a function's graph.

title: Continuity
translated_description: What is the limit of the sum of two functions?  What about the product?

title: Continuity
translated_description: Sal solves a few examples where the graphs of two functions are given and we're asked to find the limit of an expression that combines the two functions. For example  the limit at 0 of the product of the functions.

title: Continuity
translated_description: Sal solves a few examples where the graphs of two functions are given and we're asked to find the limit of a function that is a composition of the two functions.

title: Continuity
translated_description: Sal is asked which of the following two functions is continuous on all real numbers: eˣ and/or √x. In general  the common functions are continuous on all the numbers in their domain.

title: Continuity
translated_description: Sal is asked which of the following two functions is continuous at x=3: ln(x-3) and/or eˣ⁻³. In general  the common functions are continuous on all the numbers in their domain.

title: Continuity
translated_description: Introduction to the Intermediate value theorem. If f is a continuous function over [a b]  then it takes on every value between f(a) and f(b) over that interval.

title: Continuity
translated_description: Given that a continuous function f obtains f(-2)=3 and f(1)=6  Sal picks the statement that is guaranteed by the Intermediate value theorem.

title: Limits from equations
translated_description: Sal explains how you can easily find limits of functions at points where the functions are continuous: simply plug in the x-value into the function! Later we will learn how to find limits even when the function isn't continuous.

title: Limits from equations
translated_description: Sal gives an example of a limit where direct substitution ends in a quotient with 0 in the denominator and non-0 in the numerator. Such limits are undefined. What about limits where substitution ends in 0/0? Keep going and you'll see!

title: Limits from equations
translated_description: Sal finds the limit of (x²+x-6)/(x-2) at x=2 by factoring and simplifying the expression.

title: Limits from equations
translated_description: Sal finds the limits of (x+1)/(√(x+5)-2) by "rationalizing the denominator" of the expression.

title: Limits from equations
translated_description: The squeeze (or sandwich) theorem states that if f(x)≤g(x)≤h(x) for all numbers  and at some point x=k we have f(k)=h(k)  then g(k) must also be equal to them. We can use the theorem to find tricky limits like sin(x)/x at x=0  by "squeezing" sin(x)/x between two nicer functions and ​using them to find the limit at x=0.

title: Limits from equations
translated_description: An example applying the squeeze theorem.

title: Limits from equations
translated_description: Using the squeeze theorem to prove that the limit as x approaches 0 of (sin x)/x =1

title: Limits from equations
translated_description: Sal finds the limit at θ=0 of (1-cosθ)/(2sin²θ) by rewriting the expression using the Pythagorean identity.

title: Limits from equations
translated_description: Sal finds the limit at θ=-π/4 of (1+√2sinθ)/(cos2θ) by rewriting the expression using the cosine double angle identity.

title: Limits from equations
translated_description: Sal finds the limit of a piecewise function at the point between two different cases of the function. In this case  the two one-sided limits are equal  so the limit exists.

title: Limits from equations
translated_description: Sal finds the limit of a piecewise function at the point between two different cases of the function. In this case  the two one-sided limits aren't equal  so the limit doesn't exist.

title: Limits from equations
translated_description: Sal finds the value the function f(x)=(6x²+18x+12)/(x²-4) should have at x=-2 so it's continuous at that point.

title: Limits from equations
translated_description: Sal finds the value the function f(x)=(√(x+4)-3)/(x-5) should have at x=5 so it's continuous at that point.

title: Infinite limits
translated_description: Here we consider the limit of the function f(x)=1/x as x approaches 0  and as x approaches infinity.

title: Infinite limits
translated_description: Sal analyzes a function with an asymptote and finds the correct description of the two one-sided limits of the function at that asymptote.

title: Infinite limits
translated_description: Sal analyzes the behavior of f(x)=-1/(x-1)² around its asymptote at x=1.

title: Infinite limits
translated_description: Sal analyzes the behavior of f(x)=x/[1-cos(x-2)] around its asymptote at x=2.

title: Infinite limits
translated_description: Here we consider the limit of the function f(x)=1/x as x approaches 0  and as x approaches infinity.

title: Infinite limits
translated_description: Sal analyzes the limits at infinity of three different rational functions. He finds there are three general cases of how the limits behave.

title: Infinite limits
translated_description: Sal finds the limits at positive and negative infinity of (4x⁵-3x²+3)/(6x⁵-100x²-10).

title: Infinite limits
translated_description: Sal finds the limits at positive and negative infinity of x/√(x²+1). Since the leading term is raised to an odd power (1)  the limits at positive and negative infinity are different.

title: Infinite limits
translated_description: Limit at infinity of rational expression with radical

title: Infinite limits
translated_description: Sal finds the limit of cosx/(x²-1) at infinity  by putting it between two limits of rational functions  1/(x²-1) and -1/(x²-1).

title: Infinite limits
translated_description: Sal analyzes the limit of (x²+1)/sin(x) at infinity. It turns out this limit doesn't exist  as the function keeps oscillating between positive and negative infinity.

title: Infinite limits
translated_description: Sal finds the limit at infinity of √(100+x)-√(x).

title: Derivative introduction
translated_description: Why we study differential calculus.

title: Derivative introduction
translated_description: Sal solves a couple of problems where he interprets the derivative of a function at a point as the slope of the curve  or of the line tangent to the curve  at that point.

title: Derivative introduction
translated_description: Sal analyzes various graphs to find intervals where the derivative of the graphed function is positive or negative.

title: Derivative introduction
translated_description: Sal solves a couple of problems where the key to the solution is using the derivative of a function at a point as the slope of the line tangent to the function's graph at that point.

title: Derivative introduction
translated_description: Given that f(-2)=3 and f'(x)≤7  Sal finds the largest possible value of f(10).

title: Derivative introduction
translated_description: Sal finds the average rate of change of a curve over several intervals  and uses one of them to approximate the slope of a line tangent to the curve.

title: Derivative introduction
translated_description: Sal approximates the instantaneous rate of change of stores per year in a popular coffee chain.

title: Derivative introduction
translated_description: Sal approximates the instantaneous velocity of a motorcyclist.

title: Derivative introduction
translated_description: What is the slope of a line between two points on a curve?  This is called a "secant" line.

title: Derivative introduction
translated_description: Sal finds the slope of the secant line on the graph of ln(x) between the points (2 ln2) and (2+h ln(2+h)).

title: Derivative introduction
translated_description: Sal finds the slope of the secant line on the graph of ln(x) between the points (e 1) and (x lnx).

title: Derivative introduction
translated_description: Sal finds and simplifies the expression for the slope of the secant line between x=4 and x=4+h on the graph of y=2x²+1.

title: Derivative introduction
translated_description: Sal finds and simplifies the expression for the slope of the secant line between x=3 and x=t on the graph of y=2x²+5x.

title: Derivative introduction
translated_description: Sal solves a challenging problem involving slopes of secant lines to a curve.

title: Derivative introduction
translated_description: Sal interprets an expression as the slope of a secant line between a specific point on a graph and any other point on that graph.

title: Derivative introduction
translated_description: Sal arrives at a formal definition for the derivative by considering it as a limit of the slopes of secant lines that approach a tangent line.

title: Derivative introduction
translated_description: Sal relates the derivative of a function and the average rate of change of the function over intervals that become infinitely small.

title: Derivative introduction
translated_description: Sal introduces two ways of writing the limit expression for the derivative of a function at a point.

title: Derivative introduction
translated_description: Enough abstract stuff already  let's see what the formal and alternative forms of the derivative look like in practice.

title: Derivative introduction
translated_description: Sal interprets a limit expression to find that it describes the derivative of f(x)=x³ at the point x=5.

title: Derivative introduction
translated_description: Sal finds the limit expression for the derivative of f(x)=x² at the point x=3 and evaluates it.

title: Derivative introduction
translated_description: Sal finds the limit expression for the derivative of f(x)=x² at any point x and simplifies it into a simpler expression (spoiler: it's 2x).

title: Derivative introduction
translated_description: Sal interprets a limit expression as the derivative of a linear function at a point  and evaluates it.

title: Derivative introduction
translated_description: Sal interprets a limit expression as the derivative of cos(x) at x=π  and evaluates it.

title: Derivative introduction
translated_description: Sal interprets limit expressions as the derivatives of a function given graphically  and evaluates them.

title: Derivative introduction
translated_description: Sal gives a couple of examples where he finds the points on the graphs of a functions where the functions aren't differentiable.

title: Derivative introduction
translated_description: Sal analyzes a piecewise function to see if it's differentiable or continuous at the edge point. In this case  the function is both continuous and differentiable.

title: Derivative introduction
translated_description: Sal analyzes a piecewise function to see if it's differentiable or continuous at the edge point. In this case  the function is continuous but not differentiable.

title: Derivative introduction
translated_description: Given the graph of a function  Sal sketches the graph of its derivative.

title: Derivative introduction
translated_description: Given the graph of a function  Sal sketches the graph of its antiderivative. In other words  he sketches the graph of the function whose derivative is the given function.

title: Derivative introduction
translated_description: Given the graph of a function  we are asked to recognize the graph of its derivative.

title: Derivative introduction
translated_description: More practice with the relationship between the graph of a function and the graph of its derivative.

title: Basic differentiation
translated_description: Sal introduces the Constant rule  which says that the derivative of f(x)=k (for any constant k) is f'(x)=0. He also justifies this rule algebraically.

title: Basic differentiation
translated_description: Constant multiple rule says that the derivative of f(x)=kg(x) is f'(x)=kg'(x). Sum/Difference rule says that the derivative of f(x)=g(x)±h(x) is f'(x)=g'(x)±h'(x). Sal introduces and justifies these rules.

title: Basic differentiation
translated_description: Sal analyzes two attempts of students to differentiate linear functions.

title: Basic differentiation
translated_description: Given some values of the derivative of a function f  and the full definition of another function g  find the derivative of 3f(x)+2g(x)

title: Basic differentiation
translated_description: Sal introduces the power rule  which tells us how to find the derivative of xⁿ.

title: Basic differentiation
translated_description: Before actually proving the power rule  Sal shows why the power rule makes sense by considering the derivatives of x¹ and x².

title: Basic differentiation
translated_description: Here Sal prooves the formula for the derivative of x^n using the binomial theorem.

title: Basic differentiation
translated_description: Sal gives a proof of the power rule for the specific case where n=½ (i.e. for the derivative of √x).

title: Basic differentiation
translated_description: Once you know how to take the derivative of x^n  it turns out you can take the derivative of any polynomial.  Let's see why...

title: Basic differentiation
translated_description: Sal differentiates f(x)=x⁵+2x³-x²  and evaluates the derivative at x=2.

title: Basic differentiation
translated_description: Sal finds the equation of the line tangent to the graph of f(x)=x³-6x²+x-5 at x=1.

title: Basic differentiation
translated_description: Sal differentiates g(x)=2/(x³)-1/(x²)  and evaluates the derivative at x=2. This can actually be done quite easily using the Power rule!

title: Basic differentiation
translated_description: A practice problem for finding the y-intercept of a tangent line to f(x) = 1/x

title: Basic differentiation
translated_description: Sal differentiates h(x)=5x^¼+7  and evaluates the derivative at x=16. This can actually be done quite easily using the Power rule!

title: Basic differentiation
translated_description: Sal differentiates f(x)=-4∛x  and evaluates the derivative at x=8. This can actually be done quite easily using the Power rule!

title: Basic differentiation
translated_description: Learn the derivatives of several common functions.

title: Basic differentiation
translated_description: Sal differentiates g(x)=7sin(x)-3cos(x)-(π/∛x)². This can be done using the derivatives of sine and cosine  and the Power rule.

title: Basic differentiation
translated_description: Learn the derivatives of several common functions.

title: Product quotient & chain rules
translated_description: Sal differentiates x²sin(x) using the product rule.

title: Product quotient & chain rules
translated_description: Sal differentiates eˣcos(x) using the product rule.

title: Product quotient & chain rules
translated_description: Given the values of f and h (and their derivatives) at x=3  Sal evaluates the derivative of f(x)⋅h(x) at x=3.

title: Product quotient & chain rules
translated_description: Given the values of f and f' at x=-1 and that g(x)=1/x  Sal evaluates the derivative of F(x)=f(x)⋅g(x) at x=-1.

title: Product quotient & chain rules
translated_description: Sal differentiates the product of three different functions  and generalizes for the derivative of the product of any number of functions.

title: Product quotient & chain rules
translated_description: Why does the product rule work?

title: Product quotient & chain rules
translated_description: The chain rule states that the derivative of f(g(x)) is f'(g(x))⋅g'(x). In other words  it helps us differentiate *composite functions*. For example  sin(x²) is a composite function because it can be constructed as f(g(x)) for f(x)=sin(x) and g(x)=x². Using the chain rule and the derivatives of sin(x) and x²  we can then find the derivative of sin(x²).

title: Product quotient & chain rules
translated_description: Sal differentiates the composite function f(x)=cos³x using the chain rule.

title: Product quotient & chain rules
translated_description: Sal differentiates the composite function f(x)=ln(√x) using the chain rule.

title: Product quotient & chain rules
translated_description: Sal differentiates the composite function f(x)=√(3x²-x) using the chain rule.

title: Product quotient & chain rules
translated_description: Given the values of f and g (and their derivatives) at some x-values  Sal evaluates the derivative of F(x)=f(g(x)) at a specific x-value.

title: Product quotient & chain rules
translated_description: Sal shows that if a function is differentiable at a point  it is also continuous at that point.

title: Product quotient & chain rules
translated_description: Sal shows that if a function is continuous  the difference in the function's values approaches 0 as the difference in the x-values approaches 0. This is simply another way to define continuity.

title: Product quotient & chain rules
translated_description: Here we use the formal properties of continuity and differentiability to see why the chain rule is true.

title: Product quotient & chain rules
translated_description: Sal shows how you can derive the quotient rule using the product rule and the chain rule (one less rule to memorize!)

title: Product quotient & chain rules
translated_description: Given the values of f and f' at x=-1 and that g(x)=2x³  Sal evaluates the derivative of F(x)=f(x)/g(x) at x=-1.

title: Product quotient & chain rules
translated_description: Sal finds the equation of the line tangent to the curve y=eˣ/(2+x³) at the point (1 e/3).

title: Product quotient & chain rules
translated_description: Sal finds the equation of the line normal to the curve y=eˣ/x² at the point (1 e).

title: Differentiating common functions
translated_description: Sal differentiates the rational function (5-3x)/(x²+3x). This function (and any other rational function) can be differentiated using the Quotient rule!

title: Differentiating common functions
translated_description: Sal differentiates ∜(x³+4x²+7) and evaluates the derivative at x=-3.

title: Differentiating common functions
translated_description: Sal finds the derivatives of tan(x) and cot(x) by writing them as quotients of sin(x) and cos(x) and using quotient rule.

title: Differentiating common functions
translated_description: Sal finds the derivatives of sec(x) and csc(x) by writing them as 1/sin(x) or 1/cos(x) and using quotient rule.

title: Differentiating common functions
translated_description: Sal differentiates sec(3π/2-x) and evaluates the derivative at x=π/4.

title: Differentiating common functions
translated_description: Learn the derivatives of several common functions.

title: Differentiating common functions
translated_description: Sal finds the derivative of aˣ (for any positive base a) using the derivative of eˣ and the chain rule. He then differentiates 8⋅3ˣ.

title: Differentiating common functions
translated_description: Sal differentiates the exponential function 7^(x²-x) using our knowledge of the derivative of aˣ and the chain rule.

title: Differentiating common functions
translated_description: Learn the derivatives of several common functions.

title: Differentiating common functions
translated_description: Sal finds the derivative of logₐx (for any positive base a≠1) using the derivative of ln(x) and the logarithm change of base rule. He then differentiates log₇x and -3log_π(x).

title: Differentiating common functions
translated_description: Sal differentiates the logarithmic function log₄(x²+x) using our knowledge of the derivative of logₐ(x) and the chain rule.

title: Differentiating common functions
translated_description: By exploiting our knowledge of logarithms  we can make certain derivatives much smoother to compute.

title: Differentiating common functions
translated_description: Sal differentiates eᶜᵒˢˣ⋅cos(eˣ) by applying both the product rule and the chain rule.

title: Differentiating common functions
translated_description: Sal differentiates sin(ln(x²)) by applying the chain rule twice.

title: Advanced differentiation
translated_description: Some relationships cannot be represented by an explicit function. For example  x²+y²=1. Implicit differentiation helps us find ​dy/dx even for relationships like that. This is done using the chain ​rule  and viewing y as an implicit function of x. For example  according to the chain rule  the derivative of y² would be 2y⋅(dy/dx).

title: Advanced differentiation
translated_description: Implicit differentiation of (x-y)²=x+y-1

title: Advanced differentiation
translated_description: Sal finds the slope of the tangent line to the curve x²+(y-x)³=28 at x=1 using implicit differentiation.

title: Advanced differentiation
translated_description: Sal gives an example of how implicit differentiation results in the same derivative expression as direct differentiation.

title: Advanced differentiation
translated_description: Implicit differentiation of y = cos(5x - 3y)

title: Advanced differentiation
translated_description: Implicit derivative of (x²+y²)³=5x²y².

title: Advanced differentiation
translated_description: Sal finds dy/dx for e^(xy²)=x-y using implicit differentiation.

title: Advanced differentiation
translated_description: How can you find the derivative of ln(x) by viewing it as the inverse of e^x?

title: Advanced differentiation
translated_description: Derivative of inverse sine

title: Advanced differentiation
translated_description: Derivative of inverse cosine.

title: Advanced differentiation
translated_description: More inverses!  Inverse of tangent this time.

title: Advanced differentiation
translated_description: Given that f(x)=½x³+3x-4  Sal evaluates the derivative of the inverse of f at x=-14.

title: Advanced differentiation
translated_description: Given a table of values of g  its inverse h  and its derivative g'  Sal evaluates the derivative of the inverse  h'  at a given x-value.

title: Advanced differentiation
translated_description: Sal interprets an elaborate limit expression as 5 times the derivative of log(x) at x=2. This way  he can evaluate the limit using differentiation rules instead of directly analyzing the limit (which is hard!).

title: Advanced differentiation
translated_description: Taking the derivative of ln x

title: Advanced differentiation
translated_description: Proof that the derivative of eˣ is eˣ.

title: Advanced differentiation
translated_description: Doing both proofs in the same video to clarify any misconceptions that the original proof was "circular".

title: Advanced differentiation
translated_description: Sal finds the derivatives of xˣ and x^(xˣ). They are surprisingly fun to do!

title: Advanced differentiation
translated_description: Sal differentiates the composite exponential function [ln(x)]ˣ and evaluates the derivative at x=e. Composite exponential functions are functions where the variable is in both the base and the exponent.

title: Advanced differentiation
translated_description: Using a position vector valued function to describe a curve or path

title: Advanced differentiation
translated_description: Visualizing the derivative of a position vector valued function

title: Advanced differentiation
translated_description: Sal finds the derivative of the function defined by the parametric equations x=sin(1+3t) and y=2t³  and evaluates it at t=-⅓.

title: Advanced differentiation
translated_description: Sal finds the second derivative of y=6/x². Second derivative is the derivative of the derivative of y.

title: Advanced differentiation
translated_description: Sal finds the first and the second derivatives of the vector-valued function h(t)=(-t⁵-6 4t⁴+2t+1).

title: Advanced differentiation
translated_description: Sal finds the second derivative of the function defined by the parametric equations x=3e²ᵗ and y=3³ᵗ-1.

title: Analyzing functions with calculus
translated_description: Sal explains all about minimum and maximum points  both absolute and relative.

title: Analyzing functions with calculus
translated_description: Sal analyzes graphs of functions to find relative extremum points.

title: Analyzing functions with calculus
translated_description: Sal introduces the "critical points" of a function and discusses their relationship with the extremum points of the function.

title: Analyzing functions with calculus
translated_description: Sal finds the critical points of f(x)=xe^(-2x²).

title: Analyzing functions with calculus
translated_description: Sal finds the intervals where the function f(x)=x⁶-3x⁵ is decreasing by finding where f' is negative.

title: Analyzing functions with calculus
translated_description: Sal is given that the derivative of function g  is g'(x)=x²/(x-2)³. He uses that to find the intervals where g is increasing  by looking for the intervals where g' is positive.

title: Analyzing functions with calculus
translated_description: Once you find a critical point  how can you tell if it is a minimum  maximum or neither?

title: Analyzing functions with calculus
translated_description: Sal finds the extremum points of f(x)=x³-12x+2.

title: Analyzing functions with calculus
translated_description: Sal finds the relative maximum point of g(x)=x⁴-x⁵ by analyzing the intervals where its derivative  g'  is negative or positive.

title: Analyzing functions with calculus
translated_description: The Extreme Value Theorem states that if a function in continuous on a closed interval [a b]  then the function must have a maximum and a minimum on the interval. This makes sense: when a function is continuous you can draw its graph without lifting the pencil  so you must hit a high point and a low point on that interval.

title: Analyzing functions with calculus
translated_description: Sal finds the absolute maximum value of f(x)=8ln(x)-x² over the interval [1 4].

title: Analyzing functions with calculus
translated_description: Sal analyzes the absolute minimum and maximum points of g(x)=x²ln(x) over its entire domain.

title: Analyzing functions with calculus
translated_description: Sal introduces the concept of concavity  what it means for a graph to be "concave up" or "concave down " and how this relates to the second derivative of a function.

title: Analyzing functions with calculus
translated_description: Sal walks through an exercise where you are asked to recognize the concavity of a function in certain regions.

title: Analyzing functions with calculus
translated_description: Sal finds the intervals where g(x)=-x⁴+6x²-2x-3 is concave down/up by finding where its second derivative  g''  is positive/negative.

title: Analyzing functions with calculus
translated_description: Sal justifies the second derivative test  which is a way of determining relative minima & maxima  and gives an example.

title: Analyzing functions with calculus
translated_description: Inflection points are points where the function changes concavity  i.e. from being "concave up" to being "concave down" or vice versa. They can be found by considering where the second derivative changes signs. In similar to critical points in the first derivative  inflection points will occur when the second derivative is either zero or undefined.

title: Analyzing functions with calculus
translated_description: Sal analyzes the graph of a function g to find all the inflection points of g.

title: Analyzing functions with calculus
translated_description: Sal analyzes the graph of a the derivative g' of function g to find all the inflection points of g.

title: Analyzing functions with calculus
translated_description: Sal analyzes the points of inflection of g(x)=¼x⁴-4x³+24x² by looking for values where the second derivative g'' changes signs.

title: Analyzing functions with calculus
translated_description: Sal sketches a graph of f(x)=3x⁴-4x³+2 including extremum and inflection points.

title: Analyzing functions with calculus
translated_description: Sal sketches a graph of f(x)=ln(x⁴+27) including extremum and inflection points.

title: Derivative applications
translated_description: Sal introduces the idea of approximating curves using their tangent line equations. This is also called "local linearization."

title: Derivative applications
translated_description: Sal finds a linear expression that approximates y=1/(x-1) around x=-1. This is done by finding the equation of the line tangent to the graph at x=-1  a process called "linear approximation."

title: Derivative applications
translated_description: The position of a particle moving along the x-axis is given by s(t)=t³-6t²+9t. Sal analyzes it to find the times when the particle is "speeding up."

title: Derivative applications
translated_description: The speed of a particle moving along the x-axis is given by v(t)=-t³+6t²+2t. Sal analyzes it to find the time when the particle's acceleration attains its maximum value.

title: Derivative applications
translated_description: Learn how to analyze a particles motion given the graph of its position over time.

title: Derivative applications
translated_description: Given a function representing the position of a function over time  how can you find the total distance traveled?

title: Derivative applications
translated_description: The position of a particle moving in the xy-plane is given by the position vector (-3t³+4t² t³+2). Sal analyzes it to find the acceleration vector of the particle at time t=3.

title: Derivative applications
translated_description: Given that a particle moves along the implicit curve x²y²=16 and given its rate of change with respect to x at some point  Sal finds the particle's rate of change with respect to y using implicit differentiation.

title: Derivative applications
translated_description: Given that a particle moves along the implicit curve xy=16 and given its rate of change with respect to y at some point  Sal finds the magnitude of the particle's velocity vector using implicit differentiation.

title: Derivative applications
translated_description: What's the relationship between how fast a circle's radius changes  and how fast its area changes?

title: Derivative applications
translated_description: As two cars approach the same intersection from different roads  how does the rate of change of the distance between them change?

title: Derivative applications
translated_description: You're on a ladder.  The bottom of the ladder starts slipping away from the wall.  Amidst your fright  you realize this would make a great related rates problem...
