title: Derivative applications
translated_description: As you pour water into a cone  how does the rate of change of the depth of the water relate to the rate of change in volume.

title: Derivative applications
translated_description: Sal solves a related rates problem about the shadow an owl casts as it's hunting a mouse.

title: Derivative applications
translated_description: In this example  you are analyzing the rate of change of a balloon's altitude based on the angle you have to crane your neck to look at it.

title: Derivative applications
translated_description: What is the minimum possible value of x^2+y^2 given that their product has to be fixed at xy = -16

title: Derivative applications
translated_description: If you are making a box out of a flat piece of cardboard  how do you maximize the volume of that box?

title: Derivative applications
translated_description: Finishing up the last video by working through the formulas.

title: Derivative applications
translated_description: Who knows  you may end up running a shoe factory one day.  So it might not be a bad idea to know how to maximize profits.

title: Derivative applications
translated_description: With all the storage you might have to handle for your shoe factory  I bet you'd also like to be able to minize the cost of storage.

title: Derivative applications
translated_description: Sal constructs an equilateral triangle & a square whose bases are 100m together  such that their area is the smallest possible.

title: Derivative applications
translated_description: Sal constructs an equilateral triangle & a square whose bases are 100m together  such that their area is the smallest possible.

title: Derivative applications
translated_description: A difficult but interesting derivative word problem

title: Derivative applications
translated_description: Let's face it  sometimes it feels like we forget much of what we learn.  In this example we model that forgetful phenomenon.

title: Derivative applications
translated_description: Sal solves a problem involving the modeling of cost with a function  which means the function's derivative models the marginal cost.

title: Derivative applications
translated_description: In economics  the idea of marginal cost can be nicely captured with the derivative.

title: Derivative applications
translated_description: The Mean Value Theorem states that if a function f is continuous on the closed interval [a b] and differentiable on the open interval (a b)  then there exists a point c in the interval (a b) such that f'(c) is equal to the function's average rate of change over [a b]. In other words  the graph has a tangent somewhere in (a b) that is parallel to the secant line over [a b].

title: Derivative applications
translated_description: Sal finds the number that satisfies the Mean value theorem for f(x)=x²-6x+8 over the interval [2 5].

title: Derivative applications
translated_description: Sal finds the number that satisfies the Mean value theorem for f(x)=√(4x-3) over the interval [1 3].

title: Derivative applications
translated_description: Even if a cop never spots you while you are speeding  he can still infer when you must have been speeding...

title: Derivative applications
translated_description: When you are solving a limit  and get 0/0 or ∞/∞  L'Hôpital's rule is the tool you need.

title: Derivative applications
translated_description: Sal uses L'Hôpital's rule to find the limit at 0 of (2sinx-sin2x)/(x-sinx).

title: Derivative applications
translated_description: Sal uses L'Hôpital's rule to find the limit at 1 of x/(x-1)-1/lnx.

title: Derivative applications
translated_description: Sal uses L'Hôpital's rule to find the limit at infinity of (4x²-5x)/(1-3x²).

title: Derivative applications
translated_description: Sal uses L'Hôpital's rule to find the value of a in (√(4+a)-√(4-ax))/x so the expression's limit at 0 is ¾.

title: Derivative applications
translated_description: Sal uses L'Hôpital's rule to find the limit at 0 of (sinx)^(1/lnx).

title: Derivative applications
translated_description: This isn't a full proof of L'Hopital's rule  but it should give some intuition for why it works.

title: Indefinite integrals
translated_description: What's the opposite of a derivative?  It's something called the "indefinite integral".

title: Indefinite integrals
translated_description: Can you find a function whose derivative is x^n?

title: Indefinite integrals
translated_description: In this example  we find the antiderivative an expression which is not so simple.

title: Indefinite integrals
translated_description: Given the graph of a function  can you identify the graph of its antiderivative?

title: Indefinite integrals
translated_description: More practice identifying the graph of the antiderivative of a function.

title: Indefinite integrals
translated_description: What are the antiderivatives of sin(x)  cos(x) and e^x?

title: Indefinite integrals
translated_description: In differential ​calculus we learned that the derivative of ln(x) is 1/x. Integration goes the other way: the integral (or antiderivative) of 1/x should be a function whose derivative is 1/x. As we just saw  this is ln(x). However  if x is negative then ln(x) is undefined! The solution is quite simple: the antiderivative of 1/x is ln(|x|).

title: Indefinite integrals
translated_description: Sal finds f(-1) given that f'(x)=24/x³ and f(2)=12.

title: Indefinite integrals
translated_description: Sal finds f(0) given that f'(x)=5eˣ and f(7)=40+5e⁷.

title: Definite integrals introduction
translated_description: If you already know the area under a curve  you can use it to compute an integral.

title: Definite integrals introduction
translated_description: Sal uses a graph to explain why we can take a constant out of a definite integral.

title: Definite integrals introduction
translated_description: If you know the integrals of two functions  what is the integral of their sum?

title: Definite integrals introduction
translated_description: What happens when the bounds of your integral are the same?

title: Definite integrals introduction
translated_description: By subdividing the stretch of numbers where you are integrating  you can break up an integral.

title: Definite integrals introduction
translated_description: When you shift a function  what happens to its integral?

title: Definite integrals introduction
translated_description: What happens when you swap the bounds on an integral?

title: Definite integrals introduction
translated_description: Sal evaluates definite integrals of functions given their graphs. He does so using various properties of integrals.

title: Definite integrals introduction
translated_description: Given the definite integrals of f and g over a specific interval  Sal finds the definite integral (on that interval) of a combination of f and g.

title: Definite integrals introduction
translated_description: Sal evaluates definite integrals of functions given their graphs. He does so using various properties of integrals.

title: Definite integrals introduction
translated_description: Given the definite integral of f over two intervals  Sal finds the definite integral of f over another  related  interval.

title: Definite integrals introduction
translated_description: Watch how some integral properties can actually be used.

title: Riemann sums
translated_description: Approximating the area under a curve using some rectangles.  This is called a "Riemann sum".

title: Riemann sums
translated_description: Generalizing the technique of approximating area under a curve with rectangles.

title: Riemann sums
translated_description: Here we see how estimating the area under a curve representing velocity estimates distance traveled.

title: Riemann sums
translated_description: Here we express the approximation of the area under a curve in sigma notation.

title: Riemann sums
translated_description: When a function is negative  Riemann sums seem to treat it as having "negative area".

title: Riemann sums
translated_description: Estimating the area under a curve with trapazoids instead of rectangles can give a closer approximation.

title: Riemann sums
translated_description: Another example of trapazoidal approximation

title: Riemann sums
translated_description: The moment you've been waiting for.  Here we connect the idea of Riemann sums with integrals.

title: Riemann sums
translated_description: A good way to test your understanding of Riemann sums is to rank the values of various different sums.

title: Fundamental theorem of calculus
translated_description: Sal explains how to use a graph to evaluate a function defined by an integral.

title: Fundamental theorem of calculus
translated_description: Sal evaluates a function defined by the integral of a graphed function. In order to evaluate he must switch the sides of the interval.

title: Fundamental theorem of calculus
translated_description: Solving for where a function defined by an integral equals 0.

title: Fundamental theorem of calculus
translated_description: The fundamental theorem of calculus shows how  in some sense  integration is the opposite of differentiation.

title: Fundamental theorem of calculus
translated_description: See what the fundamental theorem of calculus looks like in action.

title: Fundamental theorem of calculus
translated_description: How do you apply the fundamental theorem of calculus when both integral bounds are a function of x.

title: Fundamental theorem of calculus
translated_description: See why this surpising result is true.

title: Fundamental theorem of calculus
translated_description: See what the fundamental theorem of calculus looks like in action.

title: Fundamental theorem of calculus
translated_description: Sometimes you need to swap the bounds of integration before applying the fundamental theorem of calculus.

title: Definite integral evaluation
translated_description: There are really two versions of the fundamental theorem of calculus  and we go through the connection here.

title: Definite integral evaluation
translated_description: Why should taking the integral of an derivative bring you back to the function where you started?

title: Definite integral evaluation
translated_description: Based on the fundamental theorem of calculus  we can use antiderivatives to compute integrals.

title: Definite integral evaluation
translated_description: With integrals  it can be helpful to introduce the notion of "negative area".  See why!

title: Definite integral evaluation
translated_description: Sal finds the definite integral of (16-x³)/x³ between -1 and -2 using the reverse power rule.

title: Definite integral evaluation
translated_description: Sal finds the definite integral of 12∛x between -1 and 8 using the reverse power rule.

title: Definite integral evaluation
translated_description: Sal finds the definite integral of 9sin(x) between 11π/2 and 6π.

title: Definite integral evaluation
translated_description: Sal finds the definite integral of (6+x²)/x³ between 2 and 4. To do that  he has to use the integral of 1/x  which is ln(x).

title: Definite integral evaluation
translated_description: Sal evaluates definite integral of a piecewise function over an interval that goes through the two cases of the function.

title: Definite integral evaluation
translated_description: Sal evaluates the definite integral of f(x)=|x+2| between -4 and 0.

title: Definite integral evaluation
translated_description: Improper integrals are definite integrals where one or both of the ​bounderies is at infinity  or where the integrand has a vertical asymptote in the interval of integration. As crazy as it may sound  we can actually calculate some improper integrals using some clever methods that involve limits.

title: Definite integral evaluation
translated_description: Infinite both ways!

title: Definite integral evaluation
translated_description: Sometimes the value of an infinite integral is  well  infinite.

title: Integration techniques
translated_description: By looking at the product rule for derivatives in reverse  we get a powerful integration tool.

title: Integration techniques
translated_description: Integral of x cos(x)

title: Integration techniques
translated_description: Integral of ln x

title: Integration techniques
translated_description: Integral of (x^2)(e^x)

title: Integration techniques
translated_description: Integral of (e^x)(cos(x))

title: Integration techniques
translated_description: A rather difficult integration by parts problem.

title: Integration techniques
translated_description: Using u-substitution to find the anti-derivative of a function. Seeing that u-substitution is the inverse of the chain rule.

title: Integration techniques
translated_description: Another example of using u-subsitution

title: Integration techniques
translated_description: Manipulating the expression to make u-substitution a little more obvious.

title: Integration techniques
translated_description: Doing u-substitution with ln(x)

title: Integration techniques
translated_description: Finding  ∫(2^ln x)/x dx

title: Integration techniques
translated_description: Using u-substitution and "back substituting" for x to simplify an expression

title: Integration techniques
translated_description: You can never get too much u-substitution practice

title: Integration techniques
translated_description: We do substitution two times to get the integral into a reasonable form

title: Integration techniques
translated_description: What is the "reverse chain rule"  and why it does the same thing as u-substitution.

title: Integration techniques
translated_description: Using the reverse chain for (x/2)sin(2x^2 + 2)

title: Integration techniques
translated_description: It might not look like it at first  but the reverse chain rule let's us find the integral of tan(x)

title: Integration techniques
translated_description: When you are integrating a function in the form of a fraction  it helps to find a way to break apart the expression.

title: Integration techniques
translated_description: Here we do polynomial long division to make an integral more computable.

title: Area & arc length using calculus
translated_description: By integrating the difference of two functions  you can find the area between them.

title: Area & arc length using calculus
translated_description: Here we go through a slightly more involved problem finding the area between different functions.

title: Area & arc length using calculus
translated_description: A non-rigorous justification of the arc length formula

title: Area & arc length using calculus
translated_description: A finely tuned example demonstrating how the arc length formula works.

title: Area & arc length using calculus
translated_description: More arc length practice.

title: Area & arc length using calculus
translated_description: Develop intuition for the area enclosed by polar graph formula

title: Area & arc length using calculus
translated_description: Area enclosed by cardioid

title: Area & arc length using calculus
translated_description: More practice with the area encloised by polar functions  this time with two graphs.

title: Area & arc length using calculus
translated_description: Here we walk through how to use a graphing calculator to compute the integral found in the last video.

title: Integration applications
translated_description: An example relating rates of change with a leaky bathtub.

title: Integration applications
translated_description: If you have a function representing rate  what does the area under its curve represent?

title: Integration applications
translated_description: What can you say about the velocity and position of a particle given its acceleration.

title: Integration applications
translated_description: Average value of a function over a closed interval

title: Integration applications
translated_description: Here we find the average value of x^2+1 on the interval between 0 and 3.

title: Integration applications
translated_description: As an example of finding a mean value  we find an average acceleration.

title: Integration applications
translated_description: Here Sal goes through the connection between the mean value theorem and integration.

title: Volume using calculus
translated_description: The volume of a solid with semi-circular cross sections and a triangular base.

title: Volume using calculus
translated_description: This time  the cross section of our solid is given as the area between two curves.

title: Volume using calculus
translated_description: Finding the solid of revolution (constructed by revolving around the x-axis) using the disk method.

title: Volume using calculus
translated_description: Generalizing what we did in the last video for f(x) to get the "formula" for using the disk method around the x-axis

title: Volume using calculus
translated_description: Finding the volume of a figure that is rotated around the y-axis using the disk method

title: Volume using calculus
translated_description: Solid of revolution constructing by rotating around line that is not an axis

title: Volume using calculus
translated_description: Volume of solid created by rotating around vertical line that is not the y-axis using the disk method.

title: Volume using calculus
translated_description: Calculate the integral from the last video.

title: Volume using calculus
translated_description: Finding the volume of a solid of revolution that is defined between two functions

title: Volume using calculus
translated_description: Looking at the example from the last video in a more generalized way

title: Volume using calculus
translated_description: Washer method when rotating around a horizontal line that is not the x-axis

title: Volume using calculus
translated_description: Doing some hairy algebra and arithmetic to evaluate the definite integral from the last video

title: Volume using calculus
translated_description: Setting up the definite integral for the volume of a solid of revolution around a vertical line using the "washer" or "ring" method.

title: Volume using calculus
translated_description: Evaluating the integral set up in the last video using washer method.

title: Volume using calculus
translated_description: Introducing the shell method for rotation around a vertical line.

title: Volume using calculus
translated_description: Evaluating the definite integral set up using the shell method

title: Volume using calculus
translated_description: Find the volume of a solid of revolution by rotating around the x-axis using the shell method

title: Volume using calculus
translated_description: Using the shell method to rotate around a vertical line.

title: Volume using calculus
translated_description: Evaluating integral set up with shell method for two functions.

title: Volume using calculus
translated_description: Stepping it up a notch  our solid is now defined in terms of two separate functions.

title: Sequences & series intro
translated_description: Sequences are ordered lists of numbers (called "terms")  like 2 5 8. Some sequences follow a specific pattern that can be used to extend them indefinitely. For example  2 5 8 follows the pattern "add 3 " and now we can continue the sequence. Sequences can have formulas that tell us how to find any term in the sequence. For example  2 5 8 ... can be represented by the formula 2+3(n-1).

title: Sequences & series intro
translated_description: Using the explicit formula of a sequence to find a couple of its terms.

title: Sequences & series intro
translated_description: Using the recursive formula of a sequence to find its fifth term.

title: Sequences & series intro
translated_description: In a geometric sequence  the ratio between consecutive terms is always the same. Learn more about Geometric sequences and see some examples.

title: Sequences & series intro
translated_description: Sal finds the next term in the geometric sequence -1/32  1/8  -1/2  2 ...

title: Sequences & series intro
translated_description: Sal finds the 5th term in the geometric sequence whose explicit formula is 3(-¼)^(i-1).

title: Sequences & series intro
translated_description: Sal finds the 4th term in the sequence whose recursive formula is a(1)=-⅛  a(i)=2a(i-1).

title: Sequences & series intro
translated_description: A sequence is "converging" if its terms approach a specific value as we progress through them to infinity. Get an intuitive sense of what that even means!

title: Sequences & series intro
translated_description: How can we tell if a sequence converges or diverges? See Sal in action  determining the convergence/divergence of several sequences.

title: Sequences & series intro
translated_description: A sequence is "converging" if its terms approach a specific value at infinity. This video is a more formal definition of what it means for a sequence to converge.

title: Sequences & series intro
translated_description: Applying the formal definition of the limit of a sequence to prove that a sequence converges.

title: Sequences & series intro
translated_description: Sigma  Σ  is the standard notation for writing long sums. Learn how it is used in this video.

title: Sequences & series intro
translated_description: Some sums are really long  but we can use sigma notation to write them in a shorthand way. See such an example here.

title: Sequences & series intro
translated_description: Usually  when writing a series in sigma notation  we start summing at n=1 or n=0. Sometimes though  we would like to start at n=2 or larger values. See an example here.

title: Sequences & series intro
translated_description: The sum of the first n terms in an arithmetic sequence is (n/2)⋅(a₁+aₙ). It is called the arithmetic series formula. Learn more about it here.

title: Sequences & series intro
translated_description: Sal evaluates the arithmetic series Σ(2k+50) for k=1 to 550. He does that using the arithmetic series formula (a₁+aₙ)*n/2.

title: Sequences & series intro
translated_description: Sal evaluates the arithmetic sum (-50)+(-44)+(-38)+...+2044. He does that by finding the number of terms and using the arithmetic series formula (a₁+aₙ)*n/2.

title: Sequences & series intro
translated_description: Sal evaluates the sum of the first 650 terms in the sequence defined recursively as {aᵢ=aᵢ₋₁+11  a₁=4}. He does that by finding the 650th term and using the arithmetic series formula (a₁+aₙ)*n/2.

title: Sequences & series intro
translated_description: A geometric series is the sum of the terms of a geometric sequence. Learn more about it here.

title: Sequences & series intro
translated_description: A geometric series is the sum of the terms of a geometric sequence. Learn about geometric series and how they can be written in general terms and using sigma notation.

title: Sequences & series intro
translated_description: Sal evaluates the geometric series Σ2(3ᵏ) for k=0 to 99 using the finite geometric series formula a(1-rⁿ)/(1-r).

title: Sequences & series intro
translated_description: Sal evaluates three geometric series (defined in various ways) using the finite geometric series formula a(1-rⁿ)/(1-r).

title: Sequences & series intro
translated_description: The finite geometric series formula is a(1-rⁿ)/(1-r). In this video  Sal gives a pretty neat justification as to why the formula works.

title: Sequences & series intro
translated_description: The partial sum of an infinite series as the sum of the first few terms (and hence it's only partial). This seemingly simple concept is very useful in thinking about infinite series.

title: Sequences & series intro
translated_description: The partial sum of a sequence gives as the sum of the first n terms in the sequence. If we know the formula for the partial sums of a sequence  we can find a formula for the nth term in the sequence.

title: Sequences & series intro
translated_description: The partial sum of a sequence gives as the sum of the first n terms in the sequence. If we know the formula for the partial sums of a sequence  we can find the value of any term in the sequence.

title: Sequences & series intro
translated_description: Infinite series are defined as the limit of the infinite sequence of partial sums. Since we already know how to work with limits of sequences  this definition is really useful.

title: Sequences & series intro
translated_description: Sal evaluates the infinite geometric series 8+8/3+8/9+... Because the common ratio's absolute value is less than 1  the series converges to a finite number.

title: Sequences & series intro
translated_description: Sal evaluates the infinite geometric series -0.5+1.5-4.5+... Because the common ratio's absolute value is greater than 1  the series doesn't converge.

title: Sequences & series intro
translated_description: Sal uses a clever algebraic manipulation to find an expression for the sum of an infinite geometric series.

title: Sequences & series intro
translated_description: Sal applies limits to the formula for the sum of a finite geometric series to get the sum of an infinite geometric series.

title: Sequences & series intro
translated_description: Watch Sal determine the total vertical distance a bouncing ball moves using an infinite geometric series.

title: Sequences & series intro
translated_description: See how we can write a repeating decimal as an infinite geometric series.

title: Series convergence & estimation
translated_description: If the terms of an infinite series don't approach zero  the series must diverge. Learn more about this test in this video.

title: Series convergence & estimation
translated_description: The integral test helps us determine a series convergence by comparing it to an improper integral  which is something we already know how to find. Learn how it works in this video.

title: Series convergence & estimation
translated_description: See how the integral test is put to use in determining whether a sequence converges or diverges.

title: Series convergence & estimation
translated_description: p-series are infinite sums Σ(1/xᵖ) for some positive p. In this video you will see examples of identifying whether a p-series converges or diverges.

title: Series convergence & estimation
translated_description: A p-series converges for p>1 and diverges for 0

title: Series convergence & estimation
translated_description: If every term in one series is less than the corresponding term in some convergent series  it must converge as well. This notion is at the basis of the direct convergence test. Learn more about it here.

title: Series convergence & estimation
translated_description: Using the direct comparison test to determine that the infinite sum of 1/(2ⁿ+n) converges by comparing it to the infinite sum 1/2ⁿ.

title: Series convergence & estimation
translated_description: In some cases where the direct comparison test is inconclusive  we can use the limit comparison test. Learn more about it here.

title: Series convergence & estimation
translated_description: To use the limit comparison test for a series S₁  we need to find another series S₂ that is similar in structure (so the infinite limit of S₁/S₂ is finite) and whose convergence is already determined. See a worked example of using the test in this video.

title: Series convergence & estimation
translated_description: Showing that the harmonic series 1 + ½ + ⅓ + ¼ + ... actually diverges  using the direct comparison test. This proof is famous for its clever use of algebraic manipulation!

title: Series convergence & estimation
translated_description: The ratio test is a most useful test for series convergence. It caries over intuition from geometric series to more general series. Learn more about it here.

title: Series convergence & estimation
translated_description: When a series alternates (plus  minus  plus  minus ...) there's a fairly simple way to determine whether it converges or diverges: see if the terms of the series approach 0.

title: Series convergence & estimation
translated_description: Absolute convergence means a series will converge even when you take the absolute value of each term  while "Conditional convergence" means the series converges but not absolutely.

title: Series convergence & estimation
translated_description: Example using the alternating series test to determine which values of a variable will make the series converge.

title: Series convergence & estimation
translated_description: Suppose we want to find the sum of a convergent series  and can't do it directly. We can take a partial sum  but how do we know how far we are from the actual sum? We can use improper integrals for that!

title: Series convergence & estimation
translated_description: See how we can use improper integrals to approximate the infinite sum of 1/n².

title: Series convergence & estimation
translated_description: By computing only the first few terms of an alternating series  we can get a pretty good estimate for the infinite sum.  See why.

title: Series convergence & estimation
translated_description: Using the alternating series remainder to approximating the sum of an alternating series to a given error bound.

title: Power series
translated_description: Power series is a sum of terms of the general form aₙ(x-a)ⁿ. Whether the series converges or diverges  and the value it converges to  depend on the chosen x-value  which makes power series a function.

title: Power series
translated_description: The interval of converges of a power series is the interval of input values for which the series converges. To find it  we employ various techniques. See how it's done in this video.

title: Power series
translated_description: Within its interval of convergence  the integral of a power series is the sum of integrals of individual terms: ∫Σf(x)dx=Σ∫f(x)dx. See how this is used to find the integral of a power series.

title: Power series
translated_description: Within its interval of convergence  the derivative of a power series is the sum of derivatives of individual terms: [Σf(x)]'=Σf'(x). See how this is used to find the derivative of a power series.

title: Power series
translated_description: Integrating or differentiating a power series term-by-term can only work within the interval of convergence. The interval of convergence of the integral/derivative will be the same  except maybe for the endpoints. See an example here.

title: Power series
translated_description: Taylor & Maclaurin polynomials are a very clever way of approximating any function with a polynomial. Learn how these polynomials work.

title: Power series
translated_description: Taylor & Maclaurin polynomials are a very clever way of approximating any function with a polynomial. In this video we come up with the general formula for the nth term in a Taylor polynomial.

title: Power series
translated_description: Finding the second degree Maclaurin polynomial of 1/√(x+1).

title: Power series
translated_description: Finding the coefficient of the x² term in a Maclaurin polynomial  given the formula for the value of any derivative at x=0.

title: Power series
translated_description: Finding the coefficient of the term containing (x+2)⁴ in the Taylor polynomial centered at x=-2 of x⁶-x³.

title: Power series
translated_description: The more terms we have in a Taylor polynomial approximation of a function  the closer we get to the function. But HOW close? Let's embark on a journey to find a bound for the error of a Taylor polynomial approximation.

title: Power series
translated_description: The more terms we have in a Taylor polynomial approximation of a function  the closer we get to the function. But HOW close? In this video  we prove the Lagrange error bound for Taylor polynomials.

title: Power series
translated_description: Lagrange error bound (also called Taylor remainder theorem) can help us determine the degree of Taylor/Maclaurin polynomial to use to approximate a function to a given error bound. See how it's done when approximating the sine function.

title: Power series
translated_description: Lagrange error bound (also called Taylor remainder theorem) can help us determine the degree of Taylor/Maclaurin polynomial to use to approximate a function to a given error bound. See how it's done when approximating eˣ at x=1.45.

title: Power series
translated_description: Approximating eˣ with a Taylor polynomial centered at x=3. In the video we find the first few terms of such a polynomial and graph it to see how close it gets to eˣ.

title: Power series
translated_description: Rather than approximating a function  this time we are asked to approximate the derivative of a function.

title: Power series
translated_description: Approximating cos(x) with a Maclaurin series (which is like a Taylor polynomial centered at x=0 with infinitely many terms). It turns out that this series is exactly the same as the function itself!

title: Power series
translated_description: Approximating sin(x) with a Maclaurin series (which is like a Taylor polynomial centered at x=0 with infinitely many terms). It turns out that this series is exactly the same as the function itself!

title: Power series
translated_description: Approximating eˣ with a Maclaurin series (which is like a Taylor polynomial centered at x=0 with infinitely many terms). It turns out that this series is exactly the same as the function itself!

title: Power series
translated_description: Euler's formula is eⁱˣ=cos(x)+i⋅sin(x)  and Euler's Identity is e^(iπ)+1=0. See how these are obtained from the Maclaurin series of cos(x)  sin(x)  and eˣ. This is one of the most amazing things in all of mathematics!

title: Power series
translated_description: Finding a power series to represent x³cos(x²) using the Maclaurin series of cos(x).

title: Power series
translated_description: Given a power series  we recognize it as the Maclaurin series of cos(x³) and evaluate it at a given x-value.

title: Power series
translated_description: Sample AP Calculus question asking to recognize a function from its Taylor series.

title: Power series
translated_description: The larger the degree of a Taylor polynomial  the better it approximates the function. See that in action with sin(x) and its Taylor polynomials.

title: Power series
translated_description: Expressions of the form a/(1-r) represent the infinite sum of a geometric series whose initial term is a and constant ratio is r  which is written as Σa(r)ⁿ. Since geometric series are a class of power series  we obtained the power series representation of a/(1-r) very quickly.

title: Power series
translated_description: Power series of the form Σk(x-a)ⁿ (where k is constant) are a geometric series with initial term k and common ratio (x-a). Since we have an expression for the sum of a geometric series  we can rewrite such power series as a finite expression.

title: Power series
translated_description: When a power series is a geometric series  we can find its interval of convergence without using the ratio test!

title: Power series
translated_description: We can represent arctan(2x) with a power series by representing its derivative as a power series and then integrating that series. You have to admit this is pretty neat.

title: Power series
translated_description: We can represent ln(1+x³) with a power series by representing its derivative as a power series and then integrating that series. You have to admit this is pretty neat.

title: Power series
translated_description: When a power series S₁ is an antiderivative of a geometric series S₂  we can find the function represented by S₁ by integrating the expression for S₂.

title: Differential equations
translated_description: Differential equations are equations that relate a function with one or more of its derivatives. This means their solution is a function! Learn more in this video.

title: Differential equations
translated_description: If a particular solution to a differential equation is linear  y=mx+b  we can set up a system of equations to find m and b. See how it works in this video.

title: Differential equations
translated_description: Differential equations describe relationships that involve quantities and their rates of change. See how we write the equation for such a relationship.

title: Differential equations
translated_description: Slope fields allow us to analyze differential equations graphically. Learn how to draw them and use them to find particular solutions.

title: Differential equations
translated_description: Given a slope field and a few differential equations  we can determine which equation corresponds to the slope field by considering specific slopes.

title: Differential equations
translated_description: Given a differential equation in x and y  we can draw a segment with dy/dx as slope at any point (x y). That's the slope field of the equation. See how we match an equation to its slope field by considering the various slopes in the diagram.

title: Differential equations
translated_description: Given a differential equation in x and y  we can draw a segment with dy/dx as slope at any point (x y). That's the slope field of the equation. See how we determine the slopes of a few segments in the slope field of an equation.

title: Differential equations
translated_description: Given the slope field of a differential equation  we can sketch various solutions to the equation.

title: Differential equations
translated_description: Given the slope field of a differential equation  we can sketch various solutions to the equation. In this example  we analyze the range of a specific solution.

title: Differential equations
translated_description: Euler's method is a numerical tool for approximating values for solutions of differential equations. See how (and why) it works.

title: Differential equations
translated_description: Learn how to use our interactive code to approximate functions using Euler's method.

title: Differential equations
translated_description: Separation of variables allows us to rewrite differential equations so we obtain an equality between two integrals we can evaluate. Separable equations are the class of differential equations that can be solved using this method.

title: Differential equations
translated_description: Addressing treating differentials algebraically

title: Differential equations
translated_description: Separable equations can be written in the form dy/dx=f(x)g(y). See how we analyze various differential equations to see if they are separable.

title: Differential equations
translated_description: Solving a separable differential equation given initial conditions. In this video  the equation is dy/dx=2y² with y(1)=1.

title: Differential equations
translated_description: Sometimes the solution of a separable differential equation can't be written as an explicit function. This doesn't mean we can't use it!

title: Differential equations
translated_description: Assuming a quantity grows proportionally to its size results in the general equation dy/dx=ky. Solving it with separation of variables results in the general exponential function y=Ceᵏˣ.

title: Differential equations
translated_description: Given the general solution P=Ceᵏᵗ and the conditions P(0)=100 and P(50)=200  we find the solution to an exponential modeling problem.

title: Differential equations
translated_description: The solution of the general differential equation dy/dx=ky (for some k) is C⋅eᵏˣ (for some C). See how this is derived and used for finding a particular solution to a differential equation.

title: Differential equations
translated_description: Newton's law of cooling can be modeled with the general equation dT/dt=-k(T-Tₐ)  whose solutions are T=Ce⁻ᵏᵗ+Tₐ (for cooling) and T=Tₐ-Ce⁻ᵏᵗ (for heating).

title: Differential equations
translated_description: The general function for Newton's law of cooling is T=Ce⁻ᵏᵗ+Tₐ. In this video  we solve a word problem that involves the cooling of a freshly baked cookie!

title: Differential equations
translated_description: Population should grow proportionally to its size  but it can't keep growing forever! Learn more about this problem  posed by Malthus  and embark on a journey towards its mathematical solution.

title: Differential equations
translated_description: The logistic differential equation dN/dt=rN(1-N/K) describes the situation where a population grows proportionally to its size  but stops growing when it reaches the size of K.

title: Differential equations
translated_description: Finding the general solution of the general logistic equation dN/dt=rN(1-N/K). The solution is kind of hairy  but it's worth bearing with us!

title: Differential equations
translated_description: Finding the general solution of the general logistic equation dN/dt=rN(1-N/K). The solution is kind of hairy  but it's worth bearing with us!

title: Differential equations
translated_description: The general logistic function is N(t)=(N₀K)/(N₀+(K-N₀)e⁻ʳᵗ). In this video  we solve a real-world word problem about logistic growth.

title: AP Calculus BC questions
translated_description: AP Calculus lead  Ben Hedrick  talks about the design and tips for the AP Calculus exams.

title: AP Calculus BC questions
translated_description: x coordinate of particle at a certain time

title: AP Calculus BC questions
translated_description: Point on curve where tangent line has a certain slope

title: AP Calculus BC questions
translated_description: Time when particle reaches a certain speed

title: AP Calculus BC questions
translated_description: Finding distance travelled

title: AP Calculus BC questions
translated_description: Equation of tangent line

title: AP Calculus BC questions
translated_description: Relative minima and maxima

title: AP Calculus BC questions
translated_description: Engineering expression for critical point

title: AP Calculus BC questions
translated_description: Partial fraction expansion

title: AP Calculus BC questions
translated_description: Ratio test

title: AP Calculus BC questions
translated_description: Maclaurin series for derivative.

title: AP Calculus BC questions
translated_description: Multiplying two Taylor polynomials

title: AP Calculus BC questions
translated_description: Velocity and acceleration vectors for particle

title: AP Calculus BC questions
translated_description: Position and slope of particle's path at a given time

title: AP Calculus BC questions
translated_description: Arc length for a curve

title: AP Calculus BC questions
translated_description: Arc length of a function

title: AP Calculus BC questions
translated_description: Volume of a solid of rotation and Chain Rule for rates of change.

title: AP Calculus BC questions
translated_description: Taylor Series approximation of sin(x)

title: AP Calculus BC questions
translated_description: Taylor Series for cos x at x=0

title: AP Calculus BC questions
translated_description: Calculating the 6th derivative at 0 from the Taylor Series approximation

title: AP Calculus BC questions
translated_description: Lagrange error bound for Taylor Polynomial approximation

title: AP Calculus BC questions
translated_description: Part 1a of the 2008 BC free response

title: AP Calculus BC questions
translated_description: Parts b and c of problem 1 (free response)

title: AP Calculus BC questions
translated_description: parts c and d of problem 1 in the 2008 AP Calculus BC free response

title: AP Calculus BC questions
translated_description: Part 1d of the 2008 AP Calculus BC exam (free response)

title: AP Calculus BC questions
translated_description: 2a of 2008 Calculus BC exam (free response)

title: AP Calculus BC questions
translated_description: Parts 2b and 2c of the 2008 BC exam (free response)

title: AP Calculus BC questions
translated_description: Part 2d of the 2008 Calculus BC exam free-response section

title: Thinking about multivariable functions
translated_description: An introduction to multivariable functions  and a welcome to the multivariable calculus content as a whole.

title: Thinking about multivariable functions
translated_description: Learn how to represent and think about points and vectors in three-dimensional space.

title: Thinking about multivariable functions
translated_description: Three-dimensional graphs are a way to represent functions with a two-dimensional input and a one-dimensional output.

title: Thinking about multivariable functions
translated_description: 3d graphs can be a lot to take in  but it helps to imagine slicing them with planes parallel to the x-axis or y-axis and relate them with two-dimensional graphs.

title: Thinking about multivariable functions
translated_description: An alternative method to representing multivariable functions with a two-dimensional input and a one-dimensional output  contour maps involve drawing purely in the input space.

title: Thinking about multivariable functions
translated_description: When a function has a one-dimensional input  but a multidimensional output  you can think of it as drawing a curve in space.

title: Thinking about multivariable functions
translated_description: Functions that have a two-dimensional input and a three-dimensional output can be thought of as drawing a surface in three-dimensional space. This is actually pretty cool.

title: Thinking about multivariable functions
translated_description: Vector fields let you visualize a function with a two-dimensional input and a two-dimensional output. You end up with  well  a field of vectors sitting at various points in two-dimensional space.

title: Thinking about multivariable functions
translated_description: A neat way to interpret a vector field is to imagine that it represents some kind of fluid flow.

title: Thinking about multivariable functions
translated_description: Vector fields can also be three-dimensional  though this can be a bit trickier to visualize.

title: Thinking about multivariable functions
translated_description: See an example of how you can start to understand how the formula for a three-dimensional vector field relates to the way it looks.

title: Thinking about multivariable functions
translated_description: One fun way to think about functions is to imagine that they literally move the points from the input space over to the output space. See what this looks like with some one-dimensional examples.

title: Thinking about multivariable functions
translated_description: More transformations  but this time with a function that maps two dimensions to two dimensions.

title: Thinking about multivariable functions
translated_description: Learn how you can think about a parametric surface as a certain kind of transformation.

title: Derivatives of multivariable functions
translated_description: Partial derivatives tell you how a multivariable function changes as you tweak just one of the variables in its input.

title: Derivatives of multivariable functions
translated_description: One of the best ways to think about partial derivatives is by slicing the graph of a multivariable function.

title: Derivatives of multivariable functions
translated_description: Partial derivatives are formally defined using a limit  much like ordinary derivatives.

title: Derivatives of multivariable functions
translated_description: There are many ways to take a "second partial derivative"  but some of them secretly turn out to be the same thing.

title: Derivatives of multivariable functions
translated_description: The gradient captures all the partial derivative information of a scalar-valued multivariable function.

title: Derivatives of multivariable functions
translated_description: Learn how the gradient can be thought of as pointing in the "direction of steepest ascent". This is a rather important interpretation for the gradient.

title: Derivatives of multivariable functions
translated_description: Gradient vectors always point perpendicular to contour lines.

title: Derivatives of multivariable functions
translated_description: Directional derivatives tell you how a multivariable function changes as you move along some vector in its input space.

title: Derivatives of multivariable functions
translated_description: Learn the limit definition of a directional derivative. This helps to clarify what it is really doing.

title: Derivatives of multivariable functions
translated_description: The directional derivative can be used to compute the slope of a slice of a graph  but you must be careful to use a unit vector.

title: Derivatives of multivariable functions
translated_description: The way we compute the gradient seems unrelated to its interpretation as the direction of steepest ascent. Here you can see how the two relate.

title: Derivatives of multivariable functions
translated_description: Using a position vector valued function to describe a curve or path

title: Derivatives of multivariable functions
translated_description: Visualizing the derivative of a position vector valued function

title: Derivatives of multivariable functions
translated_description: Understanding the differential of a vector valued function

title: Derivatives of multivariable functions
translated_description: Concrete example of the derivative of a vector valued function to better understand what it means

title: Derivatives of multivariable functions
translated_description: This is the simplest case of taking the derivative of a composition involving multivariable functions.

title: Derivatives of multivariable functions
translated_description: Get a feel for what the multivariable is really saying  and how thinking about various "nudges" in space makes it intuitive.

title: Derivatives of multivariable functions
translated_description: The multivariable chain rule is more often expressed in terms of the gradient and a vector-valued derivative. This makes it look very analogous to the single-variable chain rule.

title: Derivatives of multivariable functions
translated_description: See how the multivariable chain rule can be expressed in terms of the directional derivative.

title: Derivatives of multivariable functions
translated_description: For those of you who want to see how the multivariable chain rule looks in the context of the limit definitions of various forms of the derivative.

title: Derivatives of multivariable functions
translated_description: An introduction to curvature  the radius of curvature  and how you can think about each one geometrically.

title: Derivatives of multivariable functions
translated_description: Curvature is computed by first finding a unit tangent vector function  then finding its derivative with respect to arc length. Here we start thinking about what that means.

title: Derivatives of multivariable functions
translated_description: A continuation in explaining how curvature is computed  with the formula for a circle as a guiding example.

title: Derivatives of multivariable functions
translated_description: Here  this concludes the explanation for how curvature is the derivative of a unit tangent vector with respect to length.

title: Derivatives of multivariable functions
translated_description: After the last video made reference to an explicit curvature formula  here you can start to get an intuition for why that seemingly unrelated formula describes curvature.

title: Derivatives of multivariable functions
translated_description: Here  we finish the intuition for how the curvature relates to the cross product between the first two derivatives of a parametric function.

title: Derivatives of multivariable functions
translated_description: An example of computing curvature by finding the unit tangent vector function  then computing its derivative with respect to arc length.

title: Derivatives of multivariable functions
translated_description: This finishes up the helix-curvature example started in the last video.

title: Derivatives of multivariable functions
translated_description: An example of computing curvature with the explicit formula.

title: Derivatives of multivariable functions
translated_description: When a function has a multidimensional input  and a multidimensional output  you can take its partial derivative by computing the partial derivative of each component in the output.

title: Derivatives of multivariable functions
translated_description: When a vector-valued function represents a parametric surface  how do you interpret its partial derivative?

title: Derivatives of multivariable functions
translated_description: Taking the same example surface used in the last example  we now take a look at the partial derivative in the other direction.

title: Derivatives of multivariable functions
translated_description: How do you intepret the partial derivatives of the function which defines a vector field?

title: Derivatives of multivariable functions
translated_description: Here we step through each partial derivative of each component in a vector field  and understand what each means geometrically.

title: Derivatives of multivariable functions
translated_description: Vector fields can be thought of as representing fluid flow  and divergence is all about studying the change in fluid density during that flow.

title: Derivatives of multivariable functions
translated_description: In preparation for finding the formula for divergence  we start getting an intuition for what points of positive  negative and zero divergence should look like.

title: Derivatives of multivariable functions
translated_description: How does the x-component of a vector field relate to the divergence?

title: Derivatives of multivariable functions
translated_description: Here we finish the line of reasoning which leads to the formula for divergence in two dimensions.

title: Derivatives of multivariable functions
translated_description: An example of computing and interpreting the divergence of a two-dimensional vector field.

title: Derivatives of multivariable functions
translated_description: Learn how divergence is expressed using the same upsidedown triangle symbols that the gradient uses.

title: Derivatives of multivariable functions
translated_description: A description of how vector fields relate to fluid rotation  laying the intuition for what the operation of curl represents.

title: Derivatives of multivariable functions
translated_description: Here we build up to the formula for computing the two-dimensional curl of a vector field  reasoning through what partial derivative information corresponds to fluid rotation.

title: Derivatives of multivariable functions
translated_description: A worked example of computing and interpreting two-dimensional curl.

title: Derivatives of multivariable functions
translated_description: The meaning of positive curl in a fluid flow can sometimes look a bit different from the clear cut rotation-around-a-point examples discussed in previous videos.

title: Derivatives of multivariable functions
translated_description: Learn how a three-dimensional vector can be used to describe three-dimensional rotation. This is important for understanding three-dimensional curl.

title: Derivatives of multivariable functions
translated_description: Here we start transitioning from the understanding of two-dimensional curl into an understanding of three-dimensional curl.

title: Derivatives of multivariable functions
translated_description: Continuing the intuition for how three-dimensional curl represents rotation in three-dimensional fluid flow.

title: Derivatives of multivariable functions
translated_description: How to compute a three-dimensional curl  imagined as a cross product of sorts.

title: Derivatives of multivariable functions
translated_description: This finishes the demonstration of how to compute three-dimensional curl using a certain determinant.

title: Derivatives of multivariable functions
translated_description: A worked example of a three-dimensional curl computation.

title: Derivatives of multivariable functions
translated_description: A visual understanding for how the Laplace operator is an extension of the second derivative to multivariable functions.

title: Derivatives of multivariable functions
translated_description: A worked example of computing the laplacian of a two-variable function.

title: Derivatives of multivariable functions
translated_description: This is another way you might see the Laplace operator written.

title: Derivatives of multivariable functions
translated_description: If the Laplacian of a function is zero everywhere  it is called Harmonic. Harmonic functions arise all the time in physics  capturing a certain notion of "stability"  whenever one point in space is influenced by its neighbors.

title: Derivatives of multivariable functions
translated_description: Before jumping into the Jacobian  it's important to make sure we all know how to think about matrices geometrically. This is targetted towards those who have seen linear algebra but may need a quick refresher.

title: Derivatives of multivariable functions
translated_description: A visual representation of local linearity for a function with a 2d input and a 2d output  in preparation for learning about the Jacobian matrix.

title: Derivatives of multivariable functions
translated_description: An introduction to how the jacobian matrix represents what a multivariable function looks like locally  as a linear transformation.

title: Derivatives of multivariable functions
translated_description: This finishes the introduction of the Jacobian matrix  working out the computations for the example shown in the last video.

title: Derivatives of multivariable functions
translated_description: How to interpret the determinant of a Jacobian matrix  along with some examples.

title: Applications of multivariable derivatives
translated_description: The "tangent plane" of the graph of a function is  well  a two-dimensional plane that is tangent to this graph. Here you can see what that looks like.

title: Applications of multivariable derivatives
translated_description: How can you describe a specified plane in space as the graph of a function?

title: Applications of multivariable derivatives
translated_description: Here you can see how to use the control over functions whose graphs are planes  as introduced in the last video  to find the tangent plane to a function graph.

title: Applications of multivariable derivatives
translated_description: A "local linearization" is the generalization of tangent plane functions; one that can apply to multivariable functions with any number of inputs.

title: Applications of multivariable derivatives
translated_description: After learning about local linearizations of multivariable functions  the next step is to understand how to approximate a function even more closely with a quadratic approximation.

title: Applications of multivariable derivatives
translated_description: How to creat a quadratic function that approximates an arbitrary two-variable function.

title: Applications of multivariable derivatives
translated_description: A continuation from the previous video  leading to the full formula for the quadratic approximation of a two-variable function.

title: Applications of multivariable derivatives
translated_description: A worked example for finding the quadratic approximation of a two-variable function.

title: Applications of multivariable derivatives
translated_description: The Hessian matrix is a way of organizing all the second partial derivative information of a multivariable function.

title: Applications of multivariable derivatives
translated_description: How to write an expression like ax^2 + bxy + cy^2 using matrices and vectors.

title: Applications of multivariable derivatives
translated_description: This is the more general form of a quadratic approximation for a scalar-valued multivariable function. It is analogous to a quadratic Taylor polynomial in the single-variable world.

title: Applications of multivariable derivatives
translated_description: A description of maxima and minima of multivariable functions  what they look like  and a little bit about how to find them.

title: Applications of multivariable derivatives
translated_description: Just because the tangent plane to a multivariable function is flat  it doesn't mean that point is a local minimum or a local maximum. There is a third possibility  new to multivariable calculus  called a "saddle point".

title: Applications of multivariable derivatives
translated_description: An example of looking for local minima in a multivariable function by finding where tangent planes are flat  along with some of the intuitions that will underly the second partial derivative test.

title: Applications of multivariable derivatives
translated_description: How to determine if the critical point of a two-variable function is a local minimum  a local maximum  or a saddle point.

title: Applications of multivariable derivatives
translated_description: The second partial derivative test is based on a formula which seems to come out of nowhere. Here  you can see a little more intuition for why it looks the way it does.

title: Applications of multivariable derivatives
translated_description: A worked example of finding a classifying critical points of a two-variable function.

title: Applications of multivariable derivatives
translated_description: Continuing the worked example from the previous video  now classifying each critical point.

title: Applications of multivariable derivatives
translated_description: The Lagrange multiplier technique is how we take advantage of the observation made in the last video  that the solution to a constrained optimization problem occurs when the contour lines of the function being maximized are tangent to the constraint curve.

title: Applications of multivariable derivatives
translated_description: The Lagrange multiplier technique is how we take advantage of the observation made in the last video  that the solution to a constrained optimization problem occurs when the contour lines of the function being maximized are tangent to the constraint curve.

title: Applications of multivariable derivatives
translated_description: Working out the algebra for the final solution the the example from the previous two videos.

title: Applications of multivariable derivatives
translated_description: A Lagrange multipliers example of maximizing revenues subject to a budgetary constraint.

title: Applications of multivariable derivatives
translated_description: Finishing off the example from the previous video

title: Applications of multivariable derivatives
translated_description: How a special function  called the "Lagrangian"  can be used to package together all the steps needed to solve a constrained optimization problem.

title: Applications of multivariable derivatives
translated_description: In the previous videos on Lagrange multipliers  the Lagrange multiplier itself has just been some proportionality constant that we didn't care about. Here  you can see what its real meaning is.

title: Applications of multivariable derivatives
translated_description: Here  you can see a proof of the fact shown in the last video  that the Lagrange multiplier gives information about how altering a constraint can alter the solution to a constrained maximization problem. Note  this is somewhat technical
