translated_description: Sal uses different bags of trail mix to find the amount of trail mix each bag would contain if the total amount in all the bags were redistributed equally.

title: Geometry
translated_description: Introduction to the coordinate plane and plotting points on the coordinate plane.  Only quadrant 1 (positive numbers) is covered.

title: Geometry
translated_description: Sal graphs ordered pairs  such as (8  10) in quadrant 1 on a coordinate plane.

title: Geometry
translated_description: Sal plots the corners of a rectangle on the first quadrant of a coordinate plane.

title: Geometry
translated_description: Sal solves a word problem involving distance between points on quadrant 1 of a coordinate plane.

title: Geometry
translated_description: Sal works through a word problem interpreting coordinates in the first quadrant on a coordinate plane.

title: Geometry
translated_description: Learn the term quadrilateral as well as trapezoid  parallelogram  rectangle  rhombus  and square.

title: Geometry
translated_description: Learn about the properties of quadrilaterals  parallelograms  trapezoids  rhombuses  rectangles  and squares.

title: Geometry
translated_description: Sal discusses a special type of quadrilateral  the kite.

title: Geometry
translated_description: Learn to identify quadrilaterals such as kites  trapezoids  parallelograms  rhombuses  rectangles  and squares by line and angle type.

title: Geometry
translated_description: Sal classifies quadrilaterals by their properties (such as parallel sides).

title: Algebraic thinking
translated_description: Sal solves a word problem by constructing a numerical expression.

title: Algebraic thinking
translated_description: Sal evaluates an expression with and without parentheses

title: Algebraic thinking
translated_description: Sal interprets written statements and writes them as mathematical expressions.

title: Algebraic thinking
translated_description: Sal completes a pattern using a table and then graphs the results on a coordinate plane.

title: Algebraic thinking
translated_description: Sal examines the points on a number line and interprets the patterns to discover relationships.

title: Algebraic thinking
translated_description: Sal interprets and graphs the relationships between patterns in the given ordered pairs.

title: Algebraic thinking
translated_description: Sal plots ordered pairs based on sequence relationships.

title: Ratios rates & percentages
translated_description: A ratio is a comparison of two quantities.  Learn how to find the ratio between two things  for example apples to oranges.

title: Ratios rates & percentages
translated_description: How are fractions and ratios the same? How are they different? Is 2:5 the same as 2/5?

title: Ratios rates & percentages
translated_description: Sal uses ratios to figure out how far apart two cities should be on a map.

title: Ratios rates & percentages
translated_description: Sal solves a tricky ratio word problem.

title: Ratios rates & percentages
translated_description: Sal introduces rates using examples like 35 miles per hour and 10 dollars per hour.

title: Ratios rates & percentages
translated_description: Jayda takes 3 hours to deliver newspapers on her route. What is the rate per hour at which she delivers the newspapers?

title: Ratios rates & percentages
translated_description: Miranda's Maid Service charges \$280 to clean 8 offices. What is the company's price for cleaning a single office?

title: Ratios rates & percentages
translated_description: Sal puts three fish tanks in order by volume of water per fish.

title: Ratios rates & percentages
translated_description: Let's think about what percent really means by looking at a 10 by 10 grid.

title: Ratios rates & percentages
translated_description: Percents are parts per hundred. So  how does this work for percents greater than 100% like 109%?

title: Ratios rates & percentages
translated_description: Sal writes 18% as a decimal and as a fraction.

title: Ratios rates & percentages
translated_description: Percents can be written in decimal form. ​Per-cent means per-100. So  we divide the percent by 100 to get an equivalent decimal. Then  we remove the percent sign (%). For example  65% can be converted to decimal form by solving 65/100. So  65%=0.65. Another way to think of dividing by 100 is moving the decimal two places to the left.

title: Ratios rates & percentages
translated_description: Sal converts 1.501 to a percent.

title: Ratios rates & percentages
translated_description: Decimals can be written in percent form. ​Per-cent means per-100. So  we multiply the decimal by 100 to get an equivalent percent. Then  we add a percent sign (%). For example  0.8 can be converted to percent form by solving 0.8✕100. So  0.8=80%. Another way to think of multiplying by 100 is moving the decimal two places to the right.

title: Ratios rates & percentages
translated_description: Sal converts 113.9% to a decimal by demonstrating how to move the decimal point

title: Ratios rates & percentages
translated_description: Percent means per-hundred.  Use that knowledge to solve problems like what percent of 16 is 4?

title: Ratios rates & percentages
translated_description: There are several different ways to solve problems involving percentages  decimals  and fractions. Watch as Sal finds the percentage of a whole number.

title: Ratios rates & percentages
translated_description: This word problem is expressed simply which can be confusing to some. Take your time and focus on the what is being asked for.

title: Ratios rates & percentages
translated_description: In this example  you working with us to find the number that is expressed as a given percentage. We'll create a simple algebraic equation to solve!

title: Ratios rates & percentages
translated_description: We're putting a little algebra to work to find the full price when you know the discount price in this percent word problem.

title: Ratios rates & percentages
translated_description: It's nice to practice conversion problems  but how about applying our new knowledge of percentages to a real life problem like recycling? Hint: don't forget your long division!

title: Ratios rates & percentages
translated_description: You're given the percent in this example and asked to find the whole number represented by the percent.

title: Arithmetic operations
translated_description: Sal solves 9.087+15.31 using the "standard algorithm".

title: Arithmetic operations
translated_description: Sal solves 0.822+5.65 using "standard algorithm".

title: Arithmetic operations
translated_description: Sal adds 7.056+605.7+5.67 using the "standard algorithm".

title: Arithmetic operations
translated_description: Just like when add  be sure you align decimals before subtracting.

title: Arithmetic operations
translated_description: In this example where we subtract decimals we do so up to the thousandths place. It's a little tricky  but not if we do it together.

title: Arithmetic operations
translated_description: Here's a simple word problem asking us to put our adding decimals skill to work.

title: Arithmetic operations
translated_description: Let's get fancy and practice adding and subtracting decimals in the same word problem.

title: Arithmetic operations
translated_description: Sal introduces multiplying decimals with problems like 9x0.6.

title: Arithmetic operations
translated_description: Sal uses an understanding of place value to multiply 2.91x3.2.

title: Arithmetic operations
translated_description: Sometimes multiplying really small decimals (with all those zeros!) can be a little intimidating. Watch as we show you a handy trick to simplify these problems and solve them.

title: Arithmetic operations
translated_description: Learn to divide 9815/65.  The answer does not have a remainder.

title: Arithmetic operations
translated_description: Learn to divide 7182/42.  There is no remainder.

title: Arithmetic operations
translated_description: Sal divides 63/35.

title: Arithmetic operations
translated_description: Sal shows how to keep track of the decimal point when dividing a decimal by a whole number.

title: Arithmetic operations
translated_description: When dividing a whole number by a decimal  you're going to need to change that decimal into a whole number. How? We'll show you.

title: Arithmetic operations
translated_description: Decimal divisors in the hundredths place can be a little confusing. In this video we'll show you how to move the decimal and make it a whole number. Pretty nifty! Watch.

title: Arithmetic operations
translated_description: Sal shows how to divide 6.3 by 0.25.

title: Arithmetic operations
translated_description: Sal divides 6.7 by 2.211.

title: Arithmetic operations
translated_description: Sal shows that when there is a decimal divisor  you need to shift the decimal first and then divide.

title: Arithmetic operations
translated_description: Using a number line  we'll explain why multiplying by the inverse is the same as dividing.

title: Arithmetic operations
translated_description: Learn to divide two fractions.  The answer is a fraction.

title: Arithmetic operations
translated_description: Dividing two fractions is the same as multiplying the first fraction by the reciprocal of the second fraction. The first step to dividing fractions are to find the reciprocal (reverse the numerator and denominator) of the second fraction. Next  multiply the two numerators. Then  multiply the two denominators. Finally  simplify the fractions if needed.

title: Arithmetic operations
translated_description: Dividing a whole number by a fraction? Turn the tables and multiply by the reciprocal of the fraction. Boom!

title: Arithmetic operations
translated_description: Sal shows how exponents are repeated multiplication

title: Arithmetic operations
translated_description: Learn why a number raised to the zero power equals 1.

title: Arithmetic operations
translated_description: Just like whole numbers with exponents  fractions are repeatedly multiplied. If you know how to multiply fractions  you're over half way there.

title: Arithmetic operations
translated_description: This example shows the steps and clarifies the purpose of order of operations: to have ONE way to interpret a mathematical statement.

title: Arithmetic operations
translated_description: Exponents are near the top of the food chain when it comes to order of operations. Let's do some examples together.

title: Arithmetic operations
translated_description: The order of operations tells us the order to solve steps in expressions with more than one operation. First  we solve any operations inside of parentheses or brackets. Second  we solve any exponents. Third  we solve all multiplication and division from left to right. Fourth  we solve all addition and subtraction from left to right.

title: Arithmetic operations
translated_description: Work through a challenging order of operations example with only positive numbers.

title: Arithmetic operations
translated_description: Simplify this tricky expression using the order of operations.   Expression include negative numbers and exponents.

title: Negative numbers
translated_description: Mysterious negative numbers! What ARE they? They are numbers less than zero. If you understand the nature of below zero temperatures  you can understand negative numbers. We'll help.

title: Negative numbers
translated_description: These example exercises require us to interpret a number line in order to locate where our positive and negative decimals should be placed.

title: Negative numbers
translated_description: We're mixing it up by placing both fractions and decimals on the same number line. Great practice because you need to move effortlessly between the two.

title: Negative numbers
translated_description: Given a few negative numbers on a number line  let's see if we can determine what negative numbers are elsewhere on the number line.

title: Negative numbers
translated_description: Learn about number opposites like 3 and -3 or -4 and 4 using a number line.

title: Negative numbers
translated_description: Sal explains more challenging opposites like -(-3).

title: Negative numbers
translated_description: Sal solves a few challenging problems with number opposites on the number line.

title: Negative numbers
translated_description: Sal puts -25  -30  -7  -10  and -40 in order from least to greatest.

title: Negative numbers
translated_description: Sal puts 7/3  -5/2  0  -2  -12/4  -3.25 in order from least to greatest.

title: Negative numbers
translated_description: Given a  b  and c shown on the number line  Sal determines if statements like -b < c are true.

title: Negative numbers
translated_description: Learn how to find the absolute value of 5  -10  and 12.

title: Negative numbers
translated_description: Learn how to compare absolute value like | -9 | and | -7 |.

title: Negative numbers
translated_description: Learn how to place | - 27 |  -17  -28  and 22.4 on the number line.

title: Negative numbers
translated_description: Given  a  b  and c on the number line  Sal determines if statements like | a | < | c | are true.

title: Negative numbers
translated_description: Sal determines if values of x are solutions to an absolute value inequality. For example  does x = -5 satisfy | x | > 5?

title: Negative numbers
translated_description: Given that Jenna's weight changed -3 lbs  Sarah's changed 2.5 lbs  and Bill's changed 4 lbs  who lost the most weight? Who had the largest change in weight?

title: Negative numbers
translated_description: The coordinate plane is a two-dimension surface formed by two number lines. One number line is horizontal and is called the x-axis. The other number line is vertical number line and is called the y-axis. The two axes meet at a point called the origin. We can use the coordinate plane to graph points  lines  and more.

title: Negative numbers
translated_description: We're plotting an ordered pair on the x (horizontal) axis and y (vertical) axis of the coordinate plane.

title: Negative numbers
translated_description: Some of the given ordered pairs are already graphed on the coordinate pane in this example  but not all of them. Can you tell which haven't?

title: Negative numbers
translated_description: Learn about the 4 quadrants that make up a coordinate plane.

title: Negative numbers
translated_description: Plot an ordered pair like (-4  -2) and then decide which quadrant it is in.

title: Negative numbers
translated_description: In this word problem  we need to plot the ordered pairs and then figure out the difference in the y coodinate between the two. This will give us our answer!

title: Negative numbers
translated_description: Just like looking at a mirror image of yourself  but flipped....a reflection point is the mirror point on the opposite axis. Watch this tutorial and reflect :)

title: Properties of numbers
translated_description: Sal finds the LCM (least common multiple) of 12 and 36  and of 12 and 18. He shows how to do that using the prime factorization method  which is a just great!

title: Properties of numbers
translated_description: Sal finds the LCM (least common multiple) of 25 and 30.

title: Properties of numbers
translated_description: This least common multiple example gives us 3 numbers from which to find the lcm. This is a challenge  but fun. Do it with us!

title: Properties of numbers
translated_description: Find the biggest number that will divide into the given 2 numbers. This is called the GCF or greatest common factor.No worries  we'll show you how to do it.

title: Properties of numbers
translated_description: Here's a nice explanation of greatest common factor (or greatest common divisor) along with a few practice example exercises. Let's roll.

title: Properties of numbers
translated_description: Here we have a couple of word problems--one searching for the least common multiple and the other for the greatest common factor. Just read them with us slowly and follow along. You'll get it.

title: Variables & expressions introduction
translated_description: Our focus here is understanding that a variable is just a symbol that can represent different values in an expression. We got this. Just watch.

title: Variables & expressions introduction
translated_description: Great question. In algebra  we do indeed avoid using the multiplication sign. We'll explain it for you here.

title: Variables & expressions introduction
translated_description: Learn how to evaluate an expression with variables using a technique called substitution (or "plugging in").

title: Variables & expressions introduction
translated_description: We've done a few examples together where we were faced with 1 variable. Why not try one that has 2 variables?

title: Variables & expressions introduction
translated_description: Learn how to evaluate expressions that have two different variables in them by using a technique called substitution (or "plugging in").

title: Variables & expressions introduction
translated_description: Explore how the values of algebraic expressions like 100-x  5/x + 5  and (3y)/(2y) change as the values of the variables change.

title: Variables & expressions introduction
translated_description: In this example we have a formula for converting Celsius temperature to Fahrenheit. Let's substitute the variable with a value (Celsius temp) to get the degrees in Fahrenheit. Great problem to practice with us!

title: Variables & expressions introduction
translated_description: In this example of evaluating expressions  we're dusting off some geometry. On top of that  it's a word problem. We're seeing how different concepts in math are layered on top of each to create more interesting and complex problems to solve.

title: Variables & expressions introduction
translated_description: We're going to put our order of operations knowledge to work as we evaluate this expression. Exponents  specifically  are our focus here.

title: Variables & expressions introduction
translated_description: Sal writes an expression to represent 11 more than a.

title: Variables & expressions introduction
translated_description: Learn how to write simple algebraic expressions.

title: Variables & expressions introduction
translated_description: Learn how to write algebraic expressions that involve grouping quantities in parentheses.

title: Variables & expressions introduction
translated_description: Learn how to write basic expressions with variables to describe situations described in word problems.

title: Variables & expressions introduction
translated_description: Learn how to write expressions with variables to describe situations described in word problems.

title: Equations & inequalities introduction
translated_description: Learn what variables  expressions  and equations are.

title: Equations & inequalities introduction
translated_description: A solution to an equation makes that equation true. Learn how to test if a certain value of a variable makes an equation true.

title: Equations & inequalities introduction
translated_description: The example of a scale where we try to achieve balance helps to explain why we do the same thing to both sides of an equation.

title: Equations & inequalities introduction
translated_description: Equations are about relationships (no  not girlfriends and boyfriends!) between the two sides of the equation. Let's again use a scale example to help us understand.

title: Equations & inequalities introduction
translated_description: Let's get a conceptual understanding of why one needs to divide both sides of an equation to solve for a variable.

title: Equations & inequalities introduction
translated_description: This equation can be simplified through a single step to solve for the variable. Can you help?

title: Equations & inequalities introduction
translated_description: Learn how to solve one-step addition and subtraction equations by adding or subtracting the same thing from both sides of the equation.

title: Equations & inequalities introduction
translated_description: Learn how to solve this equation: a + 5 = 54

title: Equations & inequalities introduction
translated_description: Learn how to solve one-step addition and subtraction equations that have fractions and decimals in them.

title: Equations & inequalities introduction
translated_description: Let's ease into this  shall we? Here's an introduction to basic algebraic equations of the form ax=b. Remember that you can check to see if you have the right answer by substituting it for the variable!

title: Equations & inequalities introduction
translated_description: Remember that what you do to one side  you have to do to the other. Will you multiply or divide both sides to dump the fraction  x/a? Let's do it together.

title: Equations & inequalities introduction
translated_description: Learn how to solve equations in one step by multiplying or dividing a number from both sides. These problems involve decimals and fractions.

title: Equations & inequalities introduction
translated_description: Using information from the Super Yoga word problem  explore all the possible combinations and create equations which express the possibilities. Let's figure out which plan is best!

title: Equations & inequalities introduction
translated_description: If you're coming to this video before seeing the previous one  back up! Otherwise  we're solving one-step equations to learn which Super Plan is the best value for our budget.

title: Equations & inequalities introduction
translated_description: Learn how to write basic equations to model real-world situations.

title: Equations & inequalities introduction
translated_description: Learn how to spot mistakes in someone else's work as they attempt to solve one-step equations.

title: Equations & inequalities introduction
translated_description: A solution to an inequality makes that inequality true. Learn how to test if a certain value of a variable makes an inequality true.

title: Equations & inequalities introduction
translated_description: To plot an inequality  such as x>3  on a number line  first draw a circle over the number (e.g.  3). Then if the sign includes equal to (≥ or ≤)  fill in the circle. If the sign does not include equal to (> or <)  leave the circle unfilled in. Finally  draw a line going from the circle in the direction of the numbers that make the inequality true.

title: Equations & inequalities introduction
translated_description: Learn how to plot a simple inequality on a number line. The example used in this video is x < 4.

title: Equations & inequalities introduction
translated_description: Learn how to write inequalities to model real-world situation.

title: Equations & inequalities introduction
translated_description: Identifying the dependent and the independent variables in a word problem.

title: Equations & inequalities introduction
translated_description: It's helpful to express an equation on a graph where we plot at least 2 points. Watch and we'll show you.

title: Equations & inequalities introduction
translated_description: We're flipping the last video on its head and doing the opposite. This time we give you the graph and ask you to express it as an equation.

title: Equivalent expressions
translated_description: This video explains what the words term  factor  and coefficient mean. Think of an expression as a sentence. A sentence has parts  and so does an algebraic expression.

title: Equivalent expressions
translated_description: In simple addition we learned to add all the numbers together to get a sum. In algebra  numbers are sometimes attached to variables and we need to make sure that the variables are alike before we add the numbers.

title: Equivalent expressions
translated_description: Sal explains why 4a + 2a = 6a several ways

title: Equivalent expressions
translated_description: We're going to simplify this expression together putting to use our new knowledge of how to combine like terms. Ok? Let's do it!

title: Equivalent expressions
translated_description: Learn to expand and simplify an expression like 3(5x+6) + (7x+2)*4.

title: Equivalent expressions
translated_description: Learn how to apply the distributive law of multiplication over addition and why it works. This is sometimes just called the distributive law or the distributive property.

title: Equivalent expressions
translated_description: Learn how to apply the distributive property of multiplication over subtraction and why it works. This is sometimes just called the distributive property or distributive law.

title: Equivalent expressions
translated_description: Learn how to apply the distributive property to factor numerical expressions (no variables).

title: Equivalent expressions
translated_description: Learn how to apply the distributive property to algebraic expressions.

title: Equivalent expressions
translated_description: Sal finds equivalent expressions by combining like terms and using the distributive property.

title: Geometry
translated_description: Understand why the formula for the area of a parallelogram is base times height  just like the formula for the area of a rectangle.

title: Geometry
translated_description: Understand why the formula for the area of a triangle is one half base times height  which is half of the area of a parallelogram.

title: Geometry
translated_description: Area of a trapezoid is found with the formula  A=(a+b)/2 x h.  Learn how to use the formula to find area of trapezoids.

title: Geometry
translated_description: Learn how to find the area of a kite. A kite is a type of quadrilateral that is symmetric around one of its diagonals.

title: Geometry
translated_description: Sometimes it helps to rearrange the parts of geometric figures to find the area. That's what we're going to do here.

title: Geometry
translated_description: Learn to break up irregular shapes into smaller geometric shapes to determine area.

title: Geometry
translated_description: Another way of finding the volume of a rectangular prism involves dividing it into fractional cubes  finding the volume of one  and then multiplying that volume by the number of cubes that fit into our rectangular prism.

title: Geometry
translated_description: Learn how to find the volume of a rectangular prism that has fractional side lengths. The prism in this video has dimensions 3/5 by 1 1/6 by 3/7.

title: Geometry
translated_description: Sal explains how to find the volume of a rectangular prism fish tank that has fractional side lengths.

title: Geometry
translated_description: Admittedly  "nets of polyhedra" sounds like the title of a bad sci-fi movie about man-eating  multi-headed fish. But in reality  nets of polyhedra are just 2D objects that wrap around 3D objects  like wrapping paper around presents.

title: Geometry
translated_description: Learn how to compute the surface area of a triangular prism.

title: Geometry
translated_description: A polyhedron is a three-dimensional shape that has flat surfaces and straight edges.  Learn whether or not a certain net could be folded up into a certain rectangular prism.

title: Geometry
translated_description: Surface area is the sum of the areas of all faces (or surfaces) on a 3D shape. A cuboid has 6 rectangular faces. To find the surface area of a cuboid  add the areas of all 6 faces. We can also label the length (l)  width (w)  and height (h) of the prism and use the formula  SA=2lw+2lh+2hw  to find the surface area.

title: Geometry
translated_description: Learn how to find the surface area of cereal box using nets.

title: Geometry
translated_description: Sal draws a quadrilateral on the coordinate plane using the coordinates of its vertices.

title: Geometry
translated_description: Learn how to find the area of a parallelogram on the coordinate plane.

title: Geometry
translated_description: Given three of the vertices of a rectangle  can you find the fourth?

title: Geometry
translated_description: Given the vertices of a rectangle  can you find the lengths of the sides?

title: Geometry
translated_description: Sal solves a challenging problem involving a quadrilateral on the coordinate plane.

title: Geometry
translated_description: Remember our discussion of the coordinate plane? Sure you do! Let's graph the given coordinates of three of the polygon vertices  and find where the 4th vertex is.

title: Data and statistics
translated_description: Here are a few of the many ways to look at data. Which is your favorite?

title: Data and statistics
translated_description: Learn to organize data into frequency tables and dot plots (sometimes called line plots).

title: Data and statistics
translated_description: What makes a question a "statistical question"?

title: Data and statistics
translated_description: A histogram is a graphical display of data using bars of different heights. In a histogram  each bar groups numbers into ranges. Taller bars show that more data falls in that range. A histogram displays the shape and spread of continuous sample data.

title: Data and statistics
translated_description: Learn how to read and interpret histograms  which summarize data by sorting it into buckets.

title: Data and statistics
translated_description: The mean (average) of a data set is found by adding all numbers in the data set and then dividing by the number of values in the set. The median is the middle value when a data set is ordered from least to greatest. The mode is the number that occurs most often in a data set.

title: Data and statistics
translated_description: Here we give you a set of numbers and then ask you to find the mean  median  and mode. It's your first opportunity to practice with us!

title: Data and statistics
translated_description: Learn how to find the value of a missing piece of data if you know the mean of the data set.

title: Data and statistics
translated_description: Sal solves an interesting median and range challenge problem.

title: Data and statistics
translated_description: Sal thinks through the effects of removing a low outlier from a data set. What will happen to the mean and median?

title: Data and statistics
translated_description: Sal thinks through the effects of modifying a value in a data set. What will happen to the mean and median?

title: Data and statistics
translated_description: The IQR describes the middle 50% of values when ordered from lowest to highest. To find the interquartile range (IQR)  ​first find the median (middle value) of the lower and upper half of the data. These values are quartile 1 (Q1) and quartile 3 (Q3). The IQR is the difference between Q3 and Q1.

title: Data and statistics
translated_description: Is this some kind of cute cat video? No! Box and whisker plots seek to explain data by showing a spread of all the data points in a sample. The "whiskers" are the two opposite ends of the data. This video is more fun than a handful of catnip.

title: Data and statistics
translated_description: Here's a word problem that's perfectly suited for a box and whiskers plot to help analyze data. Let's construct one together  shall we?

title: Data and statistics
translated_description: Learn how to create a box plot. The data set used in this example has 11 data points.

title: Data and statistics
translated_description: Learn how to create a box plot. The data set used in this example has 14 data points.

title: Data and statistics
translated_description: Mean absolute deviation (MAD) of a data set is the average distance between each data value and the mean. Mean absolute deviation is a way to describe variation in a data set. Mean absolute deviation helps us get a sense of how "spread out" the values in a data set are.

title: Data and statistics
translated_description: Sal finds the mean absolute deviation of a data set that's given in a bar chart.

title: Data and statistics
translated_description: Sal solves practice problems where he thinks about which data displays would be helpful in which situations.

title: Data and statistics
translated_description: Some distributions are symmetrical  with data evenly distributed about the mean. Other distributions are "skewed " with data tending to the left or right of the mean. We sometimes say that skewed distributions have "tails."

title: Data and statistics
translated_description: Examples looking at different features of distributions  such as clusters  gaps  peaks  and outliers for distributions

title: Negative numbers addition and subtraction
translated_description: Use a number line to add -15 + (-46) + (-29)

title: Negative numbers addition and subtraction
translated_description: Use a number line to add 15 + (-46) + 29

title: Negative numbers addition and subtraction
translated_description: Learn how to add and subtract negative numbers. The problems solved in this video are 2 - 3 = -1 and -2 - 3 = -5 and -2 + 3 = 1 and 2 - (-3) = 5 and -2 - (-3).

title: Negative numbers addition and subtraction
translated_description: Find out why subtracting a negative number is the same as adding the absolute value of that number.

title: Negative numbers addition and subtraction
translated_description: Use a number line to add 15 + (-46) + 29

title: Negative numbers addition and subtraction
translated_description: Sal solves some missing value problems: -1 = 7 - __ and -10 + __ = -5 and 4 = -2 + __ and 6 + __ = -8

title: Negative numbers addition and subtraction
translated_description: Sal solves more missing value problems: 4 = -8 - __  and  __ - (-2) = -7  and  -4 = __ - 9

title: Negative numbers addition and subtraction
translated_description: Sal shows how to model 6 + (-2) using vertical number lines.

title: Negative numbers addition and subtraction
translated_description: Integer equations to describe diagram

title: Negative numbers addition and subtraction
translated_description: Sal chooses the correct interpretation of the integer expression 3 + (-7).

title: Negative numbers addition and subtraction
translated_description: Use a number line to add fractions with different signs.

title: Negative numbers addition and subtraction
translated_description: Add and subtract negative fractions with unlike denominators.

title: Negative numbers addition and subtraction
translated_description: Use a number line to solve a word problem that includes a negative number.

title: Negative numbers addition and subtraction
translated_description: In this video  we figure out the temperature in Fairbanks  Alaska by adding and subtracting negative numbers.

title: Negative numbers addition and subtraction
translated_description: The examples in this video use negative numbers to represent real world situations. What are these negative numbers really telling us?

title: Negative numbers addition and subtraction
translated_description: In this video  we think about what |a-b| really means  and we verify that |a-b| = |b-a| by looking at an example.

title: Negative numbers addition and subtraction
translated_description: In this video  we work through a bunch of examples that stretch our thinking on absolute value.

title: Negative numbers addition and subtraction
translated_description: This is a more formal justification for why |a - b| = |b - a| than we saw in previous videos.

title: Negative numbers addition and subtraction
translated_description: Equivalent expressions with negative numbers

title: Negative numbers addition and subtraction
translated_description: Practice substituting positive and negative values for variables.

title: Negative numbers addition and subtraction
translated_description: Let's get some practice thinking about adding and subtracting variables representing positive and negative numbers on the number line.

title: Negative numbers multiplication and division
translated_description: Learn some rules of thumb for multiplying positive and negative numbers.

title: Negative numbers multiplication and division
translated_description: Discover the basics of dividing with negative numbers.

title: Negative numbers multiplication and division
translated_description: Use the repeated addition model of multiplication to give an understanding of multiplying negative numbers.

title: Negative numbers multiplication and division
translated_description: Use the distributive property to understand the products of negative numbers.

title: Negative numbers multiplication and division
translated_description: Let's think about the meaning of negative numbers in different situations.

title: Negative numbers multiplication and division
translated_description: See examples of multiplying and dividing fractions with negative numbers.

title: Negative numbers multiplication and division
translated_description: Sal finds equivalent expressions to -g/h.

title: Negative numbers multiplication and division
translated_description: Sal shows us how to change mixed numbers into improper fractions  divide  and then change the answer back to a mixed number.

title: Negative numbers multiplication and division
translated_description: Learn how to take complex looking fractions and make them much  much simpler.

title: Negative numbers multiplication and division
translated_description: Learn to compare expressions with positive and negative fractions.

title: Negative numbers multiplication and division
translated_description: Learn to what we know about negative numbers to determine how negative bases with exponents are affected and what patterns develop. Also learn how order of operations affect the pattern.

title: Negative numbers multiplication and division
translated_description: Discover a pattern that explains why any non-zero number to the zero power equals one.

title: Negative numbers multiplication and division
translated_description: We can figure out whether multiplication and division problems give us a positive or negative result by thinking about how many negative numbers are used in the computation.

title: Negative numbers multiplication and division
translated_description: Use odd and even rules to determine the sign of an exponential expression.

title: Negative numbers multiplication and division
translated_description: Some examples that test our understanding of what happens when we multply or divided a bunch of positive or negative numbers.

title: Negative numbers multiplication and division
translated_description: Any non-zero number to the zero power equals one. Zero to any positive exponent equals zero. So  what happens when you have zero to the zero power?

title: Negative numbers multiplication and division
translated_description: As much as we would like to have an answer for "what's 1 divided by 0?" it's sadly impossible to have an answer. The reason  in short  is that whatever we may answer  we will then have to agree that that answer times 0 equals to 1  and that cannot be ​true  because anything times 0 is 0.

title: Negative numbers multiplication and division
translated_description: This example shows the steps and clarifies the purpose of order of operations: to have ONE way to interpret a mathematical statement.

title: Negative numbers multiplication and division
translated_description: Work through a challenging order of operations example with only positive numbers.

title: Negative numbers multiplication and division
translated_description: Simplify this tricky expression using the order of operations.   Expression include negative numbers and exponents.

title: Negative numbers multiplication and division
translated_description: In this video  we figure out whether or not some expressions are equivalent. To do this  we think about properties of multiplication and division.

title: Fractions decimals & percentages
translated_description: Here's an example of how we convert a decimal to a simplified fraction. Over time this will become second nature to you.

title: Fractions decimals & percentages
translated_description: Learn how to write the fraction  7/8 as a decimal.

title: Fractions decimals & percentages
translated_description: Sal writes 11/25 as a decimal.

title: Fractions decimals & percentages
translated_description: Sal writes 16/21 as a rounded decimal.

title: Fractions decimals & percentages
translated_description: Comparing Rational Numbers

title: Fractions decimals & percentages
translated_description: Sal evaluates 79% - 79.1 - 58 1/10.

title: Fractions decimals & percentages
translated_description: Sal evaluates 0.79 - 4/3 - 1/2 + 150%.

title: Fractions decimals & percentages
translated_description: In this example we grow a whole number by a percentage of itself. Growing by percentage is a common skill often used when figuring how much is owed or earned with interest.

title: Fractions decimals & percentages
translated_description: We'll use algebra to solve this percent problem.

title: Fractions decimals & percentages
translated_description: This word problem is expressed simply which can be confusing to some. Take your time and focus on the what is being asked for.

title: Fractions decimals & percentages
translated_description: In this example  you working with us to find the number that is expressed as a given percentage. We'll create a simple algebraic equation to solve!

title: Fractions decimals & percentages
translated_description: First visualize this word problem then use subtraction and multiplication of decimals and fractions to get at the answer.

title: Fractions decimals & percentages
translated_description: Remember units of measurement? Convert minutes into hours and put your knowledge of fractions to work in this word problem.

title: Fractions decimals & percentages
translated_description: Budgeting money is one of the most valuable math skills you'll learn. Practice with us as we figure out how much money is left after a cab fare.

title: Fractions decimals & percentages
translated_description: Word problems force us to put concepts to work using real-world applications. In this example  determine the volume of frozen water and express the answer as a fraction.

title: Fractions decimals & percentages
translated_description: In this word problem  we'll compare the weight of two objects using a ratio of integers. We'll practice simplifying a fraction  too.

title: Fractions decimals & percentages
translated_description: Use your knowledge of proportions and fractions to determine shareholders profit in this word problem.

title: Fractions decimals & percentages
translated_description: Your checking account is overdrawn. Not good. Use your knowledge of decimals and adding negative and positive numbers to bring your account back into the black.

title: Rates & proportional relationships
translated_description: Sal solves an example problem with rates with fractions.

title: Rates & proportional relationships
translated_description: Sal introduces the idea of a proportional relationship by looking at tables of values.

title: Rates & proportional relationships
translated_description: Sal answers the question by drawing a square and thinking about the relationship between side length and perimeter.

title: Rates & proportional relationships
translated_description: Sal answers the question by drawing a square and thinking about the relationship between side length and area.

title: Rates & proportional relationships
translated_description: Given a table of ratios  watch as we test them for equivalence and determine whether the relationship is proportional.

title: Rates & proportional relationships
translated_description: When going to the movies  is the price you pay proportional to the number of tickets you buy?

title: Rates & proportional relationships
translated_description: A proportionality problem about eating bananas

title: Rates & proportional relationships
translated_description: Learn how to tell proportional relationships by drawing graphs. Key idea: the graph of a proportional relationship is a straight line through the origin.

title: Rates & proportional relationships
translated_description: Learn the reasoning behind solving proportions. We'll put some algebra to work to get our answers  too.

title: Rates & proportional relationships
translated_description: Some examples of writing two ratios and setting them equal to each other to solve proportion word problems.

title: Rates & proportional relationships
translated_description: A recipe for oatmeal cookies calls for 2 cups of flour for every 3 cups of oatmeal. How much flour is needed for a big batch of cookies that uses 9 cups of oatmeal?

title: Rates & proportional relationships
translated_description: Mika can eat 21 hot dogs in 66 minutes. She wants to know how many minutes it would take her to eat 35 hot dogs if she can keep up the same pace.

title: Rates & proportional relationships
translated_description: Learn how to write a proportional equation y=kx where k is the so-called "constant of proportionality".

title: Rates & proportional relationships
translated_description: Writing an equation to describe the relationship between the number of scoops in an ice cream cone and the price

title: Rates & proportional relationships
translated_description: Learn how to read and understand graphs of proportional relationships

title: Expressions equations & inequalities
translated_description: In simple addition we learned to add all the numbers together to get a sum. In algebra  numbers are sometimes attached to variables and we need to make sure that the variables are alike before we add the numbers.

title: Expressions equations & inequalities
translated_description: We've learned about order of operations and combining like terms. Let's layer the distributive property on top of this.

title: Expressions equations & inequalities
translated_description: This example of combining like terms in an expression get a little hairy. Listen closely.

title: Expressions equations & inequalities
translated_description: Learn how to simplify algebraic expressions by combining like terms. The expressions in this video have decimal and fraction coefficients.

title: Expressions equations & inequalities
translated_description: Learn how to apply the distributive property to factor out the greatest common factor from an algebraic expression like 2+4x.

title: Expressions equations & inequalities
translated_description: Sal shows how to factor the expression 4x+18 into the expression 2(2x+9).

title: Expressions equations & inequalities
translated_description: Learn how to identify equivalent expressions using your knowledge of the distributive property and negative numbers.

title: Expressions equations & inequalities
translated_description: We match the expressions to their meaning in this example. We're reinforcing our knowledge of linear expressions.

title: Expressions equations & inequalities
translated_description: Let's practice matching expressions to their meaning in this example of interpreting linear expressions.

title: Expressions equations & inequalities
translated_description: The example of a scale where we try to achieve balance helps to explain why we do the same thing to both sides of an equation.

title: Expressions equations & inequalities
translated_description: Here's how we solve a two step equation. It begins with the concept of equality: what we do to one side of the equation must be done to the other.

title: Expressions equations & inequalities
translated_description: This example demonstrates how we solve an equation expressed such: ax + b = c. It's a little more complicated than previous examples  but you can do it!

title: Expressions equations & inequalities
translated_description: Sal solves the equation -16 = x/4 + 2. It takes two steps because he first has to subtract 2 from both sides and then multiply both sides by 4.

title: Expressions equations & inequalities
translated_description: Learn how to solve equations that involve decimals and fractions. The equations shown in this video are called "two-step" equations because they each take two steps to solve.

title: Expressions equations & inequalities
translated_description: Let's practice some two step equations  some of which require merging terms and using the distributive property.

title: Expressions equations & inequalities
translated_description: When doing algebra  we sometimes make mistakes! It's important to be able to check our own work (and other people's work) for correctness.

title: Expressions equations & inequalities
translated_description: Learn how to construct and solve a basic linear equation to solve a word problem.

title: Expressions equations & inequalities
translated_description: Here's a nifty word problem in which we find the dimensions of a garden given only the perimeter. Let's create an equation to solve!

title: Expressions equations & inequalities
translated_description: Learn how to solve a word problem by writing an equation to model the situation. In this video  we use the linear equation 210(t-5) = 41 790.

title: Expressions equations & inequalities
translated_description: Our discussion of linear inequalities begins with multiplying and dividing by negative numbers. Listen closely for the word "swap." Super important!

title: Expressions equations & inequalities
translated_description: In addition to solving the inequality  we'll graph the solution. Remember to swap if you mutiply both sides of the inequality by a negative number.

title: Expressions equations & inequalities
translated_description: Inequalities are more than abstract concepts and exercises. They help solve real life problems. Here's an example.

title: Expressions equations & inequalities
translated_description: Two-step inequalities are slightly more complicated than one-step inequalities (duh!). This is a worked example of solving ⅔>-4y-8⅓.

title: Expressions equations & inequalities
translated_description: We'll talk you through this fun and challenging inequality problem.

title: Expressions equations & inequalities
translated_description: Let's tackle this word problem together. We'll interpret the information and then construct a linear inequality to solve it.

title: Geometry
translated_description: Learn how the number Pi allows us to relate the radius  diameter  and circumference of a circle.

title: Geometry
translated_description: Radius  diameter  center  and circumference--all are parts of a circle. Let's go through each and understand how they are defined.

title: Geometry
translated_description: Sal finds the radius and diameter of a circle given the circumference.

title: Geometry
translated_description: The area of a circle is pi times the radius squared (A = π r²). Learn how to use this formula to find the area of a circle when given the diameter.

title: Geometry
translated_description: Learn how to find the circumference  the distance around a circle  when given the area.

title: Geometry
translated_description: Here's a fun one: find the area of a shaded region where you first determine the area of a square and then the area of a circle.

title: Geometry
translated_description: If we change the radius of a circle  how does the circumference and area change?

title: Geometry
translated_description: Two rays that share the same endpoint form an angle. Learn about angles and the parts of an angle  like the vertex.

title: Geometry
translated_description: Learn about complementary and supplementary angles  as well as the definitions of adjacent and straight angles.

title: Geometry
translated_description: By using our knowledge of supplementary  adjacent  and vertical angles  we can solve problems involving the intersection of two lines. Including this one!

title: Geometry
translated_description: Given two intersecting lines and the measure of vertical angles  watch as we solve to find the measure of the remaining angles.

title: Geometry
translated_description: Solve this word problem to find the measure of angles. In this example you'll split up a pie (don't forget to share!)

title: Geometry
translated_description: Given the algebraic expressions that represent a pair of complementary angles  learn how to form and solve an equation to find an unknown angle.

title: Geometry
translated_description: Given the algebraic expressions that represent a pair of supplementary angles  Sal forms and solves an equation.

title: Geometry
translated_description: Given algebraic expressions that represent a pair of two vertical angles  Sal forms and solves an equation.

title: Geometry
translated_description: Can you build a triangle that is both a right triangle and an isosceles triangle?

title: Geometry
translated_description: Here's a challenge: in this problem we are given constraints and asked to construct a triangle. It can be done! You'll learn about degenerate triangles  too.

title: Geometry
translated_description: Intuition behind the triangle inequality theorem

title: Geometry
translated_description: Sal first solves a problem where he orders the sides of a triangle given the angles  then solves a problem where he orders the angles of a triangle given the sides.

title: Geometry
translated_description: What happens when you slice vertically into a rectangular pyramid? What kind of geometric shape results?

title: Geometry
translated_description: Understand how a scale drawing is converted into real numbers using the scale factor.

title: Geometry
translated_description: See how we solve a word problem by using a scale drawing and finding the scale factor.

title: Geometry
translated_description: An urban planner needs your help in creating a scale drawing. Let's use our knowledge about scale factor  length  and area to assist.

title: Geometry
translated_description: See if you can find the incremental volume of a ring in cubic inches. You'll need to put to use your knowledge of how to measure volume.

title: Geometry
translated_description: Using the formulas for the volume of triangular prism and cube to solve some solid geometry problems.

title: Geometry
translated_description: How many crates can we fit into a boxcar? We'll explain that there's more than one way to solve for the volume in this problem.

title: Statistics and probability
translated_description: We give you an introduction to probability through the example of flipping a quarter and rolling a die.

title: Statistics and probability
translated_description: In order to find the probability of picking a yellow marble from a bag  we have to first determine the number of possible outcomes  and then how many of them meet our constraints.

title: Statistics and probability
translated_description: In this example we are figuring out the probability of randomly picking a non-blue marble from a bag. Again  we'll have to think about the possible outcomes first.

title: Statistics and probability
translated_description: Based on past experience  we can make reasonable estimates of the likelihood of future events.

title: Statistics and probability
translated_description: Think about what probabilities really mean. What does a probability of 0 mean? How about 1?

title: Statistics and probability
translated_description: Compare expected probabilities to what really happens when we run experiments.

title: Statistics and probability
translated_description: Predict the number of times a spinner will land on an elephant.

title: Statistics and probability
translated_description: Model the probability of a frozen yogurt line having 0  1  or 2 people in it.

title: Statistics and probability
translated_description: Explore the notion of a "sample space". See a sample space represented as a tree diagram  table  and list.

title: Statistics and probability
translated_description: We're thinking about the probability of rolling doubles on a pair of dice. Let's create a grid of all possible outcomes.

title: Statistics and probability
translated_description: Learn how to use sample space diagrams to find probabilities.

title: Statistics and probability
translated_description: Find the number of ways you can put four types of flowers into three types of pots.

title: Statistics and probability
translated_description: Tree diagrams display all the possible outcomes of an event. Each branch in a tree diagram represents a possible outcome. Tree diagrams can be used to find the number of possible outcomes and calculate the probability of possible outcomes.

title: Statistics and probability
translated_description: To make a valid conclusion  you'll need a representaive  not skewed  sample.

title: Statistics and probability
translated_description: Sal examines two distributions in dot plots to draw conclusions about the times of Olympic swimmers.

title: Numbers and operations
translated_description: Learn how to rewrite 19/27 as a repeating decimal. What's a repeating decimal? THAT is a great question. This video explains.

title: Numbers and operations
translated_description: Learn how to convert the repeating decimals 0.77777... and 1.22222... to fractions.

title: Numbers and operations
translated_description: Learn how to convert the repeating decimals 0.363636... and 0.714141414... and 3.257257257... to fractions.

title: Numbers and operations
translated_description: Learn about the square root symbol (the principal root) and what it means to find a square root. Also learn how to solve simple square root equations.

title: Numbers and operations
translated_description: Learn the meaning of cube roots and how to find them. Also learn how to find the cube root of a negative number.

title: Numbers and operations
translated_description: Learn how to find the cube root of -512.

title: Numbers and operations
translated_description: Learn how to find the square root of a decimal number. The problem solved in this video is p^2 = 0.81.

title: Numbers and operations
translated_description: Learn how to find the side length of a cube whose volume is 512 cubic centimeters.

title: Numbers and operations
translated_description: Learn what rational and irrational numbers are and how to tell them apart.

title: Numbers and operations
translated_description: Given a bunch of numbers  learn how to tell which are rational and which are irrational.

title: Numbers and operations
translated_description: Learn how to classify numbers as whole numbers  integers  rational numbers  and irrational numbers.

title: Numbers and operations
translated_description: Deciding which number set 3.4028 belongs to: integers  rationals  or irrationals?

title: Numbers and operations
translated_description: Learn how to find the approximate values of square roots. The examples used in this video are √32  √55  and √123. The technique used is to compare the squares of whole numbers to the number we're taking the square root of.

title: Numbers and operations
translated_description: Learn how to sort a bunch of numbers (4√2  2√3  3√2  √17  3√3  5) from least to greatest without using a calculator.

title: Numbers and operations
translated_description: Learn how to approximate the decimal value of √45 without using a calculator.

title: Numbers and operations
translated_description: Learn how to compare 22.9% to √0.45 using a calculator.

title: Numbers and operations
translated_description: Learn how to simplify expressions like (5^6)/(5^2). Also learn how 1/(a^b) is the same as a^-b. Towards the end of the video  we practice simplifying more complex expressions like (25 * x * y^6)/(20 * y^5 * x^2).

title: Numbers and operations
translated_description: Learn two exponent properties: (ab)^c and (a^b)^c. See WHY they work and HOW to use them.

title: Numbers and operations
translated_description: Learn how to simplify expressions like (5^6)/(5^2). Also learn how 1/(a^b) is the same as a^-b. Towards the end of the video  we practice simplifying more complex expressions like (25 * x * y^6)/(20 * y^5 * x^2).

title: Numbers and operations
translated_description: Learn how to rewrite expressions with negative exponents as fractions with positive exponents.

title: Numbers and operations
translated_description: Intuition on why a^-b = 1/(a^b) (and why a^0 =1)

title: Numbers and operations
translated_description: For any base a and for any exponents n and m  aⁿ⋅aᵐ=aⁿ⁺ᵐ and aⁿ/aᵐ=aⁿ⁻ᵐ. These are worked examples for using these properties with integer exponents.

title: Numbers and operations
translated_description: For any integers a and b and for any exponents n  (a⋅b)ⁿ=aⁿ⋅bⁿ and (a/b)ⁿ=aⁿ/bⁿ. These are worked examples for using these properties with integer exponents.

title: Numbers and operations
translated_description: Any non-zero number to the zero power equals one. Zero to any positive exponent equals zero. So  what happens when you have zero to the zero power?

title: Numbers and operations
translated_description: Learn how to multiply (9 * 10^9) (-2 * 10^-3).

title: Numbers and operations
translated_description: Learn how to approximate how much larger the world population was than the US population in 2014.

title: Numbers and operations
translated_description: Can you imagine if you had to do calculations with very  very small numbers? How would you handle all those zeros to the right of the decimal? Thank goodness for scientific notation!

title: Numbers and operations
translated_description: Scientific notation is a way of writing very large or very small numbers. A number is written in scientific notation when a number between 1 and 10 is multiplied by a power of 10. For example  650 000 000 can be written in scientific notation as 6.5 ✕ 10^8.

title: Numbers and operations
translated_description: Learn how to simplify a multiplication and division expression using scientific notation. The expression in this problem is (7 * 10^5) / ((2 * 10^-2)(2.5 * 10^9)).

title: Numbers and operations
translated_description: Multiplying really big or really small numbers is much easier when using scientific notation. This video gives an example of multiplying three numbers that are written in scientific notation.

title: Numbers and operations
translated_description: Learn how to subtract numbers written in scientific notation. The problem solved in this video is (4.1 * 10^-2) - (2.6 * 10^-3).

title: Numbers and operations
translated_description: Sal simplifies a very hairy expression in scientific notation.

title: Numbers and operations
translated_description: Vampires and math students want to know: How many red blood cells are in the a human body? We can find the answer using scientific notation.

title: Numbers and operations
translated_description: Ever wonder what your part of the national debt is? It might surprise you. What isn't surprising is that you can use scientific notation and division to figure out the answer.

title: Numbers and operations
translated_description: Amazingly  we can figure out how far the sun is from the earth if we know how to multiply numbers in scientific notation.

title: Solving equations with one unknown
translated_description: Worked example: Learn to solve the equation 2x + 3 = 5x - 2.

title: Solving equations with one unknown
translated_description: Sal solves the equation 20 - 7x = 6x - 6.

title: Solving equations with one unknown
translated_description: Sal solves the equation (3/4)x + 2 = (3/8)x - 4.

title: Solving equations with one unknown
translated_description: Sal solves the equation 7 - 10/x = 2 + 15/x.

title: Solving equations with one unknown
translated_description: Sal solves the equation -9 - (9x - 6) = 3(4x + 6) using the distributive property.

title: Solving equations with one unknown
translated_description: See how some equations have one solution  others have no solutions  and still others have infinite solutions.

title: Solving equations with one unknown
translated_description: Sal attempts to solve 8(3x + 10) = 28x - 14 - 4x only to find that the equation has no solution.

title: Solving equations with one unknown
translated_description: Sal shows how to complete the equation -11x + 4 = __x + __ so that it has no solutions.

title: Solving equations with one unknown
translated_description: Sal shows how to complete the equation 4(x - 2) + x = 5x + __ so that it has infinitely many solutions.

title: Solving equations with one unknown
translated_description: Sal solves the following age word problem: The sum of 4 consecutive odd integers is 136. What are the 4 integers?

title: Solving equations with one unknown
translated_description: Sal solves the following problem: The sum of three consecutive odd integers is 231. What is the largest integer?

title: Solving equations with one unknown
translated_description: Given information about the lengths of line segments  Sal forms and solves an equation in order to find the lengths of the segments.

title: Solving equations with one unknown
translated_description: Given an information about the distance of a segment's midpoint from its endpoints  Sal forms and solves an equation in order to find the length of the segment.

title: Solving equations with one unknown
translated_description: Given algebraic expressions that represent a pair of two vertical angles  Sal forms and solves an equation.

title: Solving equations with one unknown
translated_description: Given the algebraic expressions that represent a pair of complementary angles  learn how to form and solve an equation to find an unknown angle.

title: Solving equations with one unknown
translated_description: Given the algebraic expressions that represent a pair of supplementary angles  Sal forms and solves an equation.

title: Linear equations and functions
translated_description: Sal compares a rate given in an equation to a rate shown on a graph.

title: Linear equations and functions
translated_description: Sal chooses equations that give a faster rate than the relationship given in a table.

title: Linear equations and functions
translated_description: Sal graphs the equation of a line that represents a proportional relationship given a unit rate.

title: Linear equations and functions
translated_description: Sal graphs the equation of a line that represents a proportional relationship given a table.

title: Linear equations and functions
translated_description: Sal graphs the equation of a line that represents a proportional relationship given an equation.

title: Linear equations and functions
translated_description: Bridging algebra and geometry. What makes linear equations so linear.

title: Linear equations and functions
translated_description: The coordinate plane is a two-dimension surface formed by two number lines. One number line is horizontal and is called the x-axis. The other number line is vertical number line and is called the y-axis. The two axes meet at a point called the origin. We can use the coordinate plane to graph points  lines  and more.

title: Linear equations and functions
translated_description: Sal figures out which equation was used to generate a table of x and y values.

title: Linear equations and functions
translated_description: Sal creates a graph of the linear equation 5x + 2y = 20.

title: Linear equations and functions
translated_description: Learn how to create a graph of the linear equation y = 2x + 7.

title: Linear equations and functions
translated_description: Sal determines the x-intercept of a linear equation from a graph. Afterwards  he checks his work by plugging values back into the equation.

title: Linear equations and functions
translated_description: Sal finds the y-intercept of the graph of a linear function given a table of values.

title: Linear equations and functions
translated_description: Sal finds the x and y-intercepts of -5x + 4y = 20.

title: Linear equations and functions
translated_description: Sal finds the x and y-intercepts of the equation 2y + 1/3x = 12.

title: Linear equations and functions
translated_description: Sal graphs a line that has a slope that is negative and greater than the slope of another line.

title: Linear equations and functions
translated_description: The slope of a line is rise over run. Learn how to calculate the slope of the line in a graph by finding the change in y and the change in x.

title: Linear equations and functions
translated_description: Sal finds the slope of a line given its graph.

title: Linear equations and functions
translated_description: Find the slope of the line that goes through the ordered pairs (4 2) and (-3  16).

title: Linear equations and functions
translated_description: When two points have the same y-value  it means they lie on a horizontal line. The slope of such a line is 0  and you will also find this by using the slope formula.

title: Linear equations and functions
translated_description: Learn to convert equations like 4x + 2y = -8 into slope-intercept form.

title: Linear equations and functions
translated_description: Slope-intercept form  y=mx+b  of linear equations  emphasizes the slope and the y-intercept of the line. Watch this video to learn more about it and see some examples.

title: Linear equations and functions
translated_description: To graph a linear equation in slope-intercept form  we can use the information given by that form. For example  y=2x+3 tells us that the slope of the line is 2 and the y-intercept is at (0 3). This gives us one point the line goes through  and the direction we should continue from that point to draw the entire line.

title: Linear equations and functions
translated_description: Learn to write equations in slope-intercept form for three different lines.

title: Linear equations and functions
translated_description: Learn how to find the equation of the line with a slope of -3/4 that goes through the point (0 8).

title: Linear equations and functions
translated_description: Learn how to find the equation of the line that goes through the points (-1  6) and (5  -4).

title: Linear equations and functions
translated_description: Learn how to write an equation of the line that matches up to a table of values.

title: Linear equations and functions
translated_description: Learn how to solve problems involving writing an equation in slope-intercept form.

title: Linear equations and functions
translated_description: Functions assign a single unique output for each of their inputs. In this video  we see examples of various kinds of functions.

title: Linear equations and functions
translated_description: Learn how to evaluate f(x)=49-x² at x=5.

title: Linear equations and functions
translated_description: Evaluating a function at x=-1 using the graph of that function.

title: Linear equations and functions
translated_description: Sal uses function notation to help Frank figure out how much water he can put in his balloon.

title: Linear equations and functions
translated_description: Equations and functions are not the same thing  but they can be related in several ways. Watch Jesse Roe and Sal talk about the difference between equations and functions

title: Linear equations and functions
translated_description: Sal takes the formula for converting from Fahrenheit temperature to Celsius  and solves it for F so it serves to convert from Celsius to Fahrenheit.

title: Linear equations and functions
translated_description: Sal is given the formula of a linear function and the graph of another  and is asked to determine which function increases faster.

title: Linear equations and functions
translated_description: Sal is given a table of values of a linear function and four linear graphs  and is asked to determine which graph has the same rate of change as the function represented in the table.

title: Linear equations and functions
translated_description: Sal is given a table of values of a linear function and four linear graphs  and is asked to determine which graph increases faster than the function represented in the table.

title: Linear equations and functions
translated_description: Sal discusses how we would go about making sense of the direction of a linear graph that represents a relationship between two real-world quantities.

title: Linear equations and functions
translated_description: Sal finds the y-intercept and the slope of a linear relationship representing someone accumulating cats! He then interprets what the y-intercept and the slope mean in that context.

title: Linear equations and functions
translated_description: Sal finds the y-intercept and the slope of a linear relationship representing someone climbing a volcano. He then interprets what the y-intercept and the slope mean in that context.

title: Linear equations and functions
translated_description: Sal finds the slope of a linear relationship between the number of work hours and the money earned. He then interprets what this slope means in that context.

title: Linear equations and functions
translated_description: Sal uses a linear equation to model the amount of snow on the ground.

translated_description: Sal is given the formula and a table of values that represent two people climbing a wall  and is asked to determine which one started out higher.

translated_description: Sal is given a table of values that represents four people walking to school  and is asked to determine which one started out farther from the school.

title: Linear equations and functions
translated_description: Sal is given a table of values that represents a person walking to work  and is asked to determine which verbal description represents someone starting at the same distance from work.

title: Linear equations and functions
translated_description: Sal solves an interesting application problem using a linear model.

title: Linear equations and functions
translated_description: Constructing linear equations to solve word problems

title: Linear equations and functions
translated_description: Sal creates a scatter plot and then fits a line to data on the median California family income.

title: Linear equations and functions
translated_description: Learn to determine if points on a graph represent a function.

title: Linear equations and functions
translated_description: Learn to determine if a relation given by a set of ordered pairs is a function.

title: Linear equations and functions
translated_description: Checking whether a given set of points can represent a function. For the set to represent a function  each domain element must have one corresponding range element at most.

title: Linear equations and functions
translated_description: Sal determines if y is a function of x from looking at a table.

title: Linear equations and functions
translated_description: Checking whether y can be described as a function of x if y is always three more than twice x.

translated_description: Checking whether a table of people and their heights can represent a function that assigns a height to a name.

title: Linear equations and functions
translated_description: Checking whether a description of the price of an order can be represented as a function of the shipping cost.

title: Linear equations and functions
translated_description: Sal determines if y is a function of x from looking at an equation.

title: Linear equations and functions
translated_description: Explaining why a vertical line doesn't represent a function.

title: Linear equations and functions
translated_description: Learn to recognize if a function is linear.

title: Linear equations and functions
translated_description: Learn to determine if a table of values represents a linear function.

title: Linear equations and functions
translated_description: Learn to determine if the relationship described in a word problem is a function.

title: Linear equations and functions
translated_description: Learn to find the missing value in a table to make sure it represents a linear equation.

title: Linear equations and functions
translated_description: Learn to interpret the graphs of a linear functions.

title: Systems of equations
translated_description: A troll forces us to use algebra to figure out the make-up of his currency. We end up setting up a system of equations.

title: Systems of equations
translated_description: Solving the system of equations visually. Now we can save the prince/princess.

title: Systems of equations
translated_description: Sal uses simple elimination to figure out how many cupcakes are eaten by children and adults.

title: Systems of equations
translated_description: Sal solves another system of equations using elimination.

title: Systems of equations
translated_description: To solve a system of equations using substitution...
column9: 1. Isolate one of the variables in one of the equations  e.g. rewrite 2x+y=3 as y=3-2x.
column10: 2. You can now express the isolated variable using the other one. *Substitute* that expression into the second equation  e.g. rewrite x+2y=5 as x+2(3-2x)=5.
column11: 3. Now you have an equation with one variable! Solve it  and use what you got to find the other variable.

title: Systems of equations
translated_description: Sal gives an example of a system of equations that has no solution!

title: Systems of equations
translated_description: Sal gives an example of a system of equations that has infinite solutions!

title: Systems of equations
translated_description: A troll forces us to use algebra to figure out the make-up of his currency. We end up setting up a system of equations.

title: Systems of equations
translated_description: Solving the system of equations visually. Now we can save the prince/princess.

title: Systems of equations
translated_description: Sal checks whether (-1 7) is a solution of the system: x+2y=13 and 3x-y=-11.

title: Systems of equations
translated_description: Sal shows how to solve a system of linear equations by graphing and looking for the point of intersection.

title: Systems of equations
translated_description: Sal solves the system of equations 5x + 3y = 7 and 3x - 2y = 8 by graphing.

title: Systems of equations
translated_description: Sal graphs the following system of equations and solves it by looking for the intersection point: y=7/5x-5 and y=3/5x-1.

title: Systems of equations
translated_description: Graphical Systems Application Problem

title: Systems of equations
translated_description: Sal solves the system of equations 3t + 4g = 6 and -6t + g = 6 using elimination.

title: Systems of equations
translated_description: Learn to use elimination to solve the system of equations x + 2y = 6 and 4x - 2y = 14.

translated_description: Sal solves the system of equations -3y + 4x = 11 and y + 2x = 13 using elimination.

title: Systems of equations
translated_description: Sal solves the system of equations 2x - y = 14 and -6x + 3y = -42 using elimination.

translated_description: Sal solves the system of equations 4x - 2y = 5 and 2x - y = 2.5 using elimination.

translated_description: Sal solves the following system of equations by eliminating x: x-4y=-18 and -x+3y=11.

translated_description: Sal solves the system of equations 6x - 6y = -24 and -5x - 5y = -60 using elimination.

translated_description: Learn to use substitution to solve the system of equations 2y = x + 7 and x = y - 4.

translated_description: Learn to solve the system of equations y = 4x - 17.5 and y + 2x = 6.5 using substitution.

translated_description: Learn to solve the system of equations -3x - 4y = -2 and y = 2x - 5 using substitution.

title: Systems of equations
translated_description: Learn to solve the system of equations 9x + 3y = 15 and y - x = 5 using substitution.
