translated_description: Learn to solve the system of equations y = -5x + 8 and 10x + 2y = -2 using substitution.

title: Systems of equations
translated_description: Learn to sol the system of equations y = -1/4x + 100 and y = -1/4x + 120 using substitution.

title: Systems of equations
translated_description: Sal gives an example of a system of equations that has no solution!

title: Systems of equations
translated_description: Sal gives an example of a system of equations that has infinite solutions!

title: Systems of equations
translated_description: A consistent system of equations has at least one solution  and an inconsistent system has no solution. Watch an example of analyzing a system to see if it's consistent or inconsistent.

title: Systems of equations
translated_description: A dependent system of equations has infinite solutions  and an independent system has a single solution. Watch an example of analyzing a system to see if it's dependent or independent.

title: Systems of equations
translated_description: Sal is given three lines on the coordinate plane  and identifies one system of two lines that has a single solution  and one system that has no solution.

title: Systems of equations
translated_description: Sal determines how many solutions the following system of equations has by considering its graph: 10x-2y=4 and 10x-2y=16.

title: Systems of equations
translated_description: Sal solves several examples where he reasons about the number of solutions of systems of equations using algebraic reasoning.

title: Systems of equations
translated_description: Sal answers this question for you!

title: Systems of equations
translated_description: Sal solves the following age word problem: In 40 years  Imran will be 11 times as old as he is right now. How old is he right now?

title: Systems of equations
translated_description: Sal solves the following age word problem: William is 4 times as old as Ben. 12 years ago  William was 7 times as old as Ben. How old is Ben now?

title: Systems of equations
translated_description: Sal solves the following age word problem: Arman is 18. Diya is 2. How many years will it take for Arman to be 3 times as old as Diya?

title: Systems of equations
translated_description: Systems of equations can be used to solve many real-world problems. In this video  we solve a problem about distances walking and riding bus to school.

title: Systems of equations
translated_description: Systems of equations can be used to solve many real-world problems. In this video  we solve a problem about a toy factory. In this case  the problem has no viable solution  which means the information describes an impossible situation.

title: Systems of equations
translated_description: Systems of equations can be used to solve many real-world problems. In this video  we solve a problem about a vegetable framer. In this case  the problem has infinite solutions  which means there's not enough information to find a single solution.

title: Systems of equations
translated_description: Sal solves a word problem about the weights of TVs and DVDs by creating a system of equations and solving it.

title: Systems of equations
translated_description: Sal solves a word problem about the price of apples and oranges by creating a system of equations and solving it.

title: Systems of equations
translated_description: Sal solves a word problem about the number of nickels and quarters in a piggy bank by creating a system of equations and solving it.

title: Systems of equations
translated_description: Sal solves a word problem about the price of coffee and croissant by creating a system of equations and solving it.

title: Geometry
translated_description: Learn about parallel lines  transversals  and the angles they form.

title: Geometry
translated_description: Parallel lines are lines in a plane that are always the same distance apart. Parallel lines never intersect. Perpendicular lines are lines that intersect at a right (90 degrees) angle.

title: Geometry
translated_description: Learn how to find missing angle measurements in a figure with two parallel lines and a transversal.

title: Geometry
translated_description: Sal solves an equation to find missing angles given two parallel lines and a transversal.

title: Geometry
translated_description: Learn the formal proof that shows the measures of interior angles of a triangle sum to 180°.

title: Geometry
translated_description: Three example problems involving isosceles and equilateral triangles (partly taken from Art of Problem Solving  by Richard Rusczyk).

title: Geometry
translated_description: Learn about the angles in a triangle and a little about exterior angles being the sum of the remote interior angles.

title: Geometry
translated_description: Worked examples finding angles in triangles formed by intersecting lines

title: Geometry
translated_description: Worked examples finding angles in triangles that are part of diagrams

title: Geometry
translated_description: Interesting problem finding the sums of particular exterior angles of an irregular pentagon

title: Geometry
translated_description: Example of angle hunting!

title: Geometry
translated_description: Sal introduces the famous and super important Pythagorean theorem!

title: Geometry
translated_description: Sal uses the Pythagorean theorem to find the height of a right triangle with a base of 9 and a hypotenuse of 14.

title: Geometry
translated_description: Sal uses the Pythagorean theorem to find a missing side length in an isosceles triangle.

title: Geometry
translated_description: Sal uses the Pythagorean theorem to find area of an isosceles triangle.

title: Geometry
translated_description: Sal uses the Pythagorean theorem to find the width of some carpet.

title: Geometry
translated_description: Sal uses the Pythagorean theorem to solve a word problem about a fishing boat.

title: Geometry
translated_description: Learn how to find the distance between two points by using the distance formula  which is an application of the Pythagorean theorem.

title: Geometry
translated_description: James Garfield's proof of the Pythagorean Theorem.

title: Geometry
translated_description: An elegant visual proof of the Pythagorean Theorem developed by the 12th century Indian mathematician Bhaskara.

title: Geometry
translated_description: Proof of the Pythagorean Theorem using similarity

title: Geometry
translated_description: Visually proving the Pythagorean Theorem

title: Geometry
translated_description: A cylinder's volume is π r² h  and its surface area is 2π r h + 2π r². Learn how to use these formulas to solve an example problem.

title: Geometry
translated_description: The formula for the volume of a sphere is V = 4/3 πr³. See the formula used in an example where we are given the diameter of the sphere.

title: Geometry
translated_description: The formula for the volume of a cone is V=1/3hπr². Learn how to use this formula to solve an example problem.

title: Geometry
translated_description: Sal shows how to perform a translation on a triangle using our interactive widget!

title: Geometry
translated_description: Learn what the "image" of a transformations is  what are the rigid transformations  and which transformations are not rigid.

title: Geometry
translated_description: Sal shows how to perform a rotation on a pentagon using our interactive widget!

title: Geometry
translated_description: Learn what the "image" of a transformations is  what are the rigid transformations  and which transformations are not rigid.

title: Geometry
translated_description: Sal shows how to perform a reflection on a quadrilateral using our interactive widget!

title: Geometry
translated_description: Sal shows that a given pair of pentagons are congruent by mapping one onto the other using rigid transformations.

title: Geometry
translated_description: Sal shows that a given pair of pentagons are not congruent by showing it's not possible to map one onto the other using rigid transformations.

title: Geometry
translated_description: Sal is given a triangle on the coordinate plane and he draws the image of the triangle under a dilation with scale factor 1/2 about the origin.

title: Geometry
translated_description: Sal is given pairs of polygons  and then he determines whether they are similar by trying to map one onto the other using angle-preserving transformations.

title: Geometry
translated_description: Sal dilates a shape and then compares the side lengths of the pre-image and image.

title: Data and modeling
translated_description: Sal shows how to construct a scatter plot.

title: Data and modeling
translated_description: Sal answers a question about scatter plots that show the relationship between study time  shoe size  and test score.

title: Data and modeling
translated_description: Sal chooses the scatter plot that shows that smoking rate drops by 0.5 point each year.

title: Data and modeling
translated_description: Sal solves a problem where he has to estimate the line of best fit for a scatter plot.

title: Data and modeling
translated_description: Sal estimates the percentage of American adults who smoked in 1945 using a scatter plot.

title: Data and modeling
translated_description: Sal interprets a trend line that shows the relationship between study time and math test score for Shira.

title: Data and modeling
translated_description: Sal uses a Venn diagram to introduce two-way frequency tables.

title: Data and modeling
translated_description: Worked example video where we are asked to find a two-way table of column relative frequencies.

title: Data and modeling
translated_description: Learn how to read two-way tables.

title: Intro to biology
translated_description: Overview of biology  the study of life.

title: Intro to biology
translated_description: How the scientific method is used to ask questions and test explanations.

title: Chemistry of life
translated_description: How elements relate to atoms. The basics of how protons  electrons  and neutrons make up an atom.

title: Chemistry of life
translated_description: Learn how atoms are made up of protons  neutrons  and electrons. Elements are defined by the atomic number  the number of protons in the nucleus. The mass of an atom is determined by the total number of protons and neutrons.

title: Chemistry of life
translated_description: Introduction to orbitals. Relates energy shell to rows and periods in the periodic table.

title: Chemistry of life
translated_description: How electron configuration is related to orbitals and the structure of the periodic table.

title: Chemistry of life
translated_description: How to get Lewis structures from electron configuration  and how valence electrons are involved in forming bonds.

title: Chemistry of life
translated_description: What is a group in the periodic table  and what do elements in a group have in common?

title: Chemistry of life
translated_description: There are three major types of chemical bonds: ionic  covalent  and metallic. Ionic bonds form due to the transfer of an electron from one atom to another. Covalent bonds involve the sharing of electrons between two atoms. Metallic bonds are formed by the attraction between metal ions and delocalized  or "free" electrons.

title: Chemistry of life
translated_description: Defines electronegativity and compares to electron affinity. Explains group and period trends in electronegativity using atomic radii.

title: Chemistry of life
translated_description: Electronegativity differences in bonding using the Pauling scale. Classifying bonds as covalent  polar covalent  or ionic.

title: Chemistry of life
translated_description: Different types of intermolecular forces (forces between molecules).

title: Chemistry of life
translated_description: Reactants and products in reversible and irreversible chemical reactions.

title: Water acids and bases
translated_description: Hydrogen bonding in water.

title: Water acids and bases
translated_description: Water as a solvent. Polar solutes. Hydrophilic and hydrophobic substances.

title: Water acids and bases
translated_description: How capillary action and the meniscus are related to intermolecular forces in water.

title: Water acids and bases
translated_description: Surface tension in water  and how the surface tension is related to hydrogen bonding.

title: Water acids and bases
translated_description: LeBron asks Sal why sweating helps cool the body down.

title: Water acids and bases
translated_description: Evaporative cooling. Why sweating cools you down.

title: Water acids and bases
translated_description: Heat of vaporization of water and ethanol.

title: Water acids and bases
translated_description: Specific heat of water. A calorie as the specific heat of water. How water moderates temperature.

title: Water acids and bases
translated_description: Water less dense as ice. Why lakes don't freeze solid.

title: Water acids and bases
translated_description: Autoionization of water into hydronium and hydroxide ions.

title: Water acids and bases
translated_description: Arrhenius definition of acids and bases.

title: Water acids and bases
translated_description: Bronsted-Lowry definition of acids and bases. Conjugate acids and bases.

title: Water acids and bases
translated_description: Introduction to pH and the pH scale. Examples of calculating pH of pure water  bleach  and orange juice.

title: Water acids and bases
translated_description: Introduction to buffer systems  which regulate pH in blood.

title: Properties of carbon
translated_description: Carbon as a building block of life.

title: Properties of carbon
translated_description: Could silicon play a role similar to carbon's in supporting life?

title: Properties of carbon
translated_description: Representing structures of organic molecules using line (or line-angle) diagrams.

title: Properties of carbon
translated_description: Hydrocarbon overview.

title: Properties of carbon
translated_description: Structural isomers  stereoisomers  geometric isomers  cis-trans isomers  and enantiomers.

title: Properties of carbon
translated_description: Hydroxyl  sulfhydryl  carbonyl  carboxyl  amino and phosphate groups. Alcohols and thiols.

title: Macromolecules
translated_description: Molecular structure of glucose. Monosaccharide structure. Linear and ring forms.

title: Macromolecules
translated_description: Dehydration synthesis (condensation reaction) between sugar molecules. Monosaccharides  disaccharides  and polysaccharides. Formation of maltose from glucose monomers.

title: Macromolecules
translated_description: How hydrolysis can break down polysaccharides (carbohydrates) like starch  cellulose  chitin and glycogen.

title: Macromolecules
translated_description: Fructose in comparison with glucose. Pyranose and furanose rings. Sucrose made from glucose and fructose.

title: Macromolecules
translated_description: Understanding how a triglyceride (triacylglycerol) can be formed from a glycerol molecule and three fatty acids.

title: Macromolecules
translated_description: Saturated fats  unsaturated fats  and trans fats.

title: Macromolecules
translated_description: Types of lipids including fats  waxes  steroids and phospholipids.

title: Macromolecules
translated_description: Learn about DNA (deoxyribonucleic acid). Overview of DNA bases  complementary base pairing  and the structure of the double helix.

title: Macromolecules
translated_description: How DNA is copied (replication). How information in DNA can be used to make a protein.

title: Macromolecules
translated_description: Molecular structure of DNA. Nucleotide. Nitrogenous base  phosphate.

title: Macromolecules
translated_description: DNA is composed of two strands of nucleotides held together by hydrogen bonding. The strands each run from 5' to 3' and run in antiparallel  or opposite  directions from one another.

title: Macromolecules
translated_description: Molecular structure of RNA.

title: Macromolecules
translated_description: Amino acids and the central dogma of molecular biology. Amino and carboxyl groups  side chains  and zwitterions.

title: Macromolecules
translated_description: How amino acids form peptide bonds (peptide linkages) through a condensation reaction (dehydration synthesis).

title: Macromolecules
translated_description: Primary  secondary  tertiary and quaternary protein structure. Beta pleated sheets and alpha helices.

title: Macromolecules
translated_description: How side chain interactions can impact the tertiary structure of proteins.

title: Energy and enzymes
translated_description: Overview of metabolism  anabolism  and catabolism.

title: Energy and enzymes
translated_description: Energy is defined as the ability to do work. Energy can be found in many things and can take different forms. For example  kinetic energy is the energy of motion  and potential energy is energy due to an object's position or structure. Energy is never lost  but it can be converted from one form to another.

title: Energy and enzymes
translated_description: Energy cannot be created or destroyed. It can only be transferred or converted from one form to another.

title: Energy and enzymes
translated_description: Introduction to entropy  and how entropy relates to the number of possible states for a system.

title: Energy and enzymes
translated_description: The Second Law of Thermodynamics: there can be no spontaneous transfer of heat from cold to hot.

title: Energy and enzymes
translated_description: Second Law of Thermodynamics and entropy: the entropy of the universe constantly increases.

title: Energy and enzymes
translated_description: Why heat increases entropy—even though some of it can do work!

title: Energy and enzymes
translated_description: Gibbs free energy and spontaneous reactions.

title: Energy and enzymes
translated_description: Endergonic  exergonic  exothermic  and endothermic reactions.

title: Energy and enzymes
translated_description: Learn more about ATP: how it stores energy  and how that energy is released when it's converted to ADP and phosphate.

title: Energy and enzymes
translated_description: ATP hydrolysis mechanism. How energy is released when ATP is converted to ADP and phosphate.

title: Energy and enzymes
translated_description: Reaction coupling to create glucose-6-phosphate.

title: Energy and enzymes
translated_description: Kinetics is the study of reaction rates and how they are affected. Many factors  such as concentration  pressure  temperature  and enzyme activity  can impact the rate of a reaction. For example  a molecule's kinetic energy is directly proportional to its temperature  so increasing the temperature will result in an increase in reaction rate.

title: Energy and enzymes
translated_description: Enzymes as catalysts for reactions in biological systems; discussion of substrates  active sites  induced fit  and activation energy.

title: Energy and enzymes
translated_description: The cofactors and coenzymes (organic cofactors) that help enzymes catalyze reactions.

title: Energy and enzymes
translated_description: Seeing how an inhibitor can "compete" for an enzyme with the intended substrate.

title: Energy and enzymes
translated_description: Seeing how a noncompetitive inhibitor can bind whether or not the substrate is bound  and vice versa.

title: Structure of a cell
translated_description: Thinking about how large a cell is compared to viruses  proteins and simple molecules.

title: Structure of a cell
translated_description: Introduction to cell theory. Roles of Hooke  Leeuwenhoek and others in its development.

title: Structure of a cell
translated_description: Thinking about the limiting factors of cell size. Focus on volume to surface area ratio.

title: Structure of a cell
translated_description: Prokaryotic and eukaryotic cells. Bacteria and archaea.

title: Structure of a cell
translated_description: Structure of the endoplasmic reticulum and Golgi body (Golgi apparatus). Their role in protein secretion.

title: Structure of a cell
translated_description: An overview of the membrane-bound structures that form the endomembrane system in eukaryotic cells.

title: Structure of a cell
translated_description: The structure and role of mitochondria (plural for mitochondrion). Outer membrane  inner membrane  cristae  porins  etc.

title: Structure of a cell
translated_description: Exploring the cell cytoskeleton  including microfilaments and microtubules (with a brief mention of intermediate filaments).

title: Structure of a cell
translated_description: Overview of how cells interact with the extracellular matrix.

title: Structure of a cell
translated_description: Understanding the structure of plant cell walls.

title: Structure of a cell
translated_description: Overview of animal and plant cells. Topics include cell walls  vacuoles  chloroplasts  peroxisomes  lysosomes  mitochondria  etc.

title: Membranes and transport
translated_description: The fluid mosaic model describes the cell membrane as a tapestry of several types of molecules (phospholipids  cholesterols  and proteins) that are constantly moving. This movement helps the cell membrane maintain its role as a barrier between the inside and outside of the cell environments.

title: Membranes and transport
translated_description: Learn about how particles move from an area of greater concentration to an area of lesser concentration through the process of diffusion.

title: Membranes and transport
translated_description: A concentration gradient occurs when the concentration of particles is higher in one area than another. In passive transport  particles will diffuse down a concentration gradient  from areas of higher concentration to areas of lower concentration  until they are evenly spaced.

title: Membranes and transport
translated_description: Osmosis of water from an area of lower to an area of higher solute concentration across a semipermeable membrane.

title: Membranes and transport
translated_description: Hypotonic  isotonic and hypertonic solutions (tonicity). Seeing the effect of various types of solution on the direction of osmosis.

title: Membranes and transport
translated_description: Learn about diffusion  osmosis  and concentration gradients and why these are important to cells.

title: Membranes and transport
translated_description: Passive transport and selective permeability. Passive transport through diffusion.

title: Membranes and transport
translated_description: Understanding how channel proteins and carrier proteins can facilitate diffusion across a cell membrane (passive transport).

title: Membranes and transport
translated_description: How the the sodium-potassium (Na+/K+) pump works. Its role in establishing resting membrane potentials.

title: Membranes and transport
translated_description: How a cell can use a molecule's electrochemical gradient to power secondary active transport.

title: Membranes and transport
translated_description: Uniporters  symporters  and antiporters are proteins that are used in ​transport​ of substances across a cell membrane. Uniporters are involved in facilitated diffusion and work by binding to one molecule of substrate at a time to move it along its concentration gradient. Symporters and antiporters are involved in active transport. Antiporters transport molecules in opposite directions  while symporters transport molecules in the same direction.

title: Membranes and transport
translated_description: Bulk transport: endocytosis  phagocytosis  and pinocytosis.

title: Membranes and transport
translated_description: Introduction to exocytosis!

title: Cellular respiration
translated_description: Learn more about ATP: how it stores energy  and how that energy is released when it's converted to ADP and phosphate.

title: Cellular respiration
translated_description: ATP hydrolysis mechanism. How energy is released when ATP is converted to ADP and phosphate.

title: Cellular respiration
translated_description: Introduction to cellular respiration  including glycolysis  the Krebs Cycle  and the electron transport chain.

title: Cellular respiration
translated_description: Taking a look at oxidation and reduction in a biological context.

title: Cellular respiration
translated_description: Oxidation and reduction in cellular respiration. Reconciling the biology and chemistry definitions of oxidation and reduction.

title: Cellular respiration
translated_description: Overview: glycolysis  pyruvate oxidation  the citric acid cycle (Krebs cycle)  and oxidative phosphorylation.

title: Cellular respiration
translated_description: Overview of the basics of glycolysis.

title: Cellular respiration
translated_description: Introduction to glycolysis. Role of glycolysis in producing ATPs and NADHs and converting glucose to pyruvates.

title: Cellular respiration
translated_description: Overview of the Krebs or citric acid cycle  which is a series of reactions that takes in acetyl CoA and  produces carbon dioxide  NADH  FADH2  and ATP or GTP.

title: Cellular respiration
translated_description: How oxidation of co-enzymes like NADH can lead to the production of ATP through oxidative phosphorylation.

title: Cellular respiration
translated_description: Lactic acid fermentation. How organisms like lactobacillus convert pyruvic acid to lactic acid and oxidize NADH to NAD+ in the process.

title: Cellular respiration
translated_description: Alcohol or ethanol fermentation  including yeast and its role in bread and wine production.

title: Photosynthesis
translated_description: Learn more about ATP: how it stores energy  and how that energy is released when it's converted to ADP and phosphate.

title: Photosynthesis
translated_description: ATP hydrolysis mechanism. How energy is released when ATP is converted to ADP and phosphate.

title: Photosynthesis
translated_description: Overview of photosynthesis. What photosynthesis accomplishes  why it's important  and how the light-dependent and light-independent reactions work together.

title: Photosynthesis
translated_description: Breaking down photosynthesis into light dependent reactions and Calvin cycle.

title: Photosynthesis
translated_description: Seeing how light energy can excite electrons which can be used to create ATP and NADPH (with oxygen as a byproduct).

title: Photosynthesis
translated_description: More detailed description of the various molecular actors in the light dependent reactions.

title: Photosynthesis
translated_description: Overview of the light-dependent reactions  including the structure of the chloroplast  the photosystems  and how ATP is synthesized.

title: Photosynthesis
translated_description: The Calvin cycle  or the light-independent (dark) reactions of photosythesis.

title: Photosynthesis
translated_description: The Calvin cycle and a competing pathway called photorespiration (also initiated by Rubisco).

title: Photosynthesis
translated_description: C4 photosynthesis: how some plants avoid photorespiration.

title: Photosynthesis
translated_description: How CAM Plants are able to fix carbon at night so they don't have to keep their stomata open during the day.

title: Cell signaling
translated_description: Overview of cell signaling. Autocrine  paracrine and endocrine signaling.

title: Cell signaling
translated_description: Illustrating the complexity of signal transduction with a MAPK pathway. How mutations in the pathway are linked to cancer.

title: Cell signaling
translated_description: Yeast can reproduce sexually through a signaling pathway known as the mating factor pathway. In this process  two haploid yeast cells combine to form a diploid cell. Yeast cells secrete a signal molecule called mating factor that attracts them to their mates. Once the mating factor of one yeast binds to the receptor on another yeast  an outgrowth called a "shmoo" forms  which allows the yeast cells to fuse together.

title: Cell division
translated_description: How haploid gametes (sperm and egg cells) combine to form a diploid zygote with two sets of chromosomes.

title: Cell division
translated_description: Learn how a zygote  the single cell produced by fertilization  divides by mitosis to produce all the tissues of the human body (including germ cells  which can undergo meiosis to make sperm and eggs).

title: Cell division
translated_description: Overview of DNA transcription  translation  and replication during mitosis and meiosis. Learn about chromosomes  chromatids  and chromatin.

title: Cell division
translated_description: Interphase of the cell cycle  including G₁  S  and G₂ phases. How the cell replicates its DNA before mitosis.

title: Cell division
translated_description: Mitosis is how cells divide! Learn what happens in all the phases of mitosis: prophase  metaphase  anaphase  and telophase.

title: Cell division
translated_description: Comparison of the processes of mitosis and meiosis.

title: Cell division
translated_description: How homologous chromosomes exchange fragments in prophase I. Tetrads  chiasmata  and alleles.

title: Cell division
translated_description: How homologous chromosomes separate into two sets. Prophase I  metaphase I  anaphase I  and telophase I.

title: Cell division
translated_description: How sister chromatids separate to form gametes. Prophase II  metaphase II  anaphase II  telophase II.

title: Cell division
translated_description: An overview of early development of a zygote to an embryo. Embryonic and somatic stem cells.

title: Cell division
translated_description: An introduction to what cancer is and how it is the by-product of broken DNA replication.

title: Cell division
translated_description: How apoptosis is different from cell death by injury. Role in development and body maintenance.

title: Classical and molecular genetics
translated_description: Heredity and Classical Genetics. Dominant and recessive traits. Heterozygous and homozygous genotypes.

title: Classical and molecular genetics
translated_description: Learn how to use Punnett squares to calculate probabilities of different phenotypes. Includes worked examples of dihybrid crosses. independent assortment  incomplete dominance  codominance  and multiple alleles.

title: Classical and molecular genetics
translated_description: Learn how to use Punnett squares to calculate probabilities of different phenotypes. Includes worked examples of dihybrid crosses. independent assortment  incomplete dominance  codominance  and multiple alleles.

title: Classical and molecular genetics
translated_description: Overview of how chromosomes were first proposed as the carriers of Mendel's "heritable factors" (what we now call "genes").

title: Classical and molecular genetics
translated_description: Thomas Hunt Morgan's pioneering fruit fly work that helped validate the chromosomal theory of inheritance.

title: Classical and molecular genetics
translated_description: Sex-linked traits are associated with genes found on sex chromosomes. In humans  the sex chromosomes are X and Y. Because the X-chromosome is larger  X-linked traits are more common than Y-linked traits. An example of a sex-linked trait is red-green colorblindness  which is carried on the X-chromosome. Because males only have one X-chromosome  they have a higher chance of having red-green colorblindness.

title: Classical and molecular genetics
translated_description: Learn about DNA (deoxyribonucleic acid). Overview of DNA bases  complementary base pairing  and the structure of the double helix.

title: Classical and molecular genetics
translated_description: How DNA is copied (replication). How information in DNA can be used to make a protein.

title: Classical and molecular genetics
translated_description: A gene as a stretch of DNA on a chromosome. Alleles as versions (sequence variants) of a gene.

title: DNA as the genetic material
translated_description: Learn about DNA (deoxyribonucleic acid). Overview of DNA bases  complementary base pairing  and the structure of the double helix.

title: DNA as the genetic material
translated_description: Molecular structure of DNA. Nucleotide. Nitrogenous base  phosphate.

title: DNA as the genetic material
translated_description: DNA is composed of two strands of nucleotides held together by hydrogen bonding. The strands each run from 5' to 3' and run in antiparallel  or opposite  directions from one another.

title: DNA as the genetic material
translated_description: How Griffith and later Avery  McCarty and MacLeod found strong evidence that DNA is the "transforming principle" that encodes genetic information.

title: DNA as the genetic material
translated_description: How Alfred Hershey and Martha Chase showed conclusively that DNA is the genetic material.

title: DNA as the genetic material
translated_description: How the double helix structure of DNA was discovered. Work of Watson  Crick  Franklin  Wilkins  and Chargaff.

title: DNA as the genetic material
translated_description: How DNA is copied (replication). How information in DNA can be used to make a protein.

title: DNA as the genetic material
translated_description: Roles of DNA polymerase  primase  ligase  helicase and topoisomerase in DNA replication. An explanation of leading and lagging strands.

title: DNA as the genetic material
translated_description: Sal reflects on the amazing speed and precision with which DNA replication takes place.

title: DNA as the genetic material
translated_description: Molecular structure of DNA. Nucleotide. Nitrogenous base  phosphate.

title: Central dogma (DNA to RNA to protein)
translated_description: How DNA is copied (replication). How information in DNA can be used to make a protein.

title: Central dogma (DNA to RNA to protein)
translated_description: A gene as a stretch of DNA on a chromosome. Alleles as versions (sequence variants) of a gene.

title: Central dogma (DNA to RNA to protein)
translated_description: How DNA is copied (replication). How information in DNA can be used to make a protein.

title: Central dogma (DNA to RNA to protein)
translated_description: Introduction to transcription including the role of RNA polymerase  promoters  terminators  introns and exons.

title: Central dogma (DNA to RNA to protein)
translated_description: Molecular structure of RNA.

title: Central dogma (DNA to RNA to protein)
translated_description: How DNA is copied (replication). How information in DNA can be used to make a protein.

title: Central dogma (DNA to RNA to protein)
translated_description: An deep dive into how mRNA is translated into proteins with the help of ribosomes and tRNA.

title: Gene regulation
translated_description: Looking at how regulatory DNA sequences can repress or promote gene transcription (particularly in bacteria operons).

title: Gene regulation
translated_description: The trp operon is a well-studied operon when it comes to gene regulation. It is involved in the biosynthesis of the amino acid tryptophan.

title: Gene regulation
translated_description: Overview of gene regulation in the Lac operon. Discussion of CAP  cAMP  lac repressor and allolactose in regulation of lac operon.

title: Biotechnology
translated_description: Introduction to DNA cloning

title: Biotechnology
translated_description: Introduction to PCR (polymerase chain reaction).

title: Biotechnology
translated_description: Introduction to gel electrophoresis. How it's used to separate DNA fragments or other macromoleculs.

translated_description: An overview of early development of a zygote to an embryo. Embryonic and somatic stem cells.

title: Developmental biology
translated_description: Learn how a zygote  the single cell produced by fertilization  divides by mitosis to produce all the tissues of the human body (including germ cells  which can undergo meiosis to make sperm and eggs).

title: Developmental biology
translated_description: An overview of early development of a zygote to an embryo. Embryonic and somatic stem cells.

title: Developmental biology
translated_description: How apoptosis is different from cell death by injury. Role in development and body maintenance.

title: Bacteria and archaea
translated_description: Introduction to bacteria.

title: Bacteria and archaea
translated_description: Prokaryotic and eukaryotic cells. Bacteria and archaea.

translated_description: Introduction to viruses.

title: Evolution and the tree of life
translated_description: Introduction to how groups of organisms evolve and how natural selection can lead to evolution.

title: Evolution and the tree of life
translated_description: Ape clarification - that they have no tails.

title: Evolution and the tree of life
translated_description: The argument that evolution speaks to being the most "intelligent design."

title: Evolution and the tree of life
translated_description: Clarifying some points on evolution and intelligent design.

title: Evolution and the tree of life
translated_description: How the "Owl Butterfly" may have gotten the spot on its wings.

title: Evolution and the tree of life
translated_description: How variation can be introduced into a species.

title: Evolution and the tree of life
translated_description: An overview of the different types of evidence that support evolution  including homologous and analogous features and vestigial structures.

title: Evolution and the tree of life
translated_description: Allele frequencies in populations and how they differ from genotype frequencies.

title: Evolution and the tree of life
translated_description: This equation relates allele frequencies to genotype frequencies for populations in Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium.

title: Evolution and the tree of life
translated_description: Using the Hardy-Weinberg equation to calculate allele and genotype frequencies.

title: Evolution and the tree of life
translated_description: An overview of what happens when the conditions for Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium are not fulfilled.

title: Evolution and the tree of life
translated_description: Learn how chance events can alter allele frequencies in populations  particularly when the populations are small  via genetic drift  the bottleneck effect  and the founder effect.

title: Evolution and the tree of life
translated_description: The science of taxonomy and where humans fit into the tree of life.

title: Evolution and the tree of life
translated_description: What a species is and isn't. Ligers  tiglons  mule  hinnies  and dogs.

title: Evolution and the tree of life
translated_description: Learn about speciation  including allopatric and sympatric speciation and mechanisms of reproductive isolation.

title: Evolution and the tree of life
translated_description: Patterns and processes of evolution. How evolution and natural selection are reflected in the similarities and differences of organisms. Video by California Academy of Sciences.

title: Evolution and the tree of life
translated_description: How genetic variation is the raw material of evolution  and how restricted gene flow can lead to the formation of new species. Video by California Academy of Sciences.

title: Evolution and the tree of life
translated_description: Discover the link between evolutionary trees and biodiversity. Video by California Academy of Sciences.

title: Evolution and the tree of life
translated_description: Learn how to read and draw phylogenetic trees  or cladograms.

title: Evolution and the tree of life
translated_description: Thinking about evolutionary distance between species. Constructing phylogenetic trees (cladograms).

title: History of life on Earth
translated_description: Earth ​was formed approximately 4.6 billion years ago  likely as the result of a supernova (star explosion). The debris from this explosion began to collapse in on itself due to gravity  forming the sun. Gravity continued to draw the remaining particles together  clumping them into larger bodies  ultimately forming Earth and the other planets in our solar system.

title: History of life on Earth
translated_description: Life and photosynthesis start to thrive in the Archean Eon

title: History of life on Earth
translated_description: An overview of the question of how life first arose on Earth.

title: History of life on Earth
translated_description: Ozone layer and eukaryotes show up in the Proterozoic eon. Great oxygenation event (oxygen catastrophe).

title: History of life on Earth
translated_description: First living things on land clarification (This video copyrighted under Create Commons Attribution and Share-Alike CC-BY-SA license)

title: History of life on Earth
translated_description: Cambrian explosion and biodiversity in the Phanerozoic Eon

title: History of life on Earth
translated_description: From the extinction of the dinosaurs to humanity

title: History of life on Earth
translated_description: Discussion of the relatively recent changes in our ability as a species to shine light on our deep past

title: History of life on Earth
translated_description: Carbon 14 Dating 1

title: History of life on Earth
translated_description: Carbon 14 Dating 2

title: History of life on Earth
translated_description: How K-Ar dating can be used to date very old volcanic rock and the things that might be buried in between

title: History of life on Earth
translated_description: Working through a calculation for K-Ar dating (good to have some prior experience with e and logarithms)

title: Ecology
translated_description: Ecology is the study of how living things interact with each other and their environment. This includes living things (biotic factors) and non-living things (abiotic factors).

title: Ecology
translated_description: How do organisms use different life history strategies to maximize fitness? Learn about different ways that different species allocate energy and other resources between growth  maintenance/survival  and reproduction.

title: Ecology
translated_description: Learn about population growth rates and how they can be modeled by exponential and logistic equations.

title: Ecology
translated_description: Learn the difference between density-dependent and density-independent factors that affect population growth  and explore examples of each.

title: Ecology
translated_description: What effect do interactions between species have on the sizes of the populations involved? Learn about the dynamics of predator and prey populations  and how they can influence one another’s patterns of growth and decline.

title: Ecology
translated_description: Thomas Malthus's views on population. Malthusian limits.

title: Ecology
translated_description: Learn about the many types of interspecific interactions: competition  predation  herbivory  symbiosis  parasitism  mutualism  commensalism.

title: Ecology
translated_description: What effect do interactions between species have on the sizes of the populations involved? Learn about the dynamics of predator and prey populations  and how they can influence one another’s patterns of growth and decline.

title: Ecology
translated_description: Flow of energy and matter through ecosystems. What happens if an ecosystem is disrupted. Video by California Academy of Sciences.

title: Ecology
translated_description: Communities are dynamic and change over time  and we can observe this process with particular clarity after a disturbance or on new land. Learn about  primary and secondary succession  as well as pioneer species.

title: Ecology
translated_description: Introduction to ecosystems. How land ecosystems are classified into biomes.

title: Ecology
translated_description: Seeing how energy and matter flows and is recycled from primary producers (autotrophs) to primary  secondary and tertiary consumers.

title: Ecology
translated_description: Introduction to how water  carbon  nitrogen  and phosphorus are cycled through ecosystems.

title: Ecology
translated_description: How the sun's energy drives the water cycle on Earth.

title: Ecology
translated_description: Overview of how carbon is recycled through our biosphere in the carbon cycle.

title: Ecology
translated_description: How nitrogen is recycled in our biosphere in the nitrogen cycle  including nitrogen fixation.

title: Ecology
translated_description: Introduction to the phosphorous cycle. How phosphorus is recycled from phosphate to ATP and DNA.

title: Ecology
translated_description: How eutrophication  caused by extra nutrients in runoff  can lead to dead zones.

title: Ecology
translated_description: How biodiversity is distributed globally. Video by California Academy of Sciences.

title: Ecology
translated_description: Factors that influence the global distribution of biodiversity. Video by California Academy of Sciences.

title: Biodiversity and conservation
translated_description: Flow of energy and matter through ecosystems. What happens if an ecosystem is disrupted. Video by California Academy of Sciences.

title: Biodiversity and conservation
translated_description: Describing and quantifying the benefits that healthy ecosystems provide to humans. Video by California Academy of Sciences.

title: Biodiversity and conservation
translated_description: What a biodiversity hotspot is  and why these locations are important to preserve. Video by California Academy of Sciences.

title: Biodiversity and conservation
translated_description: How biodiversity is distributed globally. Video by California Academy of Sciences.

title: Biodiversity and conservation
translated_description: Factors that influence the global distribution of biodiversity. Video by California Academy of Sciences.

title: Biodiversity and conservation
translated_description: Human activities that cause a loss of biodiversity. Video by California Academy of Sciences.

title: Biodiversity and conservation
translated_description: Effects of climate change on biodiversity. Video by California Academy of Sciences.

title: Biodiversity and conservation
translated_description: Why rising carbon dioxide levels in the atmosphere affect the acidity of the ocean  and what the consequences are for marine life. Video by California Academy of Sciences.

title: Biodiversity and conservation
translated_description: Different approaches to conservation and how they can protect species and habitats. Video by California Academy of Sciences.

title: Biodiversity and conservation
translated_description: How does the gene pool contribute to biodiversity? Learn how genetic diversity within populations contributes to species survival. Video by California Academy of Sciences.

title: Biodiversity and conservation
translated_description: Are all coral reefs the same?  Each regional ecosystem has its own assemblage of species and each contributes uniquely to global biodiversity. Explore why ecosystem diversity is important for conservation decisions. Video by California Academy of Sciences.

title: Biodiversity and conservation
translated_description: Discover the link between evolutionary trees and biodiversity. Video by California Academy of Sciences.

title: Human biology
translated_description: The pulmonary system including the lungs  larynx  trachea  bronchi  bronchioles  alveoli and thoracic diaphragm.

translated_description: Oxygen uptake by hemoglobin in red blood cells.

translated_description: Introduction to the circulatory system and the heart.

title: Human biology
translated_description: Hemoglobin and its role in the circulatory system.

title: Human biology
translated_description: Neurons (or nerve cells) are specialized cells that transmit and receive electrical signals in the body. Neurons are composed of three main parts: dendrites  a cell body  and an axon. Signals are received through the dendrites  travel to the cell body  and continue down the axon until they reach the synapse (the communication point between two neurons).

title: Human biology
translated_description: How a sodium potassium pump can maintain a voltage gradient across a cell or neuron's membrane.

title: Human biology
translated_description: Correction to "Sodium-potassium pump" video.

title: Human biology
translated_description: Two different types of changes in the membrane potential of a neuron.

title: Human biology
translated_description: Myelin sheaths  nodes of Ranvier  and saltatory conduction in neurons.

title: Human biology
translated_description: How one neuron can stimulate (or inhibit) another neuron at a chemical synapse.

title: Human biology
translated_description: Overview of how the nephrons in the kidney filter blood and reabsorb water and other molecules.

title: Human biology
translated_description: Secondary active transport in the nephron.

translated_description: How myosin and actin interact to produce mechanical force.

translated_description: How calcium ion concentration dictates whether a muscle contracts or not.

title: Human biology
translated_description: The role of the sarcoplasmic reticulum in controlling calcium ion concentrations within the muscle cell.

title: Human biology
translated_description: Understanding the structure of a muscle fiber.

title: Human biology
translated_description: Role of phagocytes in innate or nonspecific immunity. Neutrophils  macrophages  and dendritic cells. MHC II.

title: Human biology
translated_description: Innate vs. adaptive immunity. Humoral adaptive immunity vs. cell-mediated adaptive immunity.

title: Human biology
translated_description: Overview of B cells (B lymphocytes) and how they are activated and produce antibodies.

title: Human biology
translated_description: Professional antigen presenting cells (APCs) are immune cells that specialize in presenting an antigen to a T-cell. The main types of professional APCs are dendritic cells (DC)  macrophages  and B cells. A professional APC takes up an antigen  processes it  and returns part of it to its surface  along with a class II major histocompatibility complex (MHC). The T-cell is activated when it interacts with the formed complex.

title: Human biology
translated_description: Introduction to helper T cells and their role in activating B cells.

title: Human biology
translated_description: How damaged cells present antigens from inside the cell on MHC I and are recognized by cytotoxic T cells.

title: Human biology
translated_description: Review of B cells  CD4+ T cells and CD8+ T cells.

title: Human biology
translated_description: Overview of the inflammatory response.

translated_description: Phototropism and the role that auxin plays.

title: Plant biology
translated_description: Phototropism investigation.

title: Plant biology
translated_description: How plants can regulate processes like flowering based on day length (photoperiod).

translated_description: Genetic and environmental influences on mouse activity cycles.

translated_description: Light-dark activity cycle of mutant mice and evolutionary implications.

translated_description: Questions on cellular respiration.

title: Crash Course Biology and Ecology
translated_description: Hank discusses the properties of carbon and the bonding behavior of atoms.

title: Crash Course Biology and Ecology
translated_description: Hank teaches us why water is one of the most fascinating and important substances in the universe.

title: Crash Course Biology and Ecology
translated_description: Hank talks about the molecules that make up every living thing - carbohydrates  lipids  and proteins - and how we find them in our environment and in the food that we eat.

title: Crash Course Biology and Ecology
translated_description: Hank tells us about the city of Eukaryopolis - the animal cell that is responsible for all the cool things that happen in our bodies.

title: Crash Course Biology and Ecology
translated_description: Hank describes how cells regulate their contents and communicate with one another via mechanisms within the cell membrane.

title: Crash Course Biology and Ecology
translated_description: Hank describes why plants are so freaking amazing - discussing their evolution  and how their cells are both similar to & different from animal cells.

title: Crash Course Biology and Ecology
translated_description: In which Hank does some push ups for science and describes the "economy" of cellular respiration and the various processes whereby our bodies create energy in the form of ATP.

title: Crash Course Biology and Ecology
translated_description: Hank explains the extremely complex series of reactions whereby plants feed themselves on sunlight  carbon dioxide and water  and also create some by products we're pretty fond of as well.

title: Crash Course Biology and Ecology
translated_description: Hank and his brother John discuss heredity via the gross example of relative ear wax moistness.

title: Crash Course Biology and Ecology
translated_description: Hank introduces us to that wondrous molecule deoxyribonucleic acid - also known as DNA - and explains how it replicates itself in our cells.

title: Crash Course Biology and Ecology
translated_description: Hank imagines himself breaking into the Hot Pockets factory to steal their secret recipes and instruction manuals in order to help us understand how the processes known as DNA transcription and translation allow our cells to build proteins.

title: Crash Course Biology and Ecology
translated_description: Hank describes mitosis and cytokinesis - the series of processes our cells go through to divide into two identical copies.

title: Crash Course Biology and Ecology
translated_description: Hank gets down to the nitty gritty about meiosis  the special type of cell division that is necessary for sexual reproduction in eukaryotic organisms.

title: Crash Course Biology and Ecology
translated_description: Hank guides us through the process of natural selection  the key mechanism of evolution.

title: Crash Course Biology and Ecology
translated_description: Hank explains speciation - the evolutionary process by which new biological species arise - in terms of finches  ligers  mules  and dogs.

title: Crash Course Biology and Ecology
translated_description: Hank discusses the process by which organisms grow and develop  maintaining that  in the end  we're all just tubes.

title: Crash Course Biology and Ecology
translated_description: Hank introduces us to the relatively new field of evolutionary developmental biology  which compares the developmental processes of different organisms to determine their ancestral relationship  and to discover how those processes evolved. Also fruit flies with eyes on their legs and chickens with teeth!

title: Crash Course Biology and Ecology
translated_description: Hank talks about population genetics  which helps to explain the evolution of populations over time by combing the principles of Mendel and Darwin  and by means of the Hardy-Weinberg equation.

title: Crash Course Biology and Ecology
translated_description: Hank tells us the background story and explains the importance of the science of classifying living things  also known as taxonomy.

title: Crash Course Biology and Ecology
translated_description: Hank gets real with us in a discussion of evolution - it's a thing  not a debate. Gene distribution changes over time  across successive generations  to give rise to diversity at every level of biological organization.

title: Crash Course Biology and Ecology
translated_description: Hank introduces us to comparative anatomy  which studies the similarities and differences in animal anatomy to support the theory of evolution and the shared ancestry of living things.

title: Crash Course Biology and Ecology
translated_description: Hank introduces us to the "simplest" of the animals  complexity-wise: beginning with sponges (whose very inclusion in the list as "animals" has been called into question because they are so simple) and finishing with the most complex molluscs  octopuses and squid. We differentiate them by the number of tissue layers they have  and by the complexity of those layers.

title: Crash Course Biology and Ecology
translated_description: Hank continues our exploration of animal phyla with the more complexly organized annelida and arthropoda  and a biolography on insects.

title: Crash Course Biology and Ecology
translated_description: Hank introduces us to ourselves by taking us on a journey through the fascinatingly diverse phyla known as chordata. And the next time someone asks you who you are  you can give them the facts: you're a mammalian amniotic tetrapodal sarcopterygian osteichthyen gnathostomal vertebrate cranial chordate.

title: Crash Course Biology and Ecology
translated_description: Hank and his cat Cameo help teach us about animal behavior and how we can discover why animals do the things they do.

title: Crash Course Biology and Ecology
translated_description: Hank begins a series of videos on organ systems with a look at the nervous system and all of the things that it is responsible for in the body.

title: Crash Course Biology and Ecology
translated_description: Hank takes us on a trip around the body - we follow the circulatory and respiratory systems as they deliver oxygen and remove carbon dioxide from cells  and help make it possible for our bodies to function.

title: Crash Course Biology and Ecology
translated_description: Hank takes us through the bowels of the human digestive system and explains why it's all about surface area.

title: Crash Course Biology and Ecology
translated_description: Hank takes us on the fascinating journey through our excretory system to learn how our kidneys make pee.

title: Crash Course Biology and Ecology
translated_description: Hank introduces us to the framework of our bodies  our skeleton  which apart from being the support and protection for all our fleshy parts  is involved in many other vital processes that help our bodies to function properly.

title: Crash Course Biology and Ecology
translated_description: Hank tells us the story of the complicated chemical dance that allows our skeletal muscles to contract and relax.

title: Crash Course Biology and Ecology
translated_description: Hank tells us about the team of deadly ninja assassins that is tasked with protecting our bodies from all the bad guys that want to kill us - also known as our immune system.

title: Crash Course Biology and Ecology
translated_description: Hank fills us in on the endocrine system - the system of glands which produce and secrete different types of hormones directly into the bloodstream to regulate the body's growth  metabolism  and sexual development & function.

title: Crash Course Biology and Ecology
translated_description: Hank lets us in on the meaning of life  at least from a biological perspective - it's reproduction  which answers the essential question of all organisms: how do I make more of myself? So  sex  how does it work?

title: Crash Course Biology and Ecology
translated_description: Hank veers away from human anatomy to teach us about the (mostly) single-celled organisms that make up two of the three taxonomic domains of life  and one of the four kingdoms: Archaea  Bacteria  and Protists. They are by far the most abundant organisms on Earth  and are our oldest  oddest relatives.

title: Crash Course Biology and Ecology
translated_description: Hank introduces us to nonvascular plants - liverworts  hornworts & mosses - which have bizarre features  kooky habits  and strange sex lives. Nonvascular plants inherited their reproductive cycle from algae  but have perfected it to the point where it is now used by all plants in one way or another  and has even left traces in our own reproductive systems.

title: Crash Course Biology and Ecology
translated_description: Hank introduces us to one of the most diverse and important families in the tree of life - the vascular plants. These plants have found tremendous success and the their secret is also their defining trait: conductive tissues that can take food and water from one part of a plant to another part. Though it sounds simple  the ability to move nutrients and water from one part of an organism to another was a evolutionary breakthrough for vascular plants  allowing them to grow exponentially larger  store food for lean times  and develop features that allowed them to spread farther and faster. Plants dominated the earth long before animals even showed up  and even today hold the world records for the largest  most massive  and oldest organisms on the planet.

title: Crash Course Biology and Ecology
translated_description: Hank gets into the dirty details about vascular plant reproduction: they use the basic alternation of generations developed by nonvascular plants 470 million years ago  but they've tricked it out so that it works a whole lot differently compared to the way it did back in the Ordovician swamps where it got its start. Here's how the vascular plants (ferns  gymnosperms and angiosperms) do it.

title: Crash Course Biology and Ecology
translated_description: Death is what fungi are all about. By feasting on the deceased remains of almost all organisms on the planet  converting the organic matter back into soil from which new life will spring  they perform perhaps the most vital function in the global food web. Fungi  which thrive on death  make all life possible.

title: Crash Course Biology and Ecology
translated_description: Hank introduces us to ecology - the study of the rules of engagement for all of us earthlings - which seeks to explain why the world looks and acts the way it does. The world is crammed with things  both animate and not  that have been interacting with each other all the time  every day  since life on this planet began  and these interactions depend mostly on just two things... Learn what they are as Crash Course Biology takes its final voyage outside the body and into the entire world.

title: Crash Course Biology and Ecology
translated_description: Hank discusses the history of life on Earth (including major events such as oxygenation of the atmosphere and mass extinctions).

title: Crash Course Biology and Ecology
translated_description: Hank discusses population ecology  including the factors that limit population growth  using the example of a mosquito population.

title: Crash Course Biology and Ecology
translated_description: Hank explores human population growth  exponential growth of populations  and R- and K-strategists.

title: Crash Course Biology and Ecology
translated_description: Hank explores community ecology  the competitive exclusion principle  and how different species can coexist by occupying different niches.

title: Crash Course Biology and Ecology
translated_description: Hank explores adaptations of predators  the evolutionary arms race between predators and prey  and various types of predation (including herbivory and parasitism).

title: Crash Course Biology and Ecology
translated_description: Hank examines how ecological communities change after a disturbance.

title: Crash Course Biology and Ecology
translated_description: Hank discusses ecosystems  trophic structure  and the flow of energy through food webs.

title: Crash Course Biology and Ecology
translated_description: Hank explains how carbon and water are recycled through ecosystems and the biosphere.

title: Crash Course Biology and Ecology
translated_description: Hank discusses how nitrogen and phosphorous are recycled through ecosystems and the biosphere.

title: Crash Course Biology and Ecology
translated_description: Hank presents examples of how human activity can affect ecosystems.

title: Crash Course Biology and Ecology
translated_description: Hank discusses different forms of pollution and their ecological effects.

title: Crash Course Biology and Ecology
translated_description: Hank discusses different types of biodiversity  as well as how biodiversity can be measured  preserved  and restored.

title: One-dimensional motion
translated_description: An overview video of what physics is about as we delve deeper in future videos!

title: One-dimensional motion
translated_description: Distance  displacement  speed and velocity. Difference between vectors and scalars.

title: One-dimensional motion
translated_description: How the choice of reference frame is related to speed and velocity measurements

title: One-dimensional motion
translated_description: Although speed and velocity are often words used interchangeably  in physics  they are distinct concepts. Speed is calculated by dividing the distance traveled by time. It does not have direction. Average velocity is the displacement (change in position) divided by time.

title: One-dimensional motion
translated_description: Rate  or velocity  is equal to ​distance traveled divided by time. To solve for time  divide the distance traveled by the rate. For example  if Cole drives his car 45 miles per hour and travels a total of 225 miles  then he traveled for 225/45 = 5 hours.

title: One-dimensional motion
translated_description: Worked example of calculating displacement from time and velocity

title: One-dimensional motion
translated_description: Instantaneous speed and velocity looks at really small displacements over really small periods of time

title: One-dimensional motion
translated_description: Learn how to read a position vs. time graph. He then explains how to use the graph to determine the following quantities: displacement  distance  average velocity  average speed  instantaneous velocity  and instantaneous speed.

title: One-dimensional motion
translated_description: Calculating the acceleration of a Porsche

title: One-dimensional motion
translated_description: Figuring how long it takes an a380 to take off given a constant acceleration

title: One-dimensional motion
translated_description: How long of a runway does an A380 need?

title: One-dimensional motion
translated_description: Understanding why distance is area under velocity-time line

title: One-dimensional motion
translated_description: David explains how to read an acceleration vs. time graph. He then shows how the area under the curve gives the change in velocity and does a few examples.

title: One-dimensional motion
translated_description: Calculating average velocity when acceleration is constant

title: One-dimensional motion
translated_description: Using what we know about take-off velocity and runway length to determine acceleration

title: One-dimensional motion
translated_description: How long of a runway does an A380 need?

title: One-dimensional motion
translated_description: Deriving displacement as a function of time  constant acceleration and initial velocity

title: One-dimensional motion
translated_description: Plotting projectile displacement  acceleration  and velocity as a function to change in time

title: One-dimensional motion
translated_description: Figuring out how high a ball gets given how long it spends in the air

title: One-dimensional motion
translated_description: Deriving a formula for  maximum projectile displacement as a function of elapsed time

title: One-dimensional motion
translated_description: Determining how fast something will be traveling upon impact when it is released from a given height

title: One-dimensional motion
translated_description: Viewing g as the value of Earth's gravitational field near the surface rather than the acceleration due to gravity near Earth's surface for an object in freefall

title: One-dimensional motion
translated_description: How to set up problems with constant acceleration and choose the best kinematic equation to solve for the target unknown.

title: One-dimensional motion
translated_description: Using the equations of motion to figure out things about falling objects

title: One-dimensional motion
translated_description: A derivation of a new motion equation

title: One-dimensional motion
translated_description: An example of solving for the final velocity when you know the change in distance  time  initial velocity  and acceleration

title: One-dimensional motion
translated_description: Solving for time when you are given the change in distance  acceleration  and initial velocity

title: One-dimensional motion
translated_description: How fast was the ball that you threw upwards?

title: Two-dimensional motion
translated_description: In this video David explains how to solve for the horizontal displacement when the projectile starts with a horizontal initial velocity. He also explains common mistakes people make when doing horizontally launched projectile problems.

title: Two-dimensional motion
translated_description: Visualizing  adding and breaking down vectors in 2 dimensions

title: Two-dimensional motion
translated_description: Figuring out the horizontal displacement for a projectile launched at an angle

title: Two-dimensional motion
translated_description: More complicated example involving launching and landing at different elevations

title: Two-dimensional motion
translated_description: Reconstructing the total displacement vector for a projectile

title: Two-dimensional motion
translated_description: Calculating the total final velocity for a projectile landing at a different altitude (mistake near end: I write 29.03 when it should be 26.03 m/s and the final total magnitude should be 26.55 m/s 78.7 degrees below horizontal

title: Two-dimensional motion
translated_description: Correction to "Total Final Velocity for Projectile" Video

title: Two-dimensional motion
translated_description: Challenging problem of a projectile on an inclined plane

title: Two-dimensional motion
translated_description: Using unit vectors to represent the components of a vector

title: Two-dimensional motion
translated_description: Expressing a vector as the scaled sum of unit vectors

title: Two-dimensional motion
translated_description: More on unit vector notation. Showing that adding the x and y components of two vectors is equivalent to adding the vectors visually using the head-to-tail method

title: Two-dimensional motion
translated_description: Solving the second part to the projectile motion problem (with wind gust) using ordered set vector notation

title: Two-dimensional motion
translated_description: You want a projectile to fly as far as possible  at which angle should you launch it? We'll start with formulas for the initial velocity.

title: Two-dimensional motion
translated_description: Now it's time to think about hangtime for our far-flung projectile

title: Two-dimensional motion
translated_description: In this video  we'll finish writing the formula for distance as a function of the angle

title: Forces and Newton's laws of motion
translated_description: Basic primer on Newton's First Law of Motion

title: Forces and Newton's laws of motion
translated_description: A little quiz on some of the ideas in Newton's first law

title: Forces and Newton's laws of motion
translated_description: Newton's First Law (Galileo's Law of Inertia).

title: Forces and Newton's laws of motion
translated_description: Newton's second law of motion is F = ma  or force is equal to mass times acceleration. Learn how to use the formula to calculate acceleration.

title: Forces and Newton's laws of motion
translated_description: In this video David explains how to use Newton's second law when dealing with multiple forces  forces in two dimensions  and diagonal forces.

title: Forces and Newton's laws of motion
translated_description: Every action has an equal and opposite reaction

title: Forces and Newton's laws of motion
translated_description: In this video David explains some of the common misconceptions in dealing with Newton's Third Law. He also shows how to correctly and reliably identify Third Law force pairs.

title: Forces and Newton's laws of motion
translated_description: The force that keeps a block of ice from falling towards the center of the earth

title: Forces and Newton's laws of motion
translated_description: How the normal force changes when an elevator accelerates

title: Forces and Newton's laws of motion
translated_description: David explains how to determine the normal force for a variety of scenarios (extra forces  diagonal forces  acceleration) involving a shoe on the floor.

title: Forces and Newton's laws of motion
translated_description: David shows how to determine the normal force for a shoe shoved against a wall with a diagonal force.

title: Forces and Newton's laws of motion
translated_description: Primer on identifying balanced and unbalanced forces

title: Forces and Newton's laws of motion
translated_description: Thinking about what is true about how unbalanced forces relate to motion and acceleration

title: Forces and Newton's laws of motion
translated_description: What would happen to a slowly moving frozen sock on a frictionless planet

title: Forces and Newton's laws of motion
translated_description: Whether the normal force balances the force of gravity for a frozen sock or banana

title: Forces and Newton's laws of motion
translated_description: Figuring out the components of the force due to gravity that are parallel and perpendicular to the surface of an inclined plane

title: Forces and Newton's laws of motion
translated_description: Figuring out the acceleration of ice down a plane made of ice

title: Forces and Newton's laws of motion
translated_description: Block of wood kept stationary by the force of friction (Correction made in next video)

translated_description: Correction to Force of Friction Keeping the Block Stationary

translated_description: Calculating the coefficient of kinetic friction (correction made in next video)

translated_description: Why static friction is harder to overcome than kinetic friction

title: Forces and Newton's laws of motion
translated_description: Thinking about the coefficients of static and kinetic friction

title: Forces and Newton's laws of motion
translated_description: David explains what the force of tension is  how to solve for it  and some common misconceptions involving the force of tension.

title: Forces and Newton's laws of motion
translated_description: David explains how to solve tension problems for hanging objects.

title: Forces and Newton's laws of motion
translated_description: David shows how to solve a super hot tension problem where a can of peppers hangs from two diagonal strings.

title: Forces and Newton's laws of motion
translated_description: An introduction to tension. Solving for the tension(s) in a set of wires when a weight is hanging from them.

title: Forces and Newton's laws of motion
translated_description: A slightly more difficult tension problem.

title: Forces and Newton's laws of motion
translated_description: The second part to the complicated problem. We figure out the tension in the wire connecting the two masses. Then we figure our how much we need to accelerate a pie for it to safely reach a man's face.

title: Forces and Newton's laws of motion
Forces and Newton's laws of motion
translated_description: David shows the easier way to find the acceleration of two masses connected by a rope.

title: Forces and Newton's laws of motion
translated_description: In this video David explains how to find the acceleration of two masses hanging from a pulley (using the easy method).

title: Forces and Newton's laws of motion
translated_description: In this video David explains how to easily find the acceleration of a three box system by treating it as a single mass.

title: Forces and Newton's laws of motion
translated_description: In this video David explains how to find the acceleration and tension for a system of masses involving an incline.

title: Centripetal force and gravitation
translated_description: When acceleration could involve a change in direction and not speed.

title: Centripetal force and gravitation
translated_description: The direction of the force in cases of circular motion at constant speeds

title: Centripetal force and gravitation
translated_description: Visual understanding of how centripetal acceleration relates to velocity and radius

title: Centripetal force and gravitation
translated_description: Proving that a = v^2/r

translated_description: Asks students to find the minimum speed necessary to complete the loop de loop
