translated_description: Figuring out the minimum speed at the top of the loop de loop to stay on the track

title: Centripetal force and gravitation
translated_description: Figuring out the car's average speed while completing the loop de loop

title: Centripetal force and gravitation
translated_description: In this video David gives some problem solving strategies for centripetal force problems and explains many common misconceptions people have about centripetal forces.

title: Centripetal force and gravitation
translated_description: In this video David explains how to find the tension in a string that is whirling a yo-yo in a vertical circle.

title: Centripetal force and gravitation
translated_description: In this video David explains how to find the normal force on a bowling ball rolling in a vertical loop.

title: Centripetal force and gravitation
translated_description: In this video David explains how to solve for the tension and speed of a mass swinging at an angle in a horizontal circle.

title: Centripetal force and gravitation
translated_description: Basics of gravity and the Law of Universal Gravitation

title: Centripetal force and gravitation
translated_description: Difference between mass and weight

title: Centripetal force and gravitation
translated_description: Why do astronauts appear weightless despite being near the Earth?

title: Centripetal force and gravitation
translated_description: What would fall faster on the moon?

title: Centripetal force and gravitation
translated_description: What is the acceleration due to gravity at the space station

title: Centripetal force and gravitation
translated_description: Speed necessary for the space station to stay in orbit

title: Centripetal force and gravitation
translated_description: A little bit on gravity

title: Centripetal force and gravitation
translated_description: A little bit more on gravity

title: Work and energy
translated_description: Introduction to work and energy

title: Work and energy
translated_description: More on work. Introduction to Kinetic and Potential Energies.

title: Work and energy
translated_description: Using the law of conservation of energy to see how potential energy is converted into kinetic energy

title: Work and energy
translated_description: David explains the link between work and kinetic energy

title: Work and energy
translated_description: David explains "work" as the way forces transfer energy to and from objects

title: Work and energy
translated_description: David goes through some example problems on the concept of work

title: Work and energy
translated_description: In this video David shows how the area under a Force vs. position graph equals the work done by the force and solves some sample problems.

title: Work and energy
translated_description: In this video David shows how to find the energy generated by the force of friction and solves an example conservation of energy problem involving thermal energy.

title: Work and energy
translated_description: A conservation of energy problem where all of the energy is not conserved.

title: Work and energy
translated_description: A conservative force exists when the work done by that force on an object is independent of the object's path. Instead  the work done by a conservative force depends only on the end points of the motion. An example of a conservative force is gravity.

title: Work and energy
translated_description: IIII haaaave the powerrrr! Power is the rate at which work is done.

title: Work and energy
translated_description: Introduction to Hooke's Law

title: Work and energy
translated_description: Work needed to compress a spring is the same thing as the potential energy stored in the compressed spring.

title: Work and energy
translated_description: A spring  a frozen loop-d-loop and more! (See if you can find the mistake I made and get the right answer!)

title: Work and energy
translated_description: In this video  David shows how LOL diagrams allow us to visually represent what we mean by conservation of energy as well as what we mean by an energy system.

title: Work and energy
translated_description: In this video  David explains two different strategies to deal with vertical springs and compares them with those used for horizontal springs.

title: Work and energy
translated_description: Introduction to simple machines  mechanical advantage and moments.

title: Work and energy
translated_description: More on mechanical advantage  levers and moments.

title: Work and energy
translated_description: Introduction to pulleys and wedges

title: Impacts and linear momentum
translated_description: What momentum is.  A simple problem involving momentum.

title: Impacts and linear momentum
translated_description: In this video  David shows how to solve for the impulse and force applied during a dodgeball collision using the impulse momentum relationship.

title: Impacts and linear momentum
translated_description: In this video  David shows how to use conservation of momentum for a situation where two objects bounce off of each other.

title: Impacts and linear momentum
translated_description: A simple conservation of momentum problem involving an ice skater and a ball

title: Impacts and linear momentum
translated_description: An example of conservation of momentum in two dimensions.

title: Impacts and linear momentum
translated_description: We finish the 2-dimensional momentum problem

title: Impacts and linear momentum
translated_description: In this video  David explains how to use a force vs. time graph to find impulse and solves an example problem to find the final velocity of a spaceship.

title: Impacts and linear momentum
translated_description: In this video  David explains what it means for a collision to be elastic or inelastic.

title: Impacts and linear momentum
translated_description: In this video  David shows how to solve elastic problems the hard way. In other words  using conservation of momentum and conservation of kinetic energy  David substitutes one equation into the other and solves for the final velocities.

title: Impacts and linear momentum
translated_description: In this video  David derives the expression that we can use as a shortcut to solve for finding the velocities in an elastic collision problem.

title: Impacts and linear momentum
translated_description: In this video  David solves an example elastic collision problem to find the final velocities using the easier/shortcut approach.

title: Impacts and linear momentum
translated_description: In this video  Sal gives a conceptual understanding of what center of mass means.

title: Impacts and linear momentum
translated_description: The center of mass is a point in a system that responds to external forces as if the total mass of the system were concentrated at this point. The center of mass can be calculated by taking the masses you are trying to find the center of mass between and multiplying them by their positions. Then  you add these together and divide that by the sum of all the individual masses.

title: Torque and angular momentum
translated_description: In this video David explains the meaning of angular displacement  angular velocity  and angular acceleration.

title: Torque and angular momentum
translated_description: In this video David shows how to relate the angular displacement to the arc length  angular velocity to the speed  and angular acceleration to the tangential acceleration.

title: Torque and angular momentum
translated_description: How angular velocity relates to speed

title: Torque and angular momentum
translated_description: In this video David explains the rotational kinematic formulas and does a couple sample problems using them.

title: Torque and angular momentum
translated_description: An introduction to torque

title: Torque and angular momentum
translated_description: Introduction to moments

title: Torque and angular momentum
translated_description: 2 more moment problems.

title: Torque and angular momentum
translated_description: In this video David explains how to determine the torque exerted by a non perpendicular force.

title: Torque and angular momentum
translated_description: In this video David explains moment of inertia and the rotational version of Newton's second law and shows how to solve an example problem.

title: Torque and angular momentum
translated_description: In this video David explains more about what moment of inertia means  as well as giving the moments of inertia for commonly shaped objects.

title: Torque and angular momentum
translated_description: In this video David explains what rotational kinetic energy is and how to calculate it.

title: Torque and angular momentum
translated_description: In this video David explains how to solve problems where an object rolls without slipping.

title: Torque and angular momentum
translated_description: Just like how linear momentum is constant when there's no net force  angular momentum is constant where there's no net torque

title: Torque and angular momentum
translated_description: In this video David derives and shows how to use the formula for the angular momentum of an extended object.

title: Torque and angular momentum
translated_description: In this video David explains how a mass can have angular momentum even if it is traveling along a straight line. Then David shows how to solve the conservation of angular momentum problem where a ball hits a rod which can rotate.

title: Torque and angular momentum
translated_description: The cross product and the direction of torque

title: Oscillations and mechanical waves
translated_description: In this video David defines what it means for something to be a simple harmonic oscillator and gives some intuition about why oscillators do what they do as well as where the speed  acceleration  and force will be largest and smallest.

title: Oscillations and mechanical waves
translated_description: In this video David defines the terms Amplitude and Period and shows how to find them on a graph.

title: Oscillations and mechanical waves
translated_description: In this video David explains the equation that represents the motion of a simple harmonic oscillator and solves an example problem.

title: Oscillations and mechanical waves
translated_description: In this video David explains what affects the period of a mass on a spring (i.e. mass and spring constant). He also explains what does not affect the period of a mass on a spring (i.e. amplitude and gravitational acceleration).

title: Oscillations and mechanical waves
translated_description: In this video David explains how a phase constant can be used in order to shift the graph of an oscillator left or right.

title: Oscillations and mechanical waves
translated_description: In this video David explains how a pendulum can be treated as a simple harmonic oscillator  and then explains what affects  as well as what does not affect  the period of a pendulum.

title: Oscillations and mechanical waves
translated_description: Harmonic motion refers to the motion an oscillating mass experiences when the restoring force is proportional to the ​displacement  but in opposite directions. Harmonic motion is periodic and can be represented by a sine wave with constant frequency and amplitude. An example of this is a weight bouncing on a spring.

title: Oscillations and mechanical waves
translated_description: We test whether Acos(wt) can describe the motion of the mass on a spring by substituting into the differential equation F=-kx

title: Oscillations and mechanical waves
translated_description: Figuring out the period  frequency  and amplitude of the harmonic motion of a mass attached to a spring.

title: Oscillations and mechanical waves
translated_description: Introduction to transverse and longitudinal waves

title: Oscillations and mechanical waves
translated_description: Amplitude  period  frequency and wavelength of periodic waves. How to calculate wave velocity.

title: Oscillations and mechanical waves
translated_description: In this video David shows how to determine the equation of a wave  how that equation works  and what the equation represents.

title: Oscillations and mechanical waves
translated_description: Sound is vibrating air. But how does the air start vibrating?

title: Oscillations and mechanical waves
translated_description: Let's take a closer look at the ways we can describe sound

title: Oscillations and mechanical waves
translated_description: How fast does sound actually travel?

title: Oscillations and mechanical waves
translated_description: Sounds travels at different speeds in different media

title: Oscillations and mechanical waves
translated_description: We can measure speeds relative to the speed of sound

title: Oscillations and mechanical waves
translated_description: We often use this logarithmic scale to describe the intensity of sound

title: Oscillations and mechanical waves
translated_description: Let's think about why sounds would have to get softer as you get further from the source

title: Oscillations and mechanical waves
translated_description: Ultrasound medical imaging (also known as sonography) is a diagnostic imaging tool that uses high-frequency sound waves to create images of structures in the body. Ultrasound images are captured in ​real time​ using an external probe and ultrasound gel placed directly on the skin. They can show things that a still image like an X-ray cannot  such as blood flow or organ movement. Ultrasound images are highly useful in the diagnosis and treatment of many diseases.

title: Oscillations and mechanical waves
translated_description: Learn about the Doppler Effect and how it explains the change in frequency of a wave when its source and an observer are moving.

title: Oscillations and mechanical waves
translated_description: Let's derive the formula for how the perceived frequency of a sound changes when its source is moving toward you

title: Oscillations and mechanical waves
translated_description: Let's look at the case where the source is moving away from the listener

title: Oscillations and mechanical waves
translated_description: What happens when both the listener and the source are moving together?

title: Oscillations and mechanical waves
translated_description: What happens when just the observer is moving?

title: Oscillations and mechanical waves
translated_description: Does the doppler effect still apply when sound is being reflected off a moving object?

title: Oscillations and mechanical waves
translated_description: In this video David explains wave interference and solves a few examples to find the value of the total wave when two wave pulses overlap.

title: Oscillations and mechanical waves
translated_description: In this video David explains what constructive and destructive interference means as well as how path length differences and pi shifts affect the interference.

title: Oscillations and mechanical waves
translated_description: In this video David explains how and why standing waves occur  and well as how to determine the wavelengths for a standing wave on a string.

title: Oscillations and mechanical waves
translated_description: Find out why a flute makes such specific notes

title: Oscillations and mechanical waves
translated_description: Find out why you can make music by blowing into empty bottles

title: Oscillations and mechanical waves
translated_description: In this video David explains what beat frequency means  howto find it  and solves a sample problem involving beat frequency.

title: Oscillations and mechanical waves
translated_description: In this video David derives the formula for beat frequency.

title: Fluids
translated_description: In this video David explains what specific gravity means. He also shows how to calculate the value for specific gravity and use it to determine the percent of an object that will be submerged while floating.

title: Fluids
translated_description: Sal explains the difference between liquids and gasses (both fluids). He then starts a calculation of the work done on a liquid in a U-shaped container.

title: Fluids
translated_description: Sal finishes the calculation or work to determine the mechanical advantage in a U-shaped tube. He also explains pressure and Pascal's Principal.

title: Fluids
translated_description: Sal derives the formula to determine the pressure at a specific depth in a fluid.

title: Fluids
translated_description: Using our understanding of fluid pressure to figure out the height of a column of mercury.

title: Fluids
translated_description: Introduction to Archimedes' principle and buoyant force.

title: Fluids
translated_description: A couple of problems involving Archimedes' principle and buoyant forces.

title: Fluids
translated_description: Sal introduces the notion of moving fluids and laminar flow. Then he uses the incompressibility of a liquid to show that the volume flow rate (flux) must remain constant. Sal then derives the equation of continuity in terms of the area and speed.

title: Fluids
translated_description: This is the first of two videos where Sal derives Bernoulli's equation.

title: Fluids
translated_description: This is the second of two videos where Sal derives Bernoulli's equation. In the second half of the video Sal also begins an example problem where liquid exits a hole in a container.

title: Fluids
translated_description: Sal finishes the example problem where liquid exits a hole in a container.

title: Fluids
translated_description: Clarification of  and more thoughts on  the Bernoulli's equation example problem where liquid exits a hole in a container.

title: Fluids
translated_description: Sal solves a Bernoulli's equation example problem where fluid is moving through a pipe of varying diameter.

title: Fluids
translated_description: David explains the concept of viscosity  viscous force  and Poiseuille's law.

title: Fluids
translated_description: In this video David explains how the Reynold's number allows you to determine the speed at which fluid flow becomes turbulent.

title: Fluids
translated_description: David explains the Venturi effect and the role and function of Pitot tubes.

title: Fluids
translated_description: David explains the concepts of surface tension  cohesion  and adhesion.

title: Thermodynamics
translated_description: Intuition of how gases generate pressure in a container and why pressure x volume is proportional to the combined kinetic energy of the molecules in the volume.

title: Thermodynamics
translated_description: To begin  Sal solves a constant temperature problem using PV=PV. Then he relates temperature to kinetic energy of a gas. In the second half of the video  he derives the ideal gas law.

title: Thermodynamics
translated_description: Sal makes the case for the Kelvin scale of temperature and absolute zero by showing that temperature is proportional to kinetic energy. Then he explains that you need to use the Kelvin scale in the ideal gas law. To finish he does a sample ideal gas law problem.

title: Thermodynamics
translated_description: Sal explains the concept of a mole. Then he derives the molar version of the ideal gas law PV=nRT  where the gas constant R=831 J/molK.

title: Thermodynamics
translated_description: Sal uses the molar version of the ideal gas law to solve for the number of moles in a gas. He also shows how to convert this answer into number of molecules using Avogadro's number.

title: Thermodynamics
translated_description: Using the Maxwell-Boltzmann distribution to visualize the distribution of speeds of particles at different temperatures.

title: Thermodynamics
translated_description: Defining specific heat  heat of fusion  and heat of vaporization. How to calculate the amount of heat to change the temperature of water and the energy required to change for a phase change.

title: Thermodynamics
translated_description: Fire as thermal conduction  convection  and radiation

title: Thermodynamics
translated_description: Intuition behind how heat gets transferred through thermal conduction.

title: Thermodynamics
translated_description: Why metal at room temperature feels cooler than wood at room temperature.

title: Thermodynamics
translated_description: Intuition behind formula for thermal conductivity

title: Thermodynamics
translated_description: In physics  a microstate is defined as the arrangement of each molecule in the system at a single instant. A macrostate is defined by the macroscopic properties of the system  such as temperature  pressure  volume  etc. For each macrostate  there are many microstates which result in the same macrostate.

title: Thermodynamics
translated_description: Using theoretically quasi-static and/or reversible processes to stay pretty much at equilibrium.

title: Thermodynamics
translated_description: First law of thermodynamic and internal energy

title: Thermodynamics
translated_description: Getting more intuition of internal energy  heat  and work. Examples of using the first law to calculate work.

title: Thermodynamics
translated_description: How a system can do work by expanding

title: Thermodynamics
translated_description: Why work from expansion is the area under the curve of a PV-diagram. Why heat is not a state function and internal energy is a state function.

title: Thermodynamics
translated_description: Conceptual proof that the internal energy of an ideal gas system is 3/2 PV.

title: Thermodynamics
translated_description: Isothermic and adiabatic processes. Calculating the work done by an isothermic process and seeing that it is the same as the heat added.

title: Thermodynamics
translated_description: Introduction to the Carnot cycle and Carnot heat engine

title: Thermodynamics
translated_description: Proof of the volume ratios in a Carnot cycle

title: Thermodynamics
translated_description: Proof that S (or entropy) is a valid state variable.

title: Thermodynamics
translated_description: Clarifying that the thermodynamic definition of Entropy requires a reversible system.

title: Thermodynamics
translated_description: Long video explaining why entropy is a measure of the number of states a system can take on (mathy  but mind-blowing).

title: Thermodynamics
translated_description: Introduces second law of thermodynamics. A discussion of entropy change in terms of heat and microstates .

title: Thermodynamics
translated_description: Maxwell's Demon: A thought experiment that seems to defy the 2nd Law of Thermodynamics

title: Thermodynamics
translated_description: Distinguishing between microstates and macro states. How entropy S is defined for a system and not for a specific microstate.

title: Thermodynamics
translated_description: Definition of efficiency for a heat engine.  Efficiency of a Carnot Engine.

title: Thermodynamics
translated_description: Seeing how we can scale and or reverse a Carnot Engine (to make a refrigerator)

title: Thermodynamics
translated_description: Proving that a Carnot Engine is the most efficient engine

title: Electric charge field and potential
translated_description: Learn the physics behind why a balloon clings to things after you rub it on a sweater

title: Electric charge field and potential
translated_description: Sal explains the fundamental force that causes charged particles to attract or repel each other

title: Electric charge field and potential
translated_description: Charge can flow through some materials  but not others

title: Electric charge field and potential
translated_description: Charge can't be created  and it can't be destroyed

title: Electric charge field and potential
translated_description: In this video David explains why physicists came up with the idea of the electric field  how it's useful  and explains how the electric field is defined.

title: Electric charge field and potential
translated_description: The direction of an electrical field at a point is the same as the direction of the electrical force acting on a positive test charge at that point. For example  if you place a positive test charge in an electric field and the charge moves to the right  you know the direction of the electric field in that region points to the right.

title: Electric charge field and potential
translated_description: In this video David explains how to find the magnitude of the electric field created by a point charge and solves a few examples problems to find the electric field from point charges.

title: Electric charge field and potential
translated_description: In this video David solves an example problem to find the net electric field created by multiple charges at a point in between them.

title: Electric charge field and potential
translated_description: In this video David solves an example 2D electric field problem to find the net electric field at a point above two charges.

title: Electric charge field and potential
translated_description: We can think of the forces between charges as something that comes from a property of space. That property is called the electric field.

title: Electric charge field and potential
translated_description: Advanced proof of the formula for the electric field generated by a uniformly charged  infinite plate

title: Electric charge field and potential
translated_description: We see that the infinite  uniformly charged plate generates a constant electric field (independent of the height above the plate)

title: Electric charge field and potential
translated_description: Introduction to electric potential energy

title: Electric charge field and potential
translated_description: Electric potential energy difference in a varying field

title: Electric charge field and potential
translated_description: Sal explains the difference between electrical potential (voltage) and electrical potential energy

title: Electric charge field and potential
translated_description: In this video David explains how to find the electric potential energy for a system of charges and solves an example problem to find the speed of moving charges. To see the calculus derivation of the formula watch this video.

title: Electric charge field and potential
translated_description: David explains electric potential (voltage)

title: Electric charge field and potential
translated_description: In this video David shows how to find the total electric potential at a point in space due to multiple charges.

title: Circuits
translated_description: Introduction to electricity  circuits  current  and resistance

title: Circuits
translated_description: Resistors that come one after another

title: Circuits
translated_description: Resistors that run alongside each other

title: Circuits
translated_description: A hairy resistance problem

title: Circuits
translated_description: An example of simplifying a seemingly complicated resistor circuit

title: Circuits
translated_description: Let's look at the properties of materials that cause a resistor to resist the flow of current

title: Circuits
translated_description: Kirchhoff's Current Law says the currents flowing into a node must add up to zero.

title: Circuits
translated_description: Kirchhoff's Voltage Law says if you travel around any loop in a circuit  the voltages across the elements add up to zero.

title: Circuits
translated_description: In this video David derives the formula to find the power used by a resistor.

title: Circuits
translated_description: Learn about the instruments we use to measure voltage and current

title: Circuits
translated_description: Liquids can also conduct electricity

title: Circuits
translated_description: A basic overview of capacitors and capacitance. By David Santo Pietro.

title: Circuits
translated_description: Introduction to the capacitance of a two plate capacitor.

title: Circuits
translated_description: This video explains the potential of a capacitor and how they function in a circuit. By David Santo Pietro.

title: Circuits
translated_description: When capacitors are connected one after another  they are said to be in series. For capacitors in series  the total capacitance can be found by adding the reciprocals of the individual capacitances  and taking the reciprocal of the sum. Therefore  the total capacitance will be lower than the capacitance of any single capacitor in the circuit.

title: Circuits
translated_description: The effect on voltage and current when capacitors are constructed in parallel in a circuit. By David Santo Pietro.

title: Circuits
translated_description: How dielectrics function in circuits. By David Santo Pietro.

title: Magnetic forces magnetic fields and Faraday's law
translated_description: An introduction to magnetism

title: Magnetic forces magnetic fields and Faraday's law
translated_description: Sal shows how to find the size and direction of the magnetic force using F=qvB and the right hand rule.

title: Magnetic forces magnetic fields and Faraday's law
translated_description: Introduction to the cross product

title: Magnetic forces magnetic fields and Faraday's law
translated_description: A little more intuition on the cross product.

title: Magnetic forces magnetic fields and Faraday's law
translated_description: Sal does an example problem to determine the size and direction of the magnetic force on a proton moving through a magnetic field.

title: Magnetic forces magnetic fields and Faraday's law
translated_description: Sal determines the radius of the circle traveled by the proton in the previous example by using the formula for centripetal acceleration.

title: Magnetic forces magnetic fields and Faraday's law
translated_description: Sal derives the formula F=ILB to determine the force on a current carrying wire.

title: Magnetic forces magnetic fields and Faraday's law
translated_description: See how a wire carrying a current creates a magnetic field.

title: Magnetic forces magnetic fields and Faraday's law
translated_description: Sal shows how to determine the magnetic force between two currents going in the same direction.

title: Magnetic forces magnetic fields and Faraday's law
translated_description: Sal shows how to determine the magnetic force between two currents going in opposite directions.

title: Magnetic forces magnetic fields and Faraday's law
translated_description: Sal determines the current and EMF induced in a wire pulled through a magnetic field.

title: Magnetic forces magnetic fields and Faraday's law
translated_description: Sal shows that there will be a net torque on a loop of current in a wire. Sal shows that this net torque will cause the loop to rotate.

title: Magnetic forces magnetic fields and Faraday's law
translated_description: Sal shows that a commutator can be used in order to keep the loop of wire rotating in the magnetic field.

title: Magnetic forces magnetic fields and Faraday's law
translated_description: Sal finishes the explanation of how a commutator will allow a loop of wire to continue spinning in a magnetic field  thereby allowing it to work as an electric motor.

title: Magnetic forces magnetic fields and Faraday's law
translated_description: Introduction to the vector dot product.

title: Magnetic forces magnetic fields and Faraday's law
translated_description: Understanding the differences between the dot and cross products

title: Magnetic forces magnetic fields and Faraday's law
translated_description: Calculating the dot and cross products when vectors are presented in their x  y  and z (or i j  and k) components.

title: Magnetic forces magnetic fields and Faraday's law
translated_description: Introduction and intuition for flux and magnetic flux.

title: Magnetic forces magnetic fields and Faraday's law
translated_description: How a current can be induced in a loop of wire by a change in magnetic flux.

title: Magnetic forces magnetic fields and Faraday's law
translated_description: Lenz's Law - seeing that the magnetic field induced by a current induced by a change in magnetic flux (Faraday's Law) counteracts the change in flux.

title: Magnetic forces magnetic fields and Faraday's law
translated_description: Example calculating induced current based on change in flux.

title: Magnetic forces magnetic fields and Faraday's law
translated_description: Emf induced in rod traveling through magnetic field

title: Magnetic forces magnetic fields and Faraday's law
translated_description: How Faraday's Law is used to generate electricity in turbines.

title: Electromagnetic waves and interference
translated_description: This is the underlying physics behind 3D glasses

title: Electromagnetic waves and interference
translated_description: In this video David explains what constructive and destructive interference means as well as how path length differences and pi shifts affect the interference.

translated_description: We can see interference in action if we shine laser light through two slits onto a screen

translated_description: Let's derive a formula that relates all the variables in Young's double slit experiment

translated_description: An example problem involving a double slit experiment

title: Electromagnetic waves and interference
translated_description: What happens when there's way more then two holes?

translated_description: What happens when there's only one hole?

title: Electromagnetic waves and interference
translated_description: See how there's actually constructive (rather than just destructive) interference at some points on the screen

title: Electromagnetic waves and interference
translated_description: Thin film interference occurs when light waves reflecting off the top and bottom surfaces of a thin film interfere with one another. This type of interference is the reason that thin films  such as oil or soap bubbles  form colorful patterns.

title: Electromagnetic waves and interference
translated_description: Let's work out a few details on how thin film interference works

translated_description: In this video David derives the mirror equation and magnification equation.

translated_description: Object Image Height and Distance Relationship

translated_description: Some examples of using the thin lens equation

title: Special relativity
translated_description: If waves are disruptions traveling through a medium and light is a wave  what medium does it travel through? A luminiferous ether?

title: Special relativity
translated_description: Thinking about how Earth's relative velocity to hypothetical luminiferous ether can be used to detect ether.

title: Special relativity
translated_description: Simple idea behind the Michelson‒Morley experiment to detect ether wind.

title: Special relativity
translated_description: We introduce a graph that's a lot like your good old position-vs-time graph—but with a twist!

title: Special relativity
translated_description: Now that we know what path–time diagrams are  let's see what happens when we bring along a friend!

title: Special relativity
translated_description: Here we'll see how classical physics predicts scenarios that disagree with what we observe in nature. Something's got to give…

title: Special relativity
translated_description: Including multiple observers in the "most obvious" way led to some problems. Let's see how we can start to solve those problems by introducing (what we'll later call) Minkowski spacetime diagrams.

title: Special relativity
translated_description: As counterintuitive as it might sound  it will become extremely convenient to use the same units for space and time. Happily  we can do that just by multiplying the time axis by c  the speed of light. Here's how.

title: Special relativity
translated_description: It looks like there might be some relationship between the relative angles of the axes in the two references frames we've considered. Let's take a closer look.

title: Special relativity
translated_description: So we've got two coordinate systems from the perspectives of two observers. How can we convert spacetime coordinates between these? Enter the Lorentz transformation!

title: Special relativity
translated_description: We'll consider an example of the Lorentz transformation with actual numbers  and analyze the results we get.

title: Special relativity
translated_description: The forms in which we've introduced the Lorentz transformations are really nice in that they reveal the symmetry of the two axes of spacetime. But there are other representations: some are just more common in practical use  while others reveal other interesting similarities with classical mechanics!

title: Special relativity
translated_description: Using symmetry of frames of reference and the absolute velocity of the speed of light (regardless of frame of reference) to begin to solve for the Lorentz factor.

title: Special relativity
translated_description: Continuing the algebra to solve for the Lorentz factor.

title: Special relativity
translated_description: Finishing our Lorentz transformation derivation for t'.

title: Special relativity
translated_description: Lorentz transformation for change in coordinates

title: Special relativity
translated_description: Einstein velocity addition formula derivation

title: Special relativity
translated_description: Applying Einstein velocity addition

title: Special relativity
translated_description: Let's use Einstein velocity addition to find a frame of reference where A and B are traveling in opposite directions at the same speed.

title: Special relativity
translated_description: Let's now do the math to calculate the equal speed at which both A and B could be traveling away from a "neutral" observer.

title: Special relativity
translated_description: We'll start thinking about time dilation in special relativity and how a Loedel diagram can help up appreciate symmetry between inertial frames.

title: Quantum Physics
translated_description: In this video  David explains what a photon is and how to determine the energy of a photon.

title: Quantum Physics
translated_description: In this video  David (and surfer Dan) explain how to determine the momentum of a photon.

title: Quantum Physics
translated_description: Explaining the photoelectric effect using wave-particle duality  the work function of a metal  and how to calculate the velocity of a photoelectron.

title: Quantum Physics
translated_description: In this video  David explains how Louis De Broglie got his Nobel Prize for the idea of matter having a wavelength.

title: Quantum Physics
translated_description: In this video David gives an introductory explanation of what the qauntum wavefunction is  how to use it  and where it comes from.

title: Quantum Physics
translated_description: In this video  David explains how an atom can absorb and emit photons of particular values and how to determine the allowed values.

title: Quantum Physics
translated_description: Using classical physics and vectors  plus assumption that angular momentum of electron is quantized  to derive the equation for Bohr model radii.

title: Quantum Physics
translated_description: Using equation for Bohr model radii to draw shell model for n=1 to 3  and calculating the velocity of a ground state electron.

title: Quantum Physics
translated_description: Using classical physics to calculate the energy of electrons in Bohr model. Solving for energy of ground state and more generally for level n.

title: Quantum Physics
translated_description: Calculating electron energy for levels n=1 to 3. Drawing a shell model diagram and an energy diagram for hydrogen  and then using the diagrams to calculate the energy required to excite an electron between different energy levels.

title: Quantum Physics
translated_description: Using shell model diagram to relate absorption to emission. Derives relationship between emitted photon and energy levels  the Balmer-Rydberg equation.

title: Quantum Physics
translated_description: Using Balmer-Rydberg equation to solve for photon energy for n=3 to 2 transition. Solving for wavelength of a line in UV region of hydrogen emission spectrum.

title: Quantum Physics
translated_description: Definition of Heisenberg uncertainty principle. Calculating uncertainty in position given the uncertainty in momentum for Bohr model of hydrogen.

title: Quantum Physics
translated_description: Definition of orbital as region of high probability for finding electron  and how quantum numbers are used to describe the orbitals. Compares Bohr model orbits and quantum mechanical model of atom.

title: Quantum Physics
translated_description: Calculates number of orbitals and number of electrons in different kinds of orbitals for n = 1 to 4. Explains that only two electrons are allowed per orbital  and gives shortcuts for calculating number of orbitals and total number of electrons for a given n.

title: Quantum Physics
translated_description: Nuclear binding energy is the energy required to split an atom’s nucleus into protons and neutrons. Mass defect is the difference between the predicted mass and the actual mass of an atom's nucleus. The binding energy of a system can appear as extra mass  which accounts for this difference.

title: Quantum Physics
translated_description: Using the ratio of neutrons to protons to figure out of a nucleus will be stable or radioactive.

title: Quantum Physics
translated_description: Alpha  Beta  Gamma Decay and Positron Emission

title: Quantum Physics
translated_description: Writing nuclear equations for alpha  beta  and gamma decay.

title: Quantum Physics
translated_description: Carbon dating is a real-life example of a first-order reaction. This video explains half-life in the context of radioactive decay.

title: Quantum Physics
translated_description: Definition of half-life and graphing the decay of phosphorus-32. Calculating how much phosphorus-32 remains after 57.2 days.

title: Quantum Physics
translated_description: Showing that N(t)=Ne^(-kt) describes the amount of a radioactive substance we have at time T. For students with background in Calculus. Not necessary for intro chemistry class.

title: Quantum Physics
translated_description: Introduction to Exponential Decay. Using the exponential decay formula to calculate k  calculating the mass of carbon-14 remaining after a given time  and calculating the time it takes to have a specific mass remaining .

title: Quantum Physics
translated_description: A few more examples of exponential decay. Practice calculating k from half-life  and calculating initial mass.

title: Quantum Physics
translated_description: Using exponential decay equation to solve for relationship between k and half-life. Using semi-log plot to get graph of a straight line with slope of -k.

title: Discoveries and projects
translated_description: Our ancestors noticed that certain rocks were attracted to each other. They also noticed that this force could be transferred onto certain metallic objects!

title: Discoveries and projects
translated_description: how would you know which way is north if you had no reference? Can the direction of stroke alone tell you this? Are you sure?

title: Discoveries and projects
translated_description: Does the direction which we stroke the needle determine the final orientation?

title: Discoveries and projects
translated_description: Can you use a magnet as a compass? How can you find North vs. South pole?

title: Discoveries and projects
translated_description: Making a Compass: does it matter if we stroke the needle with the North vs. South pole of the magnet? Why?

title: Discoveries and projects
translated_description: How to neutralize a compass using two needles. How could this help us later? Why does this work?

title: Discoveries and projects
translated_description: If we float two identically magnetized needles they will always orient themselves in the same way. Why?

title: Discoveries and projects
translated_description: Exploring the effect of a permanent magnet on compass. What is going on?

title: Discoveries and projects
translated_description: A compass will align with the lines of force around a magnet. How could you do this in 3 dimensions?

title: Discoveries and projects
translated_description: magnetic materials seem to have two sides (we could call them poles). Depending on orientation they can be attractive or repulsive. What is the shape of the force between fields?

title: Discoveries and projects
translated_description: What happens to the magnetic field of a magnet in the presence of a another material which is attracted to it. Why does this happen?

title: Discoveries and projects
translated_description: How can we increase the strength of a bar magnet using a piece of steel? Why is it stronger?

title: Discoveries and projects
translated_description: Will the power of two magnets stuck together increase the overall force? Why?

title: Discoveries and projects
translated_description: How can we describe the strength of the Earth's magnetic field using a magnet and a compass? What does this tell us?

title: Discoveries and projects
translated_description: Attempt to measure the change in force of a magnet over a distance using the deflection of a compass. What is wrong with this approach?

title: Discoveries and projects
translated_description: Here we compare the speed of compass oscillation vs. distance from a magnet. What kind of relationship do we observe. Is it linear?

title: Discoveries and projects
translated_description: Zinc Copper cell - example of reduction-oxidation reaction

title: Discoveries and projects
translated_description: Simple device which we can use to measure our homemade batteries. You can test it with any household battery first. What does this deflection represent? What forces are involved?

title: Discoveries and projects
translated_description: First we attach our galvanometer to a piece of copper and zinc. Then we submerge the metals in pure water and vinegar. What is the difference? Why?

title: Discoveries and projects
translated_description: What happens to the deflection when we attach the penny and zinc in the opposite direction?

title: Discoveries and projects
translated_description: Experimenting with a strong acid as electrolyte and observing the change in deflection compared to weak acid (vinegar)

title: Discoveries and projects
translated_description: What happens to the deflection when we add salt to an electrolyte? Why?

title: Discoveries and projects
translated_description: Does the distance between the copper and zinc electrodes matter? What happens to the deflection when we hold them close vs. far apart? Why is there a difference?

title: Discoveries and projects
translated_description: Here we experiment with hot vs. cold vinegar as our electrolyte. Does the deflection in our galvanometer depend on temperature? Why?

title: Discoveries and projects
translated_description: What's the difference between one piece of metal and three pieces of metal in our cell. Does deflection change? Why?

title: Discoveries and projects
translated_description: Testing out a cell which holds the metals at a constant distance. We add it to salt water and then check the deflection. Can this be used as a standard unit?

title: Discoveries and projects
translated_description: Observation: when we pull our cell out of the electrolyte it still causes a deflection  which increases when pressure is applied. How could this lead to more efficient batteries?

title: Discoveries and projects
translated_description: The key technologies in our story.

title: Discoveries and projects
translated_description: Hans Christian Ørsted made this famous observation in 1819.

title: Discoveries and projects
translated_description: Testing the direction of force when the current carrying wire is above vs. below a compass. What does this tell us?

title: Discoveries and projects
translated_description: Apply current in both directions and notice the response is different.

title: Discoveries and projects
translated_description: Applying current in various directions to a single loop of wire. Primitive electric motor?

title: Discoveries and projects
translated_description: Simple device which we can use to measure our homemade batteries. You can test it with any household battery first. What does this deflection represent? What forces are involved?

title: Discoveries and projects
translated_description: Why does the deflection change when an electromagnet is attached to the circuit? Does it matter what side of the electromagnet we test?

title: Discoveries and projects
translated_description: A pencil causes a change in the deflection  similar to the effect of adding an electromagnet. Why?

title: Discoveries and projects
translated_description: We use the inside of a pencil (graphite) to apply different "lengths of pencil" to the circuit. What relationship do you observe between length of graphite and deflection angle?

title: Discoveries and projects
translated_description: Here we draw a line on a page and use it as a variable resistor in series with a speaker. What relationship do we hear? Does it sound linear?

title: Discoveries and projects
translated_description: By pulsing the connection to the battery we can cause a compass to spin. How is this working?

title: Discoveries and projects
translated_description: In this video we show you how to build a simple motor

title: Discoveries and projects
translated_description: Our ancestors noticed that when amber was rubbed against fur it attracted small objects...why is this?

title: Discoveries and projects
translated_description: Primitive device for measuring electrostatic force

title: Discoveries and projects
translated_description: Foil Leaf Electroscope. Aluminum leaves repel in the presence of a charged object

title: Discoveries and projects
translated_description: Long before the internet people thought about sending information along wires using static electricity.

title: Discoveries and projects
translated_description: This video highlights the projectile (ping pong ball) launcher

title: Discoveries and projects
translated_description: This project shows you how to build a ping pong and test an adjustable ping pong ball launcher.

title: Discoveries and projects
translated_description: We upgrade our ping pong ball launcher to make it safer  more accurate and more reliable.

title: Discoveries and projects
translated_description: This project shows how to power a boat with a candle.
